webTitle: Now rich schools are slipping too

fields.headline: Now rich schools are slipping too
fields.trailText: Complacent teachers are failing many children in middle-class schools, despite apparently good exam results. The hidden crisis in the 'leafy suburbs' will be revealed later this week in the annual report from Chris Woodhead, Chief Inspector of Schools.
fields.body:
Complacent teachers are failing many children in middle-class schools, despite apparently good exam results. The hidden crisis in the 'leafy suburbs' will be revealed later this week in the annual report from Chris Woodhead, Chief Inspector of Schools.

Growing concern about 'coasting schools' in affluent areas has led Education Secretary David Blunkett to introduce a new category for inspections. From this term, schools not pushing their children hard enough will be marked as 'underachieving'.

Blunkett will this week introduce refresher courses for teachers thought to be stuck in their ways, which heads will be able to use as part of an 'MoT' for staff at the mid-point in their careers.

Only 3 per cent of schools are judged as failing by inspectors and these are nearly all in areas of social deprivation. The new category is designed to identify hidden problems believed to affect hundreds of schools in the suburbs.

A senior Whitehall source said: 'You would expect middle-class children to get good results. But in many schools they could be performing far better.'

Teachers' leaders last night denied complacency and accused the Government of inconsistency: 'Teachers always want training to update and refresh their skills,' said Doug McAvoy, general secretary of the National Union of Teachers. 'One reason they don't trust this Government is because it has failed to have a programme of professional development as of right. Instead, it targets individual teachers for the purposes of spin rather than real educational development.'

Inspectors will be expected to judge schools on their general effectiveness, improvement since last inspection and performance compared to other schools in a similar context. Increasing emphasis will be placed on the number of children qualifying for free school meals as an indication of relative poverty of an area.

Schools judged to be coasting will be expected to prepare a post-inspection plan outlining how they will raise standards. Blunkett hopes the plans will help Local Education Authorities target support and stop schools slipping towards failure.

Under the last government schools simply passed or failed inspection. In September 1997 Blunkett introduced a category of 'serious weaknesses' to target schools with problems which would be reinspected within two years. The Government also said schools under Special Measures (failing) would have to turn themselves around within two years or face closure. Labour has boasted that the average time of turning around failing schools has fallen from 24 to 17 months since it came to power.

Woodhead first highlighted the problem of coasting schools in last year's report, which described education as a 'lottery' for many parents. He is thought likely to return to the issue in this year's report, published on Tuesday. He will also concentrate on the inspection of local education authorities, which began in earnest this year. So far inspectors have visited 23 out of the 59 authorities and concerns have been raised about nearly half of them.

The Government's strategy of enlisting the private sector to help failing authorities was dealt a blow by news that the first school taken over by a private company is still judged to be failing. Rams Episcopal school in Hackney, east London, will be closed and reopened under a new name after inspectors said it had not made enough progress since the takeover in September 1998. The Centre for British Teachers, which was paid £80,000 to run the school, blamed the local authority, which it said had refused to act on its recommendations.

In Leeds, evangelist Christian parents have set up their own school in protest at poor standards. The Victory school, with 17 pupils, is run from a two-bedroom house in the Beeston area of the city.

martin.bright@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Heller's son catches out Manhattan's glossy set

fields.headline: Heller's son catches out Manhattan's glossy set
fields.trailText: They have made reputations overnight and destroyed them with equal ease. But now the glamorous editors, trendy publishers and fabulously paid writers of New York's glossy magazines have found themselves at the receiving end of intense and unflattering media attention.
fields.body:
They have made reputations overnight and destroyed them with equal ease. But now the glamorous editors, trendy publishers and fabulously paid writers of New York's glossy magazines have found themselves at the receiving end of intense and unflattering media attention.

Their nemesis is the novel Slab Rat by Ted Heller, who has emulated his late father, Joseph Heller, by creating a publishing sensation with his first book. For Joseph it was his mighty satire Catch 22. For Ted it is an acutely accurate exposé of back-stabbing banality in the world of Condé Nast, Tina Brown and fashion shoots.

A slab rat is a 'rat' obsessed with moving up the masthead in a midtown 'slab', a monolithic office block whose floors are devoted to publishing different magazines. For those in the business Slab Rat creates a narcissistic thrill. It is a real roman à clef , everyone says - though not the author. 'I can barely pronounce roman à clef ,' says Heller. 'These people just weren't on my mind.'

Never the less, anyone connected with business will recognise someone they know in the conniving 'rats' Zachary Arlen Post and Mark Larkin, his rival at It magazine whose soulless publisher Versailles Inc bears an uncanny resemblance to the vast empire of Condé Nast, publishers of Vogue, Vanity Fair and GQ. Some characters bear striking resemblances to real people, among them Vogue 's Anna Wintour and Condé Nast's late creative director Alexander Liberman. Others are savagely satirical composites.

It is clear Heller knows more about this world than he might care to admit, from the need to keep up appearances by drinking the 'right' designer mineral water to the monthly ritual of deciding the magazine's cover. 'It took five days to settle on "Best Bette" for Bette Midler and "Who are you Kidman?" for Nicole Kidman,' says Zachary, Heller's anti-hero. 'It seems the worse the cover line, the longer it takes to concoct: "Hanks for Everything" for Tom Hanks, "Elle on Wheels" for Elle MacPherson, had taken about a week each.'

Heller gained his insights as 'a non-entity' - a photo researcher, to be precise - at magazines such as Vanity Fair, Spy, Details and Premiere. 'I just stayed on the sidelines and did my humble clerical work,' he recalls.

It is this 'below stairs' perspective that is giving the upper classes of the magazine world such jitters. At Versailles Zachary is so desperate to get on that he reinvents his identity by masking his unac ceptable working-class Long Island background with tales of an exclusive boarding school education, a renowned architect father and an eccentric Palm Beach socialite mother.

He is a perfect denizen of a self-important world that trades on the insecurities and self-loathing of those who seek social sway and acceptance. Zachary says that 'magazine people think they are doing something great, like surviving polio or putting out something every month that rivals Moby Dick or Portrait of a Lady ' when in fact they're churning out 'unimportant nonsense, most of which could be faxed in from publicists and agents: promoting celebrities, exposing unimportant scandals, reviving dying careers or reburying or exhuming dead ones'.

Not surprisingly, many normally garrulous magazine types who never overlook a chance to be quoted are suddenly coy about talking, at least on the record, about Heller's cut-to-the-quick social satire. 'It's just not really politic to comment just now,' said one insider at Condé Nast. Makes a change.

''Slab Rat' is published in the US by Scribner, and in the UK in early March by Little Brown.

webTitle: In his utopia, Yoko is the ideal woman

fields.headline: In his utopia, Yoko is the ideal woman
fields.standfirst: Stephen Amidon's The New City falls uncomfortably somewhere between thriller and family tragedy
fields.trailText: Stephen Amidon's The New City falls uncomfortably somewhere between thriller and family tragedy
fields.body:
The New City
Stephen Amidon
Doubleday £15.99, pp447

The new city of Stephen Amidon's title is Newton, a visionary development in central Maryland intended to house rich and poor, black and white. Its architect designed gaslights for public spaces - a nostalgic touch - but otherwise looked hopefully to the future: there were to be no fences in Newton, and the police presence would be minimal.

The novel is set in the summer of 1973, a time when the idealism of the Sixties still has some potency. Austin Swope, the lawyer who masterminded the acquisition of land, is counting the days before he is given the job of city manager promised him. In the meantime, there are a few teething troubles to sort out with the help of his right-hand man, master builder Earl Wooten.

Swope is white and Wooten black, but they have both known hard times and Newton is more than a career high point for both of them. They believe in it, as a model of what community should be. Their friendship is reinforced by the even closer bond between their sons, bookish, neurotic Teddy and easy-going Joel.

The only real source of conflict between the boys is Joel's attachment to trashy beauty Susan. Teddy's image of the ideal woman seems to be Yoko Ono, an admiration which is enough to signal that his heterosexuality may not be fully formed (he must be the first person in fiction, or indeed fact, to find the cover of Two Virgins arousing). His affection for Joel may contain an element more desirous than pally.

The New City has a thriller plot of a slow-developing sort, involving a suspicious death and the framing of an innocent man, but it also has aspirations to being a family tragedy. Between those stools it pitches its tent. Amidon's style is fluent if rarely graceful ('The pall of suspicion would scotch his ascension'), with moments of an uneasy magnificence - one character imagines 'the shell of time' breaking, 'allowing him to float freely in the eternal liquid that spilled through the cracks'. Someone at Doubleday would have saved him embarrassment by mentioning that the words simulacra and substrata are not singular.

Swope's tragic flaws are a paranoia as much of the period as its hopefulness, and a blind love for Teddy, who was despaired of as a baby. No one thought he could survive, but Swope simply refused to let him die. Wooten's weakness seems lower down the scale: an inability to stick to the low-fat diet his wife Ardelia provides, which leads him to adultery with a woman willing to serve greasy meals. But this food obsession is more than simple greed. The trauma in his childhood was a period of desperate hunger when he was seven, after the great-aunt who was looking after him had a stroke. In her impaired state she was unable to tell anyone there was a child unprovided-for in her isolated house.

Amidon provides a wealth of period detail but can't make the collapse of a utopian project seem anything but preordained. In fact, he embraces the inevitability he might have considered resisting. How could Newton be anything but doomed when the gaslights periodically explode into flames, Japanese beetles are eating the newly-planted saplings, and even the fish in the artificial lake go mysteriously belly-up?

Watergate is beginning to dominate the television news, while the immediately preceding trauma of the Vietnam War continues to overshadow lives. Susan's father John is a veteran who escaped injuries during years of dangerous assignments, only to be laid low on a routine patrol by a mysterious centipede encountered in a cave. His hand never heals up, and the smell of rot which emanates from it makes problems for him in his work as an estate agent, trying to sell properties in Newton. Prospective buyers connect the bad smell with the houses rather than the realtor, and perhaps in the symbolic scheme of the novel they are justified.

As if a suppurating wound wasn't heavily metaphorical enough, Amidon supplies a scene of fateful meeting when Swope recruits John to do his dirty work, with its own grotesque prelude: a bird flying into a window. It is killed on impact, but stays mysteriously stuck to the glass by a 'blend of histamines and corpuscles'. Slowly it descends, 'laying a vertical highway of muck on the window'. Jelly pastes the dead eye to the glass: 'as the bird moved downward the ball was slowly rolling up into the socket, exposing black veins'.

With such an abundance of bad omens in evidence, the characters begin to look foolish, rather than tragic, in their inability to read the writing on the wall - or the sign on the Baptist church: GOOD INTENTIONS DIE UNLESS THEY ARE EXECUTED. Or failing that, the vertical highway of muck on the office window.

fields.headline: Audio
fields.trailText: Seamus Heaney reads his award-winning translation of Beowulf
fields.body:
Beowulf
Translated and read by Seamus Heaney
Faber Penguin Audiobooks, £8.99
Running Time 2 hrs, 15 mins
Buy it at BOL

Long ago in Hrothgar's Danish kingdom lived a gruesome, demonic monster named Grendel who roamed the countryside inflicting terror on the citizens. Rising from his marshy home every evening, he would enter the king's hall and devour 15 warriors, taking another 15 home with him to gorge upon for a late-night snack.

For 12 years the slaughter continued, until word of this heinous creature's deeds reached Beowulf, a great warrior from the land of the Geats. Beowulf killed the monster with his bare hands and then set upon its ghastly mother, freeing the Danish people from this reign of terror.

Upon returning to his own kingdom, Beowulf ruled for 50 years until he was slain by a dragon, while remaining victorious in his bravery.

This heroic Anglo-Saxon poem has no date and no author and was originally passed from generation to generation by oral narration. It was made up of speeches, songs and chants in order to make it easier to learn and recite.

There are no such tricks in Heaney's translation, although it might have been nice to hear him sing. This award-winning poet, who last month won the Whitbread Prize for this work, has skilfully reinterpreted this Nordic myth of greed and victory, conveying parallels with the terrorism that exists in today's society.

Perhaps Heaney has used the audiobook medium to experience the true art of storytelling, to inspire the listener with his voice. And what a beautiful voice it is.

fields.headline: Paperbacks
fields.trailText: Andrew Brown's witty guide to the combat between 'Gouldians' and 'Dawkinsians', plus The Long Firm, Provocation, Brave New Worlds, The Metaphysical Touch and The Cow
fields.body:
The Darwin Wars
Andrew Brown
Touchstone £7.99, pp241
Buy it at BOL

'Evolution is to analogy as statues are to birdshit.' Go on, work it out; it's worth it. Even science is not exempt from the distortions of metaphor and evolutionary theorists are fonder than most of analogies. But they don't all agree on what they're explaining or how they're saying it; the result is professional mudslinging of the highest quality. Andrew Brown is a witty, urbane guide through one of the least urbane of academic disputes, between the 'Gouldians' and the 'Dawkinsians'. Brown has researched his topic enthusiastically - the footnote to an especially rancorous comment reads: 'Personal communication, walking back from the pub.'

The Long Firm
Jake Arnott
Sceptre £6.99, pp343
Buy it at BOL

In the East End of London, Harry Starks is well known as a jack of all trades and master of most of them. He's a nightclub owner, a porn mogul and an endlessly inventive racketeer. He's also - though rarely at the same time - a sentimental old queen and a torturer of some repute.

Harry is fictional, but in Jake Arnott's outstanding first novel, he rubs shoulders with some real denizens of London's Swinging Sixties nether world: the Kray Twins, Johnnie Ray and Joe Meek, among others. Arnott's recreation of the decadent, dangerous atmosphere of the times is immaculate. His prose is as smooth as a seersucker suit, as sweet as a purple heart. Suck it and see.

Provocation
Charlotte Grimshaw
Abacus £6.99, pp282

Judging by her press releases, Charlotte Grimshaw is very worried about being pigeonholed as a crime writer. Quite right too - she's far more than a crime novelist. This is a dark, stylish story about sex, death and booze in New Zealand. Stella lives happily with Stuart, a wealthy criminal lawyer, until he takes on a high-profile murder case and things start to go very awry.

The unfamiliar cityscape of Auckland is extremely well drawn, as is the redneck town where the killing takes place. Grimshaw, an ex-barrister, has a legal-eye for detail in and out of the courtroom and an authentic sense of motive and malice. Nothing gets tied up in red ribbon and filed away at the end - you're left unsettled, but wanting more.

Brave New Worlds: Genetics and the Human Experience Bryan Appleyard
HarperCollins £8.99, pp197
Buy it at BOL

Canadian scientists claimed recently to have identified a 'suicide' gene, which predisposes an individual to self-destructive impulses. It is the latest arrow in the quiver of the genetic determinists, who propose that personality is largely pre-ordained by our DNA. Gene forecasts at birth will take the place of horoscopes and will be a lot more accurate at predicting our fortunes. By tinkering with gene codes we'll be able to 'design' people pre-natally. Of course it's a lot more complicated than this, which is why you should read Bryan Appleyard's elegant, informed and passionate account of the genetic revolution and its implications. Required reading for all inhabitants of the twenty-first century.

The Metaphysical Touch
Sylvia Brownrigg
Phoenix £6.99, pp444
Buy it at BOL

J.D. Levin posts his 'Diery' - an elongated suicide note - in daily instalments on an Internet bulletin board. It's read by Emily Piper, a philosophy student with an obsession for Kant. She e-mails J.D. directly and an online relationship springs up. Cue musing about the mind-body split and a protracted analysis of J.D.'s death-wish.

If you can bear to stay hooked up for 444 pages, the ending's worth it.

 Robert MacFarlane

The Cow
Beat Sterchi, translated by Michael Hofmann
Faber & Faber £9.99 380pp
Buy it at BOL

This is a real curiosity - a novel whose central character, Blosch, is a Swiss cow. The narrative describes how Ambrosio, a Spanish guest worker, goes to work on a Swiss farm and toils for seven years only to see his labours come to nothing as Blosch, the farm's prize beast, is sent for slaughter.

Such a bare summary does scant justice to the texture of Sterchi's prose, or the precision of Hofmann's inspired translation. The first Observer review of this novel described Sterchi as 'a kind of prose Ted Hughes'.

This edition includes a puff from Seamus Heaney, for whom the novel is 'a kind of de profundis of the cattle sheds, a milker's epic'. Enough said.

 Eldon King

Harry is fictional, but in Jake Arnott's outstanding first novel, he rubs shoulders with some real denizens of London's Swinging Sixties nether world: the Kray Twins, Johnnie Ray and Joe Meek, among others. Arnott's recreation of the decadent, dangerous atmosphere of the times is immaculate. His prose is as smooth as a seersucker suit, as sweet as a purple heart. Suck it and see. Provocation Charlotte Grimshaw Abacus £6.99, pp282 Judging by her press releases, Charlotte Grimshaw is very worried about being pigeonholed as a crime writer. Quite right too - she's far more than a crime novelist. This is a dark, stylish story about sex, death and booze in New Zealand. Stella lives happily with Stuart, a wealthy criminal lawyer, until he takes on a high-profile murder case and things start to go very awry. The unfamiliar cityscape of Auckland is extremely well drawn, as is the redneck town where the killing takes place. Grimshaw, an ex-barrister, has a legal-eye for detail in and out of the courtroom and an authentic sense of motive and malice. Nothing gets tied up in red ribbon and filed away at the end - you're left unsettled, but wanting more. Brave New Worlds: Genetics and the Human Experience Bryan Appleyard HarperCollins £8.99, pp197 Buy it at BOL Canadian scientists claimed recently to have identified a 'suicide' gene, which predisposes an individual to self-destructive impulses. It is the latest arrow in the quiver of the genetic determinists, who propose that personality is largely pre-ordained by our DNA. Gene forecasts at birth will take the place of horoscopes and will be a lot more accurate at predicting our fortunes. By tinkering with gene codes we'll be able to 'design' people pre-natally. Of course it's a lot more complicated than this, which is why you should read Bryan Appleyard's elegant, informed and passionate account of the genetic revolution and its implications. Required reading for all inhabitants of the twenty-first century. The Metaphysical Touch Sylvia Brownrigg Phoenix £6.99, pp444 Buy it at BOL J.D. Levin posts his 'Diery' - an elongated suicide note - in daily instalments on an Internet bulletin board. It's read by Emily Piper, a philosophy student with an obsession for Kant. She e-mails J.D. directly and an online relationship springs up. Cue musing about the mind-body split and a protracted analysis of J.D.'s death-wish. If you can bear to stay hooked up for 444 pages, the ending's worth it.  Robert MacFarlane The Cow Beat Sterchi, translated by Michael Hofmann Faber & Faber £9.99 380pp Buy it at BOL This is a real curiosity - a novel whose central character, Blosch, is a Swiss cow. The narrative describes how Ambrosio, a Spanish guest worker, goes to work on a Swiss farm and toils for seven years only to see his labours come to nothing as Blosch, the farm's prize beast, is sent for slaughter. Such a bare summary does scant justice to the texture of Sterchi's prose, or the precision of Hofmann's inspired translation. The first Observer review of this novel described Sterchi as 'a kind of prose Ted Hughes'. This edition includes a puff from Seamus Heaney, for whom the novel is 'a kind of de profundis of the cattle sheds, a milker's epic'. Enough said.  Eldon King

fields.headline: A panoramic view
fields.standfirst: Robert Hughes fills the broad canvas of his history of the visual arts in America, American Visions
fields.trailText: Robert Hughes fills the broad canvas of his history of the visual arts in America, American Visions
fields.body:
American Visions: The Epic History of Art in America
Robert Hughes
Harvill £19.99, pp635

Buy it at BOL

The great thing about Robert Hughes is that he is unafraid to state his opinion. His seminal history of art, The Shock of the New, combined forceful opinion with a dazzling overview. Nobody had ever pointed out before that artists such as Sonia Delauney were using such an unusual perspective because they had just been up the newly built Eiffel Tower and seen life, for the first time, from a bird's eye view. It was a ground-breaking book. American Visions is more cautious, partly because the scope of the remit is much broader. Hughes, an Australian, settled in America 30 years ago and has been art critic of Time magazine for 25 of those years.

Tracing the development of an art form in such a huge, multi-settled country as America is some undertaking, and the tone of this book is more hesitant than The Shock of the New, although a few of the old vituperative flashes emerge: commenting on a typical Warhol non-interview about ducking the meaning of his electric chair paintings, Hughes says: 'But he did know, of course, and so does anyone who sees these stark, mute images: the dark side of Warhol was the most interesting one, perhaps the only interesting one.'

Hughes approaches the subject chronologically, charting art from the first settlers (the Spanish invaders didn't take artists with them) and interspersing the pitifully sparse clues of what little indigenous art already existed there. There is a fascinating chapter on the creation of American iron cities - the high-rises, the elevators, the Brooklyn Bridge, built six years before the Eiffel Tower. The only criticism of this indispensable book is that its bulk presents a problem for those of us who like to loll and read.

fields.headline: Fighting chance
fields.standfirst: Rachel Ingalls' brings together short fiction linked by war and fate in Days Like Today
fields.trailText: Rachel Ingalls' brings together short fiction linked by war and fate in Days Like Today
fields.body:
Days Like Today
Rachel Ingalls
Faber £12.99, pp289
Buy it at BOL

A London literary critic recently wrote that there are only two categories of book, good and bad. This applies well to Rachel Ingalls, because her work resists definition in the first place. Try and stick the neat labels of form and genre on her writing and they fall off, glueless. Nothing holds except simple criticism of quality, and in this respect Ingalls is, without doubt, a highly talented and experienced writer of fiction.

Her work combines subtlety and horror, magic and stark realism, Greek tragedy and happily-ever-afters. Her characters are true to life even as they embody classical archetypes - Icarus, Odysseus, Psyche, people wandering too long, striving too far, watching their loved ones by faint lights.

In Days Like Today, her tenth volume of fiction, Ingalls brings together five works linked by war and fate, although these five are as physically different as they are thematically similar. Ranging in length from a dozen to a hundred pages, some of the pieces have the elemental focus of short stories, others the psychological depth of novels. They are novellas, novelissimos, long shorts and short longs. They are the length they need to be, whatever you call them, and together they constitute something rare and fine.

Character is Ingalls's greatest strength, and in writing there may be no better strength to have. Her people are four-dimensional, rich in pasts and hopes as well as physicality. Her narratives are relatively simple, and therefore her protagonists few. Fate overlooks them all, and conflict - urban, domestic, international - is never far away. In 'Correspondent', Joan discovers her famous war journalist husband is being unfaithful. To get her own back, or bring him back to her, she steals his pouch of lucky charms on the day he is leaving for a danger zone. What happens to him, and to her, is no more nor less than either deserves. There are echoes of Samson and Delilah here, but they are understated.

There is also an inevitability to the ending which is typical of Ingalls's work and which, somehow, does not make it predictable. This is to do with Ingalls's interest in fate, something she goes back to again and again. In 'Veterans', the man whom Franklin saves on the battlefield returns to find him, a haunting as sinister and relentless as if the saved man had died after all.

The single act of heroism changes and defines both their lives, as Franklin understands: 'From then on he had something in reserve that could balance everything to come. For ever afterwards he could point to that moment, telling himself: That's the kind of man I am... But who could tell what the same deed had done to Sherman? He might feel that he was under an obligation. And he might not like that.'

The least successful story in the book - although this is relative - is also the only one that doesn't deal with war. In 'The Icon', Stratis becomes convinced that his grandfather owns a stolen painting. Although the painting is worthless and his grandfather much loved, Stratis is led on by his own impetuousness and sense of right until he steals the icon back. Possibly it is because the characters in this story are Greek-American themselves that the Hellenic methods and archetypes - Icarus, hamartia - seem too obvious. The sense of fate is also so strong that in the end it strains credibility.

Ingalls's best-known work to date is 'Mrs Caliban', the story of a woman who falls in love with a green-skinned sea monster she finds in her kitchen: even so, the best writing in this new book doesn't deal with fictions that are stranger than truths. Quite the opposite. In her war stories, Ingalls documents truths that are stranger than fiction, and it is this that makes Days Like Today a remarkable collection.

fields.headline: Classicwatch
fields.trailText: Kierkegaard explores the cerebral pleasures of pursuit in the Diary of a Seducer
fields.body:
Diary of a Seducer
Soren Kierkegaard
Pushkin Press £8, pp238
Buy it at BOL

Diary of a Seducer was first published in 1843 as part of a collection of writings, Either/Or, under the pseudonym Victor Eremeta. Kierkegaard presented the papers that formed the collection as having been discovered in a secret drawer of a second-hand escritoire purchased by Eremeta and wrote a preface to this effect, but it was the diary section that ensured its instant success.

This 'diary' is the work of a man named Johannes and analytically details his pursuit of a young girl, Cordelia, who falls in love with and is subsequently betrayed by him. For Johannes, the quest is of utmost importance. Both self-absorbed and nihilistic, his pleasure in the seduction is cerebral rather than sensual. It is the planning and anticipation, the work of his own fantasy, that he documents most meticulously in his diary.

In contrast, he writes her letters full of lyrical passion, markedly at odds with his almost scientific fascination with his own feelings and with hers.

Although Kierkegaard disapproved of parts of Either/Or, particularly the diary, being read out of context, Pushkin Press's smartly-presented new edition makes an appealing introduction to his work, complete with a brief afterword by the translator.

fields.headline: I blame the parents...
fields.standfirst: Darian Leader's attempt to put Freud into perspective makes it difficult to tell the wood from the trees
fields.trailText: Darian Leader's attempt to put Freud into perspective makes it difficult to tell the wood from the trees
fields.body:
Freud's Footnotes
Darian Leader
Faber £9.99, pp253
Buy it at BOL

On the death of Freud, Auden wrote, 'he is no more a person/ now but a whole climate of opinion'. Like global warming, the effect of the new climate on our lives may be hotly contested but, whether we like it or not, we have come out from under Freud's Viennese family overcoat.

In Freud's Footnotes, Darian Leader, author of Why Do Women Write More Letters Than They Post?, homes in on some of the key documents and debates of the Freudian revolution. Recalling Whitehead's description of European philosophy as a series of footnotes to Plato, Leader wants to see psychoanalytic theory as a series of footnotes to Freud. Unlike Whitehead's, this is not a particularly grand claim.

Leader says he hasn't written a study of Freud's footnotes but of 'footnotes that one might add to put Freud into perspective'. This sounds nicely reassuring, as if there just happened to be only one, but of course there is nothing of the kind in the jungle of Freudian debate. In Leader's densely annotated, thesis-style prose it is hard to tell the wood from the trees. Whatever else it does, Freud's Footnotes, with its page-by-page barrage of footnotes, demonstrates that psychoanalysts have written (and posted) more papers than anyone in their right mind would want to read.

Squinting closely through the dust at the small print of Freud's German, Leader sets out to revise the orthodox 'myth' of the early Freud's relation to the 'School of Helmholtz' and insists instead on his debt to psychologists of 'the Herbartian tradition'.

Thereafter, he takes us through debates, built around landmark texts by the Freuds (father and daughter), Melanie Klein, the primitivist re-inventor of psychoanalytic childhood, and Jacques Lacan, the sorcerer's apprentice of postwar French psychoanalysis.

In doing so he sheds philosophical light on some of the darker knots of Freudian theory - for instance, the idea of the internal world and Freud's much-trumpeted ignorance of music. He gives a convincing account of the philosophical contradictions inherent in Klein's notions of the internal world; picks his way carefully through the debate in the 1920s over Freud's, Horney's and Klein's accounts of gender, with their Hellenic Gothic fantasies of castration, incest and familial rivalry; and then goes on to explore rival interpretations of the 'Child is Being Beaten' paper Freud wrote on the basis of his analysis of his daughter Anna and the different stories of development encapsulated in Klein's story of 'The Depressive Position' and Lacan's mirror stage.

Unfortunately, though, the essays add little to our sense of the development of analysis - largely because, though they are alert to debates over theoretical terminology, they give little sense of the cultural and biographical contexts that gave them life.

Despite its arresting title and cover, the book is really a series of technical papers devoted to expounding earlier technical papers, unironically dedicated to the footnote. It has nothing of the popular appeal of his earlier book or the ongoing Emersonian provocation embodied in the essays of Adam Phillips, or the narrative flair of John Forrester's brilliant Despatches from the Freud Wars of a couple of years ago.

A study of the politics and poetics of Freud's actual footnotes would have been more fun. The most interesting of Freud's footnotes are in later editions of the early ground-breaking works, where we see Freud bringing them into line with his later thinking, whether about narcissism or the superego or the authorship of Shakespeare.

Usually, such subsequent footnotes are evolutionary. They show Freud bolstering early speculations by citing later confirmations or developments, suggesting the long ongoing march of psychoanalysis. Footnoting the first mention of the Oedipus Complex, for example, in The Interpretation of Dreams, he says 'later studies have shown that the Oedipus Complex... throws light of undreamt-of importance on the history of the human race and the evolution of religion and morality (see my Totem and Taboo)'.

They suggest, indeed, that much of the later evolution of psychoanalysis can be seen as footnotes to his early works, the case histories and books on dreams, slips and sexuality. However, there are other footnotes that point the other way. Commenting on the claim in The Interpretation of Dreams that 'anxiety is a libidinal impulse', a footnote of 1930 says 'in the light of later knowledge this statement can no longer stand'. Footnoting a claim that Hamlet confronts us with 'the poet's own mind', Freud completely topples his claim that the play was influenced by the death of Shakespeare's father and son, named Hamlet, by noting 'incidentally I have in the meantime ceased to believe that the author of Shakespeare's works was the man from Stratford'.

The author of Freud's works was certainly a Jew from Vienna, however, and my favourite footnote also comes from The Interpretation of Dreams, Freud's modernist autobiographical masterpiece, which was published 100 years ago.

Commenting on dreams about his unsatisfied longing to visit Rome, which he said in 1900 he could only satisfy in dreams, a footnote of 1909 tells us, 'I discovered long since that it only needs a little courage to fulfil wishes which till then have been regarded as unattainable', adding in 1925 'and thereafter became a constant pilgrim to Rome'. This is the Rome that in Civilisation and its Discontents provided him with his most enduring image of the enduring of the past in the mind. Footnotes can be the stuff that dreams are made on, though sadly not in Leader's book.

fields.headline: Thoreau's fruit pastorals
fields.standfirst: Philip Hensher goes for a walk in the woods with one of America's literary giants in Henry David Thoreau's Wild Fruits
fields.trailText: Philip Hensher goes for a walk in the woods with one of America's literary giants in Henry David Thoreau's Wild Fruits
fields.body:
Wild Fruits
Henry David Thoreau
W.W. Norton £22, pp408
Buy it at BOL

In the work of most writers, a book like this would look like a sport, an odd inessential addition to the author's fundamental interest. Scientific studies, even when undertaken by eminent literary men, have an obsolescence which is more or less built in. We are only interested, if at all, in Thomas Browne's Pseudodoxia Epidemica or Goethe's huge body of scientific writings on plants, anatomy and colour theory because of who they are by. Browne's ideas of why badgers have two legs shorter than the others do not have an intrinsic interest; Goethe's theory of the metamorphosis of fundamental forms in plants and skeletons is just wrong, and therefore without much interest. They go on being read, but on sufferance, as it were; they cannot be at the centre of the author's work, and were never of much interest to the science they lay claim to.

Thoreau, however, is different, and Wild Fruits is both at the centre of his remarkable body of work and of continuing practical interest. It has been put together out of manuscript notes and the daily observations he took while striding around the Massachusetts countryside. It dates from the 1850s and seems to have been considered by Thoreau as the beginnings of a more substantial 'Kalendar', in which the details of New England wildlife would be set down and turned into a new Bible, of practical application. 'Surely it is a defect in our Bible,' he wrote in his journal, 'that it is not truly ours, but a Hebrew Bible. The most pertinent illustrations for us are to be drawn, not from Egypt or Babylonia, but from New England.'

That was not to be but what Thoreau produced is a catalogue of wild fruits and plants, native to New England, made up of both observation and learning. His ultimate intentions were mystical. 'My profession is to be always on the alert to find God in nature, to know his lurking places,' he wrote. But his practice was always fiercely empirical.

Nothing he cannot see on his walks is of much interest to him. But what he can see on his walks is enough. He sticks firmly to his view that what we live with is what matters to us and is hostile to the idea that anything may be imported. 'We cultivate imported shrubs in our front yards for the beauty of their berries, while at least equally beautiful berries grow unregarded by us in the surrounding fields. The tropical fruits are for those who dwell within the tropics. Their fairest and sweetest parts cannot be imported. Brought here, they chiefly concern those whose walks are through the marketplace.'

Thoreau's inspiring, holistic vision of the strength of nature tends to make him hostile towards any form of agriculture, industry or trade. For him, nature will always win out. If a man chops down a wood, then 'in how short a time will blueberries and huckleberries grow there! - the earth is immediately reclothed with a new but miniature forest'.

The fruits he describes draw their sweetness from the earth, or even from the air. They need no tending and possess a political and spiritual, as well as physical, nutrition. He is snooty about pears, largely because the varieties are named after duchesses, and in cultivation tend to be picked by 'the proprietor himself'. The more commonplace apple is much to be preferred; as for eating the pear, Thoreau decides he will 'have to wait till we get to pears with American names which a republican can swallow'.

This is the first time the book has been published. It's difficult to see why, given the high reverence in which Thoreau is held by American readers. The editors mention the scrappiness of the material, and the impenetrability of Thoreau's handwriting, but they reproduce a bit of the manuscript and it isn't unreadable at all. The book has been put together from Thoreau's notes and is only the draft of a small part of what he originally conceived. It must be said, however, it forms a coherent and substantial whole and is surprisingly compelling; anything further from The Country Diary of an Edwardian Lady than this tough-minded, hard-thinking book can scarcely be imagined.

Wild Fruits, from one point of view, is not much more than a catalogue of plants but it exerts a continuous fascination and its fascination is not entirely that of the banal literary pastoral. Thoreau is determinedly not writing for city dwellers, relaxing with the contemplation of a simpler, quieter life, but for those who walk where he walks, helping them to see what he sees.

He is wrong, of course; his insights are not just local ones, but universal. Thoreau goes on being interesting for two reasons. The first is the general application of his ecological concerns. He was almost the first to see that 'in Wildness is the preservation of the world'. The second reason, of course, is how well he writes. 'There are many [blueberry bushes] growing quite on the edge of Goose Pond, occupying a strip only some three or four feet wide entirely around it - they are a kind of eyelashes to the pond.' Norton £22, pp408 Buy it at BOL In the work of most writers, a book like this would look like a sport, an odd inessential addition to the author's fundamental interest. webTitle: Proust and Gandhi revered him. It's hard to see why...

fields.headline: Proust and Gandhi revered him. It's hard to see why...
fields.standfirst: John Batchelor's study of John Ruskin vacillates between biography and criticism
fields.trailText: John Batchelor's study of John Ruskin vacillates between biography and criticism
fields.body:
John Ruskin: No Wealth But Life
John Batchelor
Chatto & Windus £25, pp448

The Romantic poet, according to Shelley, served as 'the unacknowledged legislator of mankind'. Later in the nineteenth century, poets took to writing prose, and began to issue legislative edicts in earnest, convinced of their duty to rectify the world. Ruskin, like Carlyle and Matthew Arnold, saw himself as a sage, preaching and prophesying to the nation. As the Bible lost credibility, writers were promoted to the status of oracles, or even deities. In his last decade, Ruskin even cultivated shaggy patriarchal whiskers like those of the heroic demiurge who animates Adam on the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel.

By then, however, the elderly Ruskin was incurably mad. He raged apocalyptically, smashed furniture and hurled food at his carer, Joan Severn. Repentant, he regressed to childhood, called the long-suffering Severn 'Mama', and begged her to forgive her 'little donkey boy'. This is the tragic paradox of his life and work, not very effectively sorted out by John Batchelor in a study which vacillates between biography and criticism. Ruskin's acolytes - a company which included Tolstoy, Gandhi, Proust and most of the Labour politicians elected to the House of Commons in 1906 - cherished him as a moralist, the upright conscience of industrial society. But his prescriptions for social change were at best dotty, at worst feudally nostalgic.

Despising neoclassicism, in 1853 he ordered the citizens of Edinburgh to demolish their Georgian squares and rebuild their town in the Gothic style: pointed arches signalled godly aspiration, whereas square-cut window jambs were smug, dull and grossly worldly. In 1874, he put into practice his belief in the sanctity and sanity of manual work, assembling a gang of Oxford undergraduates to mend a muddy road at Ferry Hinksey.

Oscar Wilde did some amateurish digging (a rehearsal, perhaps, for his later hemp-picking in Reading Gaol), while the ungrateful villagers jeered. Then the university vacation came and the incompetently repaired path reverted to mire. All Ruskin could propose, as his antidote to the iniquities of industrialism and the frenetic progress of 'the steam-whistle party', was the quaintly retro Guild of St George, with specially selected agricultural tenants cultivating plots of land. He specified that these anachronistic peasants must be 'cheerful and honest, accustomed to obey orders, and afraid of God'.

As Batchelor makes painfully clear, Ruskin's fondness for easy remedies and alluring fictions led him to espouse sentimentality, silliness and soft porn. He set up a Ruskinian academy for girls (whom he addressed as 'My dear Birds') in Cheshire, and asked the conductor Hallé to inculcate domestic virtue by playing them the treacly ballad 'Home, Sweet Home'.

Hallé railed that Ruskin preferred this 'sickly and shallow' tune to the symphonies of Beethoven. Certainly, by the 1880s he had come to prefer the coy, kitsch illustrations of Kate Greenaway to the more challenging art of Whistler (whose impressionistic nocturnes made him, though Ruskin could not see it, the successor to his juvenile idol Turner). Ruskin's only objection to Greenaway's nymphets was that they wore too many clothes. He coaxed his protegée to strip off their hats, shoes, mittens, and finally their frocks.

Despite Ruskin's crazed infatuation with the anorexic teenager Rose La Touche, Batchelor claims that he was no paedophile. The reason seems to be a quibbling technicality: Lewis Carroll 'was exclusively attracted to little girls', whereas Ruskin managed to prolong his own fixations into 'the young adult life of the chosen girl'.

Grown-up women dismayed him, and he never made love to his wife Effie, unmanned by 'certain circumstances in her person'. Usually this is thought to refer to his revulsion from her pubic hair. Batchelor speculates that the gawky bridegroom might have been baffled by the lunar mysteries of menstrual flow, or perhaps put off by what T.S. Eliot called the 'female stench'. Nevertheless, Ruskin reacted tetchily when accused of impotence. He was a vigorous and assiduous masturbator, and wrote to his friend Mrs Cowper-Temple offering a demonstration: 'I can prove my virility at once.'

Whatever you decide about Ruskin's partiality for unfledged maidens, there's another secret sympathy between him and Lewis Carroll. At the end of his book, Batchelor remarks that Ruskin's imagination inhabited a series of private, privileged worlds, like the insulated city of Venice or that girls' school outside Manchester or his fantastical guild: he 'was working towards a total, spatial organisation, a kind of world-map called "Ruskin" '. Although Batchelor does not say so, this idyllic, self-absorbed garden has much in common with J.M. Barrie's Neverland and also with the Wonderland of Carroll's stories about Alice. Ruskin, prophetically intent on actualising the New Jerusalem, was actually a creator of that Victorian alternative to bleak, iron-bound reality which we call Nonsense.

His ideas, for the most part, are - as Batchelor admits - 'sublimely silly'. What remains worth celebrating is the writing which, with its visual finesse and its visionary frenzy, transforms criticism into poetry: the rhapsodies about clouds in Modern Painters, the first enraptured glimpse of San Marco in The Stones of Venice, the fulminations against industrial filth in The Storm-Cloud of the Nineteenth Century, or the aerial survey of Europe from the Mediterranean to the Volga in The Nature of Gothic.

In the year of Ruskin's centenary, we don't need more biographies of the wretched, demented man. Why doesn't someone publish an anthology of his prose?

fields.headline: A goat of many colours
fields.standfirst: Jonathan Keates' Smile Please is a smart social comedy of contemporary men of mode
fields.trailText: Jonathan Keates' Smile Please is a smart social comedy of contemporary men of mode
fields.body:
Smile Please

Jonathan Keates

Chatto & Windus £15.99, pp330

Adam, the central character in Smile Please, has a favourite gay sleazepit where you can take a break from the business of grapple and groan to 'discuss early Antonioni or the Shostakovich cello sonata'. As in Alan Hollinghurst and Edmund White, Jonathan Keates's novel ripples with gay men who combine dizzy aesthetic discrimination with unremitting goatishness, romping through the metropolis like centaurs.

Recreational sex, Adam reflects, is like an act of exegesis on a biological standard text - a nice idea, especially in this teasing story of lives that struggle to find a sense of purpose. Adam is a happy humper but can't help angling for love, especially from Frankie, a devastating Manhattan choreographer. His flatmate Theo is enmeshed in a perilous liaison with a banker who hides beneath a 'great canopy of reticence'.

Keates peppers both narrative and dialogue with literary allusions. Characters lift surnames from Restoration literature, suggesting a smart social comedy of contemporary men of mode. The novel certainly tinkles with petty vanities and is striped by barcodes of last year's allusions, from Posh and Becks to Daniela Nardini and rust-coloured pashminas. Like a Restoration play, Smile Please examines an affective but edgy clutch of friends, seen both on the urban range and marooned together for weekends in the country. Keates, unlike Hollinghurst, admits interesting female characters, from Daisy the cultural fixer to country wife Serena, who devotedly scrubs the mirrors and gouges the mud from her husband's wellingtons.

But literature for Keates also has an unyielding moral force. In one of the stories from his last collection, 'Soon to be a Major Motion Picture', a style queen is saved from superficiality by a fortuitous gift of Cranford and devours Gaskell's ample domesticity. Here, too, the references carry weight - Shakespeare and Austen, but from their least ingratiating works, particularly Troilus and Cressida and Mansfield Park. Poor Willy Loman from Death of a Salesman is also name-checked, just as perpetual non-commitment begins to exact an emotional cost. Masks and lechery inform the narrative.

This is a world where faking it - interest, happiness, desire without strings - is second nature, no more difficult to apply than moisturiser. Even the restaurants have names like Maschera (masks) and people wear Armani suits with concealed buttons. A lover's tender gift is his casting photo. Smile Please, always entertaining, becomes increasingly sympathetic and absorbing as we chase through the tendrils of clause and sub-clause.

Keates, in this novel, responds more eagerly to deception than plain dealing. Style, not sincerity, piques his interest and he writes well about the shadow-play of Frankie's hands, the oblique skirmishing between in-laws. The smoke screens, the veils, may conceal some unremarkable truths - all men are bastards, for example, always comes in useful - but then they're usually the most difficult to assimilate.

fields.headline: Goodbye to all that
fields.standfirst: Andrew Marr weaves the historical context into his account of his journey in The Day Britain Died
fields.trailText: Andrew Marr weaves the historical context into his account of his journey in The Day Britain Died
fields.body:
The Day Britain Died

Andrew Marr

Profile £7.99, pp251

Buy it at BOL

Television and the written word have both been trawling through the ashes of Great Britain in general and England and the English in particular. In recent weeks two major journeys have been carried out. First Darcus Howe's revealing White Tribe for Channel 4 took him to the parts many of us have deliberately avoided reaching. Now Andrew Marr has done the same thing for BBC2. This is the book of the film.

Marr's progress is constantly informed by history and embellished by the relevant writing of others. The exact day Britain died is not specified, nor is the author convinced that Britain is quite dead, but unless we all rise to the challenge, he's sure it pretty soon will be. That's the challenge he throws down. While Howe basks in sun-kissed aspects of the English, he is also desperate about the lot of many left behind by the Thatcher/Blair revolutions - an often racist rump of people without hope. Marr is altogether more optimistic. But then he is a Scot, apparently secure in his identity, even in the South.

This book does something few others have achieved. Robert Cheshyre journeyed through Britain in the Eighties, Jonathan Freedland compared our constitutional chances with the Americans, and Simon Sharma analysed who we are against our reaction to Princess Diana's death. Marr has pulled their best thoughts together and woven a historical context into every step of his way across the country. Through it all his own powers of incisive observation and intelligent solution are threaded.

It's impossible not to share his excitement for the opportunities thrown up by constitutional change. The Blair Government has taken critical bricks out of the moribund pile that doubles for the mother of Parliaments. It has extracted more bricks from the hopelessly over-centralised Britain that finally blamed and then expelled Conservative legislators from its geographical extremities. Despite the Royal Commission, the concept of a House of Lords is dead. So too is an unreformed 665-member House of Commons.

Marr has no truck with the 'don't do it, you never know where it will end' school of political commentary. His passion is to say if the constitutional model has run out of steam, change it and respond to where the change leads.

The same philosophy is in play as he places Britain at the epicentre of the new world of 'e-opportunity'. Charting the development of the City from colonial, family-dominated business to the multi-trillion-dollar trading and banking entity that it is now - bigger in most respects than any other financial market in the world - he demonstrates how sumptuously placed the British are to seize the money-making opportunities of the Internet.

The City has been an increasingly homogenised marketplace for years - Germans, Japanese, Brazilians and Americans working alongside their British colleagues in an environment where nationality is irrelevant. As Marr puts it, 'as an open, risk-taking, English speaking economy, Britain has been perfectly placed for the second wave of Internet development'.

He sees the effect of the Net 'flattening old hierarchies', linking groups of people who could never speak to each other before, and smashing the old British fetish of state secrecy with its free flow of information. Thus while the great national constitutional edifices crumble, the secrecy and the non-meritocratic hocus-pocus that gird the state about crumble with them.

Immigration played its part in breaking the old Britain - high achieving new Britons who cannot easily be conjoined with the old nations that contributed to the British state. The top 100 are worth £5bn between them. They chime with the globalising effects of the Net.

And then there is Europe. Here Andrew Marr appears as the Blairites once were. He's a European, convinced that a regionally empowered Britain will fit an evolving new European order. He would have us in the euro as soon as possible. He is certain that with globalisation Britain is ahead of the game, able to give Europe a lead. He wants us right in, upheaving from within, sparking fundamental questioning and radical reform of European institutions.

It's old Winston Churchill who Marr tells us was the first significant Briton to trumpet a belief in Britain being the cornerstone of a 'new United States of Europe'. No wonder dear old Margaret Thatcher found it so easy to sign the Single European Act. It's here that Marr identifies one probable culprit for our age-old failure to connect with Europe. He quotes the faceless Foreign Office bureaucrat talking of the critical founding EC conference in Sicily in 1955. 'Gentlemen, you are trying to negotiate something you will never be able to negotiate. But if negotiated, it will not be ratified. And if ratified, it will not work.'

Needless to say, the referendum over the euro - an event that has slipped even since the book emerged from the printers - is seen as the defining moment of truth. Marr sees it as setting out the stark choice between the true death of Britain and the actual birth of opportunity in a globalising world.

Marr is least convincing in finding solutions for the 'left out', who so dominate the England of Darcus Howe's White Tribe. I emerged from the book feeling that the expanding middle classes are going to have a great old time, but that the unemployed and ill-educated can expect nothing.

We can see it already - the gulf between rich and poor widening and deepening. Neither Churchill's United States of Europe nor the Internet appear to hold much hope for them. An English Parliament, a federal republic, a written constitution - Andrew Marr has no exact picture of where it all leads. But he is certain about where we are headed if we don't go with the flow, 'a chilly churchyard of the mind, throwing handfuls of clay on the Union flag'.

He sees the effect of the Net 'flattening old hierarchies', linking groups of people who could never speak to each other before, and smashing the old British fetish of state secrecy with its free flow of information. Thus while the great national constitutional edifices crumble, the secrecy and the non-meritocratic hocus-pocus that gird the state about crumble with them. Immigration played its part in breaking the old Britain - high achieving new Britons who cannot easily be conjoined with the old nations that contributed to the British state. The top 100 are worth £5bn between them. They chime with the globalising effects of the Net. And then there is Europe. Here Andrew Marr appears as the Blairites once were. He's a European, convinced that a regionally empowered Britain will fit an evolving new European order. He would have us in the euro as soon as possible. He is certain that with globalisation Britain is ahead of the game, able to give Europe a lead. He wants us right in, upheaving from within, sparking fundamental questioning and radical reform of European institutions. It's old Winston Churchill who Marr tells us was the first significant Briton to trumpet a belief in Britain being the cornerstone of a 'new United States of Europe'. No wonder dear old Margaret Thatcher found it so easy to sign the Single European Act. It's here that Marr identifies one probable culprit for our age-old failure to connect with Europe. He quotes the faceless Foreign Office bureaucrat talking of the critical founding EC conference in Sicily in 1955. 'Gentlemen, you are trying to negotiate something you will never be able to negotiate. But if negotiated, it will not be ratified. And if ratified, it will not work.' Needless to say, the referendum over the euro - an event that has slipped even since the book emerged from the printers - is seen as the defining moment of truth. Marr sees it as setting out the stark choice between the true death of Britain and the actual birth of opportunity in a globalising world. Marr is least convincing in finding solutions for the 'left out', who so dominate the England of Darcus Howe's White Tribe. I emerged from the book feeling that the expanding middle classes are going to have a great old time, but that the unemployed and ill-educated can expect nothing. We can see it already - the gulf between rich and poor widening and deepening. Neither Churchill's United States of Europe nor the Internet appear to hold much hope for them. An English Parliament, a federal republic, a written constitution - Andrew Marr has no exact picture of where it all leads. But he is certain about where we are headed if we don't go with the flow, 'a chilly churchyard of the mind, throwing handfuls of clay on the Union flag'.

fields.headline: My ruined village
fields.standfirst:
The cottages are occupied by bankers and media high fliers. The school has been closed down. The last farmer is on income support. John Mortimer condemns modern life in rural Britain

Countryside in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: It is the habit of governments, when they want to interfere in any field of activity, to start by rubbishing those who live through its problems every day. When they want to mould education to their particular purposes they start by letting it be known that all school teachers are ill-disciplined relics of the Sixties. When they plan to do something really outrageous, like denying the right to trial by jury, they denounce lawyers, who might protest, as money-grubbing conservatives. And when they decide to take the giant step of not doing much at all about the plight of rural England, farmers and country dwellers have become hopeless whingers who ought to thank their lucky stars they're not living in Manchester.
fields.body:
It is the habit of governments, when they want to interfere in any field of activity, to start by rubbishing those who live through its problems every day. When they want to mould education to their particular purposes they start by letting it be known that all school teachers are ill-disciplined relics of the Sixties. When they plan to do something really outrageous, like denying the right to trial by jury, they denounce lawyers, who might protest, as money-grubbing conservatives. And when they decide to take the giant step of not doing much at all about the plight of rural England, farmers and country dwellers have become hopeless whingers who ought to thank their lucky stars they're not living in Manchester.

I've lived in this village at the edge of the Chilterns for 70 years. When I was a child, we had, within a mile, three pubs, three shops, a post office, two schools, two churches and a chapel. A bus came and took people to the town six miles away and brought them back. Now we have no shops, no post office, no bus. One of the pubs has vanished and another is about to be closed and sold off as a desirable residence to a commuter. Cottages which once contained wood cutters, chair-leg turners and farm workers now change hands at nearly £1 million to house merchant bankers and couples in television. There are few affordable houses for the descendants of the chair-leg turns and farm labourers. One of the churches and the chapel have been converted into expensive homes and, worst of all, there is no school, and when the school goes the heart goes out of a village.

But down a bumpy road, through the beech trees, in a secret and silent valley, we have a local farmer who keeps sheep and cattle. He has a wife and four young children, a radio but no television. His accounts show that, after the deduction of his necessary expenses, he is left with a profit of £9 a week to keep himself and his family. He gets income support so that, presumably, he is perfectly all right. If he talks about the crisis in the countryside, Tony Blair apparently feels justified in asking: 'What crisis?'

After years of neglect and the mishandling of the BSE crisis by the last government, the farmers and country dwellers were bursting to vote Labour. Their present mood can be judged by the huge, well-behaved countryside marches and the reception given to bland government Ministers pointing out, with singular ineptitude, various alternatives to farming.

Our local sheep farmer should, they say, start a riding school, but he's no horseman and has no money to buy horses. He should open a theme park, but neither he nor the Government have much of a talent for theme parks. He should take in bed and breakfast visitors, but his family occupy all the bedrooms. The Government's solutions can only remind you of the one-legged actor in Peter Cook's sketch who has it in mind to play Tarzan.

The truth of the matter is that the Government is standing back and allowing farming to die, just as Mrs Thatcher presided over the death throes of heavy industry. Twenty-two thousand farmers went out of business last year, and another 22,000 the year before. There's £360m waiting in Brussels to compensate farmers for the strong pound, but the Government won't take it because they would have to provide matching money - only half the sum blown on the transient Dome. Farmers, some hundreds of whom have been driven to suicide, now have to watch another £60m being handed out to a 'millennium experience' utterly remote from the England of Cumbrian hillsides and Devon villages.

If England is thought of with affection it's often because of our countryside. Our literature, from Chaucer to Shakespeare, Milton, Wordsworth, Emily Brontë and D.H. Lawrence, is seasoned in the country, the fields and woodlands. It's the business of government to see that it's preserved for the pleasure and sanity of all of us. The fatal mistake has been to imagine that the interests of the countryside are in some way different from the interests of farmers. The countryside can only be maintained by a healthy agriculture. If farming dies a most precious part of England dies with it.

We're told, on the basis of doubtful and speculative statistics, that 3.8 million new houses are needed to cover our green and pleasant land, 900,000 in South-East England. Such houses, if needed, should be used to reclaim inner cities. We might have suggested they should be used to give jobs and provide benefits in the neglected North, did we not have it on Tony Blair's good authority that the North-South divide is as imaginary as the crisis in the countryside.

The fox hunting issue, which raises so much political excitement, is an example of the suspicion by urbanised MPs that the country is the home of bloodthirsty toffs. Hunting, far easier to defend than shooting or fishing, is enjoyed by many country dwellers including unemployed Welsh miners, long-distance lorry drivers and the mounted police. The Bill, proposed by Mr Foster and voted for enthusiastically by Labour MPs, would have made it a criminal offence to walk a dog which started to chase a rabbit and then changed its mind and ran after a hare. When an MP had to admit to Jeremy Paxman that he couldn't tell a rabbit from a hare, those in the country who regard hunting as a reasonable and legitimate pursuit were left wondering at the depths of our legislators' igno rance. It seems to us an acceptable way of controlling foxes which, having no concern for animal rights, slaughter our chickens and lambs.

We are also left wondering at a government which wants to raise road taxes and petrol prices when life in the country would mean permanent house arrest without a motor car. We are disturbed by the social divisions between town and country caused by criminalising hunters.

We wonder at the hostility of a government which was genuinely welcomed by many voters in marginal country seats. We were astonished when a party in Downing Street, intended to welcome country representatives, excluded the Countryside Alliance and the Society for the Preservation of Rural England, which is like having a party for theatricals and failing to invite anyone from the Royal Shakespeare Company or the National Theatre.

Above all, we feel that the English countryside, and a healthy agriculture, would be a more lasting tribute to the millennium than a voyage inside a plastic human body on a remote site in Greenwich.

webTitle: Ramblers face threat of electric shock treatment

fields.headline: Ramblers face threat of electric shock treatment
fields.standfirst: Countryside in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: FRESH air, sweet smells - and electrocution. Britain's ramblers and riders, used to facing nothing wilder than a pheasant, are facing a new potential killer in the countryside: fortified wiring.
fields.body:
FRESH air, sweet smells - and electrocution. Britain's ramblers and riders, used to facing nothing wilder than a pheasant, are facing a new potential killer in the countryside: fortified wiring.

The wiring - connected to the mains and with no warning signs - is proliferating across bridleways and open heathland, and is even stretched across paths which are public rights of way. Unsuspecting people have been severely shocked, ending up in hospital or dead.

Electric fences have traditionally been powered by low voltage car batteries, which give people a slight tingling feeling. It is now more common for the wire to be connected to mains. Although voltage is reduced by a transformer, it is still powerful.

Vicky Allen, bridleways officer of the British Horse Society, said mains power for fences is common because it is cheap. 'They're a substitute for managing your fences and hedges properly. It's cheaper - but it's a grave danger,' she said. 'There are so many bad accidents.'

Last year, hiker Jonathan Bridge, fit and 42, spent a week in hospital after a spot of fence trouble. A farmer had strung a wire across a stile with no warning that it was electrified. Rather than take a five-mile diversion, Bridge stepped over it, but slipped. He was entangled for 45 minutes, repeatedly shocked to the brink of unconsciousness.

'I lost my balance under the load of my rucksack, receiving a violent shock to the face' he said. 'I jerked involuntarily away, but another jolt followed, and then another, and another.'

Rolf Peacock, a retired auditor, was on his first long walk last October after a heart attack. 'The wire was impossible to see. I walked straight into it, and it gave me a huge jolt. The shock went down to my feet and back up again.' he said. 'With my heart, I was really worried.' People wearing pacemakers are more at risk.

The National Farmers' Union's guidelines on good practice with electric fences, are widely flouted. David Berskine, policy director of the Ramblers' Association said: 'It's disgusting that some landowners and farmers have such contempt for the public that they would put people's health at risk.'

For horse riders, electric fences pose a particular threat. Horses tend to conduct electricity easily, and panic wildly.

For one elderly but experienced Leicestershire rider, such a shock proved fatal. His horse bolted when it touched the electric fence, throwing him to the ground. He died in hospital a few days later.

fields.headline: Black record of Tory 'Green'
fields.standfirst:
Countryside in crisis: special report

Hague's new environment spokesman laid waste to countryside as Asda boss
fields.trailText: He is being dubbed the 'greenbelt destroyer'. Archie Norman, the multi-millionaire businessmen brought in by the Tories as environment spokesman, is under fierce attack over his business activities.
fields.body:
He is being dubbed the 'greenbelt destroyer'. Archie Norman, the multi-millionaire businessmen brought in by the Tories as environment spokesman, is under fierce attack over his business activities.

An Observer investigation links Norman to a controversial deal with a local authority, destruction of the green belt and a breach of parliamentary rules.

The revelations will heap further embarrassment on Tory leader William Hague, who hoped to use Norman's business acumen on the shadow frontbench to turn around the political fortunes of his party.

While Norman chaired Asda in the mid-Nineties the supermarket group offered hundreds of thousands of pounds to Manchester City Council for a piece of land in an effort to prevent rival Kwik Save building a store there. According to evidence given to the Commons environment select committee, Asda set up a meeting with then council leader Graham Stringer - now a Minister in the Cabinet Office - and offered the authority money for the land 'because they did not want the extra competition'.

Had Asda's bid been successful it could have faced an investigation by competition authorities. The council refused the offer and sold the land to Kwik Save.

Asda denied it acted anti-competitively saying it wanted the land to increase 'flexibility for expansion'. But the Minister wrote to the committee standing by his version of the events. He said: 'The account given by Asda is at variance with my recollection. I was present at the meeting with Howard Bern stein, who is now the chief executive of Manchester City Council. I have checked with Mr Bernstein and he, without prompting from me, said Asda offered money to Manchester City Council because they did not want the extra competition which Kwik Save would have provided.'

The disclosure will be highly embarrassing for Norman who, as chairman of Asda, would have been ultimately responsible for a deal that would have resulted in less competition for consumers and local residents.

Norman is also under fire for a 'horrendous' environmental record as chairman of Asda and previously as a director of Kingfisher, the retail group that owns B&Q, Woolworths and Comet. Last year Asda was bought by US supermarket giant Wal-Mart, renowned for its large out-of-town stores and damage to many local communities in the US. In the last decade Asda has built dozens of stores outside town centres. These have been condemned by environmentalists for ripping up the countryside and generating traffic pollution.

Until Hague gave Norman the environment brief last week he remained a consultant to Wal-Mart-Asda. While he was still involved with the company, Wal-Mart-Asda's plans have included proposals to build a 100,000 sq ft retail park on the edge of Stevenage. This scheme is linked to massive housing development that would lead to the largest loss of green belt land ever seen in the UK.

Two other new stores planned by Wal-Mart-Asda are under attack. One in Southport, Merseyside, is being opposed by Friends of the Earth, who argue that the 180,000 sq ft site will generate excessive traffic, much of it running through conservation sites including the Ribble Estuary Special Protection Area. A third proposal in Cannock, Staffordshire, is being opposed by the local community . The 76,000 sq ft store will mean the loss of a sports field and green spaceand the demolition of a community centre and school. The road where the store is to be located already exceeds air quality limits.

While Norman was at Kingfisher he was chairman of its property subsidiary Chartwell Land. This company was a key player in building a large number of out-of-town retail parks on greenfield sites.

Labour, Liberal Democrats and environmentalists have labelled Norman the 'greenbelt destroyer' and believe it is inappropriate for him to talk on the environment.

Although the Tory environment spokesman sold his shareholding in Wal-Mart-Asda last week, he has kept his investments in a company called Knutsford - an investment firm set up to take over ailing retail companies. He declared his directorship of Knutsford in the Register of Members Interests but has failed to disclose his 9 per cent shareholding in this company. Parliamentary rules insist Members of Parliament declare shareholdings if they amount to more than 1 per cent of the company.

Critics of Hague's decision to appoint a man with such business interests - Norman was also a director of Railtrack - to such a sensitive post also point to Norman's links to the controversial party treasurer Michael Ashcroft. Norman's key partner in Knutsford is businessman Nigel Wray who sits on the board of one of Aschroft's key companies, Carlisle plc.
