He was his mother's favourite, but when he was 17 Vera Shipman died of cancer. During her last months of agony, he would watch as she sat in her chair while the doctor injected her with pain-relieving morphine. Later, of course, he became the doctor, injecting morphine into the veins of other elderly women as they sat fully dressed in their chairs. In this terrible tableau that he re-enacted so many times, growing more blatant as he went, was he murdering the patients because they weren't his mother? Was he killing her over and over again, or bringing his dear mother back to life again by mimicking that vividly particular moment of his past? It seems too neat and too artistic to be true - a spooky Hitchcockian version of the birth of a murderer, the mummy's boy becoming psycho. For the pains and disappointments and traumas that Harold Shipman experienced are just the stuff of life. Nobody escapes them. They are retrospective explanations that can never really tell us how it was that one unremarkable boy from Nottingham became Western Europe's most prolific murderer, working as hard at his lethal hobby as he had worked at his medical studies. Serial killings often do appear like garish fictions, and the killers like trashy artists bent on recreating the same scene, over and over again. They have their own grotesque 'signatures', they often arrange the bodies to dramatise their own dark fantasies (they remove limbs, cut off breasts, disfigure faces). The American psychologist and detective Robert Keppel says that serial killers usually 'have a compulsion to leave their own personal stamp. The killer's personal stamp takes the form of his unique signature, an imprint left by him at the scene'. They may, he says, carve on the body, bludgeon it, leave messages written in blood, rearrange the position of the victim, performing post-mortem activities which suit their own personal desires. The Wests buried their young female victims upright, in blasphemously vertical coffins; they took away knee and foot bones. Dr Shipman - seating the women, fully dressed, on a chair, and injecting them with morphine - turns the women into his dying mother. Or perhaps he turns them into his wife, the woman he met soon after Vera died, and who looked matronly and middle-aged even as a teenager. And he turns the dead women into lists, catalogues, items on medical cards that are filed away. The 'trophies' he is suspected of taking away from some of the murder scenes are not bits of the body, as with many serial killers, but objects like rings, bracelets, money. The day that his mother died, Harold Shipman ran all night, pounding the road in the driving rain. Then he seemed to get on with his life - working hard, getting into Leeds University, becoming a doctor. He met Primrose Mary Oxtoby at a bus stop, when he was a 20-year-old medical student and she was a 16-year-old window dresser. She had never had a boyfriend before. She soon fell pregnant, to the dismay of her Methodist family, and when she was 17 the pair married, three months before the birth of their daughter Sarah. At the moment of his apparently triumphant upward mobility, the young medic married the barely literate woman from the world he seemed to have escaped. Shipman's life reads like a mixture of Thomas Hardy and Thomas Harris. It seems that Primrose lost her family and her previous existence when she married: she moved into his narrow world, became the doctor's wife, bringing up his children, sometimes helping out in the surgery. They had three more children (Christopher, David and Samuel). Harold finished his training. In 1971 he qualified as a doctor. In 1974 he became a GP in Todmorden, West Yorkshire. It was here he suffered a glitch in his career, for it was discovered he had been forging prescriptions for the pain-killing drug pethidine, to which he had become addicted. He admitted everything, checked into hospital, and pleaded guilty to forging prescriptions and stealing drugs. In 1977, 'rehabilitated', the couple moved with their growing family to the outskirts of Manchester. Here he became the 'good doctor' of Hyde, adored by his patients who flooded his surgery with letters of support after he was arrested. Even today, in an age when we distrust experts and question authority, doctors are like magicians, with their mysterious kit of tools and potions, their secret vocabulary, their impenetrable handwriting, their hidden knowledge. They can cure and listen. They know our pains and indignities, intimate details about our bodies and our lives. We believe in the doctor, and often become helpless before them. This relationship of subservience and authority gives the doctor great power. Dr Richard Nicholson of The Bulletin of Medical Ethics , asks us to consider how 'nice, intelligent schoolchildren, who go into medicine for humanitarian reasons, are 10 years later working in a system where for the most part questions are not encouraged. Where it is too easy to become arrogant and to stop thinking of patients as human beings, but as symptoms and problems; not human beings like us, but biological processes, objects.' It became a horrible thought through the trial that maybe this small, neat, pedantic man had killed 15 women (and how many more?) because they got on his nerves; needed tidying away. As if they were not people in his mind but symptoms and problems: a cold, a cancer, a heartburn, an ache, an irritation and a worry. Can evil be as terrifyingly banal as all that? Primrose is much larger than her husband; if they stood together, which now they never will, she would dwarf him. During the trial, she mostly dressed in sludge-coloured clothes. She has a pudding-bowl of greying hair and a doughy, grey face. Every day, she took her seat at the front of the public gallery and stared. Even when he collapsed into the dock to cry, coming up minutes later with a reddened nose and a pallid face, she stared and didn't look down and didn't flinch. I didn't see love or hate or pity or horror on her unreadable face. No amazement or anger. She was a loyal wife, a large and lonely figure, a closed book. Who can imagine what her life will be now - or the life of the four children, who woke up one day to find their respectable father was a serial killer? How do you remake your life after that, when his blood runs in your veins? What is your inheritance? Photographs of Primrose when young show that she never looked like a spring flower. She always looked unglamorous and safely unsexual. While the Wests and Myra Hindley lived in a perversely sexualised world, the Shipmans seemed to those that knew them to live in the opposite: a calmly de-sexed one. He was the overworked doctor (she even sometimes called him 'doctor' rather than 'Fred', his usual name to friends), she the overweight wife, dousing any hints of sexuality or youth in too much flesh and shapeless clothes. He would leave the bleak-ish semi-detached house early for the work he loved, coming back in the evening to collapse in front of the TV while she made dinner. They rarely went out together. It appears to outsiders to have been a life where the flame had been turned down low. Even those few minutes surrounding the murders were ones of secret negative pleasures or relief from extreme tension. Not for Harold Shipman the prolonged sexual frenzy of most serial killers, the grotesque drawn-out euphoria. With the Wests, or Myra Hindley and Ian Brady, or Peter Sutcliffe, the extreme sadism was like a Hieronymous Bosch canvas on which the darkest horrors of a mind were daubed. In the Shipman case there was no convulsive surface. For a long time, the murders were never even perceived as such: unnatural was thought to be natural. In a way that unsettles and induces guilt, we can understand extreme sexual perversion better than we can understand this quiet, polite, secret slaughter. One of the most shocking things about the long trial was how Shipman did not become a figure of horror, the stuff of our nightmares. We think serial killers should look different from us. We want them to look inhuman because we want to think of them as inhuman - removed from us, bestial or evil. 'They were not beasts but men, and what they did was a product of specific human ingenuity,' writes Robert Jay Lifton in his book about Nazi doctors. 'They were not demonic figures,' says an Auschwitz survivor of the Nazi doctors. 'What was demonic was that they were not demonic.' Thomas Harris's hero-monster, Hannibal Lecter, has six fingers and purple eyes and the uncanny grace of a panther. Myra Hindley was abhorred not just for what she did, but because of that photograph of her, with the blond wig and heavy make-up, transforming her into an icon of sexualised and perverse female evil. Her partner in crime, Ian Brady, remained a vague, shadowy figure. Other children are killed by children, but it was James Bulger who tugged at all our heartstrings because he was caught on a grainy security video in the shopping centre, his small hand trustingly in the older child's hand - a lamb to the slaughter; we saw the image going round and round on a loop, so that it felt as if it was still going on. Peter Sutcliffe had a chalk-white face and a black beard and ghastly voices roaring in his head. Threadbare, grey Dr Shipman looks like an identikit picture of ordinariness and respectability - an image that is an anti-image. Beyond this, Shipman was less horrifying to us because of who he killed. All of the victims were women, many of them elderly. In newspapers, they were frequently all called old, thus shamefully bundled together and tidied away with that one epithet, even though one, Bianka Pomfrett, was just 49, which is hardly even middle-aged, and her face that now gazes from the rows of photographs in newspaper pages looks young and thoughtful. We expect old people to die. We think of them as if they are in death's waiting room. When the young die, it is their future as well as their present that we mourn. The old are supposed to be ready for death, relinquishing turbulent, fretful life for peaceful, easeful oblivion. Shipman's victims were unnoticed victims for a disquieting stretch of time; murders that we didn't call murders. Even once the trial began, there was sparse coverage in most newspapers. People's reactions often seemed to be not ones of pity or fear, but of distaste. In Hyde last week, just before the verdict was reached, many of Harold Shipman's patients were even saying that they would return to him if they could. 'I'd go back tomorrow,' says one woman, scowling at me ferociously in the market place. 'I don't know about those murders, to me he was always a good doctor.' 'A perfect gentleman,' says another. 'And anyway, only God can know why he did it.' 'The best doctor, always there. Couldn't put a foot wrong.' These people aren't saying he didn't do it. They are close to saying that it doesn't really matter. Shipman is on suicide watch in prison, but warders apparently say he will not be at great risk from other prisoners. He hasn't killed children. He has only killed elderly women. There has never been a time, in the Western world, when we have denied age and death as we do today. We want to live longer and longer, forever. Once we valued age and wisdom; now we value youth, newness, and we dread old age, the lines on the face, life marking us: not just closer to death but further away from what we think of as life. Instead of thinking of the elderly as full of years, it is as if the more years we have, the emptier of life we become - we are using it up, running out of life and out of time. Ronald Blythe, in his wonderful book about old age, The View in Winter , points out that it used to be the exception to go grey, to live through the menopause, to retire, to become senile. There was a sense of the precariousness and preciousness of life, which could end at any time. To live to old age was extraordinary. Now old age is expected, ordinary - and thus contemptible. One in 10 people are over 60; by 2050, one in five will be over 60. And there are many more old women than old men. Simone de Beauvoir, in her sombre The Coming of Age , writes that when old people speak of the elderly they never use the word 'we', always 'they'. She writes about how we avoid the old; it is society's 'secret shame'. Today, in the year 2000, it seems as if we think of the old in the same, brutal way that we used to think of the poor in the nineteenth century: as an intractable problem, a burden. What shall we do with the hordes of people who have left the blessed land of youth? Age Concern has produced surveys on the media's attitudes towards the old. In a report on older people on tele vision ('Fading Out of the Picture'), they revealed that older people appear on television three times less, proportionally, than you would expect them to given their real life numbers. Older women are particularly neglected (70 per cent men to 30 per cent women). What is more, the characters they represent in dramas are often stereotyped (they moan, forget, dwell on the past, are doting and sweet and dotty_). The picture is slightly better in newspapers, where news stories about older people are not neglected. However, the concept of what stories are worth telling has not been updated: older people are mostly depicted as victims, frail objects of pity. The headlines above the stories generally use predictable, tired words. Gerry Bennet, a consultant geriatrician at the London Hospital, has done a lot of work on the abuse of the elderly. He agrees that because we see elderly people as 'terminal', we think of Shipman's crimes as 'terrible, of course, but not as terrible as we should. Look at donations to charities,' he says wryly. 'The appeals that work are for children or animals. Old people aren't sexy.When we think about old age, we feel fear and we don't want to face our own future.' Yet, he says, if we think of the last millennium, you could say that one of the greatest achievements is ageing. At the same time, people transform this achievement into a negative: a 'rising tide of old people that floods the NHS' - the NHS, he points out, that they have paid into all their lives and which now deserts them, refusing them operations and help because of their years. Abuse of the elderly, he says, is always about power. To take a life is the ultimate act of power. We deny older people crucial human qualities. They are not supposed to be sexual, eager, ambitious, angry, jealous, any of the things that we all are. Regan said to Lear: 'O sir! you are old;/ Nature in you stand on the very verge/ Of her confine: you should be rul'd and led/ By some discretion that discerns your state/ Better than yourself...' Old age is seen as relinquishment and abstinence. A time of memory, not of anticipation, past not future, nostalgia not change. We think of old people - doting on their grandchildren, retelling their mythologised past - as living on in the after-image of their own past. No kissing in the park, holding hands in the dark. Yet what old people want is usually what they have always wanted: career, family, friends, sex, appetite, a future. They feel close to the selves they were as children, or young. They look in the mirror and find it hard to believe they have come this far. They still, always, want to be wanted, needed, loved. Tracey Kidder, in Old Friends , his remarkable book about living for a year in an old people's home in America, shows us that the old are only like children in one respect - we treat them like children, talking loudly and slowly, with that over-solicitous tone; not seeing them, never allowing 'us' to become one of 'them'. Our shameful separation from ourselves. And Betty Friedan, who made herself famous with The Feminine Mystique , says in her book about growing older, The Fountain of Age , that 'there's a mystique of age more pernicious, pervasive, than the feminine mystique_ a definition of age only in terms of a decline from youth and not as it is, a period of human life that people didn't even use to have.' We are scared of old age because we are scared of our own frailty and death. Old people are often not visited by family when they are in hospitals or homes, because the family don't want to have to confront in slow-motion their own mortality. Serial killers are a mixture of order and disorder. They operate with a methodical derangement. They are not geniuses, but they are obsessed. Murder is their most passionate hobby. They are hard to catch because they operate outside the realms of reason. In the aftermath of such horror, we look for explanations, like a lesion in the brain or a childhood sexual trauma. We want to know why and how, to learn lessons from the past to protect us in our future. And we seek ways of making sure this never happens again. But one of the unsatisfying lessons of such horrors is that there is no ultimate lesson after all - nothing in the end that provides the final impregnable why, no thick line drawn underneath the horror. Professor Christopher Cordess, co-editor of Forensic Psychiatry: Crime, Psychodynamics and the Offender Patient , says that 'there are some cases that even the further reaches of psychological understanding don't reach. We are left aghast.' It happens. Out of a blue sky, on an ordinary day, to a person who is just getting on with their life, violence falls. Their faces look at us now from the newspapers and the television screen, these women the doctor selected. Marie West, Irene Turner. Lizzie Adams. Jean Lilley. Ivy Lomas. Muriel Grimshaw. Marie Quinn. Bianka Pomfret. Norah Nuttall. Pamela Hillier. Maureen Ward. Winifred Mellor. Joan Melia. Kathleen Grundy. How many more? Such different faces, one thing in common. Most of the women are smiling, as one usually does for the camera. A few are laughing, and their eyes are bright. One is shown on a home movie, dancing round the room in the arms of her partner, neat ankles in dashing high-heeled shoes. One is pictured as a young girl and she looks so carefree, with her life in front of her. They all had their lives in front of them.

webTitle: Failure to cut agency nurse levels under fire

fields.headline: Failure to cut agency nurse levels under fire
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: The Royal College of Nursing has attacked the Scottish Executive for not honouring its promise to cut the number of temporary nurses in the health service. A report by the Accounts Commission for Scotland published today says the 540 agency nurses used each day threaten patient care and waste public money.
fields.body:
The Royal College of Nursing has attacked the Scottish Executive for not honouring its promise to cut the number of temporary nurses in the health service. A report by the Accounts Commission for Scotland published today says the 540 agency nurses used each day threaten patient care and waste public money.

The attack comes at a bad time for Labour. Bed shortages during the flu outbreak over Christmas have already shaken the party's image as the guardian of the NHS. The appearance that it is not delivering on a key policy may damage its chances of holding on to the Ayr seat at the up-coming Holyrood by-election.

Nurses from private employment agencies or NHS 'staff banks' - usually nurses seeking extra work or former nurses working part-time - are used to fill the gaps in rotas. The Accounts Commission says the annual cost of £25 million for temporary nurses could be slashed and spent elsewhere.

The Royal College of Nurs ing leapt on the findings and accused the Executive of failing the NHS. At a speech to last year's RCN conference in Edinburgh, former Health Minister Sam Galbraith said: 'Short-term contracts short-change our nurses. Nurses make a commitment to the NHS. Now I want the NHS to make the same commitment to nurses. We will reduce the use of "bank" and agency staff and we will bring to an end the use of short-term contracts, in all but the most exceptional circumstances.'

The acting Scottish secretary for the RCN, Margaret Pullin, said: 'In spite of government assurances, the use of temporary nurses in the NHS is rising.'

The Accounts Commission for Scotland says temporary nurses can harm patients because they are not familiar with the equipment and procedure in each hospital.

The RCN says the problem stems from the understaffing of all NHS trusts, with the latest figures showing 1,145 nursing vacancies in 1998. They claim the cost of £25m for temporary nurses could be used to employ 1,500 new staff.

fields.headline: Shipman aide 'lied to win job'
fields.standfirst:
Mass murderer's practice manager accused of hiding NHS sacking for gross misconduct

Shipman trial: special report
fields.trailText: Health officials are set to question the former practice manager of Dr Harold Shipman - jailed for life last week for killing 15 elderly patients - over allegations that he lied about his background in order to get his job.
fields.byline: by Tracy McVeigh and Tony Thompson
fields.body:
Health officials are set to question the former practice manager of Dr Harold Shipman - jailed for life last week for killing 15 elderly patients - over allegations that he lied about his background in order to get his job.

John Gilmore, 47, had been dismissed from a previous NHS position for gross misconduct.

Gilmore was employed jointly by Shipman and four other doctors from single-handed surgeries in the Hyde area to manage their funds.

He was interviewed in the presence of a West Pennine Health Authority official.

The authority's chief executive, David Common, said Gilmore did not reveal his past misdemeamours which had only come to his attention last week.

'The consortium of GPs was in fact employing Mr Gilmore independently of the authority. But if anything is brought to our attention with regard to an individual we would naturally bring it to the attention of the GPs,' said Common.

He added that someone who had been sacked for gross misconduct would be unlikely to secure job within his authority.

From 1994 to March 1999, Gilmore was responsible for the GPs' drug budgets, becoming a close personal friend of the Shipmans, staying at the family home at times, even after the arrest.

He will now be questioned by the local medical committee where he works as a part-time administrator. The Hyde LMC secretary, Dr Kalash Chand, said: 'We were not aware Mr Gilmore had been sacked for gross misconduct and are very concerned. His explanation of why he left that job seems to have been economical with the truth. We will be having a meeting with him on Monday.'

Doctors at Shipman's practice were first alerted to his crimes by the unusually high number of cremations among patients he was trating.

'At the start of 1998, Shipman was coming in to our surgery and asking us to countersign more cremation certificates than ever before,' says Dr Raj Patel, one of the doctors responsible for sparking the first police investigation.

'We worked out that his rate of death for elderly patients was three times our own. We reported this to the coroner and the police and almost immediately the deaths stopped.

'We are certain that he found out he was being looked into and changed his behaviour accordingly.'

Shipman had killed more than 20 patients in the first three months of the year before the investigation had begun. Only during the trial was it revealed that Shipman altered notes on previous victims in early 1998, to fit cause of death. Dr Alan Banks from the West Pennine Health Authority was asked by poice to examine the files of 14 of Shipman's patients. His comment was that they were not as detailed as they should have been.

In the next four months, he would kill just three more. Sources close to the investi gation believe that the final three deaths may have been an attempt by Shipman to 'keep up appearances' rather than rouse suspicion by ending his killing spree completely.

Greater Manchester Police, who are examining the deaths of 171 of Shipman's patients, are believed to be pursuing several other lines of inquiry including a hunt for the person responsible for the tip off. If it is found that Shipman was deliberately alerted about the investigation, the mole would face a charge of conspiracy to pervert the course of justice.

Shipman was phenomenally well connected in the Hyde community and the source of the leak could have come from many avenues.

Although the cost of Shipman's murder trial was met by the legal aid board, the bill for the year-long run up was met entirely by the Medical Defence Union. Last year the union spent £65 million defending and settling claims against doctors. It supports the cases of 9 out of 10 doctors accused of wrongdoing.

The union was first alerted in February 1998 by Dr Patel, his colleague, Dr Linda Reynolds, and the local undertaker, Deborah Bambroffe, who had noticed that a large number of Shipman's patients did not appear to have been ill when they died.

The union urged extreme caution but the trio decided to inform the local coroner of their suspicions.

He in turn called the police. Both Reynolds and the coroner stressed that the inquiry should be kept 'confidential and discreet'.

The chief executive of the Lincolnshire Heath Authority, Richard Jevins, told The Observer : 'I understand we have never been approached by a new employer of Mr Gilmore's for references. Certainly I would have expected any health authority recruiting anyone to seek references.'

Three years after his sacking Gilmore charged the LHA with unfair dismissal and his claim was settled out of court.

webTitle: Gambling on a little Gallic flair

fields.headline: Gambling on a little Gallic flair
fields.standfirst: The millennium: special report
fields.trailText: While the Dome was still being built, Peter Mandelson, the Minister then in charge, visited Disneyland in Florida seeking inspiration. Two years later, the Government has gone back to Disney, seeking not inspiration, but salvation. They have given the job of running the Dome to a Pierre-Yves Gerbeau, a 34-year-old French Disneyland executive and former one-time professional hockey player.
fields.body:
While the Dome was still being built, Peter Mandelson, the Minister then in charge, visited Disneyland in Florida seeking inspiration. Two years later, the Government has gone back to Disney, seeking not inspiration, but salvation. They have given the job of running the Dome to a Pierre-Yves Gerbeau, a 34-year-old French Disneyland executive and former one-time professional hockey player.

Gerbeau, who likes to be called 'P.Y.', is almost totally unknown in Britain. Yet his new bosses boast he is a whizz-kidd, bubbling with ideas and enthusiasm, who helped save Disneyland, Paris, after its disastrous launch. They are hoping that having worked magic on the Magic Kingdom, he can now save the Dome from doom.

The Government had good reason to look to Disneyland, Paris, for help. The similarities with the Dome are striking - and the lessons potentially invaluable. In 1991, Gerbeau left a job in management consultancy to join Euro Disney, as it was then called, a year before it was opened in a blizzard of hype. Like the Dome, Euro Disney failed to live up to its promise. The target was 11 million visitors, but after just one year, the number started dropping alarmingly, and fell to just 8.8 million.

In 1993, the park lost £654 million, and speculation mounted that it would close. Gerbeau was part of the team of senior managers who saved it through a major relaunch. It needed to revamp its image, and top of the list was a name change. Like the Dome, the park was seen to lack focus, and not to capture visitors' imagination.

A scary new ride, Space Mountain, was opened and succeeded in turning around morale. The park was widely criticised for being too expensive, so prices were slashed. Alcohol was introduced. There were too many 'hosts', and many were sacked. Within a year of its relaunch, the park was making an operational profit.

fields.headline: How Dome dreams were dashed
fields.standfirst:
How a national showcase turned into a white elephant
The millennium: special report
fields.trailText: It was billed as the Greatest Show on Earth - the kind of high-flying, flag-waving event that would make the Festival of Britain look like a village fete and restore Britain's international reputation.
fields.body:
It was billed as the Greatest Show on Earth - the kind of high-flying, flag-waving event that would make the Festival of Britain look like a village fete and restore Britain's international reputation.

Michael Heseltine, announcing plans in 1996 for a new public building at Greenwich to mark the end of the 20th century, said it would put the country back on the map. 'The Dome has been built to re-energise the nation, raise the self-esteem of its people and enhance the nation's standing,' added Tony Blair, once the Dome project had been handed over to Labour along with the chains of office in 1997.

But £758 million later, news that Jennie Page, the chief executive of the Millennium Experience Company, will be replaced tomorrow by a French Disneyland executive is the end of all hopes that the Dome could ever be a source of British pride. Pierre Yves-Gerbeau, 34, has been handed a job which has defeated the best minds on this side of the Channel. With sponsors threatening to fall away and the public hardly more interested, he has been asked to turn around the fortunes of the Dome.

Page, the former career civil servant who herself was poached from her job as chief executive at English Heritage to work with the Dome in 1993, has now carried the can both for the fiasco of the opening night, when thousands were kept waiting in queues until 10 pm, and for the low ticket sales in the first month.

In the face of criticism in the first weeks of the year, Page has doggedly stuck to her line.

'When people come out of the Millenium Show they are hugging staff and saying how wonderful it was,' she said. 'You should be listening to what visitors say, not reading the newsapers.' She has repeatedly blamed a media conspiracy to see the worst in the Dome. The combined efforts of her company and the London Transport Police, which kept at least six national newspaper editors and the future Director-General of the BBC waiting for three hours on the most important night for 1,000 years, did not help.

Headhunted for the job by the then Heritage Secretary, Stephen Dorrell, Page had previously worked for the London Dockland Development Corporation and had a reputation for a hardheaded style of management. She saw her task as making sure that the Dome opened on time and had less sympathy with the creative side of the project. Page, however, was just one of a series of unfortunate foster parents for the Dome.

In 1992 the Government first woke up to the approach of the millennium when they heard about a US TV company trying to hire the Greenwich Observatory for 31 December, 1999. A new building near the site was suddenly seen as the ideal centrepiece of a millennium festival. Two years later the Prime Minister, John Major, set up the Millennium Commission and asked his deputy, Michael Heseltine, to take up the job. The PR problems began in earnest then as the project was ridiculed for being chiefly about Heseltine's ego. Transport difficulties became the key problem the Millennium Commission team had to tackle. The new Docklands Light Railway was unreliable and not the way to move a projected 12 million visitors out to the outskirts of London. The Jubilee Line extension became the lifeline for the whole project, and construction delays and problems were scrutinised by the national press, many of whom looked down on the site from their offices in the Canary Wharf tower.

Cracks developing behind the scenes began to show in January 1998 when Stephen Bayley, creative director of the project, resigned. He described Mandelson, whose project it had become, as a dictator reminiscent of 'an East German Stalinist'. Mandelson said he had been 'decisive'.

The Dome's structure was completed on 22 June and it became a mysterious, low-key tourist attraction. Mandelson's resignation over his undeclared home loan meant responsibilty for the Dome passed on once more. This time Lord Falconer took up the thankless task of defending the Dome at Westminster. He worked closely with Page in a desperate attempt to iron out construction and transport difficulties that loomed.

Last year a sponsorship drive bore fruit as Coca-Cola came in as official drinks sponsor and ex-TV controller Michael Grade was brought in as a kind of stepfather to vet proposals for the creative content of the 14 zones.

fields.headline: £160bn transport bonanza
fields.standfirst:
Efforts to modernise road, rail and air networks will accompany moves to ease traffic, reports

More about transport
fields.trailText: Britain is set to double spending on transport within 10 years, cherry-picking the best schemes from Europe to provide the most effective travel network in the EU .
fields.body:
Britain is set to double spending on transport within 10 years, cherry-picking the best schemes from Europe to provide the most effective travel network in the EU .

Plans are being drawn up on the basis that transport spending over the next 10 years will total £160 billion - twice as much as previously expected - according to several ministerial sources.

Public funding will double from £50bn to around £100bn and the rest is expected to come from the private sector through public-private partnerships to modernise and expand public transport and investment in new trains, planes and buses.

The Government has asked its transport advisers to come up with a 'shopping list' of road and public transport schemes by the end of April to help Britain accelerate away from the chronic congestion and crumbling systems that put it among the worst in Europe.

They will scour the European Union for 'best practice' in tram systems, road use, cycling, bus and rail travel as well as planning, fiscal and safety policies.

Professor David Begg, chairman of the Commission For Integrated Transport (CFIT), which advises the Government on policy, said it was not yet known how much extra funding would be earmarked for transport, but the Government had indicated it was prepared to spend more.

But he warned it would take a huge increase in spending to bring the network up to scratch - and measures to curb congestion would be needed alongside improvements in public transport.

The Institute for Fiscal Studies has calculated that Chancellor Gordon Brown has a surplus of up to £7bn to distribute in tax cuts and increased public spending in his Budget next month, although it is acknowledged that health and education currently have a higher profile. But there is scope to award extra funds for local transport plans, rail projects and the roads programme.

Last week Begg firmly endorsed the policies to ease traffic jams by introducing congestion charging and a levy on workplace car-parks. Local authorities are expected to invest up front, with a combination of public funding, soft loans from Government and secured funding to improve public transport in advance of collecting revenue from motorists (congestion charging) or employers (workplace parking levy).

Begg said: 'Most people assume that better public transport is the answer to congestion, but Paris has superb public transport and terrible congestion. It has to be part of a package of measures, but without congestion charging and planning measures; just improving public transport is not going to work.'

Begg said that there was not a single EU state that came out best on all aspects of transport and could be used as a model.

None of the EU members has an effective policy for reducing traffic congestion. The best example that CFIT has come across is much further afield - in Singapore, where they have draconian congestion charging to limit traffic in the island state.

CFIT will examine different systems and policies across the EU. Ministers want to know why Germans own more than 500 cars per 1,000 inhabitants but use them a lot less than Britons, who own 400 cars per 1,000 people but rely on them more than anyone else in Europe, with 88 per cent of journeys in the UK undertaken by car.

Britain spends less than 1 per cent of its gross domestic product on transport, less than Germany, France, Finland, Portugal, Spain, Sweden and Switzerland, according to the Organisation for Eco nomic Cooperation and Development.

Britain's roads are five times more congested than Germany's, twice as congested as Italy's and 3.5 times more choked up than France's.

Begg endorsed the view of transport minister Lord Macdonald that the Government accepted that car ownership would rise in a growing economy and that ownership was an issue of 'social inclusion'.

But while Macdonald has sought to encourage more affordable car use at the same time as softening the Government's line on reducing traffic levels, Begg insisted that there should be local programmes to reduce congestion, pollution and overall car use.

'Car ownership is acceptable but we need to shift the burden from ownership to car use. If we are going to achieve less car use within growing car ownership, we need fiscal measures to reduce the fixed cost of motoring and increase the variable cost of journeys,' he said.

This means congestion charging and duty on petrol, offset by a new system of lower vehicle excise duty - the annual 'road tax'.

Begg wants the Government to tighten up on planning policy and reverse the trend towards out-of-town shopping that is accelerating the decline of many town centres and villages.

CFIT has put off until next year a policy decision on whether parking spaces at out-of-town retail and leisure complexes should be taxed. But the priority is to help the Government flesh out its 10-year vision for transport with a plan that, according to Begg, involves the kind of money and ambition 'that has not been seen in Britain since the Victorian era'.

webTitle: Blood sport inquiry's hunt links revealed

fields.headline: Blood sport inquiry's hunt links revealed
fields.standfirst:
The hunting debate: special report

'Objective' committee accused of bias
fields.trailText: The Government was last night accused of a 'stitch-up' over its election pledge to ban hunting as opponents of blood sports expressed anger and astonishment that members of the Government's 'independent' committee to gauge the impact of outlawing hunting have close links with pro-hunting bodies.
fields.body:
The Government was last night accused of a 'stitch-up' over its election pledge to ban hunting as opponents of blood sports expressed anger and astonishment that members of the Government's 'independent' committee to gauge the impact of outlawing hunting have close links with pro-hunting bodies.

The Observer has discovered that:

 Professor Michael Winter went on hunts as a child and has as an adult;

 Lord Soulsby of Swaffham Prior offered his services 'free' to the British Field Sports Society, where he tried to counter an academic study showing cruelty suffered by deer being hunted;

 Sir John Marsh is governor of the Royal Agricultural College, which owns a beagle hunt;

 Winter, Soulsby and Marsh have attended meetings run by the pro-hunting Countryside Alliance and accepted their hospitality.

Another member, Victoria Edwards, also has close links with the Royal Agricultural College.

John Cooper, chairman of the League Against Cruel Sports, said: 'How can our members have any confidence in this process? The more we learn about the inquiry members, the more obvious it appears that we have been stitched up.'

The league, together with the International Fund for Animal Welfare and the RSPCA, are now seeking an urgent meeting with the Home Secretary, Jack Straw, to express their concerns.

Angry Labour backbenchers have said they will write to Straw demanding to know how a so-called independent inquiry became loaded with people linked to the hunting community.

Ian Gibson, Labour MP for Norwich North, said: 'I am astonished that three years into a Labour Government pledged to ban hunting we are having a debate about the make-up of a so-called independent committee. It is simply unbelievable that its members seem to be biased one way.'

Mike Foster, the Labour MP for Worcester whose Private Member's Bill banning fox hunting failed because the Government did not give it enough parliamentary time has also demanded answers from the Home Office. A number of animal welfare groups have said they will no longer co-operate with the inquiry.

One Whitehall source says the committee's make-up has led to a furious row within the Home Office, with one Minister blaming civil servants for the appointments.

The committee chairman, Lord Burns, a former Treasury permanent secretary, was appointed by Straw.

Anti-hunt campaigners are particularly concerned about the role of Lord Soulsby, a vet who, it has emerged, helped counter evidence that stag hunting was cruel.

Marsh is exposed as a governor of the Royal Agricultural College in Cirencester, Gloucestershire, whose students are automatically billed for joining its hunt.

The Observer has learnt that the former master of the College's hunt, Simon Hart, is running the Countryside Alliance's response to the Burns inquiry. The college has also received a grant from the Standing Conference on Countryside Sports - whose objective is to ensure survival of hunting and shooting.

Both Marsh and fellow committee member Winter - who has described deer hunting as a rural institution - attended recent meetings of the Standing Conference.

This pro-blood sports think-tank helped devise the study, commissioned by the British Field Sports Society, which concluded 16,000 jobs would be lost if fox hunting was banned. This statistic is used by the Countryside Alliance to lobby against a hunting ban and investigating its veracity forms a crucial part of the work of the Government's committee.

Anti-hunt campaigners fear the Burns inquiry is a time-wasting measure to ensure a ban is not brought in before a general election.

The bitter row over Labour's pledge to ban hunting has raged since the election. In November 1997, Foster obtained overwhelming support in the Commons for his Bill banning hunting. But the Government refused to give it parliamentary time.

The row re-ignited last July when Tony Blair promised to ban hunting as 'soon as we possibly can'. The Government then backtracked on this commitment after fierce lobbying from the pro-hunt Countryside Alliance.

Last November, Straw promised support for a backbench Bill to ban hunting. But the Government failed to support Ken Livingstone weeks later when he said he would introduce such a Bill.

A Home Office spokesman said the committee was objective.

fields.headline: Chechens defiant after bloody flight
fields.standfirst: Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: A group of 40 fighters had gathered yesterday in a village to the west of the capital to mourn their commander, Zainadi, who died alongside hundreds of rebels as they withdrew en masse from Grozny on Monday night.
fields.body:
A group of 40 fighters had gathered yesterday in a village to the west of the capital to mourn their commander, Zainadi, who died alongside hundreds of rebels as they withdrew en masse from Grozny on Monday night.

A handful of them were standing in silence, their heads bowed, outside their commander's house along with elderly men from the village - observing the traditions of a Chechen wake. The only unusual aspect to the ceremony was that the body of the dead man was absent; the commander's corpse had yet to be retrieved from the minefield on the outskirts of the city where so many fighters lost their lives.

The commander's brother, Zaindi - who works for the rebels from behind the front, supplying them with medicine and food - paid tribute to his dead brother, describing how he had managed the village football team in more peaceful times.

Naib, 27, who was with him as he died, described the night-time flight through Russian lines from the besieged capital. Once his initial bravado faded, he conceded that the walk had been terrifying.

'Our commander was killed at about two in the morning, after we had already been walking for two hours,' he said. 'It was hard to go on, but things got worse towards morning, when we realised we had two kilometres of mined territory still to walk through and it was beginning to get light. We could see the bodies of dead and wounded fighters to the left and the right of the path, but we had to go on.'

Naib and the other men in his command said they planned to regather their strength in hiding places in this village as they waited for orders from their field commander, Arbi Barayev. Despite the setbacks of the last week, the men were defiantly positive.

'We expect to get a command to go back into Grozny some time soon; we will go back and we will take it again,' said Aslan, 25, another fighter.

Other villagers in this Russian-controlled settlement were dismayed at the appearance of fighters, whose arrival had attracted a new attack from the Russian army on Wednesday.

Houses in the village, which had been destroyed in the first war and again in earlier fighting in November, were hit again. Bits of masonry from newly col lapsed buildings lay in the streets.

Askhan Kumvalov, 42, showed the fresh damage to his house on Proletarskaya Street and described how two schoolchildren had been wounded in the attack as they made their way to school.

Throughout the afternoon yesterday, the rumble of artillery fire was audible from neighbouring villages in this area, which the Russian military has for many months described as 'liberated territory'.

'The fighting is beginning all over again,' said Khumid, 62. 'Is a cow a terrorist? Are cats, dogs, children and old people - are we all terrorists? If not, then why are they attacking us?'

Houses in the village, which had been destroyed in the first war and again in earlier fighting in November, were hit again. Bits of masonry from newly col lapsed buildings lay in the streets. Askhan Kumvalov, 42, showed the fresh damage to his house on Proletarskaya Street and described how two schoolchildren had been wounded in the attack as they made their way to school. 'The fighting is beginning all over again,' said Khumid, 62. 'Is a cow a terrorist? Are cats, dogs, children and old people - are we all terrorists? If not, then why are they attacking us?'

webTitle: Bomb blast kills five in Pakistan

fields.headline: Bomb blast kills five in Pakistan
fields.standfirst: The India-Pakistan conflict: special report
fields.trailText: Bombs planted on a busy train and in a Saturday market killed at least five people in the southern Pakistani town of Hyderabad.
fields.body:
Bombs planted on a busy train and in a Saturday market killed at least five people in the southern Pakistani town of Hyderabad.

They said the explosion occurred just as the train left Hyderabad railway station in Sindh province for the town of Mirpur Khas, which lies west of there.

It was the latest in a series of such attacks in the province that Pakistani officials have previously blamed on an intelligence agency of arch-rival India.

Officials accused India's Research and Analysis Wing intelligence agency of carrying out the attacks.

fields.headline: IRA must stop this idiocy
fields.standfirst:
Northern Ireland: special report

The gunmen are family men too. So do they really want a bloody civil war in Northern Ireland?
fields.trailText: You know this already, but let me repeat it. Journalists make a lot of stuff up. So great is the demand for comment and 'insider' analysis that wild hunches, tripe really, is packaged as fact, trimmed with self-importance and flung into the insatiable mouth of the news beast. You know this already, but let me repeat it. Journalists make a lot of stuff up. So great is the demand for comment and 'insider' analysis that wild hunches, tripe really, is packaged as fact, trimmed with self-importance and flung into the insatiable mouth of the news beast. So let us be honest about Northern Ireland: there is one conversation that matters and nobody who writes in any newspaper you will read, or speaks in any broadcast you will hear, has a clue about it.

Are the IRA commanders in Armagh and South Tyrone sitting in silence watching the same TV reports as the rest of us? Do they even speak, at any length? Or are they, even now, yelling across kitchen tables, smashing phone receivers down, testing every last syllable of the Sinn Fein message? Reader, I don't know. And nor, until perhaps many years hence, when one of them writes a trustworthy memoir, will you.

The frantic to-ing and fro-ing between London and Dublin, the meetings of civil servants and politicians, the statements of Peter Mandelson and David Trimble - all this is as nothing compared to the Provos' internal debate. Everything rests on them. Three hundred terrorist prisoners have been released. The RUC is being dismantled and recast. The Irish constitution has been amended. Unionists have sat down in government with Republicans.

The complexity of the job already done by successive politicians and diplomats in their search for peace can hardly be described. It must have been like building a fantastically complicated, three-dimensional jigsaw, with greasy, unreliable pieces, in the dark, during a hailstorm. Anyone who thinks that there is no honour left in public life, or that civil servants are mostly useless, should stop and think of the peace process. Which now, teetering and swaying in the wind, is on the point of collapse because the IRA will not keep its promise about decommissioning. Sinn Fein's Mitchell McLaughlin, who is, despite his hard line on television, a decent and intelligent man emotionally committed to peace, has made much of the fact that the real deadline, the one in the agreement, is still many weeks away. But given that he can hold out little hope of the IRA decommissioning by then either, it seems almost irrelevant.

There is an argument, held by respectable and thoughtful people, that we should forget decommissioning. It is a symbolic act only, they say. Of course, some arms will always be held by some people. The war could be re-started at any time, whatever stockpiles were or were not around the place. So don't rub Republican noses in this. Peace is peace. Silent, hidden guns kill no more people than decommissioned ones. Let sleeping terrorists lie.

What this seductive argument omits, of course, is the agony and division in Unionist politics. In London and even Dublin, people don't really want to know about Northern Ireland. They think that so long as no-one is being killed, no pubs blown up or army checkpoints machine-gunned, then everything has stopped. That 'it is over'. But it isn't over. Both Gerry Adams and David Trimble know that. Adams and his colleagues believe that taking the gun out of Irish politics is a stage in a process which will lead to the reunification of the island.

Or, to put it shortly, the Unionists are stuffed. The greater wealth south of the border; the growth in the province's Catholic population; the loosening of the British Union from Scotland and Wales _ these are all signs of a fundamental political shift in the islands which will end, willy-nilly, with the dismantling of the UK as presently constituted.

Therefore, the Republican analysis goes, 'we are going to win in the end'. It may take 10 or even 20 years, but the outcome is certain. In which case, what are the Unionists going to do? Now, the next bit might make some readers choke, but here goes: hardline Republicans are worried about a cycle of uncontrollable violence. If the Unionists really think they are going to be outvoted eventually, and will be betrayed by London, then they may fight. These are hard, gritty people, the descendants of settlers, with something of the frontier spirit in their blood still. With little to lose, they would go down in fire. Before the ceasefire, Sinn Fein decided, there was a real chance of full-scale civil war in Northern Ireland, violence of a scale far greater than the 'Troubles'.

Civil war would be, in many ways, an utterly bizarre outcome. The raw bigotry and discrimination of the old Unionist statelet has passed away. There is more prosperity and less religious fanaticism year by year. Taking Northern Ireland in 2000 AD and turning it into Beirut at its worst would take some doing.

But we should not be complacent; and the Sinn Fein analysis needs to be taken seriously. Republicans have been demonised for so long and so effectively in the British press that it is sometimes hard to remember that they are also family people, with hopes for their children. They really fear a new cycle of poverty, unemployment and killing; and they are acting as wise leaders of their community in fearing it. In short, they need David Trimble and they need to make the IRA understand why.

For the failure of the IRA to move on decommissioning is a massive political failure also in the strategy of Gerry Adams and Martin McGuinness. They have managed to bring things to a pass where they may lose the only substantial Unionist leader they could do business with; and send Unionism into a spin of uncontrollable anger and despair. Politically, the IRA are behaving idiotically.

Why? I don't know. I fear that it's about very basic reactions. The gunmen in the dripping border villages aren't doing well out of this. The flash, vocal townies, McGuinness and Adams - well, they have a fine old time, don't they just? Trips to the White House. Government jobs. Cars. Deferential civil servants. Dandy for them. Fine for the boys let out of a Brit prison. But us? The poor bloody infantry, and the poor bloody sergeants, with our council flats and farmworkers' cottages?

These are the people who now matter most, and are about the only people who haven't been bribed. Everyone else benefits from the peace process. So, taking a long view, will the gunmen and their families. But in the here and now, these are the only people who lose. They lose local status, they lose the grim romance of it all - and now they are told they must lose their weapons, the tangible emblems of their power and status. All this talk of the historic refusal of the IRA to surrender, and the memories of the Twenties, reduces, I suspect, to that.

Sinn Fein has been trying to help, to find work for redundant 'volunteers' and to encourage others into education. They know very well that defusing the IRA is a tricky job, calling for steadier fingers than you need to defuse a bomb. But if they fail then they too have had it. Suspending the Assembly, whether or not Trimble goes as well, leaves the Sinn Fein leadership very exposed. They will be blamed by their own side for failing to deliver the political leap forward they promised, and by everyone else for failing to deliver the IRA.

As this process has gone on, I have found my admiration growing for David Trimble on one side, and the Adams-McGuinness-McLaughlin triumvirate on the other. Both leaderships have moved, and taken very real, personal risks. Both have been sincere in wanting peace, though both remain utterly unreconciled in their longer-term view of Northern Ireland's future.

But both are standing on the lip of catastrophe, pushed there by fissile and frightened coalitions they have partly encouraged and partly controlled. The Government is saying that we may go back to a time of direct rule, with neither peace nor war, a continuing ceasefire and a blocked political process.

Ministers' panicky reaction shows that they know, just as surely as Sinn Fein knows, that it could be far worse than that.

fields.headline: Who's afraid of Michael Portillo?
fields.standfirst: He's a born-again political star, big in Westminster, but that doesn't mean he's any more loved by the audience that really matters
fields.trailText: He's a born-again political star, big in Westminster, but that doesn't mean he's any more loved by the audience that really matters
fields.body:
In politics - as in comedy, marketing and sex - timing is everything. At the time that he was ejected from parliament by the voters of Enfield Southgate, everyone assumed (and huge numbers were delighted) that it was a disastrous, potentially fatal slither down the greasy pole for Michael Portillo. 'Portillo's on the dole,' chanted a gleeful mob outside Conservative Central Office as they cheered the destruction of the man who encapsulated everything they hated about the toppled Tory regime. People asked each other: 'Were you still up for Portillo?' The question was so symbolic of the relish which greeted the scalping of the Castillian quiff that it was even used as the title of an excellent book about the May Day massacre.

There is an alternative world in which the nation was deprived of that unifying surge of joy. Michael Portillo held his seat. In the Tory leadership contest that followed, and with William Hague as his campaign manager, Portillo overwhelmed all rivals to succeed John Major at the head of the Tory rump. Had that happened, I am fairly sure that the Tories would be little more loved - it is quite as likely that they would be even more loathed - than they are today. Were Michael Portillo already the Leader of the Opposition, I and the rest of the commentating class would regularly report on the menacing mutterings among Tory MPs about his failure to make any significant impression on Tony Blair. Widespread would be the speculation about the identity of the successor to Portillo after he had led the Tories to their inevitable defeat at the next election. Hague - heaped with praise by the parliamentary sketchwriters for his witty performances as Shadow Chancellor - would be much tipped as a man to watch as the next leader of the Conservative Party. He is christened the bald-apparent. Hague's regular protestations of undying loyalty to the leader - he calls Portillo 'unassailable' - are believed by no one. How big a chunk will Portillo have to take out of the New Labour majority to protect himself against a post-election leadership challenge by Hague? That is what everyone would very likely be writing.

Look at it this way and it's now evident that, far from being an awful blow to his career, Portillo's defenestration from the Commons was the best possible thing that ever happened to him. Not only has he been distanced from the Tories' failings, he has enjoyed the space to rebrand himself. He took a televised train voyage around his Spanish republican father. He swabbed the floors in a hospital and wrote of his admiration for those working in the health service. He groped towards a more compassionate brand of Conservatism. He self-outed himself, a step he would not have voluntarily taken had he become Tory leader after the election. Most of all, he has not been required to prove in hard political combat that he would be more effective or popular as Tory leader than any of the alternatives.

So long as Portillo has been absent from the front line, Conservative MPs have sighed to themselves, 'If only'. If only El Caudillo was in charge, we wouldn't be submerged with this subterranean poll rating. If only Portillo was our leader, we wouldn't be such a joke. If only Portillo was the bull at the head of the herd, we might be within a shout of winning the next election.

In this respect, the absence of Portillo has been very undermining of William Hague. So it was sensible to accelerate his return to the front bench and, up to a point, shrewd to place him in the exposed position of Shadow Chancellor. Portillo is pitted against the formidable Gordon Brown who has already chewed up and spat out Peter Lilley and Francis Maude. We will now begin to see whether Portillo really does possess the Right Stuff. Alternatively, he will be exposed as a pair of lips, a hairstyle and a dash of aftershave masking an absence of original thought.

He made a brisk start by dropping Tory opposition to independence for the Bank of England and ending their hostility to the minimum wage. Both shifts have been signalled for some months. Both were inevitable. It was never going to be clever politics to fight the next election on a promise to put interest rates back in the hands of the same Tory politicians who presided over record home repossessions, and a pledge to cut the wages of two million people. It is a tribute to Portillo's panache - which could be another way of saying shamelessness - that most of the press coverage has described these U-turns as something of a personal triumph.

There is more dumping to be done. The Conservatives are also going to have to come to terms with the 48-hour maximum working week - unless they want to fight the next election with Labour posters declaring that the Tories would force millions of people to work longer hours.

I expect Portillo, always much more of a pragmatist than his ideological posturing tends to suggest, will be pretty ruthless at ditching voter-repellent bits of Tory baggage. Where he has so far been terribly weak - despite all that spare time he has had to spend thinking - is describing what the Conservatives are positively about. For someone often described as the philosopher-prince of a 'New Toryism', he has been silent about what this might come to in either theory or practice. Are his ideas too alarming to be undressed in public? Or is the problem that he doesn't have anything less banal to say than he's in favour of freedom, choice and lower taxes.

Which raises the question whether any of that reinvention was more than skin deep. People talk of the New Portillo. Well, so they do in the Westminster Village and Media Gulch. What I wonder is whether he looks any different out there, beyond Parliament Square, in the real world where votes are cast. It's unarguable that he's a big hitter. In a Tory solar system mainly composed of black holes and brown dwarfs, Michael Portillo has stellar quality. What doesn't necessarily follow, as the man himself would probably privately acknowledge, is that this means the voters like him anymore than they did before. The only opinion poll I've found that bothered to ask the question suggests that the Conservatives would be even less popular led by Portillo. He is the man who was, in one previous incarnation, the Minister for the Poll Tax. He was Chief Secretary to the Treasury during the humiliation of Black Wednesday and when VAT was imposed on fuel. He was the foam-flecked ranter to the lowest prejudices of the Tory party conference. If these are not the things that the voters most recall about Michael Portillo, then you can be certain that Labour will do its best to remind the country why his defeat produced such paroxysms of delight.

Elections are a contest between disillusion and fear: 'kick the buggers out' versus 'better the bastards you know'. The roles played by Labour and the Conservatives at the last election, and the four elections before that, will be reversed at the next. The Tories, as the insurgents, must look to ways of attracting fresh support. Labour, as the incumbents, will seek to keep its coalition together by terrifying the voters about the alternative. Does the prospect of Michael Portillo being resurrected as a Cabinet Minister make it easier or harder for Tony Blair to scare the country with the thought of the Tories returning to office? I merely note that, when it was announced that he was back on the Tory front bench, what I did not see was a crowd outside Central Office joyfully chanting: 'Portillo's off the dole.'

fields.headline: Kosovo hit by ethnic clashes
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: French peacekeepers clashed with ethnic Albanians in Mitrovica, Kosovo, for a second straight day yesterday, using clubs and tear gas against hundreds trying to push across a bridge to the Serb-controlled north side of the city.
fields.body:
French peacekeepers clashed with ethnic Albanians in Mitrovica, Kosovo, for a second straight day yesterday, using clubs and tear gas against hundreds trying to push across a bridge to the Serb-controlled north side of the city.

Meanwhile, the death toll from four days of ethnically motivated violence rose to 10 with the deaths of two ethnic Albanians wounded days earlier. Violence has swept this city since a rocket attack on a UN bus killed two elderly Serbs south of the city.

Nato-led peacekeepers were struggling to restore order in Kosovo's most multi-ethnic and troubled city. A German unit was sent to help the French if the crowd tries again to cross the bridge.

In the latest attack, at least six French soldiers and one ethnic Albanian were injured. The Albanian man was seen stumbling from the bridge drenched in blood.

In apparent retaliation, two ethnic Albanian men were shot to death onThursday in the Serb-controlled section of Kosvska Mitrovica. Soon afterwards grenades at two Serb cafés injured 25.

Others died in a series of clashes and shootings which swept the city. About 9,000 Serbs control the north bank, and 90,000 ethnic Albanians live on the south side of the town, 30 miles north of the province's capital, Pristina.

On Friday, French troops fired tear gas to disperse hundreds of Albanians who pelted them with stones and bottles on the Ibar Bridge.

Up to five French soldiers were injured, including one who suffered a broken arm, troops said.

Elsewhere in Kosovo, violence was also on the rise.

fields.headline: Labour in vain
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Sceptics who say little has changed under Labour can always be pointed firmly towards the National Minimum Wage. More than two million workers have benefited from the new pay floor, especially women and part-time workers.
fields.body:
Sceptics who say little has changed under Labour can always be pointed firmly towards the National Minimum Wage. More than two million workers have benefited from the new pay floor, especially women and part-time workers. Tory scaremongering about job losses turned out to be just that. Labour supporters can feel proud of this achievement.

But, as so often with New Labour, a sound and progressive policy is being promoted with insufficient vigour. It is astonishing and disappointing that the Government chose to freeze the level of the minimum wage at £3.60 an hour. If New Labour believes there should be a minimum salary rate below which no one should fall, how can the Government not believe this minimum should rise in line with general living standards? Indeed, the UK is the only industrialised country without a mechanism for lifting the minimum wage.

Even business leaders have been caught unawares by the Government's caution on this issue. The Confederation of British Industry was comfortable with a rise of 20 pence or so, and is now in the decidedly odd position of supporting a higher minimum wage than a Labour government. The trade unions are rightly furious. Now, following the announcement by the Tories last week that they would leave the minimum wage in place in the unlikely event of forming a government in the near future, suspicions that New Labour lacks courage and commitment on this issue are bound to increase further. Conservative Treasury spokesman Michael Portillo, who announced the change in policy, can live with a minimum wage set at £3.60. That alone suggests it is too low.

There is a good chance that Labour - and for this read Gordon Brown - wants to wait until next year, and then introduce a bigger rise in order to get as big a political bang for its buck as possible. If this is the plan, then Gordon Brown should be ashamed. He gave the Bank of England power to set interest rates in order to remove monetary policy from the grubby hands of politicians, to stop politically inspired interest rate cuts. If it is wrong to play with mortgages for political ends, what about the pay of our poorest workers?

Brown's role in all of this is especially troubling. The deep background spin has been that he was in favour of a rise, but Blair blocked it. This has helped Brown to maintain his image as the Left-leaning side of the partnership. It is also rubbish. The decision to freeze was made by Brown and Brown alone. The minimum wage is now a fixed part of the political landscape. We know now that it does not damage the labour market. So enough, Gordon. Raise your sights. Raise two million pay packets.

fields.headline: Cash-strapped Tories abandon hard sell
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: The Conservative Party is to abandon its trademark negative poster campaigns at the next election, as a cash crisis forces it to slash its campaign spending.
fields.body:
The Conservative Party is to abandon its trademark negative poster campaigns at the next election, as a cash crisis forces it to slash its campaign spending.

Conservative chairman Michael Ancram believes the massive spending on posters was ineffective in the 1997 election partly because the billboard campaign was too close to polling day to change minds. Private polling also showed they were unpopular.

He wants the party to redirect more of its limited resources on direct mailshots, in which Labour was far ahead in the 1997 election. The party is trying to buy up mail lists including the Automobile Association.

Central Office, gearing up for an election as early as October, believes it also has to rethink its campaign strategy of the past four elections.

Ancram believes that the party will need to rebalance the campaign so it is less based on generating fear of Labour, and focuses more on creating a sense of excitement about the Tories.

Previous campaigns masterminded by Charles Saatchi concentrated on creating a fear that Labour represented a threat to economic prosperity and low taxes. Poster phrases, such as 'New Labour, New Danger, Tax Bombshell' will not work after four years of Labour government, a senior party official said. Instead Tories aim to create disillusionment about Labour's record.

The Tories spent £28 billion at the last election, of which £10.9 million was spent on posters and £2.29m on press advertising. Labour spent £7.4m on all advertising. New legal spending caps, due to come into force next February will limit spending to £20bn. Labour backbenchers are pushing for this to be cut by another £5bn.

Privately Central Office does not believe it will raise enough cash between now and the election to spend even £20m in total, probably making it the first election in memory in which Labour outspends the Conservatives.
