webTitle: Johnny Rebel sows  panic in the South

fields.headline: Johnny Rebel sows  panic in the South
fields.standfirst: McCain's threat to drive the Republican money changers from the temple of politics has the Bush camp scared - but far from beaten, reports  Ed Vulliamy
fields.trailText: As John McCain barnstorms his way south, fresh from victory in last Tuesday's New Hampshire primary, the interesting - and difficult - phase in his remarkable shakedown of American politics begins. From now on this is no media hype for a veteran hero of the Hanoi Hilton: this is for real.
fields.body:
As John McCain barnstorms his way south, fresh from victory in last Tuesday's New Hampshire primary, the interesting - and difficult - phase in his remarkable shakedown of American politics begins. From now on this is no media hype for a veteran hero of the Hanoi Hilton: this is for real.

McCain has now closed polling gaps of between 20 and 45 points with his rival, George Bush, in the next primary appointment, South Carolina on 19 February. In New York, he has beaten back the Republican Party machine which, backing Bush, had tried to strike McCain off the ballot in some districts, citing obscure technicalities. The party has now backed down, swept aside by the sheer popularity of the man and the potential political price of its own arrogance.

These details, however, are but symptoms of where Mc-Cain is going: in progressing from challenger to contender for the Republican nomination, McCain could detonate a revolution not only within his party but in the way modern politics work in the US.

Now is the McCain mo-ment. Some months ago he was a little-known moral hawk urging war for Kosovo. Then a no-hoper for the Republican nomination, then suddenly a loquacious media darling, his life story charged with pain and courage.

Now McCain is more than any of these things: for the first time, America is watching the emergence of a candidate carving out his position and political persona in the open. Voters witness the moulding of a manifesto and an entire political culture which responds to them, which breaks both the new rules of retail political packaging and the old ones of straitjacket ideology.

And all bundled together by a man with a mischievous glint in his eye who cannot comb his own hair because he was so brutally mistreated by his Vietcong captors. By a man who feels 'mortified' because he once signed a meaningless statement that he was a 'black criminal' after four days of torture. By a man who can say: 'In prison, I fell in love with my country.'

Predictions are dangerous, but McCain euphoria has to be tempered by reality. True, the Bush camp is scrambling, as adviser Karl Rove told The Observer , 'to look at the way we do things' - within such an edifice, tantamount to an admission of panic .

However, McCain faces an avalanche of punishing primary battles against the national frontrunner's gold-plated machine, the $60 million and 31 state governors it has thus far amassed. New Hampshire spoke after months of campaigning by McCain in a small, maverick state. South Carolina, through which the McCain hurricane is now blowing, becomes suddenly winnable.

But behind the gentle Carolina hills lie the steep mountain slopes of Super and Southern Tuesdays; such political fortresses as Texas, California and Florida, where the Republican apparatus and its puppet masters in big business have been preparing indirectly, since their arch-enemy Bill Clinton became President, for their man to come. And their man is George Bush.

The establishment now threatens them more seriously than any Democrat could. 'He has,' says Rove, 'a message that is fundamentally at odds with the party.' Rove is right, and therein lies the raw, infectious excitement of McCain's candidacy; of the McCain revolution, successful or otherwise.

McCain's aides and allies this week set out to achieve one of two things. They can proceed with what is becoming a remarkable popular revolt against not just Bush and the Democrats but the political system itself. 'Anyone happy with the status quo should vote for someone else,' says McCain.

Or they can convince the Republican establishment that Bush cannot deliver the only thing it wants of him - the White House - and persuade big business that McCain is its man. But here lies a contradiction: it's like asking a cat-burglar to house-sit your home so that no one will steal anything.

McCain's political heresy, or apostasy, is sampled in the way his roadshow works. It is fun-but-serious, democratic and macho; like a rolling locker room with McCain as top jock. People rib him and get ribbed back; he chastises his 'incompetent staff, most of whom are on release programmes from prison'.

He is 'Honest John' - the good, the bad and the angry. He thrives on banter, he chews the fat, he likes, as he says, to 'shoot shit'. To Mc-Cain, flak is fuel. He teases his heiress wife Cindy about an old boyfriend she once had, calling her 'one of those girls who attended the University of Spoiled Children'.

He tells endless jokes, some of which are quite good: 'I feel like Zsa Zsa Gabor's fifth husband - I know what to do, but I don't know how to make it interesting.' 'The scandal in Washington wasn't Monica, it was that the President turned the Lincoln Bedroom into Motel 6 and he was the bellhop.' His favourite band is Nine Inch Nails.

McCain runs an 18-hour daily press conference with aides crammed against the back of the bus to make way for yet more reporters accustomed to the pompous arrogance of Al Gore's team, now aghast at effortless access to a presidential candidate. 'London? How many of your readers vote in Staten Island? Only kidding, take a seat, if you can keep it.'

And not only physical access: there appears (deceptively, no doubt) to be no protective coating around the inner John McCain, whose willingness to confess his own flaws drives aides to distraction. When asked about the reprimand for his 'lack of judgment' in a savings and loan fund scandal back in Arizona, he leans forward and replies to The Observer : 'It was worse than that. What I did was wrong. ' Actually, he did hardly anything wrong at all - it was a case of what the media calls 'guilt by association' with a chancer called Keating.

There is, then, a revolution in political style driven by the kind of man McCain is. The fact that he is now fighting politics for real does not mean that McCain's personality and life story count for any less than they did during the days of the 'McCain Swoon' at the end of last year. The love affair with the media has abated after some spats over abortion and realisation (at long last) of his impeccable conservative voting record. But McCain's own record of heroism is still his most important political asset.

His family has been military since the era of George Washington. His grandfather was a rugged naval warrior who led his carrier task force into battle wearing a non-regulation cap and no shoes. His father was an admiral, and McCain duly went to naval academy, where he was best known for success with women (including a Brazilian supermodel) and organising break-outs to go drinking.

Alongside such escapades, McCain developed the steel that made him proud to serve in Vietnam, where - as he puts it - 'I managed to intercept a missile with my A-4E' fighter bomber in 1967. Parachuting into a lake, he was 'rescued' by angry Vietnamese who smashed his shoulder joints, examined his other wounds and took him to prison to die.

What followed has become a modern American legend: how McCain refused early release and for more than five years endured torture and beating; had his arms crushed; established a system of tapping so that those in solitary could tell their comrades they had not 'squealed'; was later elected 'movie teller' to narrate film plots and persistently insulted his captors, ensuring more beating.

Bush managed to skip Vietnam after a call from Daddy caused him to jump a waiting list of 100,000 and secure a cushy number with the Texas National Guard. It is a measure of how desperate the Republican establishment is to reconquer the White House that it is prepared to cede even the holy grail of Vietnam to brand McCain a 'Clintonite'. Or to insist that his appalling temper - a major theme for a while last year - makes him unfit for the presidency.

McCain's voting record won a zero rating from the liberal group, Americans for Democratic Action. He appears as a thoroughbred conservative on abortion, the minimum wage, the Clinton impeachment, the lot. But the candidate now carving his niche before the eyes of America is not the man who has represented Arizona for 17 years.

In conversation, he starts off talking about campaign finance reform and the 'corrupting influence of money in politics'. Money is Bush's water of life, and this was McCain's first heresy against party orthodoxy. McCain wants a Cabinet post to oversee government and electoral reform: 'Let the warning go out.' He menaces 'the army of lobbyists who resist our campaign'.

McCain hit trouble over this puritanism when it turned out he was also seeking favours for his main backers. Characteristically, he blames 'a system which taints us all'. With only $5 million left in the kitty after New Hampshire, McCain himself needed money to continue - and his victory on Tuesday produced a flood of it, arriving mainly by the Internet.

But campaign finance reform was only the beginning of McCain's self-discovery. He then moves on to talk about tax, and here lies his new terrain - a new meaning to American 'conservatism' in an era of budget surplus. 'To put the surplus dollars into tax cuts,' he says, 'is not conservative policy.' Isn't it? Tax cuts are the cornerstone of Republican philosophy.

The mathematics are these: Bush will raid $483 billion of the surplus for tax cuts of which a third goes to the top 1 per cent of incomes. McCain's plan is for a cut of only $240 billion, aimed at the lower and middle classes.

Moreover, $150 million of McCain's cuts will be paid for by cutting back tax breaks for big business. It is dynamic stuff. 'Every tax dollar,' he says, 'now wasted on special breaks for oil companies, ethanol giants, insurance companies and the multitude of other powerful interests with their army of lobbyists is now at risk.' On the other hand, budget surplus funds will be set aside to furnish the social security trust fund.

The premise for this rebellion is simple. 'There is,' says McCain, 'a growing gap between rich and poor in this country, and that is my concern.' His solution defies the Republican credo that what is good for the rich helps the poor. Indeed, it presumes the opposite.

McCain has thus established a brand of conservative radicalism which trumpets 'patriotism, honour and duty' (his mantra), but also applies the fiscal prudence and antipathy towards big business of Theodore Roosevelt to the economy of Alan Greenspan. It is almost like trying to combine Reagan's language with Roosevelt's social vision. For McCain, prosperity comes from reducing the federal debt and helping the lower and lower middle classes, not by paying off the rich. He wants to 'reclaim the Republican Party's heritage of reform'.

With such populist Republicanism, McCain has severed himself from the current theology of the party. And still we do not know (it is unlikely McCain himself knows) how far he will go from here. But already McCain's heresy must now meet the counter-charge by every dollar and ton the Bush juggernaut can muster against him - starting in South Carolina.

This is the kind of hardline conservative country that should - but won't - bury McCain. He can relish the fact that a disporportionate number of these conservatives are veterans, to whom he pleads, in a latest circular: 'Join me in one last campaign.'

South Carolina is a terrain of euphemisms, and for Mc-Cain they are dangerous ones. 'Pro-Life' of course means anti-abortion, and already McCain has faltered in the eyes of the Christian Right. Campaign finance reform is known as 'free speech restriction' in Republican circles down there. But, above all, there is the word 'heritage'.

The Confederate flag flies over the state Capitol, making South Carolina a one-issue state this primary time. The Republican majority refuses to lower it; the National Association for the Advancement of Coloured People has called for a boycott of the state so long as it flies. To call the flag a 'symbol of heritage' is to sympathise with the Confederacy - and to enter an entire world of further euphemisms whereby the Civil War was fought to defend 'States' Rights' (more recently a euphemism for segregation), not slavery.

On the other hand, to call the flag a 'symbol of racism and slavery' is to be clearly on the Yankee side, and to insist that these themes were the war's raw material.

The problem is this: both quotations - 'heritage' and 'racism' - came recently from the mouth of John McCain. While Bush, forever observant of the long haul, has said that this is matter for South Carolina alone, McCain, with his usual lust, has entered the fray.

It is hard for McCain: he is the history man in this fight, and his family fought on the Confederate side. 'My fore-fathers fought under that flag,' he says, adding equivocally: 'I believe they believed their service was honourable'. On the other hand, McCain's senior strategist in the state is Richard Quinn, editor of the Southern Partisan newspaper, one of the flag's principal defenders.

Whether the controversy could melt down well for McCain is unclear: the flag issue may win him some of the right-wing vote he will need in South Carolina, only to outrage much of the middle ground that should be his further down the line.

Either way, the issue is history and only emphasises McCain as the emotional centrepiece of this election.

He is the heart of the story - and, in his way, at the authentic heart of a new, impatient America. It now remains to be seen whether - as Bush must prove - that heart is for sale.

He then moves on to talk about tax, and here lies his new terrain - a new meaning to American 'conservatism' in an era of budget surplus. 'To put the surplus dollars into tax cuts,' he says, 'is not conservative policy.' Isn't it? Tax cuts are the cornerstone of Republican philosophy. The mathematics are these: Bush will raid $483 billion of the surplus for tax cuts of which a third goes to the top 1 per cent of incomes. McCain's plan is for a cut of only $240 billion, aimed at the lower and middle classes. Moreover, $150 million of McCain's cuts will be paid for by cutting back tax breaks for big business. It is dynamic stuff. On the other hand, budget surplus funds will be set aside to furnish the social security trust fund. The premise for this rebellion is simple. Indeed, it presumes the opposite. McCain has thus established a brand of conservative radicalism which trumpets 'patriotism, honour and duty' (his mantra), but also applies the fiscal prudence and antipathy towards big business of Theodore Roosevelt to the economy of Alan Greenspan. It is almost like trying to combine Reagan's language with Roosevelt's social vision. For McCain, prosperity comes from reducing the federal debt and helping the lower and lower middle classes, not by paying off the rich. He wants to 'reclaim the Republican Party's heritage of reform'. With such populist Republicanism, McCain has severed himself from the current theology of the party. And still we do not know (it is unlikely McCain himself knows) how far he will go from here. This is the kind of hardline conservative country that should - but won't - bury McCain. Campaign finance reform is known as 'free speech restriction' in Republican circles down there. But, above all, there is the word 'heritage'. The Confederate flag flies over the state Capitol, making South Carolina a one-issue state this primary time. To call the flag a 'symbol of heritage' is to sympathise with the Confederacy - and to enter an entire world of further euphemisms whereby the Civil War was fought to defend 'States' Rights' (more recently a euphemism for segregation), not slavery. On the other hand, to call the flag a 'symbol of racism and slavery' is to be clearly on the Yankee side, and to insist that these themes were the war's raw material. The problem is this: both quotations - 'heritage' and 'racism' - came recently from the mouth of John McCain. While Bush, forever observant of the long haul, has said that this is matter for South Carolina alone, McCain, with his usual lust, has entered the fray. It is hard for McCain: he is the history man in this fight, and his family fought on the Confederate side. 'My fore-fathers fought under that flag,' he says, adding equivocally: 'I believe they believed their service was honourable'. On the other hand, McCain's senior strategist in the state is Richard Quinn, editor of the Southern Partisan newspaper, one of the flag's principal defenders. Whether the controversy could melt down well for McCain is unclear: the flag issue may win him some of the right-wing vote he will need in South Carolina, only to outrage much of the middle ground that should be his further down the line. Either way, the issue is history and only emphasises McCain as the emotional centrepiece of this election. He is the heart of the story - and, in his way, at the authentic heart of a new, impatient America. It now remains to be seen whether - as Bush must prove - that heart is for sale.

fields.headline: High noon for IRA's hardliners
fields.standfirst:
Henry McDonald, Mary Holland and Patrick Wintour trace the tortuous events of the past week which brought Martin McGuinness to tears : 'We gave the leadership the ceasefire, we gave them their big jobs at Stormont, but we are not giving them our guns'

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Last Thursday afternoon four of the Irish government's senior negotiators overseeing Northern Ireland policy anxiously awaited a call from Prime Minister Bertie Ahern. They included Martin Manserg, one of Dublin's key advisers on the North since the beginning of the peace process, and Dermot Gallagher from Dublin's Department of Foreign Affairs.
fields.body:
Last Thursday afternoon four of the Irish government's senior negotiators overseeing Northern Ireland policy anxiously awaited a call from Prime Minister Bertie Ahern. They included Martin Manserg, one of Dublin's key advisers on the North since the beginning of the peace process, and Dermot Gallagher from Dublin's Department of Foreign Affairs.

The 'four wise men' were poised to go to Belfast for discussions with republican leaders aimed at saving the Good Friday peace agreement. Their task was to find out whether the IRA's position on decommissioning of its arsenal would change over the next few hours in order to prevent Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland Secretary, from putting the nine-week-old power-sharing government in Belfast on hold.

The phone call never came. Their long wait for word from the republican movement delayed Ahern's flight to meet Tony Blair in Cornwall. But when Ahern finally arrived at Blair's clifftop hotel he had nothing new to report. The IRA had not budged from its 'no surrender' stance on handing over guns and explosives.

Northern Ireland Office sources say they were told, right up to the last moment, that these two men were confident they would 'get something' from the IRA. The British side was said to be considerably annoyed at having been misled on the prospects for some movement.

The delay in learning there would be no movement is likely to have left Mandelson with little or no choice but to set in motion suspension of the Northern Ireland Executive and its associated bodies. It was not a move he wished to make. He privately believes the IRA will not decommisison unless the Executive is in place. He believes the republican movement is in a state of transition, but has not yet reached the logical conclusion that it must decommission.

His only short-term hope is that by keeping in place the other elements of the Good Friday Agreement, such as the prisoner release programme and reforms to justice and police, he will be able to persuade the IRA to decommission. But that might be another year down the road.

He does not rule out a sudden volte face this week in head-to-head talks between Gerry Adams, president of Sinn Fein, and David Trimble, the Ulster Unionist leader, but he does not expect it. His only hope is that Sinn Fein miscalculated and did not believe he would press ahead with suspension.

But reconciliation is not the current republican mood. Within 20 minutes of Mandelson sitting down at the end of his Commons statement on Thursday, when he accused the paramilitaries of betrayal, Adams, was on the phone to the Minister complaining about the statement he had watched on television.

Adams said he had been told there would be a holding statement. Instead, the suspension of the Executive would kick in next Friday and the IRA was being accused of betrayal. Adams told Mandelson he was endangering his talks with the IRA. Mandelson, physically exhausted, tried to calm him down, but Adams said he would be attacking him the next day. He duly did, telling him he was a disgrace and a spin doctor for the Ulster Unionists.

The Northern Ireland Office recognises pressure on the Sinn Fein leader is enormous. Adams has told the British Government he would be forced to resign if he had pressed the case for decommissioning further. For, even if the republican leadership wanted to decommission, they would undoubtedly encounter huge hostility among their rank and file, especially in Fermanagh and South Tyrone. A disastrous split would occur, serving no one.

One former IRA prisoner from the Whiterock area of west Belfast encapsulated the opposition to any IRA decommissioning: 'The republican base are saying: "We gave the leadership the ceasefire, we gave them their big jobs at Stormont, we gave them their fancy cars and their international adulation but we are not giving them our guns." For republicans who have accepted so much, the guns are the last line of resistance to the Sinn Fein leadership.'

Other IRA members are not even certain the organisation's leadership is united on the question of arms. Another IRA volunteer from west Belfast who has served a long prison sentence said: 'If there was unity among the leadership about giving up something as a gesture then they would have started to persuade the base by now. But there have been no moves to change attitudes towards decommissioning on the ground, so it's clear the leadership are divided over the question as well.'

British Ministers acknowledge they do not know how hard Adams has been trying to persuade the base to decommission. Intelligence sources will have told him about 40 people in the IRA matter, and that people like Pat Doherty will not shift.

In republican redoubts outside Belfast the picture is bleaker. Republican sources in south Armagh, home to the IRA's most active and dangerous brigade during the Troubles, say the organisation's national leadership has been told nothing in the way of guns or explosives is being offered up from the region. They say they have accepted the overturning of so many core principles such as entry into a partitionist Assembly still under British rule, that decommissioning would be a step too far. If the republican leadership pushed for decommissioning they would risk a major split, they add.

The trouble for Blair and Ahern is that without a move on decommissioning, and that means putting actual guns and bombs beyond use by the 22 May deadline set out in the Good Friday Agreement, the Ulster Unionist leader and Northern Ireland First Minister David Trimble will resign by the end of this week. Trimble remains their best hope. If Blair was seen to abandon him, it would harden Unionist opinion still further.

Last November, Trimble risked a historic break-up of his party by persuading it to change its 'no guns, no government' policy regarding a coalition with Sinn Fein on the Northern Ireland Executive. Trimble, pressurised by Mandelson, asked his party to take a gamble, to set up the institutions and wait for the IRA to disarm.

Trimble did so on the basis that he believed an understanding had been reached in the 10-week talks chaired last autumn by ex-Senator George Mitchell. No guarantee was given during those talks that disarmament would occur, but it was made crystal clear the Unionists could stay in government with Sinn Fein only if there were movement. Mandelson also pointed out that the IRA appeared to endorse decommissioning in its statement at the end of the Mitchell review which said it accepted the political leadership shown by Sinn Fein.

The moment of decision was bound to come last Monday, the date on which General John de Chastelain was due to report progress on his talks with the IRA on decommissioning. That report would come a fortnight before the meeting of the 860-strong Ulster Unionist Council empowered to direct its leadership to quit the Executive if it was not satisfied with progress on IRA arms.

The brutal truth was that in three rounds of talks between De Chastelain and two IRA representatives, no progress was made. There was no sign the IRA was willing to decommission, offer clarity on a date by which decommissioning would start, or even discuss the means by which it would occur and be verified.

The optimistic noises from Dublin were not matched in the private discussions with De Chastelain. Despite intense pressure over last weekend, including calls from the Catholic Church and President Bill Clinton, the IRA hunkered down. De Chastelain was not prepared to play politics with his report and it was stark in its gloom. In the only chink of light, he said decommissioning would not need to start in his opinion until late March for it to be completed in time for the May deadline. In addition, he stated the obvious, the ceasefire was holding. Faced by such a report, finally delivered to the two governments early on Tuesday morning, Mandelson and Blair knew they were running out of road. Blair was facing the moment of decision he had been seeking to avert for months. The Irish pleaded with Blair to delay publication to give them one more chance at levering the IRA to shift. Adams would be summoned to Dublin and the thumb screws applied.

ON TUESDAY, Trimble told Blair the obvious: in the absence of suspension, he would have no option but to resign. 'We have made the move, the IRA have not.' Adams repeated again and again the deadline was an artificial Unionist construct. Decommissioning was not in his gift to deliver.

In going for suspension, Blair had the very reluctant support of the Irish government, even if there has been disagreement over timing and tactics in the past week.

An Irish government source explained: 'We know Trimble can't move anymore, but the suspension creates some more space for the IRA to change position. But the Irish government knows we can't ignore the issue anymore. Whether we like it or not in the Unionist mentality only a start to decommission is the real signal that the IRA's war is over for good. That means there must be decommissioning, that's the Irish position.'

Mandelson duly made the announcement in the Commons promising suspension of the Executive would come into force this Friday. He held back from announcing Sinn Fein was in default of the agreement, which would have thrown Sinn Fein from the Assembly altogether.

Martin McGuinness, at points close to tears, claimed the suspension was the most disastrous moment in Irish history for the past 100 years.

The loss of Dublin's support represents a huge strategic setback. Sinn Fein and the IRA have looked to the Irish government to sponsor their interests since the first ceasefire six years ago.

The buzzword among Irish and British officials this weekend is 'clarity', meaning a clear statement of intent from the IRA that it will decommission and provide a timetable for when the process begins and ends.

There is little room for the two governments to play up a concession if the IRA come up with a new statement this week.

Trimble's letter of resignation as First Minister is locked in a safe, to which the UUP's president, Josias Cunningham, holds the key. Cunningham has made it clear he will activate the resignation even if the two governments try to 'spin' a new IRA statement as a seismic shift in republican policy.

For the IRA's part, the suspension poses a fundamental dilemma for the republican movement. There are many grassroots voices calling for a return to what the IRA does best - a surgical strike on the security forces or a prestigious target in Britain - to exert severe pressure on the British to grant more concessions to the republican movement.

But Sinn Fein would pay a heavy price for a one-off act of IRA violence. Specifically, it would lose the sponsorship of the Irish government and its fragile alliance with the SDLP. Yet the IRA might fear that not to react would demonstrate weakness.

Mandelson now faces the prospect of a long period of direct rule. He believes the IRA has not yet worked out the full logic of its position and that it is time for the gunmen to be stood down. Things have got to gestate, possibly for as long as a year.

In the meantime, to prevent a political vacuum, he must keep alive the rest of the Good Friday Agreement. Michael McGimpsey, the Ulster Unionist Executive member, thinks both sides, Unionists and Sinn Fein, have nowhere else to go.

'There will be a lot of huffing and puffing from Sinn Fein after suspension but I still believe this agreement will survive. Martin McGuinness likes being a Minister as much as I do.'

But anger is growing on the republican side and there is a danger that Adams and McGuinness would not survive a prolonged political vacuum. One Republican source said last week: 'There's already a suspicion that they have been suckered into this by the British Government with the aim of destroying both the IRA and Sinn Fein. If they can't show the political strategy is working, where can they go?'

What is in the terrorists' arsenal...on both sides

Buried in a network of underground bunkers - from Co Kerry in the south-west of Ireland to Donegal, the northernmost point - are enough IRA bullets to kill every man, woman and child in Ulster. Meanwhile, in Northern Ireland the loyalist paramilitaries have enough guns and explosives to kill and maim thousands in an outright civil war. Here is an inventory based on RUC and Gardai intelligence of the number of guns and explosives held in the hands of Ireland's private armies.

The Provisional IRA:
 Enough guns to arm two infantry battalions:
 An estimated 800 to 1,000 mainly AK47 assault rifles, the bulk of which were smuggled in from Libya in the late Eighties.
 Up to 400 handguns, 200 of which were posted from the United States by IRA supporters in Florida in the past two years.
 40 sub-machine guns.
 29 heavy machine guns, mainly Soviet-made DSHK weapons from Libya.
 25 heavy weapons including two Sam surface-to-air missiles and two Barrett Light 50 sniper rifles brought in from the US, which have killed 10 police officers and soldiers in South Armagh.
 Two tonnes of Semtex explosive from Libya (four tonnes have already been either used or captured by the security forces).
 Around 1.5 million rounds of ammunition.
 A vast array of home-made mortars and rocket launchers including hand-held rockets known as Prigs, can pierce armour and are used to kill RUC officers. Prigs are constructed from baked bean tins packed with Semtex and nails. The home-made equipment also includes various mortars whose warheads have knocked British Army helicopters out of the sky.

Ulster Volunteer Force:
 Around 80 AK47 rifles smuggled in from South Lebanon in 1987.
 Hundreds of home-made sub-machines constructed by loyalist supporters using knowledge gleaned in the Province's engineering industries.
 Around 100 Uzi submachine guns which are eastern European copies of the Israeli weapon used to deadly effect in close quarter killings.
 Two tonnes of Powergel plastic explosives.
 500 handguns
 180 grenades.

The Ulster Defence Association/Ulster Freedom Fighters:
 Around 100 Uzi submachine guns smuggled from arms dealers in the former Soviet bloc.
 Around 100 AK47 rifles from the Lebanon arms shipment of 1987.
 Several hundred home-made weapons including sub-machine guns and handguns.
 Several hundred factory-made handguns.
 Around 180 hand-grenades, mainly Soviet in origin which also came from the Lebanese arms shipment.

The Real IRA:
 Several RPG-18 rocket launchers, which are post-Soviet weapons that were bought in the former Yugoslavia last year.
 A dozen or so AK47 rifles.
 An unknown quantity of Semtex and other commercial explosive, some of which was taken from Provisional arms dumps when the Real IRA split from the Provisionals in 1987.
 A dozen or so handguns.

webTitle: How the editor's big deal soured

fields.headline: How the editor's big deal soured
fields.standfirst:
When accusations flew at the Mirror's Piers Morgan, Fleet Street was merciless. John Arlidge reports : Fighting talk in the red top rival
Share tipping explained
fields.trailText: When accusations flew at the  Mirror's Piers Morgan, Fleet Street was merciless.
fields.body:
It was 5pm on Tuesday afternoon when the telephone rang in Piers Morgan's office in Canary Wharf tower. On the walls hung tokens and memorabilia of his beloved Arsenal, framed Mirror front pages, including one of Rupert Murdoch as the devil, and a jaunty signed tie from the Chancellor Gordon Brown. 'Editor's office. How can I help you?' said his secretary, putting down her cup of peppermint tea.

'It's Suzy Jagger, from the Daily Telegraph City Desk here,' the broadsheet's stock market reporter said. 'Is Piers Morgan around?'

"Fraid not,' the Mirror editor's secretary replied. 'But he won't be long. Would you like to leave a message?' On a bright yellow Post-It note she yes-yessed and okayed as she wrote '£20,000. Viglen. Shares. Alan Sugar. January 17. Did you?'

Jagger, a new recruit to the Telegraph , did not expect Morgan to return her call. A contact had tipped her off that Morgan had bought Viglen shares before his City team published an exclusive story that would force up the price. 'Fleet Street editor in insider dealing' was a scoop worth promotion or a pay rise at least - but surely he would not be so naïve as to call her back straight away?

A telephone call interrupted the announcement of the closing share prices on the London Stock Exchange. 'Hi. It's Piers Morgan. What can I do for you?' Jagger repeated the question. 'Yes. It's true. I bought about £20,000 worth. They were about 150p.' No, Morgan added, he had not sold them because he thought they were a long-term investment.

The Telegraph ran the story that night: ' Mirror editor saw his shares soar after paper tipped company.' It ignited one of the most bitterly fought battles in tabloid history, prompted calls for Morgan to resign, and sparked questions in the House of Commons. Within 24 hours the Stock Exchange, the Press Complaints Commission and the Department of Trade and Industry launched investigations into Morgan and one of the Mirror's self-styled 'City Slicker' columnists, Anil Bhoyrul, who wrote the fateful Viglen story.

The latest salvoes were fired yesterday when the Sun dubbed Morgan an 'idiot who doesn't read his own paper' and told readers: 'You cannot trust the Mirror . They are a bunch of spivs.' And Stephen Hodgkinson, the man who reported Morgan and Bhoyrul to the Press Complaints Commission, dismissed Morgan's decision to dump his once long-term investment on Friday as 'too little too late... He should resign'.

This weekend the story shows no sign of dying. Morgan is just one questionable deal away from being forced out. Bhoyrul, too, could find himself spending more time with his family if an internal Mirror investigation uncovers evidence that he has been using the column to make a killing on the markets. Meanwhile, Mirror Group circulation managers are anxiously eyeing sales figures for signs that the story will hit market share.

The controversy marks an astonishing reversal of fortune for Morgan and his paper. The youngest-ever editor of a Fleet Street daily - Morgan is 34 - he is credited with single-handedly re-establishing the paper as an intelligent populist force after the title nearly folded in the wake of the Maxwell scandal. After a string of exclusives - including the scoop of the year when he revealed Cherie Blair's pregnancy - sales were rising.

Hiring the Slickers was a popular move. The column's 'barrow boy meets City whizz-kid' style had won friends in the usual parts of the city and Morgan relished Bhoyrul's 'wide boy' image.

With the gap between the Mirror and the Sun the narrowest for six years, the former Sun showbiz correspondent was on his way to his first Editor of the Year gong. Now, friends say, he has 'totally lost his spark'.

Privately, he has admitted that buying the shares and the way he handled public criticism was a 'terrible lapse of judgment'. He failed to see the danger of buying and selling shares himself, mishandled the bright young Daily Telegraph reporter, mistakenly tried to face down his critics before being forced into an abject U-turn.

Sources who have worked with Morgan blame 'a touch of spivvery' and 'over-bearing arrogance' for his troubles. One self-confessed admirer said: 'Piers is a great guy and an excellent editor. He can be funny, charming, incisive, but he is a mischief-maker who has a huge ego. He does not listen to anyone. He does it his way. He is convinced he cannot be wrong.'

Morgan had at least two chances to avoid controversy. He missed one and ignored the other until it was too late. The first came on Tuesday afternoon. Jagger's decision to confront Morgan directly was a long shot. By dictating her question to his secretary, Jagger gave Morgan valuable time to get himself out of trouble.

He could have 'lost' his secretary's note, told her to fob off Jagger for 24 hours saying he was busy, sold his shares, made a hefty donation to charity and then called Jagger back and told her he did not have any Viglen stock.

There may still have been some awkward questions but with no shares in his name the story would have run for a day or two and then fizzled out. Friends say he 'simply did not realise' what he was getting into when he picked up the receiver and dialled Jagger's direct line. It was not long before he found out.

When the Sun's night news editor read the first edition of Wednesday's Telegraph just before midnight on Tuesday, he immediately called David Yelland, editor of the Sun , at his Surrey home. Yelland had been investigating rumours of dodgy dealing at the Mirror ever since Morgan declared personal war on Yelland over the Sun's decision to publish pictures of Sophie Rhys-Jones topless.

But Yelland was curiously silent when the night desk told him what Morgan had admitted. One senior Sun source recalls: 'I don't think he actually believed Piers could have been so stupid.'

It was not long before Yelland got to work. He immediately remade the Sun's front page. ' Mirror editor in share storm,' it screamed the next morning, with an editorial accusing Morgan of 'letting down' his readers and the Mirror board. 'The editor of the Mirror must go.'

When he arrived for work on Wednesday Morgan had a second chance to save his rep utation. Friends told him he should issue a statement denying any wrongdoing and informing readers that to avoid any allegations of greed or impropriety he was selling the shares and would donate the proceeds to charity. Once again, he ignored the advice - dismissing the Sun's call as traditional 'red top' knockabout. 'My rivals have an opportunity to try to embarrass me which they are taking with commendable excitement,' he joked.

But it was not just the Sun . When he read Wednesday's Telegraph sitting in his Chambers in the Temple, barrister Stephen Hodgkinson thought: 'This stinks.' One hour later the fax machine in the Fleet Street offices of the Press Complaints Commission whirred into life.

'Dear Lord Wakeham,' Hodgkinson wrote, 'I trust the PCC will be investigating Piers Morgan's alleged share dealings in an Alan Sugar company.' Two days later Hogkinson made a similar complaint against Anil Bhoyrul - after the Guardian revealed he held 10,000 shares in Belgo, a restaurant chain he had repeatedly tipped in the City Slickers column.

The PCC regulates newspapers and its rules on journalists dealing in shares are draconian. They 'must not buy or sell either directly or through nominees or agents, shares or securities about which they have written recently or intend to write about in the near future'.

For now Morgan and Bhoyrul, 33, have bought valuable time. An internal Mirror group inquiry has cleared Morgan - saying it believes he did not see the Slickers' Viglen puff piece until after he had bought the shares. He sold the shares on Friday and promised to donate the £14,000 profit to charity. Insiders say Bhoyrul, too, is safe for now.

But the cold creeping fear that sweeps over editors embroiled in the kind of scandals that boost the circulation of rivals will not go away. The PCC is not the toothless body that tabloid editors used to enjoy ignoring.

If the PCC and the DTI believe Morgan and Bhoyrul are telling the truth, then they will have had a narrow squeak and live to fight another day. But if Robert Maxwell-like claims of an insider dealing ring at the Mirror emerge when the PCC publishes its ruling next month, the two young men's glittering careers will be over. Their tabloid trick of issuing spoof P45's to badly performing City executives will not seem so funny when the real things land on their desks.

webTitle: TV Weed blooms into a feminist

fields.headline: TV Weed blooms into a feminist
fields.trailText: Weed, the verbally challenged friend of Bill and Ben The Flowerpot Men , has finally found her voice, in a victory for women and weeds everywhere.
fields.body:
Weed, the verbally challenged friend of Bill and Ben The Flowerpot Men , has finally found her voice, in a victory for women and weeds everywhere.

The character will be reinvented as a stronger, more articulate pot plant in an updated version of the Sixties' Watch with Mother classic, being made for BBC television near Manchester.

'She won't even say "Weeeeed!" any more,' said Frank Vose, producer of the new show for Cosgrove Hall Films. 'We have made her into a wise character who has quite a lot to say and is able to express herself clearly. A more modern, feminist vision, if you like.'

While Bill and Ben will continue to talk nonsense, relying heavily on their well-established catchphrase 'flobalobalob', Weed will be shown solving all their problems and negotiating relations between a whole cast of new animal characters.

Vose said: 'The old version of The Flowerpot Men does look rather dull now. We felt we needed to introduce more elements into the stories to keep children interested.'

This female-friendly re-interpretation is supported by the doyenne of children's television, Floella Benjamin, the former presenter of Playschool who now makes her own programmes.

'Children have so much else distracting them these days, you do need to grab their attention,' she said.

'I think it is fine for them to change this aspect of the original programme. When the character of Weed was created most mothers stayed at home and had more of a supportive role.

'These days women are running companies and many mothers are businesswomen. Weed should reflect these changes,' said Benjamin, who organises the annual Woman of the Year lunch.

webTitle: I was South Africa's public enemy No 1

fields.headline: I was South Africa's public enemy No 1
fields.standfirst: In his diary, Labour MP Peter Hain charts his return as an honoured guest to the land he was forced to flee as a teenager with his anti-apartheid parents while a schoolboy
fields.trailText: Sleeping the night on Robben Island, it's hard not to think of life, the universe and everything. Tranquillity personified, the island is now an ecological and historical museum nurturing buck, penguins and a wonderful variety of other birds.
fields.body:
Sleeping the night on Robben Island, it's hard not to think of life, the universe and everything. Tranquillity personified, the island is now an ecological and historical museum nurturing buck, penguins and a wonderful variety of other birds.

Thirty-four years ago, as a 16-year-old on an ocean liner out of Cape Town, I steamed past the island with my South African parents who were forced into exile through their anti-apartheid activities.

The prison still stands, no longer incarcerating Nelson Mandela and his comrades, but a gaunt reminder of the dark, brutal days of apartheid. Tourists pass through, led by guides, many of whom were former prisoners, and by former white warders, once oppressors, now co-operating to build a new future.

I spend the night in a four- poster bed in the old guest house of the governor, as the guest of the chief of the island, my old anti-apartheid comrade André Odendaal.

This was a private night during my visit as Britain's Minister for Africa. As we look up at the stars, enjoying a glass of excellent South African wine over a braaivleis [barbecue], it is hard not to marvel at the continuing miracle of the new South Africa.

In Pretoria, I stay in the British High Commissioner's Residence. This is the city where I lived as a child and where my family suffered constant surveillance and regular Special Branch raids on our home.

At an evening reception, the great trumpeter Hugh Masekela turns up. 'I wanted to come because of all your anti-apartheid work,' he says generously. I introduce him to my parents who are here on holiday for only their second time in 34 years.

Now in their seventies, they were the leading anti-apartheid activists in Pretoria in the early Sixties. They were jailed and issued with 'banning orders', turning them into 'non-persons'.

Pretoria is curiously unthreatening now. I visit the top seat of power, the Union Buildings, a majestic colonial legacy, and walk through corridors and meet new Ministers in rooms previously inhabited by those architects of apartheid, Verwoerd, Vorster, and Botha, to meet the new Ministers of South Africa.

Essop Pahad - President Thabo Mbeki's aide and a Cabinet Minister - is an old comrade from the days of the anti-apartheid movement in London. He tells me how, on the first day they took power, Mbeki (then Deputy President) arrived and found he was not even allocated an office, and one had to be commandeered.

We have a long, excellent meeting with Essop's brother, Deputy Foreign Minister Aziz Pahad, in Diplomatic House, a comfortable retreat built for the former apartheid Foreign Minister Pik Botha (who recently applied to join the ANC). We cover almost everything, from tackling the sanctions-busters supplying Jonas Savimbi's murderous Unita rebels in Angola, to our common agenda on nuclear disarmament.

There is so much agreement, that I remark afterwards at a press conference: 'Marching together on demonstrations in London, we used to call each other Aziz and Peter. This morning we kept saying, "Yes, Minister".'

I was last at Pretoria Boys' High School in 1966, when I waved a sad goodbye to my classmates. Now nearly 50, I am back to address the school assembly. It is an emotional occasion and I am introduced by my old English teacher, who once explained the meaning of persona non grata by saying: 'Hain's parents are persona non grata with the government because they think.'

Dad is an old boy, from the Forties, and he and Mum are in the school hall. In the mid-Sixties they were not permitted on school premises to talk to my teachers because of their banning orders. Dad had to watch me play cricket over the school fence. Banned people were not permitted to communicate with each other. Which presented a problem when Dad was banned in 1964, a year after Mum. They had special clauses inserted in their banning orders enabling them to talk to each other.

Ii;s an odd sensation being back and representing Her Majesty's Government. The apartheid regime denounced me as 'public enemy number one' after my leadership of demonstrations in Britain which stopped all-white South African sports teams visiting the UK in the 1969-70 season. The South African press called me 'Hain the Pain', or 'Peter Hate'. Yet here I am with a special place reserved for the state opening of parliament.

On the same occasion, a decade ago, the last white President, F. W. de Klerk, made his historic speech signalling the unbanning of the ANC, the release of Nelson Mandela and the effective end of apartheid.

It is ten years to the week since Nelson Mandela walked free after spending 10,000 days in prison. 'Ah, Peter, return of the prodigal son,' he says, warmly greeting me and generously praising my role in the anti-apartheid struggle. People like him and countless others contributed so much more.

We discuss his role as a peace facilitator in the long-running war in Burundi and how we should clamp down on the sanctions busters. As sharp as ever, Madiba (the leader) was in remarkable form. You really do feel in the presence of greatness.

I am an official guest of the country's cricket supremo, Ali Bacher, on Friday at the one-day international between England and South Africa. He was captain of the 1970 Springbok side which we stopped touring Britain.

Such an invitation would have been unthinkable even six years ago. I gave up running on cricket pitches to stop the Springboks a long time ago, so I am not much use to England now.

Many whites who once hated my guts have made a point of coming up to me to say they now understood what I was doing. But a sign from the bad old days greeted me on the drive outside the school gate. Someone had painted: 'Peter Hain - go back home to Kenya'. (I was born there). But at the height of the stop-the-tour protests angry critics demanded that I 'go back home to South Africa'.

It's high time these people got on message. 'Go back home to Wales' would be fair enough, though they tell me it's been rainy and cold there. It's sunny out here.

Peter Hain is Minister of State at the Foreign Office, MP for Neath and author of 'Sing the Beloved Country: The Struggle for the New South Africa'

fields.headline: Schools mean more than guns
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: This weekend thousands of children in Northern Ireland are feeling bitterly disappointed. The results of the 11-plus examination, which determine whether they get into a grammar school, were delivered to more than 17,500 homes yesterday.
fields.body:
This weekend thousands of children in Northern Ireland are feeling bitterly disappointed. The results of the 11-plus examination, which determine whether they get into a grammar school, were delivered to more than 17,500 homes yesterday.

Thirty-four per cent of those who sat the exam will be offered grammar school places. The remainder, more than 11,500 pupils, will experience a sense of failure which many educationalists believe is damaging and discriminatory.

It's one of the ironies of the present political crisis in the Province that those who would like to see the 11-plus abolished may lose, in the coming days, one of their most powerful allies. Martin McGuinness, the Minister for Education in the new Executive, is on the record as saying that he would like to see the exam phased out, and that he is awaiting new research on the issue from Queen's University, Belfast.

The Minister has experience of what it means to fail the 11-plus. From time to time over the past 30 years there has been speculation on how the recent history of Northern Ireland might have been affected if young Martin had gained entry to St Columb's, the Catholic grammar school in Derry which has produced Nobel Prize winners Seamus Heaney and John Hume.

Martin McGuinness has now been Minister for Education in Northern Ireland's new Executive for two months. Many unionists were appalled at his appointment, which they saw as handing over responsibility for their children's education to a former terrorist.

In the brief time that he has held the job, McGuinness has disarmed many of his critics. He has been energetic in pursuing his brief and sometimes surprisingly radical in his views.

Besides expressing his reservations about the 11-plus, he has pledged his support for integrated education in Northern Ireland. He has also gone out of his way to show that he is not beholden to sectarian shibboleths when he intervened personally to ensure that the Duchess of Abercorn would be able to go ahead with her visit to a Catholic primary school in Pomeroy.

There have been other members of the new Executive who have impressed both communities by their performance, however brief, in office.

Last Tuesday, as frantic discussions continued to try to avert the suspension of the political institutions set up under the Belfast Agreement, thousands of Ulster farmers gathered outside Stormont. The industry is in crisis, with the latest figures showing that farm incomes in the Province have fallen by 80 per cent over the past five years, even more dramatic than the decline in Scotland and Wales. The perception is that they have been forgotten by central government and the hope is that a local administration may do better.

The Northern Ireland GPs committee of the British Medical Association is reported to be in 'total despair', because they fear that suspension could lead to further delays in making urgent decisions about the future of regional hospitals and other services.

Such issues have, understandably, been put on the back-burner while the British and Irish governments pull out all the stops to resolve the problem of decommissioning.

fields.headline: Pinochet thugs tortured British priest
fields.trailText: The horrific last moments of a British priest tortured by henchmen of Chilean dictator General Augusto Pinochet were revealed for the first time yesterday.
fields.byline: by Andy McSmith Chief Political Correspondent
fields.body:
The horrific last moments of a British priest tortured by henchmen of Chilean dictator General Augusto Pinochet were revealed for the first time yesterday.

Michael Woodward, the only British victim of the September 1973 coup led by Pinochet, which overthrew the elected government of Chile, was officially said to have died of a heart attack under questioning.

Now, however, his sister has revealed the harrowing last moments of his life as the British government prepares to allow Pinochet to return to Chile without standing trial for his crimes.

Patricia Bennetts has written to the Foreign Office, enclosing evidence of the circumstances of her brother's death and pleading that Pinochet be held here until the murder is investigated.

She claims that the naval command in Valparaiso, where Woodward was held and killed, was closely linked to Pinochet's junta and the dictator must have known about the torture ships moored in the harbour.

Woodward was among prisoners rounded up on board the Esmeralda, a ship moored outside the port. The navy wasted no time getting to work. They gave him a shower, and while he was still wet, applied electrodes where his skin was softest.

Then they beat him, repeatedly and cruelly. To disguise this, they wrapped their fists in towels to hide bruises. The blows made him bleed profusely from internal injuries until his body turned almost black. They used hammers to break both his arms.

They starved him for several days. Others, being tortured at the same time, were allowed worm-infested beans. They screamed insults at him in front of other prisoners and accused him of indulging in sexual orgies. This carried on for about 10 days.

Then the commander of the naval cruiser Latorre, moored alongside the Esmeralda, received an urgent call for a doctor for someone seriously ill on the Esmeralda.

The officer, Captain Carlos Fanta, appears to have been relatively humane and was suspicious about what was being done to the prisoners on the Esmeralda. He ordered one of his ship's doctors to report back at once.

The doctor returned to say he had seen a priest laid out on the deck of the Esmeralda, his internal organs haemorrhaging so badly he would be dead in an hour. The doctor was in no doubt that the injuries came from brutal beatings. Captain Fanta ordered the injured man be taken by ambulance to a nearby naval hospital, but he was dead on arrival.

Speaking from Madrid, where she was taking part in a demonstration outside the foreign ministry, Bennetts said yesterday: 'When Pinochet was first arrested I had the press harassing me on my doorstep and Amnesty International wanting me to speak out but I didn't. The reason was simply my sentiment towards my father (who died last year) because I know what it's like to see in print that someone you love has been tortured to death. I always wanted to protect my parents because I thought it was so horrible.'

Home Secretary Jack Straw says he is 'minded' not to extradite Pinochet to Spain but let him return to Chile due to poor health.

Bennetts and her English husband, who live in Madrid, learned the truth about Woodward's death from a 1975 report in The Observer. The report quoted Chilean exiles recently arrived in Britain saying that an Anglo-Chilean priest had been tortured to death by the Chilean navy.

After a fruitless first visit to learn about her brother's death, Bennetts returned to Chile in 1991. They learned that the death had been registered at Valparaiso cemetery, and his body tossed into a communal grave.

A priest, Fr Edward Courzet, found Captain Fanta and obtained his account of Woodward's death. The crime which made Woodward a target for Pinochet's thugs was that he rejected the formal church hierarchy and went to work among the poor.

webTitle: Banks forced to display cash machine charge

fields.headline: Banks forced to display cash machine charge
fields.trailText: Banks are to be compelled to warn cash-machine users if they intend to charge for transactions.
fields.byline: by Andy McSmith Chief Political Correspondent
fields.body:
Banks are to be compelled to warn cash-machine users if they intend to charge for transactions.

Cash point users have been angered and confused by recent increases in the number of banks charging non-customers without warning.

But Trade and Industry Secretary Stephen Byers has been told by advisers that under a 25-year-old Act of Parliament he can force banks to warn customers of the so-called 'disloyalty charges'.

Under the 1974 Prices Act, he could force every bank to flash up a message on cash point screens, stating how much it intends to charge users and giving them the opportunity to cancel the transaction.

The advice follows increasing government concern about 'rip-off Britain', and comes during a review of the banking system.

Less than two weeks ago, Don Cruickshank, head of the banking review team, wrote to members of the Link cash machine network expressing concern about the charges.

His letter coincided with a warning from the Office of Fair Trading. OFT director-general John Bridgeman said: 'It is disagreeable that some banks appear insensitive to the fact that fixed-rate charges disproportionately penalise people who are less well-off.'

At present, about 40 banks and building societies are joined through the Link system, which allows customers of one bank to withdraw money, without suffering a charge, from a cash machine operated by a rival. Barclays Bank has been pushing for an industry-wide agreement under which all banks and building societies will charge a fee.

The DTI has been hostile to the Barclays plan which it sees as an example of 'rip-off Britain'.

Barclays says it is not opposed to regulation compelling banks to give advance warning of charges. A spokeswoman for the bank said: 'We are calling for a standard user fee whereby we charge non-customers for using cashpoints, but we would make it clear.'

fields.headline: Family life 'mirrors the workplace'
fields.trailText: Outsourcing, networking, flat hierarchies, portfolio working, associates - the jargon is familiar. But the buzzwords of business now apply to another institution: The Great British Family.
fields.body:
Outsourcing, networking, flat hierarchies, portfolio working, associates - the jargon is familiar. But the buzzwords of business now apply to another institution: The Great British Family.

Just as firms are having to adopt new strategies to survive - buying in skills as needed and demanding flexibility from employees - so families are transforming themselves to fit new gender roles and working patterns.

Helen Wilkinson, editor of a Demos report published tomorrow, Family Business , said families were having to adapt to a changing external environment and become more businesslike.'Pressures from outside the family, especially from paid work, are contributing to the convergence between the two, with downsizing and outsourcing,' she says.

Calling for greater Government commitment to paid care leave and a Minister for the Generations, she argues that with blood relatives often separated by long distances, friends were being enlisted to help raise children as 'family associates' - in just the same way that a company might buy in IT support.

'There are many parents who would rather use friends for childcare than get paid help,' she said. 'Friends might take the place of relatives because of mobility, and become part of the new extended family.'

With more people choosing not to have children of their own, there is a symbiosis between time-pressed parents and childless 'supply' mothers and fathers - the equivalent of contract workers.

'There are lots of people who may not want to have children of their own, but who do want access to children's lives,' she said.

But Patricia Morgan, a researcher on family policy at the Institute for Economic Affairs, condemned attempts to commercialise the family.

'Child development is not like a production line', she said. 'This is not something that can be looked at in a commercial way.'

The Demos report points out that, especially in house holds with two full-time workers and children, services such as cleaning, cooking, childcare, DIY and laundry are being 'contracted out'. Sixty-two per cent of households with dependent children have both adults in work, the report says. As a result, domestic services together form one of the fastest-growing areas of the economy.

Wilkinson said shifting gender roles meant that traditional divisions of labour in the household were breaking down, allowing for portfolio parenting, shared by both partners in just the same way that job descriptions are becoming increasingly fuzzy.

Tom Bentley, director of Demos, said the debate over the future of the family should be informed by trends in business thinking. 'For too long the debate has focused on the structure of families, in the same way that businesses used to worry about the nature of hierarchies, which are actually pretty insignificant,' he said.

'More important are ethos, culture, leadership and the quality of relationships.'

But Morgan said it was a mistake to dismiss structures so lightly, pointing out that unmarried parents were much more likely to separate than a husband and wife.

'The fact is that structure does influence quality,' she said. 'There is lots of evidence to show that step-families don't do so well compared with traditional families, especially in terms of child development.'

The Demos paper estimates that household labour is worth 23 per cent of Gross Domestic Product, more than manufacturing and 10 times the size of the agricultural economy.

webTitle: CO 2  sea dumps to beat global warming

fields.headline: CO 2  sea dumps to beat global warming
fields.trailText: Billions of tons of carbon dioxide may be dumped underground or pumped into the ocean in a drastic bid to stop global warming.
fields.body:
Billions of tons of carbon dioxide may be dumped underground or pumped into the ocean in a drastic bid to stop global warming.

Engineers are backing a series of schemes - which include projects to pour liquefied gas into old salt mines or pile frozen chunks of carbon dioxide into undersea trenches - because they believe attempts to control global carbon dioxide emissions are doomed to failure.

Coal, gas and oil will remain cheap and plentiful, despite predictions they would run out, and are likely to continue to power cars, homes and factories for the next 100 years, the scientists say in the current issue of Scientific American . The only hope for preventing disastrous heating of the Earth is therefore to remove carbon dioxide after it is pumped into the air, and hide it.

However, these ideas have alarmed conservationists. 'I am sure carbon dumping may be of some use, but we should be very suspicious,' said Dr Patrick Green, senior energy and climate campaigner for Friends of the Earth. 'It will provide a perfect excuse to industrialists for taking no remedial action.'

At a gas well in the Sleipner field off Norway, 20,000 tonnes of carbon dioxide have been extracted from the rig's natural gas output every week since 1996, and then pumped back into sandstone pores below the sea bed. Burying carbon dioxide from this single well reduces Norway's total emissions by three per cent.

Carbon sequestration will involve 'scrubbing' emissions from factories and power plants. Carbon dioxide could be extracted and then chilled, compressed and liquefied or even solidified. Such technology is expensive - the Sleipner gas removal kit cost $80 million - but would quickly become viable if taxes were imposed on firms and utilities that pump carbon dioxide into the atmosphere.

As a liquid, carbon dioxide could then be pumped into relatively shallow sea waters where it would dissolve. 'Other injection scenarios that have been suggested include dropping dry ice [solidified carbon dioxide] into the ocean from ships, introducing carbon dioxide at 1,000 metres through a pipe towed by a moving ship, and running a pipe down 3,000 metres or more to depressions in sea floors,' state the authors, Howard Herzog, of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Baldur Eliasson, of the International Energy Agency, and Olav Kaarstad, of Norwegian oil company Statoil, in their Scientific American feature. This last scheme would create deep underwater lakes of liquid CO <->2 .

Hi-tech schemes like these contrast with established, natural ways of sequestering carbon - of which tree-planting is the principal technique. 'The potential for trees to serve as a reservoir for carbon is limited,' the authors say. 'Tree plantations drain native plant biodiversity and can disturb local communities, forcing them to relocate.'

However, they acknowledge that salt mines, ocean-bed trenches and other dumps all pose dangers. Pumping carbon dioxide into the sea could increase the water's acidity, destroying delicate eco-systems such as coral reefs. Similarly, layers of carbon dioxide on the ocean bed could be disturbed and abruptly bubble to the surface - with potentially devastating consequences. A huge bubble of CO <->2 - produced by deep volcanic events - killed 1,700 people when it burst to the surface of Lake Nyos in Cameroon in 1986.

webTitle: Mandelson and I aren't speaking, says Mowlam

fields.headline: Mandelson and I aren't speaking, says Mowlam
fields.trailText: Mo Mowlam, the former Northern Ireland Secretary, has not spoken to her successor, Peter Mandelson, since he took over her job in the summer,  writes Patrick Wintour.
fields.body:
Mo Mowlam, the former Northern Ireland Secretary, has not spoken to her successor, Peter Mandelson, since he took over her job in the summer, writes Patrick Wintour.

Their silence - save to say 'Good morning' at Cabinet meetings - underlines the rifts at the top of the Government. It was revealed by Mowlam, left , now Cabinet Office co-ordinator, in a radio interview.

Mandelson is understood to have been angered by the resistance Mowlam put up to him taking over. She would have preferred him to be her number two.

He came into the job with the aim of doing more to woo Unionists, who were increasingly suspicious of Mowlam.

fields.headline: Adams: IRA won't budge
fields.trailText: Gerry Adams has told the British Government he will be thrown out of the Sinn Fein leadership if he presses for decommissioning of IRA arms in the current political climate.
fields.byline: by Henry McDonald and Patrick Wintour
fields.body:
Gerry Adams has told the British Government he will be thrown out of the Sinn Fein leadership if he presses for decommissioning of IRA arms in the current political climate.

Confirmation that the IRA is not in a mood to disarm came in a fresh statement from its leadership yesterday saying it would not decommission. The communiqué, issued after talks between Adams and Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble, makes suspension of the power-sharing Northern Ireland Executive on Friday a near certainty.

The new statement insists the IRA represents no threat to peace. But it offers no timetable for arms decommissioning, the precondition for Northern Ireland Secretary Peter Mandelson lifting the threat to restore direct rule. Mandelson privately thinks the IRA may be a year or so away from agreeing to disarm.

In the only ray of hope, the statement said: 'The IRA believes that this crisis can be averted and the issue of arms can be resolved. This will not be on British or unionist terms nor will it be advanced by British legislative threats. We recognise the issue of arms needs to be dealt with in an acceptable way and this is a necessary objective of a genuine peace process - for that reason we are engaged with the IICD [decommissioning body]. We have supported and will continue to support efforts to secure the resolution of the arms issue. The peace process is under no threat from the IRA.'

Senior Ulster Unionist Party sources said yesterday that, if the British and Irish governments attempt to sell this fresh IRA statement as a shift in republican policy without actual arms being given up, Trimble would be forced to pull out of the power-sharing government.

Neither the British Government nor the Northern Ireland Office commented on the IRA statement. But Shadow Northern Ireland Secretary Andrew Mackay said: 'This confirms, sadly, that there is not going to be decommissioning in the near future so, as we have consistently said, the Secretary of State has no alternative but to suspend the Executive and the assembly next week. The fault lies squarely with the paramilitary groups.'

The British Government is reluctant to suspend the Executive, but believes it has no alternative if it is to protect Trimble's leadership. The chairman of the decommissioning body, General Sir John de Chastelain, has privately advised that the IRA would not need to start disarming until March to meet the Good Friday Agreement deadline for full decommissioning by 22 May.

fields.headline: News In Brief
fields.trailText: Body found on a traffic island
fields.body:
Body found on a traffic island

The decomposing body of an adult has been discovered in a tent on a traffic island at Junction 1 of the M5 at West Bromwich. Police have not yet established whether the body is that of a man or a woman, but believe it has lain there for several months.

Teenager counterfeiters

Two 13-year-old boys in Eastbourne have been cautioned by police for making counterfeit £5 notes on a home computer. They boys had allegedly tried to buy sweets, crisps and drinks at their school tuck shop and had 18 notes on them when they were arrested.

Dutchman admits smuggling £1m cocaine into Britain

Dutchman Cornelis van Tilburg pleaded guilty to smuggling cocaine worth about £1 million into Britain. The drugs were discovered at Harwich hidden in the dashboard of a hired car, Colchester magistrates heard. He was sent to a crown court to be sentenced.

Fiennes fattens up

Explorer Sir Ranulph Fiennes, 56, who has arrived at his base camp in Canada, started eating chunks of butter to fatten himself up for his attempt to become the first person to walk solo and unsupported to the North Pole.

Dog in distress dialled 999

Rescuers in Poland found a dog alone in a flat after it had dialled 999 and was heard howling.

Polly on Prozac

An African Grey parrot in Cardiff has been prescribed Prozac by its vet after its temper became so bad it ripped up its owner's furniture and books.

They don't grow on trees

An East Surrey Aids awareness team angered locals by hanging condoms, lubricants and leaflets from trees on Banstead Common.

Thief alarm

Robbers broke into a Hull warehouse and, ignoring TVs and other goods, stole £2,500 worth of burglar alarms.

fields.headline: Digital licence 'would break the law'
fields.trailText: The BBC's plans to expand into the new digital age have been thrown into disarray by a leading QC's advice that funding them with a special levy on top of the TV licence would breach European law.
fields.body:
The BBC's plans to expand into the new digital age have been thrown into disarray by a leading QC's advice that funding them with a special levy on top of the TV licence would breach European law.

Commercial TV companies, which sought the barrister's opinion, said that, if Culture Secretary Chris Smith went ahead with his expected announcement of a levy this week, they would take court action.

The firms say the levy could not be implemented until the European Court of Justice had ruled on it. The legal opinion, drawn up on Friday night and sent to Smith, comes as the Government prepares to make its long-awaited decision on the proposed £24-a-year levy.

An announcement is expected on Thursday, following talks between the Treasury, Smith and Downing Street.

The BBC wants the planned digital licence fee to subsidise its expansion into digital broadcasts, but has given no detailed figures on how the extra income would be spent.

The opinion states: 'Support for the BBC's digital ambitions in the form of an increase in the licence fee, or a specific digital supplement, would constitute state aid requiring notification to the European Commission before it could come into effect. Approval for such funding could be given only if the services were deemed to be of general national interest rather than as commercial services, and for funding to be shown to be proportionate with such an obligation.

'The Commission would then have to evaluate the adverse effect on competition and issue a properly reasoned decision.'

The opinion, by Nicholas Green QC, claims it is 'fatal' to the BBC's ambitions that it has not disclosed what programmes the digital levy would be used to produce. Nor has it given detailed figures to show that the income from the levy is proportionate to its needs.

Separate legal advice has also raised a question mark over whether the Government would have the powers to enforce collection of a digital licence, even if it was ruled lawful by the EU. Ministers have been deadlocked for months over whether to bow to demands for a £24 annual digital licence fee to boost the BBC's coffers and make it competitive in the new TV age. Downing Street backs the move, against opposition from the Treasury and the Department of Industry.

A £24 fee for digital users, likely to raise £250m a year by 2004, was recommended by the BBC funding review chaired by Gavyn Davies.
