webTitle: 'My left foot was not part  of me'

fields.headline: 'My left foot was not part  of me'
fields.standfirst: Outrage greeted the news this week that two people had begged surgeons to amputate their healthy legs. In an exclusive interview one of them tells  Pennie Taylor of  the Sunday Herald why the operation has ended years of torment
fields.trailText: Kevin Wright knew what he needed from the age of eight. That was when he was first aware of his pathological desire to lose his left leg.
fields.body:
Kevin Wright knew what he needed from the age of eight. That was when he was first aware of his pathological desire to lose his left leg.

'I just didn't want it. It didn't feel a part of me,'he says. 'I didn't understand why, but I knew I didn't want my leg.'

Almost 30 years later, his wish was granted, thanks to a Scottish surgeon who was willing to risk international notoriety to put Kevin out of his intense emotional pain.

Since it was unexpectedly announced last week, the case has attracted worldwide interest because there was absolutely nothing wrong with Kevin's limb. He just knew it had to go. 'By taking my leg away that surgeon has made me complete,'he says.

The operation, which was performed by Robert Smith at Falkirk Royal Infirmary in September 1997, was both a clinical and a personal success. 'Of course I am not a different person now, but I might well be,' says Wright. 'I have happiness and contentment and life is so much more settled, so much easier.'

From the moment news of his voluntary surgery broke on Monday, Wright's Essex home has been besieged by the media. Tabloid hacks interviewed colleagues and neighbours, but dug up nothing more revealing than the fact that he does not have the disabled sticker for his car to which he is entitled.

Last night, as his 21-month-old son Stephen played in the background, Wright gave his first - and he insists his last - interview on the subject of his amputation and the Body Dysmorphic Disorder that caused it.

Speaking about it is obviously not easy for him to do, but he hopes it will end some of the more prurient speculation that much recent coverage has inspired.

Wright always knew that the way he felt about his leg was something he ought to keep secret, and as a child he did not share his thoughts with anybody.

'I knew I couldn't be the only one to feel this way, but I couldn't find anything to help me try to understand it,'he said. 'It really wore me down. I was so desperate for help.'

Despite the intensity of his antipathy towards his lower left leg, nobody realised how Kevin felt until he was 28, and had been married to Susan, a midwife, for seven years.

She was 'surprised, but accepting' of the confession, and gave him the confidence to work up the courage to seek professional help. However instead of enlightenment, he found blind ignorance.

'I encountered some very short-sighted psychiatrists who didn't know what they were talking about,'said Kevin. 'They threatened compulsory electric shock treatment and I had some nasty experiences with heavy prescribed drugs. But none of them touched the problem.'

He was variously told he was 'off his trolley', that he was paranoid and had dementia and delusions. 'They were desperate to label me, but nothing fitted,'he said.

As far as he was concerned, amputation above the knee was the only feasible option. He couldn't bear life with his leg intact, and confesses to having contemplated suicide when he could not locate a surgeon willing to remove it. 'Few of the medical profession knew about it, and even fewer wanted to know,'he said. 'It was total blackness.'

Some people call his complaint Body Dysmorphic Disorder, a psychological condition where sufferers fixate on parts of their body and become convinced that they have to be changed. Nobody knows how many people are affected by it, but BDD has been estimated to be the reason for up to 7% of the plastic surgery usually performed on noses, breasts and buttocks.

The accepted wisdom is that because it is assumed to be a psychological problem, BDD ought to be treated without surgery. In some cases psychiatrists claim to be able to alleviate the condition with psychotherapy. But that had no effect on Wright, who said he was eventually 'palmed off' with Prozac.

Although what he was requesting was not illegal, nobody would refer him to an NHS surgeon, and few private surgeons were willing. 'I just wanted someone to recognise that I had a problem,'he said. 'I hoped to spark their interest. But there wasn't much.'

In 1995 he finally found a surgeon in England willing to perform a private operation. Then three days before it was due to take place, it was cancelled. The hospital where it was scheduled had second thoughts.

That was Wright's lowest point. But shortly afterwards an acquaintance mentioned a surgeon in Falkirkwho had a particular interest in amputation surgery. Robert Smith usually strives to save the legs of people suffering the effects of diabetes and peripheral vascular disease.

A necessary part of his job, though, is performing up to 30 amputations a year. But he had never been asked to remove a healthy limb. 'I obviously thought it was controversial, but I was intrigued,'he said. 'And yes, I was touched by his story.'

He agreed to read the two psychiatric assessments and one psychological report on Wright that had been prepared by experts, indicating BDD. Since then, Smith has read everything on the subject. Of particular interest was the work of an American neuro-scientist, Professor V S Ramachandran, author of the book Phantoms in the Brain .

Ramachandran is now exploring the thesis that severe expressions of BDD, such as that suffered by Wright, may be caused not some psychosomatic illness, but a functional disorder within the brain that erases the limb from the mind, making it feel an entirely unwanted object.

Like Wright, Smith is unhappy with the umbrella label BDD. He believes that people seeking amputation of healthy limbs may have one of four different conditions which can be hard to tell apart.

Smith classifies the first group as 'psychopathic serial self-mutilators', those who seek out amputations as the ultimate in personal gratification. Secondly, there are those who try to have healthy limbs taken off so that they can become more dependent on relatives or carers.

The third group gain vicarious sexual pleasure from the fantasy of being an amputee. The fourth group are people like Wright for whom the desire to lose a limb is an all-consuming part of life.

'These are very distressed, troubled people, and for them surgery may be appropriate,'said Smith. 'I would not consider it for people in the other groups.'

Smith and Wright finally met in London in early 1996. 'I came to the conclusion I would like to try and help him, but not without great trepidation because of the legal, ethical and media interest involved,'said Smith.

Before he agreed to the operation, Smith consulted a local psychiatrist who advised him against it. He took advice from the Medical Defence Union, which sanctioned the operation on the grounds that the surgeon believed it was in the best interests of his patient, and that every check and double-check had been made.

Eighteen months of serious consideration eventually led Smith to approach a nearby private hospital, King's Park, where he would have preferred to have done the operation. 'I didn't feel I wanted to do it on the NHS because I felt it shouldn't be asked to fund it as there was no policy on it,'said Smith.

He had the support of the private hospital's medical advisory committee, but the managers said 'no', fearing adverse publicity. As a last resort he approached the then medical director of the Falkirk Royal Infirmary NHS Trust, who consented.

The chief executive at the time gave the final sanction. Smith recruited a surgical and nursing team within the Infirmary who were all willing to help.

Finally, on 16 September 1997, Wright lost his leg. The operation cost him £1,400, which paid for the costs of theatre time and a five-day hospital stay. Smith waived his fee. 'Kevin is now a happy man,'he said. 'I have no regrets about it.'

Last year, Smith was approached by another 'patient. 'I felt considerable trepidation, but that was an easier decision to reach,'he said.

Once again the trust's medical director agreed, only this time the patient paid £6,600. By the time the third prospective patient turned up last year seeking voluntary amputation, the trust had a new board of managers.

The new chief executive referred the decision to the chairman, who had been unaware of the previous two operations. He put an immediate ban on the surgery, and ordered an internal ethical committee inquiry.

Its report has concluded that while there was no impropriety in the decisions to proceed with the first two operations, any more would have to be closely considered by the whole board before they could be allowed.

After last week's revelation that the amputations had taken place, the trust chairman, Ian Mullen, declared that no such operation would happen again in his hospital.

He was responding to the outrage of local MSP Denis Canavan, who called on the Health Minister to ensure that it would never arise anywhere in Scotland.

'What has bugged me most is the ill-informed comments of some of the MSPs. I'm sure they'd never heard of BDD till half an hour before, and it took me a year and a half to decide,'said Smith.

'You can't just refuse people unless they are fully and carefully assessed. The surgery is a bagatelle compared to that.'

His greatest concern is distinguishing between those with group four BDD, the who always complain about the same limb at the same level, and those with group three BDD, who fantasise about amputation and who may take offence to various limbs, increasing the chances of the condition resurfacing even after one limb has been removed.

'It is however possible to tell the difference with close questioning,' said Smith, who believes a great deal more could be done to improve diagnosis. He is now working with a psychoanalyst, preparing an academic paper for publication in a medical journal on the decision-making process involved in agreeing to operate under such circumstances.

He would like to see more operations for those in the fourth category like Kevin Wright.

'There are not large numbers of people out there who might benefit,'he said. 'But there will be some, very troubled people, and at the moment the NHS is failing them.'

He hopes the 'yuk' factor associated with such surgery will one day fade. 'The reaction to operations like these is the same as it was 30 years ago to gender reassignment,' he said.

'That is accepted now, in rare cases, and in my opinion so should this be.'

BDD typically emerges pre-teen, and Smith is concerned that there may be children in Scotland as young as four and five living with the secret loathing that so blighted his patients' lives.

'They are so embarrassed and so ashamed, and they think they are the only person in the world who suffers from it when they are not,'he said. 'Surely they deserve help, not derision?'

Wright, too, believes that more ought to be done to bring BDD, in all its forms, into the open. 'Some people start to get better as soon as they know they aren't the only one,'he said. 'That in itself may be enough to help them.'

Others, though, are more extreme. For them, only amputation will suffice and if they cannot get help to do it properly, they may seek relief in other ways. 'I am aware of a number of people with the condition who have died as a result,'said Wright. 'Some simulate accidents, while others turn to back-street operators. It is truly tragic that they are ignored by the medical profession.'

Much of the commentary surrounding Wright's case has lingered over the more voyeuristic aspects of BDD. There are a few internet websites for people seeking amputees for sexual gratification, and some are distinctly challenging in their content.

Pictures of women and men with missing limbs, posing provocatively, have been described as pornographic and condemned.

Wright describes the extreme sites as 'appalling'. For eight years he was involved in the running of a support group, OverGround, which among its other work had a website that stated it provided 'support and information for those who are attracted to others with physical disabilities, and for the people to whom we are attracted'.

That has led the tabloid press to question his respectability and motives for wanting the amputation, but Wright vehemently defends the work of OverGround. 'It is an information site that has been way ahead of the medical publications on BDD,' he said. 'It is a meeting point, not a dating agency.'

The site, now closed, did not display pictures but it did carry 'lonely hearts' advertisements.

Wright can understand the need for people with BDD to find sympathetic support from others sharing the same experience.

'These people are not weird freaks, they are just very unfortunate,' he said. 'Some are looking for friends, others for partners. So what? Sexuality is part of personal identity after all - able-bodied or not.'

A new openness about BDD is what Kevin Wright is prepared to speak out for. He wants to see informed debate taking place, and he is bravely starting it.

However he sincerely hopes he will soon be left alone to get on with his long-desired normal, happy, family life.

'I have not regretted the operation one bit,'he said. 'I don't want to think of what I'd have been like without it.'

His greatest concern is distinguishing between those with group four BDD, the who always complain about the same limb at the same level, and those with group three BDD, who fantasise about amputation and who may take offence to various limbs, increasing the chances of the condition resurfacing even after one limb has been removed. 'It is however possible to tell the difference with close questioning,' said Smith, who believes a great deal more could be done to improve diagnosis. He is now working with a psychoanalyst, preparing an academic paper for publication in a medical journal on the decision-making process involved in agreeing to operate under such circumstances. He would like to see more operations for those in the fourth category like Kevin Wright. 'There are not large numbers of people out there who might benefit,'he said. 'But there will be some, very troubled people, and at the moment the NHS is failing them.' He hopes the 'yuk' factor associated with such surgery will one day fade. 'The reaction to operations like these is the same as it was 30 years ago to gender reassignment,' he said. 'That is accepted now, in rare cases, and in my opinion so should this be.' BDD typically emerges pre-teen, and Smith is concerned that there may be children in Scotland as young as four and five living with the secret loathing that so blighted his patients' lives. 'They are so embarrassed and so ashamed, and they think they are the only person in the world who suffers from it when they are not,'he said. 'Surely they deserve help, not derision?' Wright, too, believes that more ought to be done to bring BDD, in all its forms, into the open. 'Some people start to get better as soon as they know they aren't the only one,'he said. 'That in itself may be enough to help them.' Others, though, are more extreme. For them, only amputation will suffice and if they cannot get help to do it properly, they may seek relief in other ways. 'I am aware of a number of people with the condition who have died as a result,'said Wright. 'Some simulate accidents, while others turn to back-street operators. It is truly tragic that they are ignored by the medical profession.' Much of the commentary surrounding Wright's case has lingered over the more voyeuristic aspects of BDD. There are a few internet websites for people seeking amputees for sexual gratification, and some are distinctly challenging in their content. Pictures of women and men with missing limbs, posing provocatively, have been described as pornographic and condemned. Wright describes the extreme sites as 'appalling'. For eight years he was involved in the running of a support group, OverGround, which among its other work had a website that stated it provided 'support and information for those who are attracted to others with physical disabilities, and for the people to whom we are attracted'. That has led the tabloid press to question his respectability and motives for wanting the amputation, but Wright vehemently defends the work of OverGround. 'It is an information site that has been way ahead of the medical publications on BDD,' he said. 'It is a meeting point, not a dating agency.' The site, now closed, did not display pictures but it did carry 'lonely hearts' advertisements. Wright can understand the need for people with BDD to find sympathetic support from others sharing the same experience. 'These people are not weird freaks, they are just very unfortunate,' he said. 'Some are looking for friends, others for partners. So what? Sexuality is part of personal identity after all - able-bodied or not.' A new openness about BDD is what Kevin Wright is prepared to speak out for. He wants to see informed debate taking place, and he is bravely starting it. However he sincerely hopes he will soon be left alone to get on with his long-desired normal, happy, family life. 'I have not regretted the operation one bit,'he said. 'I don't want to think of what I'd have been like without it.'

webTitle: Everyone's talking about...  Golden Globe winner Janet McTeer

fields.headline: Everyone's talking about...  Golden Globe winner Janet McTeer
fields.trailText: There was an interloper among the showbiz royalty at the recent Golden Globes awards. It was no surprise to see Hollywood blue-bloods Tom Cruise and Denzel Washington collect gongs, but many of the 50 million television audience probably reached for their celebrity Who's Who, B-list section, when Janet McTeer went up on stage.
fields.body:
There was an interloper among the showbiz royalty at the recent Golden Globes awards. It was no surprise to see Hollywood blue-bloods Tom Cruise and Denzel Washington collect gongs, but many of the 50 million television audience probably reached for their celebrity Who's Who, B-list section, when Janet McTeer went up on stage.

The 38-year-old Brit had, against the odds, walked away with the Best Actress award for her role in the bittersweet comedy, Tumbleweeds. McTeer's Mary Jo is a gregarious single mother; a happy-go-lucky Southern gal who drags her adolescent daughter around the country fleeing from dead-end jobs and boyfriends. Mary Jo is sexy, and effortlessly seductive to both sexes, but her trials and tribulations wouldn't look out of place in a daytime soap. The script and McTeer's irresistible performance make the film a warm-hearted little gem.

Given her Rada background, it's McTeer's impeccable Southern accent that has attracted most attention in the States. After last year's Sundance Film Festival, one fan was particularly taken with her performance. 'You're the sweetest Southern girl I ever seen,' he shouted. 'Ain't you my cousin?'

'I rather think not,' McTeer replied tartly, 'unless you mean the south of England.' In fact she was born and raised in York.

She spent three months in North Carolina listening to the local vernacular to prepare for the part. Her preparations left her out of pocket since she was paid a relative pittance for her performance. But it was worth it. The success of Tumbleweeds has made her a hot property. She now shares the same agent as Calista Flockhart.

It's not the first time McTeer has been the one to watch. The ink on her Equity card had barely dried when she was chosen to play Beatrice in Much Ado About Nothing. The classical roles piled up. By 27, she was exhausted. 'I used to look in the mirror and think, I look terrible.' Her unrelenting schedule eventually took its toll. She was struck down by a mysterious infection, which plagued her with migraines and poor sight for six months. It also made her reassess her career.

In 1996 she came to popular attention as a prison governor in Lynda La Plante's typically hard-boiled TV series, The Governor . At 6ft 1in she cut an imposing figure as she patrolled the institution.

The move to Hollywood wasn't a natural career progression. Her Tony-winning performance in the Broadway revival of Ibsen's A Doll's House , the role she had first played in the West End, alerted Americans to a new talent.

'I'd never even been to America,' she told Entertainment Weekly . 'As far as I was concerned, I was coming to do my little play and go home.' With a probable Oscar nomination on the cards, she can afford to discard her return ticket.

fields.headline: Close-up and personal
fields.standfirst: From Bert Hardy to Robert Mapplethorpe, a new photographic exhibition addresses the age-old question: what is love?
fields.trailText: From Bert Hardy to Robert Mapplethorpe, a new photographic exhibition addresses the age-old question: what is love?
fields.body:
In a poem from the late Thirties, W. H. Auden kept rhetorically asking if someone would tell him 'the truth about love':

'Can it pull extraordinary faces?
Is it usually sick on a swing?
Does it spend all its time at the races,
Or fiddling with pieces of string?'

Auden's whimsical and visual inventory of possibilities is so in keeping with the spirit of All For Love at the Hulton Getty Picture Gallery that it might well have been plundered for captions.

Drawing on the huge reservoir of images from the Hulton Getty archive, the exhibition surveys the ways in which photographers have tried to show some truths about love. The scope is sufficiently wide-ranging to make you wonder what a picture would have to depict in order to render itself ineligible. There's frustrated love of a football team, patriotic love of a country, sentimental affection for a pup. Dreary John and Yoko are here to let us know that 'War Is Over', and so are the loved-up hippies at Olympia who, with a bit of colour added, make a comeback on the recent Chemical Brothers album.

The show's symbolic epicentre is provided by a shot of two flamingos, their necks forming the outline of a heart. It's quite clever in a Valentine sort of way, but the pleasure it affords the eye is exhausted by a single look.

This is something it shares with those much-loved images by Bert Hardy (who concocted his own version of the heart trick, using the interlocked arms of two Latuko wrestlers) first published in Picture Post. Like Life, Picture Post no longer refers simply to a magazine; it has also come to connote a style, an aesthetic, a way of looking at the world so instantly recognisable that it seems, now, to come in quotation marks. Pictures in this style work, so to speak, like visual captions.

Other pictures in the show are similarly content-driven; they are of love. More elusive and fascinating is the way in which photographers have conveyed love. Auden was adamant about this: by keeping its distance. In 'I am Not a Camera', the close-up is rebuked for its rudeness, for the way it flies in the face of modesty:

'Lovers, approaching to kiss,
instinctively shut their eyes before their faces
can be reduced to
anatomical data.'

To our Mapplethorpe-hardened eyes, explicit anatomical data no longer seems such an affront. On the contrary, it's not just war photographers who have taken Robert Capa's dictum - if your pictures aren't good enough that's because you're not close enough - to heart. In the case of Nan Goldin, love is synonymous with refusing to look away.

In the Eighties, Goldin photographed her friends jacking up and jerking (each other) off. Then, in the Nineties, in the aftermath of this extended honeymoon of druggy promiscuity, she photographed them shrivelled by addiction and Aids. These pictures have the intimacy of the snapshot, 'one of the highest forms of photography,' according to Goldin, 'the form of photography that is most defined by love.'

Needless to say, this love is never manifest as the kind of radiant glow that suffused screen beauties in Hollywood movies of the Forties. Faithful to the kind of objectivity Rilke learnt from his study of Cézanne, the best photographers do not visually declare their love for a person, thing or place - they simply say, 'Here it is'. The onus is on us to look carefully enough to recover their feelings.

Look hard enough and another sense is, invariably, brought into play. Look at Roy DeCarava's pictures of John Coltrane and his love of the music becomes audible. Look at his pictures of her hands and you are touched by Alfred Stieglitz's feelings for Georgia O'Keeffe.

This weird synaesthesia of the photograph brings us close to the essence of romantic love itself; never tiring of watching what the beloved says. Given this elision of the visual and the verbal, it's not surprising that Eudora Welty, that rare thing - a first-rate writer and photographer, has best expressed the shifting relation between gesture and feeling: 'The human face and the human body are eloquent in themselves... and a snapshot is a moment's glimpse... into what never stops moving, never ceases to express for itself something of our common feeling. Every feeling waits upon its gesture.'

Technical questions aside, the biography of a photographer lies in training the eye and heart to recognise such gestures, such moments, to bring them into accord, to synchronise them visually. When this traffic between eye and heart becomes instinctive (assuming, of course, that it is matched by technical facility), the photographer achieves a kind of - in this context how else can one term it? - enlightenment.

The best account we have of this is by the American photographer William Gedney. In a journal kept during an extended stay in India in the Seventies he describes an extraordinary encounter in which the photographer's inquiring eye is itself subjected to prolonged, near psychic scrutiny: 'Mystic palmist, Tantric eye reader and coconut seller of Benares's Sonarpura district. Takes a five-minute look into my eyes and tells me that I am controlled by prem - love, indiscriminate, all-encompassing love.'

If instead of 'all-encompassing' he had said 'all-seeing', that would have been even better.

 All For Love is at the Hulton Getty Picture Library, 3 Jubilee Place, London SW3 3TD until 25 March. Tel: 0171 376 4525

webTitle: How can I learn to like my son?

fields.headline: How can I learn to like my son?
fields.trailText: I have two children. My eldest child is four and she is an angel. My second child, a boy, has just turned two and is a complete nightmare. I find this hard to admit, but I don't like him. I find it hard to show him affection. Developmentally he is fine, but compared to my daughter he is rough, noisy and has tantrums. How can I change the way I feel?
fields.body:
I have two children. My eldest child is four and she is an angel. My second child, a boy, has just turned two and is a complete nightmare. I find this hard to admit, but I don't like him. I find it hard to show him affection. Developmentally he is fine, but compared to my daughter he is rough, noisy and has tantrums. How can I change the way I feel?

Anon of Hull

You have courageously articulated things which are almost unmentionable in society, and it's good that you have found an anonymous vehicle by which you can do so. I'm sure you are not alone with these thoughts which mothers all over the world and through time have probably agonised over, in the privacy of their own minds.

Closely related people can differ strikingly and in ways that cause tensions, and personality is not readily changed. All the same, loving is different from liking and especially in a mother's feeling for her child. In the days of large families it was accepted that one child would be a favourite. In two-children families, it is harder to admit that one might be preferred above the other.

But mother-love is something apart, a primordial emotion, so deep-seated that you don't always realise its power until it is tested. If either of your children were threatened, you would act without conscious thought to protect them at all costs.

Your son is barely two, and though you can't change his essential nature, there are two things he must have from you in order to develop his best potential. The first is happiness, the second is discipline, and the two are interdependent. He must not be made to feel rejected because he is badly behaved. Tantrums are an expression of extreme frustration in someone who has not yet worked out how to deal with his own powerful emotions.

Certain aspects of his character are as yet unknown, but many people of influence, ability and drive have a history of difficult infantile behaviour, like your child. There may be mighty developments going on inside this helpless and inarticulate being, and his temper is undoubtedly quite as painful to him as to you.

He needs your help to govern himself. He must not learn at such a tender age that noisy rage can be used to manipulate his own way. He must perceive that there are others out there whose wishes and needs must also be taken into account. While he should learn this from your firmness in opposing his tiny will, he should feel equally the strength of your affection when the storm has passed.

Sometimes, for a peace-loving adult, it is too easy to take the line of least resistance in a battle of wills. But if you don't manage these tantrums now, you never will later. It is demanding and exhausting, but once he understands that you invariably mean what you say, and that the limits you set are rock-firm, you will eventually see him learning and mastering self-control.

Discipline does not imply anger, harsh words, threats and punishments, but does necessitate a will stronger than his. Two is the most difficult age, when there seems least co-ordination between social, mental and motor development. He would benefit hugely from group play, so enrolment in a nursery group at the earliest opportunity is a good plan.

Be assured that mothers of difficult children who succeed in steering them through these turbulent early years do often develop a particularly strong bond with their sons.

Reader's responses

While I sympathise with the shock you feel in having a second child so different from your first, you have a responsibility to this young innocent who does not deserve to be judged so negatively. If you don't show your son the love he needs at this stage in his life, you will have a much bigger problem later on. Talk to other mums for reassurance that your son's behaviour is quite normal. Read Stephen Biddulf's Raising Boys for an insight into the young male psyche.

Sara Hallam of London

Your reader's letter struck a chord - it could have been me a few months back. It is only now that I can begin to put it behind me and build a decent relationship with my son. The following tips helped me: finding time to be on my own with him; walking away from unpleasant situations rather than getting into confrontations, and remembering that he did need my love, no matter how trying he was being. I now have a loving, articulate little boy when I at one point considered a child psychologist.

L.A. of Brighton

Next week's dilemma C.B. of Sutton

My 15-year-old daughter has a friend who I am 99 per cent sure is anorexic. Her hair is starting to thin and I have seen a marked weight loss in the last few months. We talk about weight jokingly but she never says she has a problem. How do I broach the subject, what can I do to help her?

webTitle: It's been a good year for the rosaries...

fields.headline: It's been a good year for the rosaries...
fields.standfirst: The movies are full of priests and hellfire these days, says  Philip French. Why is Hollywood obsessed with Catholicism?
fields.trailText: The movies are full of priests and hellfire these days, says  Philip French. Why is Hollywood obsessed with Catholicism?
fields.body:
Have you thought of escaping from TV repeats of the oppressively Catholic world of Father Ted and Ballykissangel or of finding refuge in the company of sensible vicars and rational rabbis in movies at your local multiplex? Forget it. Bell, book and candle, incense and confession will confront you at every turn.

With continental movies, of course, you expect to be faced with Roman rituals - the First World War funerals that punctuate Ra Ruiz's Time Regained; the Catholicism that informs the lives of everyone on Almodóvar's All About My Mother; the ethical-theological concerns that underlie the intrigues of films by Eric Rohmer, who recently completed his seasonal quartet with An Autumn Tale and back in the late Fifties co-wrote (with Claude Chabrol) a seminal book acclaiming Alfred Hitchcock as a great Catholic artist. But the cinema of the English-speaking world is currently obsessed with Catholicism.

The movie business and virtually all the major Hollywood studios were created by Jews. But every Jewish mogul had an Irish-American Catholic as his right-hand man (for example Brian Foy at Warner, Winfield Sheehan at Fox, Eddie Mannix at MGM) and the content of the cinema was determinedly Episcopalian in its upper reaches, Presbyterian in the middle registers and Roman Catholic when engaging with the immigrant working class. The Hollywood Production Code was created by a Catholic journalist, Martin Quigley, and a Jesuit priest, the Reverend Daniel Lord, then enforced by a prominent Irish-American layman, Joseph Breen.

Although the Italian-American Catholic Jack Valenti took over as president of the Motion Picture Association of America in 1967 and immediately abolished the restrictive code, he never attempted to influence social trends.

There are still, outside of Woody Allen's movies, surprisingly few Jewish characters in the cinema, and it is not without interest that the eponymous central characters in both of of Spielberg's Second World War pictures, Schindler's List and Saving Private Ryan, are Catholics. Perhaps Catholicism is more colourful and intense than Protestantism or Judaism, as well as a better focus for guilt.

This could explain why the cinema is currently giving the impression that the working classes of the British Isles are almost entirely composed of Catholics. You might expect it of Ireland, of course, the narrowly restrictive home from which the central characters of Angela's Ashes and Felicia's Journey flee. But the Glasgow family grieving for their mother in Peter Mullen's Orphans and the Yorkshire villagers welcoming a local miracle in The Darkest Light are fervent Catholics, while East is East begins with the children of a Muslim immigrant secretly taking part in a Catholic procession at their Lancastrian mother's behest.

No doubt, another factor - millennial angst - accounts for the Catholicism of three large-scale apocalyptic extravaganzas currently on release. In Dogma, two renegade angels threaten the existence of God himself by seeking to take advantage of a loophole offered by a liberal Catholic priest in New Jersey. webTitle: Swords? They were more like wet umbrellas...

fields.headline: Swords? They were more like wet umbrellas...
fields.trailText: Otello, Royal Opera House | Birmingham Contemporary Music Group
fields.body:
Otello Royal Opera House

Birmingham Contemporary Music Group CBSO Centre, Birmingham

Historically dismissed as a dud in spite of its initial success, Rossini's Otello has two unassailable strengths: it gets better and it ends briskly. By the time you leave the theatre, three-and-a-half hours after entering, you feel quite bright about the whole affair. The protracted, irrelevant overture - as well suited to The Thieving Magpie as to a Shakespearean tragedy - has become a dim memory, the first act a mere haze of dramatic inactivity with some pretty music.

In addition, with a good performance you hear three tenors scaling the kind of high-wire vocal repertory which puts singing on a par with other pinnacles of physical achievement. Early nineteenth-century opera, more than any other, demands that singers have the flexibility of a gymnast, the stamina of an athlete, the intricate delicacy of a vocal lace-maker.

Only the musically acute can transform such sport and craft to high art. The Royal Opera's new production, which originated at the Rossini Opera Festival, Pesaro, scored highly in that respect. With a cast led by the incomparable Rossinian Bruce Ford, with Juan Diego Flórez as Roderigo and Octavio Arevalo as Iago, this was a singer's show, a wise approach for such an uneven work. The orchestra, conducted by Gianluigi Gelmetti, improved vastly after a rough start, with nimble woodwind playing and a steady growth of energy and flair.

In this 1816 opera written for Naples, the young Rossini and his librettist Francesco Berio di Salsa showed only a passing allegiance to the Elizabethan original. An alternative happy ending was even provided for the 1820 Rome season to quell papal outrage at a work with a murder and a suicide at its climax.

Desdemona, a vocally polished, bell-like and adroit Mariella Devia, barely appears on stage with Otello. They have no love duet in which to establish their feelings. While her emotions are evident, his remain obscure, bypassing amorous devotion and going straight to jealousy. Without prior knowledge of the story, you might assume Roderigo, a major part with a magnificent show-off aria (beautifully sung), was the ideal chap for her. Iago, far from being Shakespeare's (or Verdi's) embodiment of evil, is more of a stock-in-trade operatic villain. Despite a powerful duet with Otello, his motives are never entirely clear. The chorus contributes nothing to what drama survives - in marked contrast to their role as protagonists in Verdi's Otello .

Pier Luigi Pizzi, who directed and designed, did little to help us over these hurdles. The production is conventional to the point of obduracy. Characters, dressed in replica Renaissance costumes, walk on and off stage without evident purpose. Otello's supposedly triumphant arrival was hardly noticeable. Fortunately the ensembles need no inventive staging since the music provides everything. All the performers looked good; Bruce Ford has a natural dignity and credibility on stage and Roderigo and Iago managed to appear in turn susceptible and nasty. But had anyone directed their movement? There was an occasional banging together of swords, after which their weapons dangled half-heartedly at their sides like wet umbrellas.

Pizzi, an experienced Milanese director whose career dates back to 1951, trained originally as an architect. His eye for structure was evident in the play of columns, doorways and loggias of the realistic set, obedi ent to paintings by Carpaccio and the coloured marbles of Venice (where Rossini places the action throughout). Unfortunately, the staging gravitated against using the elegant doors or steps for their usual function since no one came or went by them. This gave the production an unintentional air of surrealism - a sensation intensified by three mobile phones going off in the stalls, as if members of the audience were ringing one another to compare notes on Ford's black wig or fixing where to dine after he'd killed Desdemona.

In Birmingham they're better trained. No extraneous noises marred Birmingham Contemporary Music Group 's concert conducted by Nicholas Kraemer in which the listeners' attention became part of the performance. Now 13 years old and spreading its tentacles far beyond its home city, BCMG remains one of the best ensembles of its kind. In its lively programming and commissioning policy, it shares the innovative flair of its parent orchestra, the City of Birmingham Symphony Orchestra. Howard Skemp ton's gem-like Suite from Delicate , reviewed here last year, shone as brightly on second hearing in a programme of sympathetically contrasting works by Thomas Adès, Judith Weir and John Woolrich. The high point was a captivating new commission by Thea Musgrave, entitled Lamenting with Ariadne . This spirited Scottish-born composer, now in her seventies, moved to America in 1972 and has been effectively (and unjustly) cold-shouldered in Britain ever since. Her luscious miniature double concerto for viola and trumpet mirrored Ariadne's journey from desolation at the loss of Theseus to joyous abandon with the arrival of Dionysus.

Several individual supporters had paid £100 towards this new commission. You can quite see why. ROH patrons can pay as much or more merely to sit in their seat. Is it fair that the Royal Opera House, frantically trying to learn all the variables of a complicated new environment, should be condemned for a few technical hitches when some of its patrons haven't even learned how to use their off buttons?

fields.headline: We love our children too
fields.standfirst: Despite what the critics may suggest, working mothers are not child abusers
fields.trailText: In last week's  Observer, Angela Neustatter wrote about the hell she went through 22 years ago, when she would stagger home from a long, demanding job as a feature writer for the  Guardian to a toddler son who was clearly not thriving - and desperate for more attention than a part-time mother could ever give
fields.body:
In last week's Observer, Angela Neustatter wrote about the hell she went through 22 years ago, when she would stagger home from a long, demanding job as a feature writer for the Guardian to a toddler son who was clearly not thriving - and desperate for more attention than a part-time mother could ever give. After one very bad evening, she decided that something had to give. That something was the desk job and all the ambitions that went with it. As big a sacrifice as that was, she has never regretted it. It was, she now thinks, the best decision she ever made. While she wouldn't dream of pretending she went on to become a perfect parent, she insists that her boys 'are happier than they would have been if I'd gone on the way I started'.

It's a heartwarming story, especially if you know what the Guardian offices were like at the time. Many of her female colleagues will have dismissed her as a failed feminist and a shirker; most of her male colleagues would have taken her decision as proof that women cease to be serious from the moment they give birth. But instead of listening to them, she listened to her own conscience. She made the decision she believed to be the only right one, and she took the consequences without a word of complaint. I admire anyone who can do that. So why, when I read her article, or indeed any article by a woman who has faced the home/ work dilemma, and chosen her children over her career, do I feel so angry and so badly used?

Why do I take a story that has nothing to do with me so personally? Well, the story is never just about one woman. The woman in the story always feels obliged to defend her position from her ideological detractors. So in this account, we hear about the child psychologist Donald Winnicott, who believed that certain forms of maternal neglect could cause serious and lasting psychological damage.

We hear about a study that showed mothers became cooler and less sensitive to their children if they left them for long hours in daycare. And we hear that mothers must be the ones to oppose these practices, and to stand up for the children, as 'biological destiny puts us in the hot seat'.

In other words, I take these articles personally because they urge me to do so. They put me in the hot seat. They invite me and all mothers in the audience to examine our consciences, review our own resolutions of the work/life dilemma and ask ourselves if, from time to time, our decision to work hasn't caused our children irreparable harm. And that makes me mad.

It makes me mad partly because I have the following items on my rap sheet. 1) Although I have four children, I have always worked. 2) Although I wish I didn't have to work today, because I'm tired and have a headache and would give anything to walk away from this computer and take the children swimming instead, by and large I love my work, and cannot imagine life without it. 3) Although I am lucky to be able to do a lot of my work from home, I'm still mentally absent a lot of the time, as I often have to put in 70-hour weeks. 4) Once I did not see my two older children for four-and-a-half months, because I took a job at a university on the other side of the Atlantic. 5) I am away from my younger children (now aged six and eight) every week from Wednesday morning to Thursday evening, because I teach part-time at a university 90 miles away from my home.

Last week when my eight-year-old and six-year-old did a skit about their parents, they did their father frowning as he gathered up their coats and their packed folders and herded them to school, and they did me prancing about in high heels, kissing crying children on the foreheads, and then saying in a carefree singsong voice: 'Goodbye darlings! See you on Thursday!' Has my unrelenting commitment to work harmed my children? I'll never know, but (because hardly a week goes by without someone somewhere shedding doubt on working motherhood) I doubt I'll ever stop asking the question.

At the same time, I can't help feeling helpless rage against the way this question is framed. Because if I look around me, at the other mothers I know who work, I can't find a single one who would say she had put her work before her children. Even the ones who work hard to come across like corporate desk slaves are slaving behind the scenes to shift things around, so that they can get more time with their children.

Although many would admit there were times in their work lives when they were 'stupid enough to buy the package', most have made not just one, but a whole string of big sacrifices in the interests of their children. And so have I. To make a long story short, I'll just mention the biggest: once upon a time, I had a good, permanent, well-paid, full-time job. I gave it up because keeping it would have meant losing my children. Not for nine or 10 hours a day. But forever. Have I ever regretted that decision? Never. Not even for a second. I am absolutely certain that my children are happier because I made that decision. And so am I. But I paid dearly for that decision, and so did they, because I earned under £5,000 a year for the next five years. The children may have had more of my love and attention, but they had to go without many basics.

When I had my first child, 21 years ago, the lady-or-the-tiger version of the work/ home dilemma had some basis in reality. A woman with a newborn child did have to make an either/ or choice, and the choice she made was all but impossible to reverse. But today's world makes a nonsense of that metaphor. Unless she is very rich, a mother who leaves her job for her chil dren is making her family financially vulnerable. Even if she has a gainfully employed husband, she cannot count on him - or his job - being there forever. And if he leaves, gets made redundant or dies? She's a fool if she assumes that the DSS will always be there to pick up the pieces. The days of income support for single mothers are numbered. The new world order requires that all able-bodied women have at least one foot in the paid economy.

If I look around me at the home-based, child-centred mothers who outnumber full-time working mothers 10 to one in the village where I live, I have a hard time finding a single one who hasn't got the message. The only ones who aren't frightened for the future are the tiny handful who are rich. For the others, the sole topic of conversation is: where are they going to find the money that will allow them to continue to put their children first? Many have decided that the only way forward is go back into part-time work or to retrain. Almost all of them have discovered that in making this move, they have plunged their families even deeper into poverty, either because benefits get withdrawn overnight, weeks and months before their first puny pay cheques, or because the famous new safety net of credits and subsidies for working parents has humongous holes in it. For example, a mother who goes back into education cannot get help with her childcare costs unless she also spends more than 16 hours a week in paid work . When is she supposed to find the time see her children? If she has to pay the full whack for childcare, how is she going to find the money for food, transport, and rent?

The women I know who are struggling with those dilemmas are all those who, six, seven, eight, nine years ago, chose to put their families before their careers. And how do they feel now, when they pick up the paper to read about the importance of maternal sacrifice? They are fit to be tied. They say: 'Yes, right, I did that, and I'm proud of what I've achieved. But look at how I'm being rewarded for it. Look at how little I'm valued. Look, when I fill out these employment forms, everything I've done for my children becomes a "gap in employment". Why?'

It's not just the mothers who talk like this. It's the fathers, too. The work/ life dilemma may have started as a woman's issue, but now it's come of age and belongs to everybody. It is excruciatingly difficult for most families in this country to give their children the care they need and deserve while also providing them with the support and security they need just as much.

To present caring work and paid employment as opposites - and that is what the popular debate on working motherhood does - is to forget that all families need both .

It also suggests that when a family is not getting both, the blame must go to a working mother. If not to her personally, then to some sort of feminist cabal that led her astray with false promises. But working mothers are not the architects of the new world order. We did not meet secretly 20 years ago and dream up the care-blind employer in the flexible workforce in the free market in the global economy. We are coping and reacting like everyone else.

The one positive thing we could do is use whatever clout we have in the working world to stand up for the importance of caring work, and the importance of supporting all those who do it. But it is very hard to make this case when the popular debate continues to cast us as child abusers.

fields.headline: Whitehall raps Labour 'chaos'
fields.trailText: The Government's approach to the poor is chaotic and fragmented, says a damning Cabinet Office report due to be published this month. The finding will add fuel to the flames ignited by the resignation last week of Defence Minister Peter Kilfoyle who claimed that Labour had deserted its heartlands.
fields.body:
The Government's approach to the poor is chaotic and fragmented, says a damning Cabinet Office report due to be published this month. The finding will add fuel to the flames ignited by the resignation last week of Defence Minister Peter Kilfoyle who claimed that Labour had deserted its heartlands.

The report, Reaching Out , will say that some of the party's strongholds are being swamped by fragmented anti-poverty programmes by different government departments, which threaten to harm the efforts of local authorities and anti-poverty campaigners.

The authors suggest that the heartlands' problem may not be a simple lack of resources or a policy vacuum, but an incoherence in approach from Whitehall.

Kilfoyle, under attack from the party hierarchy, denied yesterday that he had said there was a policy vacuum at the heart of government. He had, in fact, claimed there was a lack of ideological glue. But he echoed criticisms in the report by claiming the heartlands were suffering from 'zone-itis', a reference to myriad Education Action Zones, Employment Action Zones and Health Action Zones.

The cities in the North were weighed down by bureaucracy, Kilfoyle said. 'It's not joined up. I was supposed to be a Minister, but I just could not keep up with the initiatives. Too many civil servants were working in splendid isolation, with far too little contact with real people on the ground.'

The chief executive of the Local Government Association, Norman Briscoe, warned the Government that there was 'a plethora of iniatives which overlap, do not necessarily have the same geographical boundaries, treat the same people and require different partnership arrangements on the ground'.

Briscoe said local authorities were required to submit as many as 40 different plans to receive government cash. He met Whitehall permanent secretaries at the Civil Service College last Friday to discuss the logjam.

The Cabinet Office report, overseen by Health Minister John Denham, is likely to say that too many targets conflict with one another, have been drawn up with inadequate community involvement and impose excessive reporting burdens on local partnerships. In one case it had cost a partnership £10,000 simply to work out the range of government iniatives.

Blair will confront critics such as Kilfoyle when he addresses the Labour local government conference in Blackpool today.

The Prime Minister will say that the politics of unity must defeat the politics of division, adding that he rejects claims that the problems of the North are caused by people in the South.

Kilfoyle is thinking of developing his views on urban regeneration through a new parliamentary group, likely to be called Hard Labour. He is also calling for the Treasury to hold back on the income tax cut planned for the Budget.

Some of his allies are pressing him to stand for the chairmanship of the Parliamentary Labour Party, but he is unlikely to do so for fear of being seen as disloyal.

John Prescott, whose Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions is leading the anti-poverty programme in run down neighbourhoods, hit back at Kilfoyle.

'We have now put £5 billion into housing and that is what the party wanted us to do.

'We now talk of full employment, not mass unemployment. We are reducing the waiting lists,' said the Deputy Prime Minister. 'We are doing everything we promised, something like 80 per cent plus of our manifesto has already been implemented.'

webTitle: Michael is told: 'Win vote or go'

fields.headline: Michael is told: 'Win vote or go'
fields.trailText: The crisis facing the Labour leadership in Wales deepened yesterday when senior Labour MP Paul Flynn called on First Secretary Alun Michael to quit Welsh politics if he loses this week's crucial vote of no confidence.
fields.byline: by Andy McSmith Chief Political Correspondent
fields.body:
The crisis facing the Labour leadership in Wales deepened yesterday when senior Labour MP Paul Flynn called on First Secretary Alun Michael to quit Welsh politics if he loses this week's crucial vote of no confidence.

Flynn advised the embattled Welsh Labour leader to go back to 'a comfortable job in London', because the spectacle of him clinging to office would aggravate the problem of 'devo-droop' - public disillusion with devolution.

This outburst underlines the increasing strain behind the facade of unity which the Welsh Labour Party has maintained throughout the growing political crisis in Wales. Some members of Michael's Cabinet agree privately with Flynn's view that the First Secretary should hand over to Rhodri Morgan, the man he narrowly beat in last year's Labour leadership election, although all are supporting him in public.

Flynn said: 'My ideal solution would be for Alun Michael to stand down. There is still time for him to take up a comfortable job as a minister in Westminster. The nightmare solution is that he loses a vote of no confidence, he clings on, and "devo-droop" continues.'

Michael has been trapped in the middle of a row between London and Cardiff over millions of pounds in EU grants which could be used to revive the depressed economies of West Wales and the valleys. The grants have effectively been blocked by Chancellor Gordon Brown. Under EU rules the money can be released only if the British Government promises to match it pound for pound.

Michael's failure to squeeze the money out of the treasury has created an unlikely alliance between the Liberal Democrats, Tories and Plaid Cymru, who have enough votes to defeat Labour in the vote of no confidence which the nationalists propose to table on Wednesday.

Michael's own officials admit they cannot save him being ejected, but say he will immediately stand for re-election, possibly the next day, and as long as the Labour Party backs him, he will win then. Labour has 28 out of 60 Assembly seats, and the other parties cannot agree on an alternative leader.

But reinstating Michael could trigger a farcical game of ping-pong, in which he is repeatedly sacked by the Assembly and re-elected.

Michael hopes to strike a power-sharing deal with the Liberal Democrats to save himself from repeated votes of no confidence. But the Lib Dems say they won't save him unless he gets more Government money for Wales.

They point to last week's by-election in Ceredignon, a Welsh Nationalist stronghold where Labour slipped from second to fourth place, as a sign that Welsh voters are increasingly fed up with the Welsh Labour leadership.

Michael Hines, adviser to the Welsh Liberal Democrat leader Mike German, said: 'I can't see anyone being prepared to watch a vote of no confidence and not push it to the end. The credibility of the Assembly is on the line, and if we fail to remove a First Secretary who has been voted out it would be ridiculous.'

The crisis has reopened divisions. Michael is seen as Tony Blair's candidate, imposed on the party through a complicated voting system in which the person with the most votes came second.

webTitle: Panic over impact of rights law

fields.headline: Panic over impact of rights law
fields.standfirst: Ruling on speed cameras fuels fears of new 'gravy train' for solicitors after adoption of European Convention
fields.trailText: Unease is spreading through the Scottish Executive after a legal ruling which may rule out the use of speed cameras. Senior sources fear the European Convention on Human Rights, now part of domestic law, has been identified as a new 'gravy train' for solicitors throughout Scotland.
fields.body:
Unease is spreading through the Scottish Executive after a legal ruling which may rule out the use of speed cameras. Senior sources fear the European Convention on Human Rights, now part of domestic law, has been identified as a new 'gravy train' for solicitors throughout Scotland.

The convention is now the first reference to be consulted by all lawyers and authorities fear this trend may have a disruptive influence on Scottish law.

The Scottish Executive has commissioned an exhaustive report in a bid to spot other legal loopholes. A 'long list' of possible challenges has been identified, according to legal sources. Every department of the civil service is now 'frantically' reviewing its policies.

The panic has been caused by two rulings, both of which flowed from the convention, which was incorporated into Scots law by the Scotland Act 1988 as part of the devolutionary process. It will become part of English law in October.

Last year, the use of temporary sheriffs was found to be illegal and last week Section 172 of the Road Traffic Act was overruled. Lord Rodger, the Lord Justice General, said the section compelled people to confess, in this instance whether they were the driver of a car or not. He said this breached Article Six of the convention that upholds an individual's right against self-incrimination.

The SNP's justice spokesperson, Roseanna Cunningham, says a Human Rights Commission is 'desperately' needed to advise on future rulings. She says the convention has 'profound implications' for many aspects of the law.

The Executive is understood to be considering the use of retired sheriffs to solve the problem caused by the first ruling. The use of temporary sheriffs was declared incompatible with the convention because the renewal of their appointments depended on the patronage of the Lord Advocate, himself a member of the Executive. The Executive has responded by appointing more full-time sheriffs, but in some districts, such as Perth, serious backlogs in the handling of cases have developed.

The next area of law that might be challenged concerns the detention of remand prisoners. Experts believe imprisoning people who have not been tried may be in breach of the convention. Scotland's low age of criminal responsibility could also be tested.

Friday's ruling may also have implications for the Prevention of Terrorism Act, which can compel a person to give self-incriminating evidence.

The immediate problem following the decision on Section 172 of the Road Traffic Act is that drunk drivers and hit-and-run drivers may also escape conviction. Legal sources said that Scotland may need to learn rapidly from the continent, where the convention is in force and car crimes are successfully prosecuted.

The ruling came about because 30-year-old Margaret Brown was charged with drink-driving after being forced to admit that she had driven to a shop while over the limit. Police use the same powers to force people to admit if they were driving a car which has been caught by speed cameras. Since they are no longer able to do this, the cameras' future is in doubt.

fields.headline: The cost of living
fields.standfirst: A healthy diet needn't be bad for your wallet
fields.trailText: A healthy diet needn't be bad for your wallet
fields.body:
I have received a letter expressing concern that while healthy eating is all well and good for the body, it can harm the wallet. Consuming a well-balanced diet, hitting the five-plus portions of fresh fruit or vegetables a day target, can only be beneficial when our budgets aren't stretched beyond their comfortable limits.

The first issue must be whether or not organic is worth paying more for. Organic produce is, on average, 30-50 per cent more expensive than non-organic produce - a Waitrose organic kiwi can cost 25p, while non-organic is only 17p; an organic wholemeal loaf costs 18p per 100g, compared to 10.9p per 100g for non-organic. Organic frozen sweetcorn checks in at £2.38 per kg, compared to £1.58 per kg for ordinary frozen. There are some advantages to eating organic produce - you're less likely to encounter large amounts of unwanted pesticides and waxes, and more likely to have food that's fresher. Since organic produce has a shorter shelf life, supermarkets replenish stocks more frequently, which potentially means eating produce that contains higher amounts of time-sensitive nutrients, such as vitamin C.

Still, there is an alternative. Since we know that fresh is best (the less time between picking and eating, the more vitamins and minerals the food is likely to contain), when you buy non-organic produce, wash thoroughly to remove pesticide and wax residues, and eat as soon as possible. Shopping according to the seasons is the best way with cheaper produce - it'll taste better and will probably contain more nutrients. Use soft fruits during the summer and view them as a treat, making up the bulk of your fruit intake with cheaper options, such as oranges, pears and apples. Their price belies their nutritional value - apples have recently been shown to help stave off lung infections.

Do also consider buying frozen foods. Contrary to common perception, frozen vegetables can contain more vitamins and minerals than fresh, as manufacturers must freeze produce within a very short period of time once picked. (There is, however, no legal guideline for the word 'fresh' - food thus described may have sat in cold storage for months; the nutrients diminishing by the minute.)

Growers of frozen foods will also only freeze ripe produce, which has a positive affect on the way the body absorbs the nutrients - unripe food can be harder to digest, meaning you derive very little nourishment. Frozen food can be cheaper, too, so penny for penny, you'll glean more nutrients. It's also convenient; getting your five portions of fresh fruit or vegetables every day is easier to attain when you can quickly and easily pop broad beans into a pasta sauce or stuff cannelloni shells with frozen spinach.

It may not be fashionable, but tinned produce can also be nutritious and cheap. Tinned tomatoes are very economical in price and slightly higher in nutrients such as lycopene - which can reduce the incidence of cancer of the prostate - than fresh. Most tinned foods work perfectly well in soups or pasta sauces and are nutritious cupboard stockers. If you have the time, though, choose dried pulses; they have a better taste and texture than some tinned versions - chickpeas, particularly - and are substantially cheaper. Pulses are also a cheap source of protein when accompanied by carbohydrate - serve lentil soup with a slice of wholegrain bread to ensure that the body receives the right balance of amino acids. They also make meals go further - lentils go very well with meats such as pork in casseroles, or make a small piece of naturally smoked haddock much more filling. You can also use them to make chicken into rissoles - which can work out cheaper than ready-made burgers.

Wholemeal, higher-fibre foods can be costly - wholemeal bread is still more expensive than white. High-fibre breakfast cereals also tend to cost more than low-fibre Cornflake-style cereals, but it's important to remember that fibre-filled foods (when accompanied with water) are much more satisfying; a slice of wholemeal bread can fill you up as much as two slices of white, so wholemeal foods are actually more economical. It really is worth investing in fibre. It's also worth taking your water from the tap. Over an adult lifetime we drink about 40,000 litres of water. The cost for bottled would be £22,500, while the tap water bill would be approximately £24.60 - including the cost of a water filter. Some of the biggest cost cons are the 'economy' ranges of processed foods such as sausages and burgers. They may seem cheaper, but when you compare the quantity and quality of the core ingredients, the chicken in the nuggets or the fish in the pie, you find that manufacturers frequently use inferior cuts and cheaper filling ingredients, such as potatoes or bread, to enable them to keep the price down. And cheaper lines in bacon and sausages often contain more water, so, by the time they're cooked, they've reduced greatly in size. All things considered, it's worth paying the extra and avoiding the economy lines if possible.

Talking of shrinking produce, there are advantages to eating dried fruits - they're practical and can contain substantial amounts of beneficial nutrients such as calcium, even if they do contain less vitamin C than the fresh. They're also cheaper, but do bear in mind that you should ideally choose the fruits that have not been exposed to sulphur dioxide (SO2), as this preservative can interfere with vitamin and mineral absorption.

Finally, prices really rocket when it comes to pre-prepared items. If you buy chopped carrots, washed salads or oven-ready meals, you'll pay over the odds for the time you save. Of course, for people living alone, shopping this way can be economical, because buying the small quantity of ingredients needed to make just one meal can be expensive. Ideally, those who live alone should invest in a small freezer, and make larger dishes to be used in portions. Also, do avoid designer produce; the vitamin-enhanced drinks, or cholesterol-reducing spreads, they're expensive and unnecessary. Some manufacturers will go all out to exploit our desire to become healthy, but by eating the cheaper real foods we can still reach our health goals and have spare change.

So, healthy eating on a budget is possible, but it requires careful shopping and the know-how to be able to cook, rather than paying out for food manufacturers or fast-food outlets to do the work. It's appalling that children can go through their schooling without being taught how to cook simple foods that they'll enjoy. Learning to prepare pasta sauces, home-made soups or stews would be far more likely to get them cooking at home than the rock cakes they inevitably end up making in domestic science. Investing money in good cookery classes, that have healthy, enjoyable eating as the core goal, would be one of the best, and most cost-efficient ways for the government to improve the health of the nation.

webTitle: Phil Hogan walks down the aisle

fields.headline: Phil Hogan walks down the aisle
fields.trailText:
I'm just dashing off to the garden centre following the news that we've been invited to someone's elegant Elizabethan manor house for lunch and that to turn up without Belgian chocolates and a nice plant would, apparently, be to blacken our family name in the undiluted pig mire 
of social ignominy where they live, when 
I suddenly realise that my wife has completely forgotten to force the children to come kicking and screaming along with me in the car and, obviously, while I'm not one to turn my nose up at the prospect of being able to listen to Sid and whatsername in The Archers having sex in the shower without resorting to our set of hand-tooled travel muzzles from the Innovations catalogue, the very novelty of travelling alone does slightly reduce the status of my journey from aggravated errand to something that might be counted by some people 
I'm married to as holiday.
fields.body:
I'm just dashing off to the garden centre following the news that we've been invited to someone's elegant Elizabethan manor house for lunch and that to turn up without Belgian chocolates and a nice plant would, apparently, be to blacken our family name in the undiluted pig mire of social ignominy where they live, when I suddenly realise that my wife has completely forgotten to force the children to come kicking and screaming along with me in the car and, obviously, while I'm not one to turn my nose up at the prospect of being able to listen to Sid and whatsername in The Archers having sex in the shower without resorting to our set of hand-tooled travel muzzles from the Innovations catalogue, the very novelty of travelling alone does slightly reduce the status of my journey from aggravated errand to something that might be counted by some people I'm married to as holiday.

But look at this! For reasons best known to doctors of horticultural marketing, the garden centre is hosting a Wedding Fayre today in recognition of the fact that, as one of Britain's fastest-growing sports, marriage is almost as popular as spraying greenfly, with many enthusiasts enjoying it so much that they often come back several times with an exciting different partner on each occasion. There are white Bentleys parked outside and little stalls selling tiaras and underwear and a striped marquee full of everything you could possibly need for a wedding reception, except mentally disturbed relatives, plus there's a catwalk fashion show with crimped and powdered models pretending to be brides swathed in net curtains, and grooms strutting about with David Beckham hair and sporting rococo waistcoats inspired by fully washable settee covers.

Music, anyone? It's all very sophisticated, with the choice of a cello player, classical guitarist and string quartet all simultaneously working through their repertoire of haunting TV theme tunes, and a uniformed toastmaster for hire, standing about with a wooden hammer waiting to alarm everyone with his shouting skills.

The garden centre people have obviously been desperately scratching their heads for some kind of thematic tie-in for the event and have at last come up with the excellent idea of a competition to name a goat, the winning happy couple being awarded with a £25 voucher redeemable against a bag of treebark chips for that new patio area, or perhaps a litre of weedkiller to put in each other's tea when the first scummy mats of armpit hair start turning up in the plughole.

I am intrigued by the company which thinks that having to endure your own wedding isn't quite horrendous enough without offering to send someone along to film it ('All our cameramen are fully trained!'), but I do find myself glued to the featured video clips of women unaccustomed to wearing hats in a strong breeze and spotty ushers brushing dandruff off their shoulders wearing the gormless expressions of people who have just been told that, actually, Nike don't do top hats and tails.

Ah, and doesn't it all take me back to our own memorable big day. Except, of course, videos hadn't been invented then, and we walked to the register office to save money and didn't really fuss ourselves with traditional top hats or photographers or flowers or invitations, though we did allow our chums and the least embarrassing members of our families to come for a drink and anchovy canapés at the King's Head, and afterwards went on an interesting honeymoon in Peru, where my beautiful young bride quickly distinguished herself as a stranger to altitude sickness by fainting in the airport, while I fulfilled the ambition of a lifetime by vomiting from a speeding train. How we laughed that evening as we tucked into a romantic supper of grilled guinea pig serenaded by an Andean nose-flute quartet.

All in all, I can't help thinking that there's nothing like a wedding for bringing out the bad taste in people and, as a result, the Fayre is a terrific hit with customers, which is just as well, because the topiary and bonsai sections are practically deserted, as is the area selling off Christmas and millennium lines, even though the last few hundred illuminated year-2000 branch sculptures seem very reasonably priced at £1.20 and could easily be adapted for someone's 200th birthday party by anyone owning a saw.

Eventually, I remember what I came for and panic my way through the crowds of brides getting their humorously tall hair caught in the pergolas and find a whole hangarful of plants which tend to look very much alike and it doesn't take me long to find something for £3.50, which is only just over budget. I dash for the exit.

'You may kiss the bride,' I hear someone saying. Which is very kind, but I'm afraid I have a marriage to save.
