fields.headline: Disarming Martin McGuiness [i]
fields.standfirst: Martin McGuiness's recent appointment to the Stormont Assembly in Northern Ireland completes a 30-year journey from Provo poster boy to IRA Chief of Staff and, finally, to Crown minister. But in a week in which the decommissioning issue once again threatens to make or break the peace process, the man who was once dubbed 'Britain's number one terrorist' is showing a touching faith in politics.
fields.trailText: Martin McGuiness's recent appointment to the Stormont Assembly in Northern Ireland completes a 30-year journey from Provo poster boy to IRA Chief of Staff and, finally, to Crown minister. But in a week in which the decommissioning issue once again threatens to make or break the peace process, the man who was once dubbed 'Britain's number one terrorist' is showing a touching faith in politics
fields.body:
Seventh Avenue and 32nd, Manhattan, January 2000 and the Northern Ireland Minister for Education, member of the Stormont Executive, member of the Northern Ireland Assembly, member of the Queen's Parliament and former Chief of Staff of the Provisional IRA is rooting about in a glass bowl on the breakfast bar of the Southgate Hotel for Bran Flakes.

McGuinness arrived in New York two days ago on a working visit. At home, the decommissioning issue is heading towards a panicky crisis. In the absence of an IRA 'gesture', the Stormont Excecutive - and his ministry - may be dissolved within days of his return. If McGuinness is concerned, it doesn't show.

Yesterday, in Washington, he shared a working lunch of stuffed pancakes and salad with the US Secretary for Education, Richard Riley in the executive suite of Riley's department overlooking Capitol Hill. Later, with their respective officials, the two education supremos discussed 'improving academic performance'.

After lunch, McGuinness and his permanent secretary drove with Riley in a three-limo flotilla to Paint Branch High School in Maryland. The minister inspected a photosynthesis project, flunked a multiple choice question on centrifugal force ('I was never that good at physics'), conducted a one-question interview with the media studies group and posed beside some glass tubes.Driving back to Washington, McGuinness's adviser, Aidan McAteer, leaned towards the driver. 'Would you ever,' he asked, 'drop Martin off at the White House?'

Back in New York, he and Sinn Fein president Gerry Adams will shortly travel uptown to meet the ailing Cardinal O'Connor at St Patrick's Cathedral on Fifth Avenue. If there's time he and Adams might squeeze in a quick fix of imperialist oppression with a visit to a Native American Museum. Meantime, he has discovered that the Bran Flakes are gone, so McGuinness settles for juice and eggs and bacon and talks about his eight-month-old grandchild, the infant son of his eldest daughter, Grainne McGuinness. 'He's a Riverdancer,' he says, putting aside his knife and fork and raising his two arms up and down in besotted, rhythmic imitation of this child. 'You just put the music on, any music and at all, and he's away bouncing. It's absolutely comical.'

Derry, April 1972, and another meal with another journalist, this time a bottle of fizzy orange and a bun, a 'bap' bolted down in the back of a car and described by the 21-year-old McGuinness as a 'republican's tea' - a sugar -and-carbohydrate hit taken only yards from your mother's door, which you can't enter because if the soldiers see you they'll arrest you because you are now the Officer Commanding (OC) of the Derry IRA.

Twenty-eight years ago there was no dissembling. McGuinness's membership of the IRA was openly, uneuphemistically disclosed. He had joined in 1969. 'It seemed to me,' he said at the time, 'that behind all the politics and marching, it was plain as daylight that there was an army in our town, in our country, and that they weren't there to give out flowers. Armies should be fought by armies. So, one night, I piled into a black Austin, me and five mates, and we went to see a Provo across the border. We told him our position and there were several meetings after that. Then we joined. Nothing really happened until Seamus Cusack [an unarmed nationalist] was killed and internment came soon after. Then the Provos in Derry were ordered into full-time military action. I gave up my job working in the butcher's shop.'

The Gertrude Blane Union Hall off Times Square on 8th Avenue and 44th street. The first visit of Adams and McGuinness to immigrant republicans since they entered the Stormont Assembly. The crowd is predominantly working class, some drinking beer at the back of the hall as the band plays jigs and reels and the 'Fields of Athenry', the safe sex of republican balladry. As McGuinness is introduced, there is, as ever, that extra little ripple in the standing ovation, the nod to that part of his republican CV that once defined him in his entirety.

'Bullshit,' yells a member of the audience as the minister rises to explain how membership of the Stormont parliament and the traditional Brits Out policy of the republican movement are 'absolutely' complementary. As the guy is simultaneously frisked and bounced out of the hall by six Friends of Sinn Fein, McGuinness says that while everyone has a right to raise those issues, they 'must raise them in a courteous manner'. Gerry Adams later describes the heckler as a 'drunk' (lest anyone think that the guy had a point) and lightens the evening by commenting on how truancy levels have fallen since Martin became minister. The crowd go 'aaaah' as he tells them about his new granddaughter's name. 'In English it means "sparkle",' says granddad.In a sideways reference to decommissioning, Adams muses: 'I have concerns about the short term; I have a fairly positive view of the long term.'

Last December, Martin McGuinness took off where he left off on 9 August 1971 when he walked out of Doherty's butchers, and regained full-time employment as Sinn Fein's Minister for Education, an appointment that marked the distance travelled in the peace process to date. Because Martin McGuinness wasn't (isn't?) just any Provo. For the last three decades, McGuinness has been the hardline, public face of the IRA, variously described as 'Britain's number one terrorist,' and (in Esquire) 'The most powerful man in Britain after Rupert Murdoch'.

There is scarcely an epithet for evil that McGuinness hasn't attracted. In a 1993 Central Television Cook Report, named and unnamed former IRA activists, claimed that McGuinness had personally murdered people, including British soldiers, and had ordered the murder of countless others as he moved through the IRA senior ranks from Derry OC to head of Northern Command to Chief of Staff.

'He's had a taste for blood,' said a former IRA bomber, 'he's killed people.' McGuinness has denied every such allegation, while also supporting the right of the IRA to carry out the type of action he has stood accused of.

In 1986, he told an interviewer, 'ITN [in 1974] reported that I had killed 12 soldiers in Derry; there was no substantiation for that, but whether you deny it or not it will always be attributed to you anyway... I would deny anything that would be of benefit to British Military Intelligence. The most important issue in all of this is what the people thought of me, and of the friends I associated with. The people clearly saw us in political opposition to British rule in Ireland. Some people will say that saying political opposition meant that you regarded killing British soldiers at that time as political, and we certainly did.'

McGuinness is still believed to be on the IRA Army Council. At the very least, he is the Sinn Fein leader that the IRA most cleaves to. From Provo poster boy to Stormont minister. Republicans cope with the paradox by speaking of 'transition'.

'Well, we might have to wait a bit longer for a united Ireland,' says McGuinness in his Stormont office, 'but from a Unionist perspective, there are many Unionists looking at this process, and looking at the British government's handling of this process and working out whether or not the British government signing up to the Good Friday Agreement is effectively a declaration of Britain's intent to, at the very least, bring about an entirely new relationship with the island of Ireland which is capable of, in their view, evolving towards a united Ireland.' It's a political aspiration that doesn't trip off the tongue quite as lightly as 'Brits Out'.

When I point out some days later that Gerry Adams, in New York, has actually named the day the republican 'la' will 'tiocfaidh' ('day will come') as the 100th anniversary of the Easter Rising - that is, in 2016, McGuinness actually blushes. 'That Gerry Adams is an awful man,' he says, 'I can just hear those phones starting to ring on that Easter Monday.'

Unionists cope by sneering. 'I though it was never the plan for the Provos,' says Ulster Unionist Party Assembly member and education committee chairman Danny Kennedy, 'to be part of a partitionist government in Stormont.'

McGuinness's US visit is preceded by a week of intense ministerial activity. The executive, as McGuinness says, may have 'the sword of Damocles hanging over it', but this man is attacking his brief with all the vigour of a politician with an eye on the promotional possibilities of a cabinet reshuffle.

A visit to a Protestant school is barred to reporters. Last December, children from a number of such schools staged protests over his appointment. 'The school doesn't want publicity,' explains the acting department press officer, Derek Black. 'It's very sensitive. It's a mixed school. We'll issue a press release later.' Later, the school is revealed to be the cream of Belfast's Protestant crop, Methodist College.

As McGuinness tells it, the Queen herself could scarcely have received a warmer welcome. 'We talked about the great success of the choir,' he announces solemnly. Instead, McGuinness's first public engagement of the New Year takes place in the Belfast offices of the Northern Ireland Council for Integrated Education. McGuinness is ratifying funding for two integrated schools, his first policy initiative. He enters, smiling and sober suited to a room full of flapping officials, trays of buttered brack and cream cakes, four television crews and 12 reporters.

In his lapel he wears a small green button badge, an emblem which most people assume is the latest republican memento mori, but isn't. 'This is for the Council for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children,' smiles McGuinness. And he smiles a lot. He jokes, he congratulates, he is word and statistic perfect, and the integrated schools people are utterly charmed. It is the charm that takes those who have previously viewed him as the devil incarnate by surprise. 'McGuinness would talk to a stray dog,' says his minder. 'Trimble used to hate talking to Adams,' says a Belfast journalist, 'because Adams would come in and he'd stroke his beard and say nothing, so Trimble would end up exasperated and saying things that he never meant. So he'd love it when McGuinness would come in, because he'd just yap away for hours.'

There is also a curious courtliness about McGuinness. On a visit to his department at Rathgael House in Bangor, I tell him that I hate lifts and move to take the stairs. It's seven flights up, but McGuinness insists on accompanying me. 'My wife hates lifts, too,' he pants, 'and aeroplanes.'

McGuinness's choice of integrated schooling as a launch pad for his ministry is not accidental. Catholics have eschewed the integrated option on the grounds that it dilutes the Catholic education option. But McGuinness is calming nerves. I may be an Old Provo, is the message, but today I'm as New Labour as Cherie Blair's bump. The buzz words are 'equality', 'choice', 'accessibility', 'excellence'. When he sees a child, he says soothingly, he doesn't see a republican child, or a loyalist child, or a Catholic child or a unionist child. He simply sees 'a child'.

Danny Kennedy, on the other hand, sees a largely unreconstructed Provo when he sees McGuinness. In his Stormont office, the UUP man who will effectively 'mark' McGuinness in his role as education committee chairman, says that the McGuinness charm has yet to work on him. 'I don't expect it to be a warm personal relationship,' he says. 'I haven't succumbed to his charm - nor he to mine for that matter. I've met him once formally, as minister and chairman, in my office. We both accepted that we weren't there because we liked each other. I despise what he stands for; I don't know him as a man.'

Kennedy is convinced that McGuinness's choice of the education portfolio was prompted by malice. 'He wanted to give Trimble a black eye over Trimble's decision to put a February deadline for decommissioning. There was a gasp of horror when he was nominated; there was genuine disbelief. It wasn't just because it was Sinn Fein, it was because of who he was. He played a very prominent role in the IRA in the past. He's still possibly on the Army Council of an organisation which is the most dedicated guerrilla organisation in western Europe.'

Why was education so sensitive? 'It was as though McGuinness and the others were saying,' says Kennedy, '"Ha, we've got your children now, so screw you".' After the press conference, we travel to the BBC studios in McGuinness's Sinn Fein-issue, green Mondeo. McGuinness has refused to accept the ministerial Mercedes. 'I want the department to produce something less flashy,' he explains. 'Well, it wouldn't do to be driving home to the Bogside in a Merc,' says a department official,' ignorant of McGuinness's almost puritanical asceticism, a feature he shares with Gerry Adams. Martin McGuinness doesn't smoke, he gave up drinking Guinness and Powers whiskey when he joined the IRA, as much for security reasons as for a zealot's sense that if the struggle had to be pure, then so had he.

The charm and the clean living are part of the paradox of the man, the contradiction that he rides. IRA informer Sean O'Callaghan, wrote in his 1998 memoir, Informer: the Real-life Story of One Man's fight Against Terrorism: 'Austere, a non-smoking tee-totaller and practising Catholic, he (McGuinness) is a fanatic almost beyond personal corruption, who has been, along with people like Adams, responsible for mass murder.'

'Sometimes you'd see him out buying chips for the children's tea,' says a Derry friend, 'you'd never see him in a pub unless he was there just for a meeting. He'd go out occasionally to a restaurant with his wife, or maybe to a GAA [Gaelic Athletic Association - Irish football, hurling] game.' His wife, Bernie McGuinness (nee Canning), works occasionally in a cafe in William Street in Derry; his mother, Peggy, is a high-profile supporter of the local GAA club. His children, Grainne, Fionnuala, Fiachra and Emmet, of whom McGuinness is famously protective, have shown to date no interest in political activity.

McGuinness's two daughters have both worked in local shops. The children have rarely, if ever, been photographed, apart from Grainne when a portrait taken by a friend won a photographic competition and attracted the attention of the News of the World. 'Sinn Fame!' screeched the 'exclusive'. En route to the BBC, after the integrated schools press conference, McGuinness's adviser, former republican activist Aidan McAteer, hands him a file. 'Here's a letter from Patrick,' says McGuinness,' he's inviting me to visit his school and he says that you'll get a great welcome and Rosie the dinner lady will give you a good feed.' In the studio, waiting to go live, McGuinness recalls his favourite Ali G interview. 'I loved the one when he was talking to [DUP] Sammy Wilson and he asked him if he was Irish and Wilson said that no he was British. So Ali G asked him what he was doing here, was he on holidays? I loved that...' The 11-plus issue is raised during the interview. It is Sinn Fein policy to abolish it, but the minister says today that he will await the outcome of the ongoing Queen's University study into the exam.

It is the charm that takes those who have previously viewed him as the devil incarnate by surprise. 'McGuinness would talk to a stray dog,' says his minder. 'Trimble used to hate talking to Adams,' says a Belfast journalist, 'because Adams would come in and he'd stroke his beard and say nothing, so Trimble would end up exasperated and saying things that he never meant. So he'd love it when McGuinness would come in, because he'd just yap away for hours.' There is also a curious courtliness about McGuinness. On a visit to his department at Rathgael House in Bangor, I tell him that I hate lifts and move to take the stairs. It's seven flights up, but McGuinness insists on accompanying me. 'My wife hates lifts, too,' he pants, 'and aeroplanes.' McGuinness's choice of integrated schooling as a launch pad for his ministry is not accidental. Catholics have eschewed the integrated option on the grounds that it dilutes the Catholic education option. But McGuinness is calming nerves. I may be an Old Provo, is the message, but today I'm as New Labour as Cherie Blair's bump. The buzz words are 'equality', 'choice', 'accessibility', 'excellence'. When he sees a child, he says soothingly, he doesn't see a republican child, or a loyalist child, or a Catholic child or a unionist child. He simply sees 'a child'. Danny Kennedy, on the other hand, sees a largely unreconstructed Provo when he sees McGuinness. In his Stormont office, the UUP man who will effectively 'mark' McGuinness in his role as education committee chairman, says that the McGuinness charm has yet to work on him. 'I don't expect it to be a warm personal relationship,' he says. 'I haven't succumbed to his charm - nor he to mine for that matter. I've met him once formally, as minister and chairman, in my office. We both accepted that we weren't there because we liked each other. I despise what he stands for; I don't know him as a man.' Kennedy is convinced that McGuinness's choice of the education portfolio was prompted by malice. 'He wanted to give Trimble a black eye over Trimble's decision to put a February deadline for decommissioning. There was a gasp of horror when he was nominated; there was genuine disbelief. It wasn't just because it was Sinn Fein, it was because of who he was. He played a very prominent role in the IRA in the past. He's still possibly on the Army Council of an organisation which is the most dedicated guerrilla organisation in western Europe.' Why was education so sensitive? 'It was as though McGuinness and the others were saying,' says Kennedy, '"Ha, we've got your children now, so screw you".' After the press conference, we travel to the BBC studios in McGuinness's Sinn Fein-issue, green Mondeo. McGuinness has refused to accept the ministerial Mercedes. 'I want the department to produce something less flashy,' he explains. 'Well, it wouldn't do to be driving home to the Bogside in a Merc,' says a department official,' ignorant of McGuinness's almost puritanical asceticism, a feature he shares with Gerry Adams. Martin McGuinness doesn't smoke, he gave up drinking Guinness and Powers whiskey when he joined the IRA, as much for security reasons as for a zealot's sense that if the struggle had to be pure, then so had he. The charm and the clean living are part of the paradox of the man, the contradiction that he rides. IRA informer Sean O'Callaghan, wrote in his 1998 memoir, Informer: the Real-life Story of One Man's fight Against Terrorism: 'Austere, a non-smoking tee-totaller and practising Catholic, he (McGuinness) is a fanatic almost beyond personal corruption, who has been, along with people like Adams, responsible for mass murder.' 'Sometimes you'd see him out buying chips for the children's tea,' says a Derry friend, 'you'd never see him in a pub unless he was there just for a meeting. He'd go out occasionally to a restaurant with his wife, or maybe to a GAA [Gaelic Athletic Association - Irish football, hurling] game.' His wife, Bernie McGuinness (nee Canning), works occasionally in a cafe in William Street in Derry; his mother, Peggy, is a high-profile supporter of the local GAA club. His children, Grainne, Fionnuala, Fiachra and Emmet, of whom McGuinness is famously protective, have shown to date no interest in political activity. McGuinness's two daughters have both worked in local shops. The children have rarely, if ever, been photographed, apart from Grainne when a portrait taken by a friend won a photographic competition and attracted the attention of the News of the World. 'Sinn Fame!' screeched the 'exclusive'. En route to the BBC, after the integrated schools press conference, McGuinness's adviser, former republican activist Aidan McAteer, hands him a file. 'Here's a letter from Patrick,' says McGuinness,' he's inviting me to visit his school and he says that you'll get a great welcome and Rosie the dinner lady will give you a good feed.' In the studio, waiting to go live, McGuinness recalls his favourite Ali G interview. 'I loved the one when he was talking to [DUP] Sammy Wilson and he asked him if he was Irish and Wilson said that no he was British. So Ali G asked him what he was doing here, was he on holidays? I loved that...' The 11-plus issue is raised during the interview. It is Sinn Fein policy to abolish it, but the minister says today that he will await the outcome of the ongoing Queen's University study into the exam. Click here to continue with this story

fields.headline: Holocaust needs its own day
fields.trailText: If Nick Cohen wants to be taken seriously, couldn't he have done more research before arrogantly rubbishing the idea of Holocaust Memorial Day at a time when the far-right in Austria is on the ascendant, a libel trial centring on Holocaust denial is under way and alleged war criminals are fleeing from justice?
fields.body:
If Nick Cohen wants to be taken seriously, couldn't he have done more research before arrogantly rubbishing the idea of Holocaust Memorial Day (Comment, last week) at a time when the far-right in Austria is on the ascendant, a libel trial centring on Holocaust denial is under way and alleged war criminals are fleeing from justice?

The aims of Holocaust Memorial Day are clear enough: to raise awareness and understanding of the Holocaust as a continuing issue for all humanity and to renew a continuing commitment to oppose racism, anti-semitism, victimisation and genocide. This is a day of education and action. No one wants to claim 'victimhood' and it is insulting to those who have suffered from the Holocaust or other genocides to be labelled in that way.

Mr Cohen is somewhat confused about the motivation behind my involvement: last year I visited Auschwitz-Birkenau with the Holocaust Educational Trust and 150 teachers from across the country. On my return I shared the feeling of so many of the participants - it is not enough to say 'never again'. We have to do something. If Holocaust Memorial Day does one thing, it will reach people who may not know about the Holocaust and encourage them to stand up to prejudice.
Andrew Dismore MP
London WC1

I was extremely disappointed to read Nick Cohen's article. I suggest he visits the Anne Frank exhibition that has been touring Britain for the last decade. I would introduce him to a Holocaust survivor and perhaps he would change his mind.
Basil H. Mann
Isleworth, Middx

The proposal for a national Holocaust Memorial Day is obscene. The only possible purpose for having such a day is as a warning against the evils of racism, intolerance and bigotry.

The hypocrisy of Tony Blair, fresh from introducing an Asylum Act that would have condemned even more Jewish refugees to death in the camps, beggars belief. The dead of Auschwitz have no need of New Labour's spin doctors.
Tony Greenstein
Brighton

webTitle: Section 28 - keep it or lose it?

fields.headline: Section 28 - keep it or lose it?
fields.trailText: There's no one more fundamentalist than a liberal fundamentalist. Andrew Marr does the cause of truth no service by putting words into the mouths of religious leaders in order to castigate them for their opposition to the repeal of Clause 28.
fields.body:
There's no one more fundamentalist than a liberal fundamentalist. Andrew Marr does the cause of truth no service by putting words into the mouths of religious leaders in order to castigate them for their opposition to the repeal of Clause 28. Many of us who are heterosexual are struggling to understand what life is like for gay people and are implacably opposed to their persecution. At the same time we do not accept that a homosexual partnership is equivalent to a heterosexual family lifestyle - and that, surely, is what Clause 28 is all about.

Mr Marr ignores all that, preferring to parody our view as an obsession with 'buggery'. If his misrepresentation of the debate within the Church is evidence of our failure to explain how we try to discern the will of God, the charge may be justified. But somehow I doubt it. John Barton
Archdeacon of Aston
Birmingham

It is good to see the positive stand The Observer is taking on the repeal of Section 28. It is one of the most pernicious pieces of legislation Mrs Thatcher ever put in place during her assault on British society.

One of the Labour Party's aims throughout its history has been to create a fairer society. One of the ways of achieving this has been by supporting minority groups who faced regular and systematic discrim ination. To date it has had some success; we now have laws against racial discrimination and against discrimination in the job market on the grounds of gender, religion, sexuality or disability. Why on earth has the government now started to compromise on the repeal of Section 28?

In opposition the Labour Party was clear on its intention to remove Section 28 from the statute book once it was in government. The Labour Government has a mandate; why, then, is it now cowing before the two big Bs - business, providing the money for the campaign against repeal; and bigotry, on the part of some religious and political leaders?
Peter Robert Haswell
Berlin

Contrary to what Marr says, in Scotland not all 'religious leaders are lining up against liberal, secular society'. The Moderator, and the Education Committee of the Church of Scotland, and the Bishops of the Scottish Episcopal Church have supported the repeal of this objectionable provision.
(Rev) Norman Shanks
The Iona Community
Glasgow

It is surprising that some religious leaders, including a number from groups that have themselves been subject to persecution and prejudice, support this law which, in effect, has helped promote bullying and added to the misery of gay and lesbian school pupils, sometimes to the point of suicide. Such support does a disservice to tolerance and understanding, which are the hallmarks of a civilised society.
Lionel Smith Bibby
Manchester

Along with your leader, Marr must be congratulated for his civilised and intelligent piece on the absurdity and bigotry which lies behind the supporters of Clause 28.

Cardinal Winning and his fellow churchmen believe, and observe daily at mass, that they literally, not symbolically, eat Christ's flesh and drink his blood. Many of us find this, if not perverted, certainly a distasteful relic of early cannibalistic beliefs. However, a gay man myself, I would not seek to introduce legislation to stop his freedom to 'promote' such a way of life if it is meaningful to him.
Roger Payne
London NW3

fields.headline: News 24 not free
fields.trailText: There is no 'Murdoch conspiracy' to close down BBC  News 24  as suggested by senior BBC correspondents (Letters, last week). Our argument is over the way it is funded. Letting the BBC use the licence fee to give  News 24  away free to cable operators is anti-competitive and has resulted in  Sky News  being dropped from some cable systems
fields.body:
There is no 'Murdoch conspiracy' to close down BBC News 24 as suggested by senior BBC correspondents (Letters, last week). Our argument is over the way it is funded. Letting the BBC use the licence fee to give News 24 away free to cable operators is anti-competitive and has resulted in Sky News being dropped from some cable systems.

The corporation could eliminate such distortions by transferring News 24 to its commercial arm, BBC Worldwide, where it would be able to charge for cable carriage and generate additional revenue from subscriptions or advertising.

As for the oft-repeated claim that 6.5 million people are watching the service, the BBC never explains that the vast bulk of these viewers are actually catching simultaneous night-time transmissions on BBC1 and weekend programming on BBC2 - numbers already accounted for in the terrestrial television ratings.

That senior BBC correspondents have chosen to join a corporate propaganda campaign sullies the corporation's reputation for impartiality and does little for its standards of accuracy.
Tony Ball
Chief Executive, British Sky Broadcasting

fields.headline: Tell it to Dada
fields.trailText: So the visual oxymoron of sticking fags on a life jacket (or turning beer cans into male genitalia) is 'compelling and utterly original - and has no antecedents'? Tell that to Meret Oppenheim's 1936 fur-lined cup - or to Dada and Surrealism.
fields.body:
So the visual oxymoron of sticking fags on a life jacket (or turning beer cans into male genitalia) is 'compelling and utterly original - and has no antecedents'? Tell that to Meret Oppenheim's 1936 fur-lined cup - or to Dada and Surrealism.

Shame, then, on interviewer Lynn Barber (Life, last week) for promoting the specious bandwagon of BritArt and Sarah Lucas's fey and facile one-liners. There are further principles of creativity without which progressive art - with sophisticated ideas and sustained narratives - is not possible. Without the special, hard-won knowledge of itself, perception is a closed and misleading hall of mirrors.
David Rodway
Lecturer in Art Philosophy
Kensington & Chelsea College,
London SW10

fields.headline: Mothers' pride
fields.trailText: I was appalled by Angela Neustatter's article (Comment, last week). For many working women there is no 'dilemma': they work, often in unsatisfying posts, to avoid poverty.
fields.body:
I was appalled by Angela Neustatter's article (Comment, last week). For many working women there is no 'dilemma': they work, often in unsatisfying posts, to avoid poverty.

The quality of my life is greatly enhanced by going out to work. My child does not cling to my ankles screaming 'Mummy, don't go' because my going out to work is part of our normal routine. The debate needs to be shifted towards a discussion of parental responsibility. It is no longer acceptable to talk of childcare as women's work.
Dr Susan Hogan
Derby

fields.headline: Lessons of abuse
fields.trailText: Last year the NSPCC published its Out of Sight report highlighting the fate of hundreds of children killed by their parents and carers in recent years. Sadly it will now include the four-year-old boy whose stepfather Gary Davis was jailed this week for his murder
fields.body:
Last year the NSPCC published its Out of Sight report highlighting the fate of hundreds of children killed by their parents and carers in recent years. Sadly it will now include the four-year-old boy whose stepfather Gary Davis was jailed this week for his murder. Yet less than 10 per cent of the formal inquiries into deaths of abused and neglected children are published. Nobody is sure how many reports there are or where to find them.

If vital lessons are to be learnt, there must be responsible and open reporting of the circumstances surrounding the deaths of children from abuse. This is not to apportion blame, but to give all of us the opportunity to learn and act on these grave lessons.

The Government must appoint a Commissioner for Children with wide-ranging powers to oversee child law and practice, to conduct inquiries and to instigate reforms, all of which would promote greater protection for vulnerable children.
Allan Levy QC

webTitle: Chaos as 35-hour week threatens French pay

fields.headline: Chaos as 35-hour week threatens French pay
fields.standfirst: Paris
fields.trailText: ECONOMISTS, businessmen and trade unionists have warned that the French government's daring attempt to slash dole queues by cutting working hours could trigger a wave of industrial action that would do as much damage to the country as the crippling strikes of 1995.
fields.body:
ECONOMISTS, businessmen and trade unionists have warned that the French government's daring attempt to slash dole queues by cutting working hours could trigger a wave of industrial action that would do as much damage to the country as the crippling strikes of 1995.

The adoption last month of the Socialist-led government's controversial law - unique in Europe - to reduce the working week from 39 to 35 hours was greeted by chaos on the roads as lorry drivers mounted roadblocks and public transport workers walked off the job in protest.

Further action is planned by post office employees, civil servants and hospital staff worried that less work will mean less pay, while opposition to the law grows among corporate bosses who say it is bad for business and difficult to implement.

From this month, companies with more than 20 staff are obliged to conclude pacts with trade unions on limiting working hours to an average 35 a week. Extra hours can be worked in busy periods and taken off in quiet times, but the annual limit is legally set at 1,600 hours.

Smaller businesses and the state-employed have until 2002 to switch to a regime that will eventually affect 14 million workers. The government hopes the reduction in hours will oblige companies to hire more staff, lowering France's obstinate 10 per cent unemployment rate.

A quarter of firms have implemented the reform, bribed by big tax sweeteners and extra state aid.

'It's a nightmare,' said Michel Dalbour, head of human resources at a General Motors subsidiary in Strasbourg. 'Negotiations are very, very difficult. We have one union that wants to reach an agreement, but is very demanding, and another that is against any deal at all.'

The chief executive of the Peugeot-Citroën group, Jean-Martin Folz, declared: 'I've always said this law will put French companies at a disadvantage. French workers will have to perform as well as those in other countries, but with four working hours fewer in each week. It is a heavy handicap.'

Workers are bemoaning the fact that, as their bosses try to limit the risk of an overall rise in labour costs of up to 10 per cent, most are imposing an 18-month wage freeze. Some say that they would prefer to be paid overtime than get more time off.

The truckers are a case in point. The barricades they mounted last week followed similar blockades in early January by their bosses, who were worried that putting drivers on a strict 35-hour week would leave French haulage companies at a disadvantage against foreign rivals. Drivers oppose a deal the government reached with their bosses which allows monthly rather than weekly hour limits.

With many earning no more than the national minimum wage of roughly £600 a month, some want the right to work long hours to boost their pay, while others are happy to reduce their hours - as long as their pockets do not suffer.

'The project may be an interesting social experiment, but the way it has been implemented is, frankly, badly flawed,' said Philippe Herzog, an economics professor at Nanterre University outside Paris.

While economists predict that an increase in productivity at major industrial groups will probably offset much of the rise in costs, small firms and the service sector are expected to be badly hit, with some small firms saying they will not be able to increase their turnover by enough to afford new staff on a reasonable wage.

Newspaper leader writers were scathing about the law's chances of success, saying the government had overestimated its impact on job creation and been heavy-handed in implementing it. 'To apply a single remedy to all companies, whether they are healthy or fragile, highly profitable or gravely loss-making, highlights a Soviet style of medicine the government could have done without,' said France Soir last Tuesday.

Midi Libre said the strikes proved 'the method was not right' and predicted 'the 35-hour week will create few jobs and reduce social dialogue to violent clashes'.

fields.headline: Bitter sweet
fields.trailText: Warnings that the dazzling rise of Internet stocks cannot last have been rife. Some of these companies make no profits and pay no dividends except in the form of new shares. Many are issued to their own staff as options, providing a dazzling addition to salaries. Joe Public is subsidising the wage bill of the Internet's shooting stars.
fields.body:
Warnings that the dazzling rise of Internet stocks cannot last have been rife. Some of these companies make no profits and pay no dividends except in the form of new shares. Many are issued to their own staff as options, providing a dazzling addition to salaries. Joe Public is subsidising the wage bill of the Internet's shooting stars.

If it all goes pearshaped, many investors may seek consolation in drink, which is unlikely ever to go out of fashion. An irony of the current stock market is that many brewers' stocks are undervalued but undeniably sound. Brewers have substantial assets and customers for life. They make steady profits and pay dividends. Sensibly, they also have moved into the hotel business so that their patrons can more conveniently enjoy their products without fear of infringing the drink- driving laws.

No futurologist has yet envisaged the day when a computer will dispense beer over a phone line. Even nerds get thirsty and have to go to the pub or the off-licence. When the Internet bubble bursts, beer will prove a truer friend than ever.

An irony of the current stock market is that many brewers' stocks are undervalued but undeniably sound. Brewers have substantial assets and customers for life. They make steady profits and pay dividends. Sensibly, they also have moved into the hotel business so that their patrons can more conveniently enjoy their products without fear of infringing the drink- driving laws. No futurologist has yet envisaged the day when a computer will dispense beer over a phone line. Even nerds get thirsty and have to go to the pub or the off-licence. When the Internet bubble bursts, beer will prove a truer friend than ever.

fields.headline: Apartheid's spy hiding in Spain
fields.standfirst: Terry Bell  in Johannesburg unravels the murky past of the ex-Rugby teacher who siphoned aid funds into police coffers
fields.trailText: Favio Barraclough, 75, has been watching the Pinochet case with a certain anxiety. Unlike the former Chilean dictator, he is not charged with crimes for which he may be extradited. But his role as a spy for South Africa's apartheid regime is unravelling and, fearful of an official investigation, he has gone to ground in Spain.
fields.body:
Favio Barraclough, 75, has been watching the Pinochet case with a certain anxiety. Unlike the former Chilean dictator, he is not charged with crimes for which he may be extradited. But his role as a spy for South Africa's apartheid regime is unravelling and, fearful of an official investigation, he has gone to ground in Spain.

The part played by the dapper former art teacher at Rugby school in an elaborate scheme called 'Operation Daisy' has emerged from the transactions of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission. For more than four years the operation hoodwinked the liberal West and diverted into the security services funds sent to help fight apartheid.

From November 1976, money from sources such as Scandinavian aid agencies, the British Overseas Development Agency and independent humanitarian groups found its way to two trust funds in South Africa. Both, it has now emerged, were set up and run by the security police - with Eduardo Joel Favio Barraclough as sole trustee.

He was one of a network of operatives and 'sources' in Europe who carried out the orders of the South African Security Police chief, General Johan Coetzee. Together with confessed murderer Craig Williamson and British-born bomb-maker Jerry Raven, Coetzee was among the nine men granted amnesty in South Africa for the 1982 bombing of the London office of the then exiled African National Congress.

Williamson and Raven are also among a group of security policemen who have applied for amnesty for the letter-bomb killings of academic Ruth First in Mozambique in 1982 and of teacher Jeanette Schoon and her six-year-old daughter, Katryn, in Angola two years later.

It was Williamson who was Barraclough's 'handler' when the Spanish-born art teacher left South Africa after helping to establish one of the most successful projects of larceny ever mounted by the police.

Barraclough had arrived in South Africa in 1974 to take up the chair of fine arts at the University of the Witwatersrand on an initial three-year contract. But within days of his arrival, growing numbers of staff and students were demanding his removal for incompetence.

The administration compromised by appointing him director of what was to become the Getrude Posel art gallery. But he remained a professor at 'Wits', which had an international reputation as a centre of anti-apartheid struggle. He proved the ideal candidate for a scheme to provide a phoney conduit for anti-apartheid funds.

In Williamson, Coetzee already had an agent who was acting as the liaison in South Africa for the Geneva-based International University Exchange Fund. It was a steady source of additional funding for the police.

In mid-1976, Williamson asked leading anti-apartheid lawyer Geoff Budlender in Johannesburg to draw up trust deeds for the Prisoners Support Trust and the Education Research Trust. Barraclough, described as Wits professor and former council member of the Royal British Society of Sculptors, was sole trustee. The names of Barraclough and Budlender were used to give the trusts a superficial legitimacy. But the deeds Budlender drew up were never registered. Another set, again with Barraclough as sole trustee, was drawn up by a Pretoria legal firm with close links to the government and police.

By then, Barraclough was in danger of losing his job. The police turned to what they called their 'friends in the media'. In the Citizen, set up and financed by the government's information de-partment, Barraclough was portrayed as a liberal-tinged intellectual. His colleagues began to think they may have done him a disservice.

Barraclough played no further part in the trusts as the money rolled in. How much was siphoned off to private pockets and police projects will never be known. But the sums were substantial. In one case, Coetzee took 40,000 rands (£4,000) and, in the name of John Davis, bought a large tract of land north of Pretoria. It became a training base for apartheid agents. Among the many who trained there was Peter Casselton, a British pilot, mercenary and spy who died in Pretoria in 1997 when a truck he was working on rolled off its supports and crushed him. It was Casselton who first mentioned the fact that a former 'Wits professor' had been part of Coetzee's network.

Williamson also boasted to his lawyer that a South African agent in Spain had 'run the local anti-apartheid movement'. The tiny Spanish anti-apartheid movement had no record of Barraclough. But Mike Terry, longest-serving secretary of the British Anti-Apartheid Movement, remembered a Spanish delegate, Pablo Valls, who regularly attended international anti-apartheid conferences. Activists in Madrid also knew of Valls. Late last year, amid growing suspicions, he was asked to resign from the 'support South Africa' network.

The suspicions were well founded. The name Pablo Valls-Tarrago appears on a list of security police operatives issued with undercover passports between 1986 and 1991. On 27 June, 1988, Valls-Tarrago was issued with passport P00227389 for use in an undisclosed operation. Valls-Tarrago is the maiden name of his Spanish mother.

But the final link was provided by the spy himself. He made the elementary mistake of leaving a mobile telephone number - as Valls - with the solidarity group, Co-op Africa Austral, in Madrid. It was the same number listed at the former home of Favio Barraclough as the contact for the Anglo-Spanish professor who had worked at Wits.

In a telephone interview, Barraclough said repeatedly that his name had not been mentioned at the Truth and Reconciliation Commission hearings. He expressed grave concern that he had been linked with Williamson and others and disclosed he was writing a book which would 'give real insights into the South African story'.

Terry Bell, with former TRC investigations head Dumisa Ntsebeza, is researching a book on some of the unfinished business of South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission.

webTitle: Ailing Bin Laden needs to leave lair for surgery

fields.headline: Ailing Bin Laden needs to leave lair for surgery
fields.trailText: The alleged terrorist mastermind Osama Bin Laden is suffering from a serious kidney complaint which, according to a doctor who examined him recently, needs surgery.
fields.body:
The alleged terrorist mastermind Osama Bin Laden is suffering from a serious kidney complaint which, according to a doctor who examined him recently, needs surgery.

Bin Laden, who has a $10 million price tag on his head, is in hiding in Afghanistan. It would be almost impossible for him to have treatment without leaving the country and abandoning his safe haven.

Reliable sources in Pesh-awar, the Pakistani city on the border with Afghanistan, say a top specialist from a Gulf state saw Bin Laden late last month in the southern Afghan city of Kandahar. He is said to have recommended surgery as soon as possible. The Saudi dissident has been complaining of serious lower back pains for at least two years.

Journalists interviewing the 44-year-old scholar and former guerrilla fighter have noticed that he has been walking with the help of a stick, although he has tried to conceal his frailty from cameras.

Residents of Jalalabad, a city in east Afghanistan close to a Bin Laden base, have said he regularly sends men to buy Western medicines from chemists. On one occasion early this year, Bin Laden was seen waiting in a car while his men brought him the drugs.

Leaving Afghanistan for surgery will cause massive problems for the terrorist. He will no doubt be aware of the fate of Carlos the Jackal, who was kidnapped from Sudan by French intelligence services after being anaesthetised before a minor operation. Carlos woke up in Paris, where he is still in prison.

webTitle: Police clash marks New Year in China

fields.headline: Police clash marks New Year in China
fields.trailText: Chinese police tightened security at Tiananmen Square yesterday, hours after they beat and detained 50 members of the banned Falun Gong sect who staged a protest at the start of the Lunar New Year.
fields.body:
Chinese police tightened security at Tiananmen Square yesterday, hours after they beat and detained 50 members of the banned Falun Gong sect who staged a protest at the start of the Lunar New Year.

Their presence apparently thwarted a second protest Falun Gong followers planned to conduct near the Gate of Heavenly Peace where Mao Tse-tung's portrait hangs.

Police tried to separate sect followers from families and tourists out in Beijing on the first day of the Year of the Dragon. At least a dozen people were questioned and then driven away in police vans.

Earlier, dozens of Falun Gong members of all ages converged on the square at midnight. Many waved red banners. Several sat cross-legged in one of the group's typical meditation poses.

Police immediately kicked, punched and dragged the protesters away.

fields.headline: Animals eat banned feed
fields.standfirst: What's wrong with our food? - special report
fields.trailText: France, which has maintained a ban on British beef, itself failed to ensure that animal feed no longer contained substances banned in the wake of Europe's mad cow disease scare, according to  Le Figaro .
fields.body:
France, which has maintained a ban on British beef, itself failed to ensure that animal feed no longer contained substances banned in the wake of Europe's mad cow disease scare, according to Le Figaro .

The French daily cited a report by European Commission experts who said they found continued traces of banned animal proteins in feedstuffs during checks as recently as last June.

The revelations in a front-page story headlined 'New Mad Cow Scandal' could prove highly embarrassing for a government which has defied its European partners to maintain a British beef ban on the grounds that safety measures were still not foolproof.

The newspaper said Commission veterinary experts had found elements of banned protein and bone matter in feed destined for cattle herds, despite a prohibition across the European Union since July 1996 for grazing herds.

The experts carried out tests in France last May and June, shortly before the decision by European Union part ners to lift the ban on beef from Britain, where the scare over bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE), or mad cow disease, began.

The newspaper said the Commission report also faulted France for failing to ensure that animal feed containing the proscribed protein and bone matter was specifically labelled as 'not for grazing herds'.

The Commission also found fault with herd surveillance, such as delays by breeders in reporting cases of infected cattle, the newspaper said.

webTitle: Bill grooms Hillary for Clinton dynasty

fields.headline: Bill grooms Hillary for Clinton dynasty
fields.standfirst: The President sees his wife's Senate race as a last chance to secure his legacy. He's even writing her speeches
fields.trailText: Hillary Clinton will today deliver the speech that finally makes her the first First Lady ever to run for Congressional office - but it has not been written by her.
fields.body:
Hillary Clinton will today deliver the speech that finally makes her the first First Lady ever to run for Congressional office - but it has not been written by her.

The pen that will make history in New York this afternoon - The Observer has learnt - is that of the man who will be standing at her side: her husband, the President of the United States.

Hillary has stood at Bill Clinton's shoulder during the good and the bad times, and been his guiding strength through so many of them. But it was all worth it. Now comes a role reversal: today, Hillary launches - among other things - Bill's last campaign, for which he arrived in New York yesterday.

Her closest aides talk about President Clinton being 'intimately involved' in the speech during a flurry of phone calls; one adviser says that they 'talk about it all the time'; 'pretty much, it's his', another tells The Observer . 'There's no better political consultant than the President,' adds another.

When Hillary's rival, Rudy Giuliani, accuses her of having her campaign HQ in Washington, he has a point. The White House Map Room has become the central venue for planning the Mayor's defeat, with Hillary's key advisers commuting from New York. It was the President who steered Hillary to her major media debut on the prime time Late Night with David Letterman .

Bill has his reasons. Increasingly melancholic and wan about his future and 'legacy' (his favourite word), the President sees victory for his wife as part of a bigger, epic campaign - the battle for history. He needs to show that there is such a thing as 'Clintonism', with heirs such as his spouse and his political 'son', Al Gore - two people who have claimed him when it suited them, and shamelessly disavowed him when it didn't.

In Washington, Clinton hardly gives a speech without mentioning the looming twilight of his term - time weighs on him. But in New York, the President can ooze his usual charm, smooch around and dominate events other than the drawn-out farewell party that his White House engagements have become.

Even without Bill, the wrestle between Hillary and Giuliani will be an outrageously entertaining spectacle, fought between two of only four people on America's political stage known instantly by their first names. Hillary's problem is this: the other two are her husband and Monica Lewinsky. For Hillary, there are risks in staging today's family panto. There is a practical matter: Bill's entwinement with her campaign will throw into even sharper relief her own incompetent mishandling of local political nitty-gritty, which has already alienated key officials.

Then there is the question of Hillary's independence. The fight against Giuliani is her lone adventure, her resurrection from the Lewinsky scandal, her own political beginning. She is forever making a fraudulent comparison between herself and Eleanor Roosevelt - the difference being that the latter really was independent of her husband. It will look today as though Hillary never quite became her own person.

Most dangerously, Bill's presence exacerbates fears that Hillary is not so much a Senator as a soap star. It was, after all, the TV drama of the decade, of which this could be the latest, maybe final, episode: cheated Hillary makes a bid for freedom, seeking love and attention in New York. She looks defiantly glorious on the cover of Vogue - but suddenly Bill appears, helping her unpack and kissing her on the podium at the moment that matters. 'I certainly intend to spend the rest of my life with him,' Hillary cooed on the radio the other day. Tough party apparatchiks in Brooklyn cringe into their Bud Lite.

True to the soap script, Hillary is fishing for celebrity endorsements - the currency of modern Democrat politics - and has netted a glittering shoal: Calvin Klein, Ralph Lauren, Martin Scorsese, Steven Spielberg, Paul Newman, Glenn Close, Andre Agassi, Nicole Kidman, Barbra Streisand Michael Douglas and others, all sending cheques.

Rudy has, by contrast, been hosting dinners with a smaller, more cerebral and serious crowd, and the gravitas works firmly in his favour. He has recruited Henry Kissinger, banker David Rockefeller and former diplomatic arch-hawk Jeane Kirkpatrick. Designer Bill Blass is as trendy as Giuliani gets, but he does have the most popular superstars of all who had delivered Hillary a stinging snub: the New York Yankees and their fans.

For all the family drama and celebrity icing, the Clinton v Giuliani contest will be hallmarked primarily by the fundamental nastiness - for better or worse - of both candidates. In that, at least, Hillary and Rudy are ideally suited to one another; many have suggested that the couple would make an ideal bride and groom.

Last week the hors d'oeuvres were served, of a bitter flavour that candidates traditionally reserve until after Labour Day. And there was a gift for Hillary: sitting behind Giuliani's shoulder on the VIP dais at a recent function was none other than the handsome face of the man of the moment: Austria's far-right coalition partner Jörg Haider.

Haider was one of 80 guests at, of all things, Rudy's Congress of Racial Equality dinner. The mayor warmly shook the hand of the pariah Haider, and later said - when challenged - he did not know who the chisel-jawed visitor was. 'I go to a lot of dinners,' he pleaded. 'Clip those right wings, Rudy,' gloated Hillary.

The incident plays on to crucial battle terrain. Opinion polls find that most voters have decided one way or the other (and neck-in-neck) between Clinton and Giuliani, with the exception of an eight per cent Jewish vote. It is this which could finally decide the outcome.

fields.headline: Rainier survives lung operation
fields.trailText: Prince Rainier of Monaco was undergoing a 'very satisfactory' recovery after surgeons removed part of his lung to examine a small nodular growth, his doctors announced yesterday. They did not say whether the growth was cancerous.
fields.body:
Prince Rainier of Monaco was undergoing a 'very satisfactory' recovery after surgeons removed part of his lung to examine a small nodular growth, his doctors announced yesterday. They did not say whether the growth was cancerous.

The prince, 76, has received visits from his children and is able to move around in his bedroom after the second surgery in two months.

The Grimaldi family, which has ruled the tiny Riviera principality since 1297, is one of Europe's oldest royal families. Rainier has been Monaco's ruler for the past 50 years.

webTitle: UN genocide investigators close in on Rwandan exile in London

fields.headline: UN genocide investigators close in on Rwandan exile in London
fields.trailText: Genocide allegations against a senior Rwandan soldier now living in Britain will be published next week in a report that includes eye-witness testimony from both collaborators and families of his alleged victims.
fields.body:
Genocide allegations against a senior Rwandan soldier now living in Britain will be published next week in a report that includes eye-witness testimony from both collaborators and families of his alleged victims.

Former Lieutenant-Colonel Tharcise Muvunyi is suspected of having played an active role in the 1994 genocide in which 800,000 of Rwanda's Tutsi minority were slaughtered by the Hutu majority. His role is now under investigation by the United Nation's war crimes tribunal.

An asylum-seeker claiming social security, Muvunyi lives with his wife and children and has been in Britain for over a year. When confronted at his flat in Lewisham, south London, on Friday morning, Muvunyi seemed hardly surprised to be facing journalists. A slight, modestly dressed man, he refused to answer questions and ran off. His only words were: 'Call my solicitor'.

But Muvunyi's alleged crimes are well detailed. Africa Watch, the human rights organisation that has compiled the first comprehensive study of Muvunyi's activities, say they have traced families of his alleged victims and have interviewed accomplices. The witness testimony, says the report's author, further strengthens the case against Muvunyi.

'The report will show beyond all reasonable doubt that Muvunyi is guilty of these crimes,' says Rakiya Omaar, its author. 'The report has been quite straightforward to compile - many of the witnesses and his accomplices are still alive.'

Omaar continues: 'All of the evidence points [in] a chronological line back to Muvunyi - with witnesses actually being able to see and identify what he did. Their testimony argues that he should be extradited back to face charges at the war crimes tribunal.'

British authorities have so far ignored the presence of Muvunyi in the UK, which has no extradition treaty with Rwanda. But the British Government would have to issue an arrest warrant if asked by UN prosecutors.

The Rwandan tribunal is under increasing pressure to indict suspected war criminals. On 24 January, the US Supreme Court moved to turn over an elderly Rwandan clergyman to face war crimes charges. If it extradites Elizaphan Ntakirutimana, 75, he will be the first person the country hands over to the UN's International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda, based in Arusha, Tanzania. Ntakirutimana was a former president of the Seventh Day Adventist Church in Rwanda.

One of the most detailed accounts in Omaar's report highlights an incident at the Benibikara convent in Butare, where Tutsi children were being sought out and killed. Local nuns gave them sanctuary. Muvunyi is suspected of signing a military order for soldiers to sweep the convent of children - cleaning them out of cupboards and ceiling hiding spaces. The 22 children were then driven into neighbouring woods. None have been seen since.

In Lewisham, Muvunyi leads a low-key existence: residents say he is rarely seen outside his home. Suresh Kumar, a local shopkeeper, says Muvunyi maintains a polite silence in the area - neither he nor his family have made any attempts to integrate themselves into the community.

'He keeps himself to himself; we haven't seen much of him. He sometimes comes in here to buy things, but he never says anything. And I have never seen him walking with people who might be his friends. As far as I can tell, he's quite isolated here with his family.'

Officials at the Rwandan Embassy in London say they have been alerted to Muvunyi's movements by a string of informants. And, according to their information, other genocide suspects are also hiding in Britain - a group has been identified in Kent.

'These people come over to mainland Europe mainly by ferry,' said a spokesman for the Rwandan Embassy. 'Many are named suspects in the war crimes tribunal, and we hope they will eventually face extradition back to face the charges levelled against them.'

webTitle: Portrait of the artist as a cheat

fields.headline: Portrait of the artist as a cheat
fields.standfirst: David Hockney has outraged the art world by claiming that some of the world's most revered artists used optical aids to help create their work. So, what's wrong with that, asks  Andrew Marr
fields.trailText: David Hockney has outraged the art world by claiming that some of the world's most revered artists used optical aids to help create their work. So, what's wrong with that, asks  Andrew Marr
fields.body:
'Did the old masters cheat?' That was the inflammatory cover line above David Hockney's new thinking on how a cascade of the greatest names in Western art - including Caravaggio, Raphael, Frans Hals, Vermeer, Velázquez and Ingres - used lenses to trace out their pictures. That was how they achieved their near-miraculous use of perspective; that was how they caught transient smiles with such a swagger.

Hockney would regard none of this as cheating: 'The lens can't draw a line, only the hand can do that, the artist's hand and eye ... This whole insight about optical aids doesn't diminish anything; it merely suggests a different story.'

Even so, the audacity and verve of his argument, overturning a long tradition of art connoisseurship with the flick of a pencil, has arrived like a depth-charge in the art world. Hockney is arguing that the camera obscura principle, the passing of light through a small hole into a darkened room to produce an inverted image, was taken up and modified with lenses and mirrors throughout the great age of Western painting. That - yes - they copied.

It is a sensational idea. It directly challenges the image of the divinely-inspired Old Master catching perspective and those fleeting expressions and complicated, jumbled shapes, by pure eye and hand co-ordination, with a confident fluency modern artists can only marvel at.

To add insult to injury, Hockney was set off on his theory by last year's great Ingres exhibition at the National Gallery in London. There he found a similarity between a room of stunning little drawings by the French master and sketches made by Andy Warhol in the 1970s using a slide projector, which are routinely dismissed by art critics as a prime example of modern machine-assisted decadence. Hockney has been pursuing his idea with the dedication of the protagonist in a crime novel, searching out paintings, art books, friends and experts, and testing the theory in his own studio by buying and learning to use a prism called a camera lucida, with which he can draw fast, accurate lines for portrait sketches. But can it be true?

There has long been an intense argument about whether Vermeer used the camera obscura to create his paintings, particularly the great, uncannily realistic View of Delft. Lesser artists certainly used such devices. But Hockney's single most convincing candidate is Caravaggio, perhaps the most fashionable of Old Masters, who worked in dark rooms, often basements, without preparatory sketches and never let others watch him paint.

Caravaggio was famed for his ability to capture the fleeting, for images of posed models that almost topple on to the viewer, and for his intense, artificial illumination. Apart from murder and sodomy, he was also accused by contemporary critics of lacking invention or understanding of the science of painting; and there are references to him carrying a 'glass'.

Hockney has a simple theory of how Caravaggio worked. In a letter to Lawrence Weschler of the New Yorker, he described how the painter would divide a basement with a curtain and set up his lens. Then he 'covers the canvas with a rich dark undercoat that, being wet, reflects light back. He takes a brush and with the wrong end draws guidelines for the figures in the composition, to enable him to get the models back in position after [breaks for] resting, eating, pissing, etc ...'

Caravaggio would then quickly fill in the difficult bits before dropping the curtain, turning the canvas round and completing the scene in the ordinary way.

The marks quickly drawn in with the brush-handle can indeed be seen on Caravaggio paintings. But Hockney extends his argument to many other great painters, arguing that there was a whole tradition of lens and mirror aids in painting which was forgotten when photography arrived and painters lost interest in imitating nature. This explains the eerie photographic-like realism of Bellini's Doge of Venice and Holbein portraits. It explains why Renaissance portraiture abounds in left-handed people (the reverse effect, before artists learnt to correct it with mirrors). And it explains the historically sudden mastery of complex perspective and 'naturalness'.

Academic opponents are sniffily dismissing it as a non-academic amateur's hobby-horse, without hard evidence. Other experts are simply cautious: Susan Foister, the National Gallery curator whose charges include the Holbeins, said she didn't think Holbein used mechanical aids for his portraits, but that he probably had done for the famous distorted skull in his French Ambassadors painting. 'Indeed, it is quite hard to understand how he could have painted that without a mechanical aid.'

Hockney's supporters are marshalling and include eminent names. Martin Kemp, professor of art history at Oxford and author of The Science of Art, has been in long correspondence with Hockney and is full of admiration: 'I entirely approve of what he's doing. I think it's incredibly interesting; he's asking significant and frequently uncomfortable questions.'

Whereas art historians would be looking for written documentary evidence, Hockney, as a major working artist, had set himself practical questions and looked for evidence embedded in the works themselves. He had, said Kemp, shown how an artist like Frans Hals might have used optical devices, glancing quickly and briefly through a lens to draw out the 'map co-ordinates' of a face, before using his skill at freely handled paint to fill and create the finished portrait. This did not conclusively prove, said Kemp, that Hals had worked as Hockney suggests, but it showed that he could have done, and still produced the fresh, spontaneous brushwork he is famous for.

Lisa Jardine, professor of Renaissance studies at Queen Mary and Westfield, London, wrote a book called Ingenious Pursuits, charting the interweaving of art and science in the seventeenth and early eighteenth centuries. She said of Hockney's theory: 'He's right. And we have all really known it for a long time ... But it needed somebody who could read the brush strokes, the pencil strokes. There were those of us who knew painters had always had lenses, but it needed a painter to see this.'

Like Hockney, Jardine has come up against the hostility of critics and the public to the idea that painters used artificial aids to create convincing illusions. Part of the reason, she suggests, is that science-based explanations of art threaten the connoisseur art critics, who have accumulated expensive and valuable expertise which has little to say about lenses and 'tricks'. To borrow Bagehot's phrase about the British monarchy, it is to let light in upon magic.

Hockney is also threatening to art academics because they don't know how to paint, and he does. He's a doer, with a doer's insight. Hockney complains: 'Many art historians regard themselves as too lofty - too concerned with the history of ideas, of iconography and so forth - to bother with questions about the mere craft of a painter's making.

'I must say, frankly, that I'm not all that interested in what sometimes passes for art history.'

And here is the larger significance of Hockney's challenge. It goes beyond a dispute, however fascinating, about whether the Old Masters traced some designs using lenses.

It is also an argument about how we regard 'fine art' generally. To say they 'cheated' with camera-like techniques is silly, in the end, because it suggests that this invalidates their skills in composition, colour, imagination, the handling of paint and so on.

Is it so qualitatively different from using grids, plumb-lines and maulsticks? Yes - for those who regard these painters as a pantheon of mysterious demigods, more than men if less than angels, anything which smacks of technical aid is blasphemy. It is akin to giving scientific explanations for the miracles of saints. And in an age which regards paintings as a substitute for religious faith, where art-worshippers mutter in hushed awe at the images in high-ceilinged public temple-galleries, this is a serious offence.

Hockney is reminding his critics that art is not so mysterious or so prissy. It is also a physical business of making. It is not a refuge from technology and science, though a great division in Western consciousness has tried to make it so. In fact, the two have always been closely connected.

There has been a constant and significant progress in the development of paint, from the discovery of new pigments, replacing unstable or poisonous ones (the old 'emerald green' or copper aceto-arsenite, for instance, was toxic and also sold as insecticide; 'Indian yellow' was made by heating the urine of cows fed on mango leaves; and 'Vandyke brown', made from earth, decomposed vegetation and bitumen, quickly cracked and turned black).

Without the discovery of collapsible metal tubes in 1841, which quickly replaced animal bladders for carrying ready-mixed oil paint, the outdoor lightness and speed of Impressionism would have been far harder; Degas brilliantly exploited manufactured oil pastels; Daumier would not have been Daumier without the lithograph; Andy Warhol had his silkscreen and polymer paints, not to mention his overhead projector; the photo-realists had their air-brushes; today's artists use video, latex, household paints, aluminium and so on. And Hockney has deployed instant cameras, computers, photocopiers, fax machines and newspaper presses.

None of this reduces artists to the slaves of the latest technology. Far from it. Hockney suggests that modern painting, from Cézanne to abstract expressionism, was partly a reaction against photography, a forced march to a different role. And if that is so, a franker understanding of the earlier relationship between lenses and painting - the 300 years when, says Hockney 'awkwardness seems to disappear completely from Western European art' - may put things in perspective.

It may encourage a return to drawing alongside lenses, and a more relaxed and less frantic attitude to technology.

Hockney's intervention is subversive in one final way, too. It questions the modern obsession with uniqueness, the idea that Ingres is somehow lesser if he copied lines thrown by a glass, as well as free-handing.

Yet the history of painting is also the history of copying, both literally and by quotation, of appropriation, of modifying, working jointly and in teams, reworking and borrowing.

Hockney himself is full of echoes of Picasso and Ingres, Manet and Hogarth.

So, in sum, a whole way of thinking about art is challenged here - the notion of self-contained geniuses, whose skills we can no longer comprehend, cut off from the grubbier society of science and manufacturing around them, and interpreted for us today by a priesthood of art historians ...

If Hockney is right, then a lot of this is suddenly and rudely up-ended. It is, by far, the greatest thing he has done without a brush.

fields.headline: It's London vs Britain
fields.standfirst: The capital is the dynamic engine driving the UK. But the shires are growing weary of its irresistible force.  Richard Reeves  and Andy McSmith  report
fields.trailText: Question: What has Europe's eighth biggest economy, 77 floodlit artificial football pitches and the world's most ethnically diverse population? Another clue: if you own a house in this place, it's worth nearly twice the national average for homes in Britain.
fields.body:
Question: What has Europe's eighth biggest economy, 77 floodlit artificial football pitches and the world's most ethnically diverse population? Another clue: if you own a house in this place, it's worth nearly twice the national average for homes in Britain.

The answer, if you haven't already guessed, is London. If it were a country, the capital would rank above Sweden in terms of economic power; within a couple of years it will have overtaken Switzerland.

London has always differed from the rest of Britain - but political, economic and social trends are conspiring to drive the wedge deeper. Londoners and other Britons look at each other with growing suspicion across the concrete border between the two worlds, the M25.

A beer commercial starring two pointy-headed aliens drinking through their snouts featured a rural barman asking politely: 'Up from London, are we?'

New Labour's strongly metropolitan tilt, with deals cooked up in trendy Islington restaurants, adds to a sense that the Government rules for the Big Smoke - prompting a swift rural tour by the PM, insufficient to prevent Agriculture Minister Nick Brown's messy encounter with a chocolate eclair hurled by a green activist.

One of William Hague's few political successes has been to make capital out of the grievances of rural, middle-class England including the crisis in farming, the threat to ban fox hunting, and the intrusion of new homes on to the green belt. The 'Townie Tony' tag has stuck. Labour is resigned to the prospect of losing hundreds of council seats to the Tories in May, particularly in the 89 rural councils where voting will be taking place.

The seats now up for grabs were last contested in 1996, when Labour was enjoying the incredible run of electoral success which preceded the general election. In that year, Labour won nearly 1,700 seats, and the Tories fewer than 500, so they now have more than three times as many to lose.

But the latest spat goes beyond the usual rural versus urban jostling, and the tired 'north-south' divide. Phil Redmond, creator of Brookside, says it is 'a battle between the London clique and the rest of us'. The bifurcation of Britain is under way.

Tony Travers, from the London School of Economics - not, notice, the British School of Economics - says that the process of devolution and the election of a London mayor and assembly is adding fuel to the fire.

'Having a mayor and assembly will help to create an even stronger sense of civic culture in London,' he says. 'There is no question that the process of devolution and directly-elected mayors will further fragment our political culture.'

Political reform is formalising differences, giving a voice to long-buried sentiments and creating a breed of politicians who are obliged to echo local, partisan sentiments. Last week's embarrassing resignation by junior Defence Minister Peter Kilfoyle had nothing to do with complaints from the countryside. He was motivated by the relentless economic decline of his native Liverpool and a desire to see a Liverpool mayor with real power - a job that no one would be shocked to see him go for.

And in the next few days the Welsh First Secretary Alun Michael is set to be the fall guy for a growing feeling in Wales that the valleys have been forgotten by a Labour Government obsessed with pursuing the votes of Middle England. Welsh-speaking Michael has never managed to cast off the image of being 'London's man'.

The genie is out of the bottle. One of the greatest ironies of the constitutional reform process is that the attempt to disperse power has created platforms from which different parts of the country can blast away at each other. The prejudices have always been there, of course. A.N. Wilson thinks of 'London as a City State with a number of boring and rather expensive appendages (known as England, Wales, Scotland and Ireland) to which we have to be polite and which we are obliged, rather unwillingly, to subsidise, to ease the chips on their provincial shoulders'. But the prejudices are becoming politics: Trevor Phillips, when he was a candidate to become London's first directly-elected mayor, kick-started a debate about the level of subsidisation between London and the rest of the country, demanding that Scotland 'give back' £1-2 billion a year. The wars of distribution are likely to intensify once London has a mayor in place - and as the economic divide deepens.

Economic output is £13,000 per head in London, compared to a national average of £11,000. The gap between GDP per head in London and the rest of the country has increased sixfold in the past 15 years. The pay gap, already 30 per cent, is set to widen to 35 per cent by 2003 according to the Centre for Economics and Business Research. House prices continue to soar in the capital. And with London's service-based, international economy booming, the level of subsidy from London to poorer regions is more than £20 billion a year - or £8,000 for every metropolitan household.

So while Britain complains about the political dominance of the capital, the capital moans about being used, in the London Evening Standard's phrase, as a 'giant cash machine'.

But the real differences between the two nations, London and Britain, are not measured by Gross Domestic Product or fiscal transfers. The differences are visible to anyone who walks around Soho, Brixton or Brent.

Travers says the ethnic diversity of the capital is the most important difference from the rest of Blighty. Half of the UK's black and Asian citizens live in London. 'Look at it this way,' he says. 'There are more black and Asian people in Brent, in just one of London's 33 boroughs, than in the whole of Scotland.'

London absorbs between half to two-thirds of immigrants to the UK every year - refugees from Kosovo, nurses from South Africa, bartenders from Australia, bankers from America. It is now the world's melting pot. 'London is becoming a Manhattan-upon-Thames,' says Travers. 'Sustained economic growth, a flexible labour market and a reputation for tolerance are all making London a magnet.' And even when immigrants are 'dispersed' - think of the Vietnamese population - follow-up studies show a drift back to the capital.
