'Programmes about the countryside tend to be about vets or rural detectives,' says Travers. 'All the exotic, high-powered, trend-setting images are urban ones, while rural images reinforce the image of thatched cottages, of an Agatha Christie Britain.'

London's image has also been transformed by the lesbian and gay movement. Soho has gone from being a sink for drunks and prostitutes to a cafe society full of beautiful young things on the cruise. The debate over Section 28 was one of those moments when London looks at England in mystification, and vice versa.

A couple of years ago the London Tourist Board advertised on the US West Coast using a picture of Big Ben and a strapline reading: 'If you think South Beach is the only place for tea, think again', a reference to gay 'tea dances'. The old cliché that there are no gays in Scotland has some truth to it - most of them run to London to escape the homophobia north of the border.

And London is far from a uniformly wealthy, hip place: 94 per cent of the poorest council estates in England are in London; 75,000 families live in overcrowded conditions. And London supports - and welcomes - 50,000 destitute asylum seekers each year.

But the debates about the place of London in Britain will only intensify. Pessimists point to France, where the metropolitan bias is still stronger, and the 'desertification' of the French countryside and rural economy. Maybe Westminster should up sticks itself, and meet as Travers suggests, in village halls around the country - revolve rather than devolve. 'What a difference that might make to policy!' he says.

Two countries in one land?

 If London were a nation, it would rank above Sweden, Finland and Hungary in terms of economic output, with a Gross Domestic Product £2,500 higher per person that the UK as a whole

 Financial and business services account for 38 per cent of London's economic activity, compared to 25 per cent nationally. Manufacturing accounts for 11 per cent in London, against 21 per cent nationally

 Fourteen of the 33 London boroughs are in the top 20 most deprived in the United Kingdom

 London has 12 per cent of the UK's population - but 18 per cent of the nation's restaurants

 One in four people in central London are from an ethnic minority, compared to one in 20 in the UK as a whole

 House prices have been rising twice as quickly in London as the rest of the country for the past five years

 16- to 34-year-olds in London watch an average of 19 hours TV a week; compared to 22 hours for the UK

 If all subsidies between the regions and nations were abolished, and local income tax systems introduced, London could have a basic tax rate of 18 pence in the pound, and top rate of just 30 pence - while Scotland would need rates of 38 per cent and 62 per cent respectively

 The average price of a detached London house is £293,000, compared to a national average of £145,000, and £94,000 in Wales

 The Government spends £677 per head on public transport in London, compared to £75 in the West Midlands

 Londoners walk 260 miles a year, compared to a national average of 200 miles

 Twice as many non-Londoners as Londoners make it to work in less than 20 minutes (62 per cent versus 31 per cent)

Another clue: if you own a house in this place, it's worth nearly twice the national average for homes in Britain. The answer, if you haven't already guessed, is London. If it were a country, the capital would rank above Sweden in terms of economic power; within a couple of years it will have overtaken Switzerland. London has always differed from the rest of Britain - but political, economic and social trends are conspiring to drive the wedge deeper. Londoners and other Britons look at each other with growing suspicion across the concrete border between the two worlds, the M25. A beer commercial starring two pointy-headed aliens drinking through their snouts featured a rural barman asking politely: 'Up from London, are we?' fields.headline: Over 21 - but under the cosh
fields.standfirst: Get a degree, get a job, get a life... In the first of a series on the financial ages of man, Jill Insley finds life's no picnic for debt-ridden twentysomethings
fields.trailText: Get a degree, get a job, get a life... In the first of a series on the financial ages of man, Jill Insley finds life's no picnic for debt-ridden twentysomethings
fields.body:
Deborah Jennings is 23 and heavily in debt. She has borrowed £6,000 in the past four years, and she expects to be even further in the red by the end of this year.

Deborah is not a profligate spender - she pays £100 a week rent and goes out to the cinema or pub only once or twice a week - but she has been forced to take out loans to finance her education.

'All my debts are student loans. I've been really careful. I don't spend a lot, but each year my debts are even bigger,' she says.

Like thousands of other twentysomethings, Deborah has to spend a lot of time worrying about money. Saving in a bank or building society account is the top financial priority for people in their twenties, says research organisation Mintel. While 63 per cent of 20- to 24-year-olds want to save, 38 per cent would rather buy a good holiday or new clothes and shoes, and 35 per cent would pay off debt. Only 28 per cent would spend much on having a good time.

'Twentysomethings aren't what they used to be,' says Martin Campbell at Virgin Direct. When the company launched five years ago, it expected that the Virgin brand would attract a large number of young customers, and was shocked to find that less than 10 per cent were under the age of 30 by the end of the first year. Since then, general advertising on TV and in the home news sections of newspapers has attracted a younger audience - 25 per cent of all Virgin Isa and pension customers are under 30.

The addition of the Internet as a selling medium has helped - 45 per cent of Virgin's pension customers who buy via the Internet are in their twenties, and the company is even getting inquiries from people who are still at college.

Campbell says: 'When I was 20 I couldn't even spell pension. There is definite evidence that twentysomethings are taking their financial future more seriously. Although this may make them seem boring, they are assured of having the last laugh when they can retire at 50.'

Many people in their twenties are choosing to start pensions and open savings accounts while running hefty debts with credit cards and personal and student loans - which could affect their ability to take out a mortgage. Phillip Cartwright of independent mortgage broker London & Country says debts with less than one year to run should not count against you, provided you have a good payment record. But some lenders may deduct payments for credit card bills and longer-term structured loans from your annual income before doing the sums to work out how much you can borrow.

This problem particularly affects twentysomethings in higher education. People who graduated in 1998 owed a staggering £1 billion. The average debt was £4,497. Though seventy per cent of those questioned had borrowed cheaply from the Student Loan Company, 59 per cent had gone on to take much more expensive loans from their banks. Barclays found that although graduate salaries have increased by 17 per cent in the five years since 1994, their borrowing levels spiralled by 103 per cent over the same period. Graduate finances have deteriorated partly because student grants have been abolished, and partly because of the introduction of fees for students whose parents earn more than £17,370 a year.

Worse, there are signs that fear of debt is driving hard-up students to jeopardise their academic chances by taking part-time jobs to pay their way. Forty per cent of students do 20 hours' paid work a week, says the National Union of Students. Two-thirds of them admit this affects their studies, a third miss lectures for work and 20 per cent miss study deadlines. And new graduates often feel obliged to grab the first job offered them - even if they have no interest in it, so desperate are they to reduce debts.

Sarah studied history and politics at university, and was keen to continue with a doctorate. But because of her debts - £2,000 owed to her parents and £4,000 in student loans - she felt obliged to start work as soon as possible.

'My first job was on the shop floor of a large retailer. It wasn't what I wanted to do at all, but I thought it would allow me to move to London and start paying off my debts,' she says.

Three years on Sarah has switched to a more demanding job, and her salary is up from £12,000 a year to £17,000. But the first job has left its legacy. 'You buy a lot of clothes when you work on the shop floor, and because I hated the job I used to go out a lot to make it bearable.

'I now have credit card bills totalling £3,000 as well as the student loans, and although I have paid my parents back, it involved taking out a graduate bank loan.'

fields.headline: Sites for investor eyes
fields.standfirst: For speed the Internet cannot be beaten, but the challenge is to find useful sources of information in the first place.  Mark King  offers some tips
fields.trailText: For speed the Internet cannot be beaten, but the challenge is to find useful sources of information in the first place. Mark King offers some tips
fields.body:
The internet is proving a great leveller between private investors and the professionals. A few years ago, investment data was available only to large institutions; now private investors have access to information that even some brokers struggled to get very recently.

Information is available from a wide variety of Internet sources. Here are some of the main ones:

Company sites
The best company websites give details such as historical performance data, reports and accounts, environmental statements, share price information, press releases and current trading statements. To find a site, use your web browser's search engine, or visit Peter Temple Associates' 'linksite', which contains links to FTSE 100, mid-250 and other FTSE 500 companies on the web.

General personal finance sites
Historical share price data, editorial advice, portfolio monitoring tools, contact details, new issues, business news, newsgroups and noticeboards are available on sites such as Hemmington Scott (Hemscott), moneyeXtra, Interactive Investor, TrustNet, Yahoo Finance and epo.com. Most are free.

Note that these sites' price feeds are delayed by 20 minutes. For several companies' prices it is quicker to open a live account with an online stockbroker (see below). Yahoo UK & Ireland Finance is an excellent site for prices and contact information as well as three-year performance records. The site also carries links to other Yahoo finance sites around the world.

More comprehensive data is available from Hemscott, including share price graphs and market capitalisation details. It also provides past, present and future new issues data, along with historical information on every listed UK company.

Interactive Investor is more of an editorial site providing good basic guidance for beginners. Used with the new epo.com site (an online new issues news centre), it allows private investors access to new issues from which they would otherwise be excluded.

TrustNet runs one of the most comprehensive sites on unit trusts, Oeics and invest ment trusts. Management groups subscribe to the site and offer data on their individual funds.

Similar to iii's site is moneyeXtra's, which offers a useful portfolio monitoring tool, allowing you to select a range of shares to track at any one time. Another well-designed offering is ukinvest.com, which offers all the usual tools.

A warning on newsgroups and noticeboards: sometimes, private investors are acting for their own financial gain, and share-ramping often occurs.

Online stockbrokers
Online share dealing has grown dramatically since the first service was launched in 1998. Online brokers offer other data such as real-time prices and brokers' research notes. Merrill Lynch, for example, offers its own research online. All online brokers can offer live prices once you have opened an account.

The most important issue for investors is how much it costs to buy and sell shares. Check out some of the newer entrants, such as E*Trade and DLJ Direct.

Though this happens rarely, sites can crash without warning, causing investors to lose money.

The following is a useful checklist:

 What is the minimum balance to begin trading?
 Will I be penalised if I wish to use the phone to trade?
 Is there an annual management charge?
 What is the maximum size of deal I can make?
 Will I be penalised for spells of inactivity?

Online banks

There are two types of Internet bank: existing high-street providers that offer online facilities and Internet-only banks such as first-e and Egg. Administering an online account is cheaper and rates should be better, although this is not always so.

The media
Sections of the media can provide an unrivalled business news service, not least Money Observer. The most comprehensive site is ft.com, the online arm of the Financial Times . Its free search facility is particularly helpful. Other sites include Business Day (from the Evening Standard ), the BBC, the Times, the Economist and Teletext.

Official sites
The Treasury, the Inland Revenue and National Savings provide information. Many individual stock exchanges and trading arenas have websites, and it is worth looking at the site of FTSE International. Financial services regulators and trade bodies also have sites.

 This is taken from the February issue of 'Money Observer', on sale at newsagents price £3.50. For 12 issues at £31.97 - a saving of £10 - call 0870 870 1324 and quote reference MYBG001

webTitle: Out of the piggy bank into the fray

fields.headline: Out of the piggy bank into the fray
fields.standfirst: How can I leave home, buy a flat, start a pension - and still go on holidays, Katie Lee asks  Margaret Dibben
fields.trailText: How can I leave home, buy a flat, start a pension - and still go on holidays, Katie Lee asks Margaret Dibben
fields.body:
Katie Lee is about to leave home. Although she will be taking out the largest mortgage she can afford, she also wants to continue saving, start a pension, eat out and go on holiday twice a year. She realises that this involves grown-up financial planning. 'This will be my first move away from piggy-bank saving,' she says.

She is looking for a flat in London's Fulham, but will need her parents' help. On her salary, she will not be able to borrow more than £55,000; she wants to spend about £190,000. Her parents are lending her the balance as an investment.

While she is living at home, she saves £400 a month and has accumulated £2,000 in a building society. But this is not earmarked for the flat: 'This is also for holidays. I want to go skiing, and to Dubai later this year.'

She will share the flat with a girlfriend, who will pay rent to help offset the cost of the mortgage, but Katie is still unsure how much her new way of life will cost: 'I don't really know how much it costs to live.'

She also wants to lay the foundation for a pension but says: 'I am a bit scared of pensions. What happens if I stop work and can't pay? I hope that my salary will increase quite rapidly, though it will never be huge. So I want to be able to increase my mortgage and pension payments. I would also like the chance to stop paying towards the pension if I stop work to have children or something.'

At the moment, though, starting a family is years away: 'I plan to be single for a long time, so I want to be independent financially.' She has a sensible attitude to financial planning: 'I have no student loan and try to spend very little on credit cards. When I do, I pay it off immediately.'

She also knows that it is important to save regularly: 'As well as a pension, I am interested in putting money in an Isa, but I don't even know which companies have good reputations.' She plans this as a long-term investment but does not want to take much risk: 'I am definitely a safe person.'

fields.headline: Cash you could be claiming
fields.standfirst: Half of eligible parents don't know about new help with childcare costs, writes  Neasa MacErlean
fields.trailText: Half of eligible parents don't know about new help with childcare costs, writes Neasa MacErlean
fields.body:
Thousands of working parents are thought to be missing out on Working Families Tax Credit (WFTC) - a new benefit that typically pays out between £15 and £50 a week.

As many as 1.4 million households could be eligible for WFTC, according to the Government. The benefit replaced Family Credit last October - and is more generous. But as only 800,000 people usd to claim Family Credit, advisers are worried that up to half of those who are eligible may not be aware of their rights.

'Lone fathers are a potential problem group,' says a spokeswoman for Gingerbread, a charity advising single parents. 'When we have spoken to them, we have sometimes found they though it related only to lone mothers.'

WFTC was devised to help parents to hold down a job. It aims to tackle the poverty trap through which some parents found it would cost them money in lost benefits to go back to work. Under this scheme , one-child families with income of less than £22,000 could qualify, as could larger families earning up to £30,000.

But claimants need to take into account all their income, potential income, childcare costs and any other expenses, such as travel involved in taking up a job. There is no fixed rate for WFTC: it depends on individual circumstances.

Advisers are finding that WFTC is generally running more smoothly than expected, and is better explained and more swiftly handled that Family Credit.

Part of the improvement may be down to the fact that Family Credit was administered by the Department of Social Security, but WFTC, described as a 'tax credit', rather than a benefit, is being handled by the Inland Revenue, a far more accessible and efficient department than the DSS. Even so, there are some teething problems and pitfalls.

'The overriding issue,' says Alison Garnham of the National Council for One Parent Families, 'is that lone parents are getting estimates of their entitlement from the Government's WFTC helpline - but they need to get a proper benefits check, comparing their income before and after WFTC.'

Some citizens advice bureaux have seen clients who have been no better off after getting a job, finding childcare and coming off benefits. In some cases, what has been gained has been lost through the client forfeiting Housing Benefit and Council Tax Benefit.

According to Gingerbread, those who are particularly likely to find that the benefit of WFTC is marginal include:

 homeowners with mortgages, who find that they lose the assistance they get to pay the mortgage;

 tenants who have a high rent;

 parents who pay very high childcare costs (so that even though WFTC can cover up to 70 per cent of the cost, the remaining 30 per cent can still be a substantial sum);

 workers who find it difficult to get childcare and are using au pairs or other unregistered forms of care (WFTC applies only to childcare that is registered with the local authority's Social Services department);

 workers with high travel costs.

Several charities and other groups will perform a 'better off in work' calculation. These include Gingerbread, the National Council for One-Parent Families, your local citizens advice bureau (check your Yellow Pages or telephone 192), the welfare rights units of local authorities, some law centres and neighbourhood advice units.

Many people may not appreciate the extent to which WFTC is more generous than Family Credit. Under the new system, maintenance income is disregarded in making the calculation.

So, if you get £50 maintenance a week, you can keep it all and will not lose any WFTC if you declare that income (under Family Credit, you would have been only £15 better off a week).

Benefits experts are lobbying the Government to take a broader view of what qualifies as registered childcare, ahead of a green paper expected this spring. Night-workers, for instance, often find it difficult to find a registered childminder at awkward hours, especially if they are lone parents, and so often fall back on family and friends.

Also, many childminders are not registered. Some of them are worried that they would have to pay tax if they became 'official', and Gingerbread believes many do not realise that all or most of their earnings could be covered by the personal allowance, currently £4,335.

The Government is also being urged to investigate the delays being incurred in processing Housing Benefit claims for people applying for WFTC.

Anyone applying for WFTC needs to reapply for Housing Benefit because of the change in their circumstances and income levels. But it can take local authorities weeks to process the new claim.

The system's saving grace is that a new WFTC claimant is allowed a four-week 'run-on' period at their old Housing Benefit rate. Some - but not all - councils are managing to process the new application in this time.

 Gingerbread free advice line: 0800 018 4318 (Mondays:10-7; Tuesdays-Fridays: 10-4).

 National Council for One-Parent Families free advice line: 0800 018 5026 (Mondays and Fridays: 10.30am-1.30pm; Wednesdays: 3-6pm)

 Inland Revenue WFTC helpline ( Monday-Fridays: 7.30-6.30): 0845 609 5000

webTitle: Spare dosh to salt away? Here's how

fields.headline: Spare dosh to salt away? Here's how
fields.trailText: The first rule of saving is to leave it until after you've paid your debts off. It makes no sense to tuck £50 or £100 a month into a bank or building society account earning low interest while you are paying up to 20 times more to service overdrafts, credit cards and loans.
fields.body:
The first rule of saving is to leave it until after you've paid your debts off. It makes no sense to tuck £50 or £100 a month into a bank or building society account earning low interest while you are paying up to 20 times more to service overdrafts, credit cards and loans.

Nick Bamford of Cranleigh independent adviser Informed Choice says: 'Your short-term goal should be to clear your debts and have a good time. In your twenties you want to go on holidays, go clubbing, eat at restaurants and buy cars. You'll want to spend the lion's share on enjoying yourself rather than saving for something that's going to happen many years in the future.'

If there is any money left after painting the town red, Bamford suggests you start by building up a store of accessible cash. The best rate at the moment is offered by Northern Rock's Base Rate Tracker account (0845 600 6767) which is paying 6.5 per cent gross for sums of £250 or more, and allows six withdrawals a year. If you prefer an unlimited number of withdrawals, First-e (www.first-e.com is paying 6.31 per cent gross on its savings account.

When it comes to longer- term investments, Bamford says the importance of being able to access money and control capital in the future swings the pendulum in favour of individual savings accounts (Isas) rather than pensions. Although it is easy to switch pension contributions from one fund to another managed by the same insurance company, switching from one company to another can involve exit penalties and the costly calculation of transfer values. And no money can be withdrawn from a pension fund until you reach 50. In contrast, you can withdraw money whenever you want from an Isa, and all you have to do to move money from one Isa provider to another is fill in a transfer form.

The issue of stakeholder pensions - a low-cost scheme to be introduced in April next year - complicates matters. Andrew Stronach of Norwich Union says that many potential investors are postponing the opening of a personal pension until stakeholder schemes are available.

However, those who are keen to get going could opt for a 'stakeholder friendly' pension. Several companies already offer these, including Norwich Union, Virgin Direct, and Marks & Spencer.

However, you should join a company or occupational pension scheme if offered the chance. Bamford says: 'Your employer will make a usually quite generous contribution on your behalf as well as paying the administration costs of the scheme. To turn this down would be like refusing part of your pay packet.'

Investors in their 20s are often more risk-tolerant than older savers. Graham Hooper at Bath independent adviser Chase de Vere says: 'Provided you're investing for the longer term, you can take bigger risks - even if things go wrong temporarily, they have time to recover.'

During your 20s you should be investing for capital growth, not income. Hooper points out that as most 20-year-olds have grown up with computers, they will feel confident investing in technology funds - considered high-risk by older investors.

Hooper suggests Framlington NetNet, a fund which invests in Internet stocks, but also in companies that use Internet technology intelligently, or manufacture goods that make use of the Internet possible. He also recommends the Société Générale Techology and Henderson Global Technology funds. All three are available as Isas, providing tax-free capital gains.

Hooper also believes young investors will place a greater emphasis on international investment. Although Japan and the Far East are enjoying a rapid recovery at the moment, Hooper recommends that investors concentrate on Europe and the US: 'Investment in the Far East is all about cutting cost and producing goods at a low rate, but I believe that real growth in the future will come from investment in invention. For that you need to be in technologically advanced places such as Silicon Valley.'

His recommendations for the US and Europe are Credit Suisse Transatlantic, Fidelity American, Invesco European and Gartmore European Selected Opportunities.

Most fund management groups offer regular savings schemes, allowing you to invest as little at £20 a month. The charges for these schemes - typically a 5 per cent initial charge and 1.5 per cent annual management charge - are no greater than if you invest a lump sum.

fields.headline: Stamping out property inequalities
fields.trailText: Soaraway prices in the housing market are increasing the likelihood not only that interest rates will rise again, but also that buying a house could become an even more costly business.
fields.body:
Soaraway prices in the housing market are increasing the likelihood not only that interest rates will rise again, but also that buying a house could become an even more costly business.

As the Budget nears - it's on 21 March this year - speculation is increasing that stamp duty will go up. We predicted last November that stamp duty may be targeted again this year as a way of trying to taming house prices. The emphasis is on 'trying': Britain's housing market is once again proving an economic wild card; the cost of homes in areas that are doing well economically are rising while the cost of most other essentials is stable or falling.

Already, stamp duty is 2.5 per cent on properties costing between £250,000 and £500,000 and 3.5 per cent for properties over that. There is no duty on homes worth less than £60,000, but you pay 1 per cent of the full transaction above £60,000.

The trouble with changing stamp duty is that in the short term it can add to the problem. Homeowners will rush to buy, and bid up prices, if they think they will pay more after Budget day.

The Council Of Mortgage Lenders is advocating a system that works more like income tax. But a graduated rate would surely hit poorer areas, where prices may still be languishing. There are so many distortions and inequalities in the housing market, that there must be a case for a full review of policy.

For example, could properties in areas where homes cannot find buyers be revived or restored and made desirable for city escapees working from home? A rise in stamp duty may be a quick and easy response to rampant house price inflation, but it probably won't be a permanent fix.

webTitle: Lofty ideals win the space race

fields.headline: Lofty ideals win the space race
fields.standfirst: Adding rooms is still a good bet, says  Maria Scott, but think PCs and   offices, not granny flats
fields.trailText: Adding rooms is still a good bet, says Maria Scott, but think PCs and offices, not granny flats
fields.body:
Your computer could one day affect the size of your house. If you live in one of the 10 million households that have a PC, finding space for it could become as big an influence on your next choice of property as the number of children you have.

Housing researchers are beginning to identify the rise of technology in the home as one of the driving influences behind demand for certain properties and, ultimately, on prices.

Demand for homes with computer rooms and offices that enable people to work from home is set to soar, according to James Barlow, senior research fellow at Sussex University's Science Policy Research Unit, and author of a recent report on the future of housing for the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors.

'I was in California a few months ago. Over there people expect there to be not only one home office but two, one for each partner, and they want homes to be cabled up to take a number of computers.'

Although the scope to build new homes in the UK is limited by planning constraints and shortage of land, the demand for space to accommodate technology at home is likely to have an increasing bearing on prices in the second-hand market.

In a research project Barlow is working on at present, involving interviews with 300 people looking for properties, one of the key themes is the search for space. 'A substantial minority are concerned about lack of space for home working.'

Barlow, who conducted our interview on a mobile telephone, seated at a computer in his loft, says: 'All the evidence is that people want more space. 'The way people will use space in the home is changing. They will want rooms designed for home working, with access to the Internet.'

He also predicts that we will spend increasing amounts of leisure time at home, as the Internet and other forms of technology provide activities and entertainment on the doorstep.

So, does this mean the death of the three-bed semi, Britain's best-loved house? Not necessarily, says Barlow. While there will certainly be more demand for larger properties, buyers will seek out properties that can be adapted by converting the roof space, for example, or building an extension over the garage.

The desire to house home computers and create work space at home will, he says, be a bigger influence on demand for larger properties than the need to accommodate extended families - a factor some commentators have identified.

Barlow says the jury is still out on whether we are ready to reinvent the extended family, inviting grandparents to live in as carers for children and, ultimately, to be cared for themselves.

Richard Donnell, research analyst for estate agent Savills, says the quest for space may drive more people to buy homes outside the major city centres, but to have small second properties in the cities, particularly London.

'We could see a return to a strong market for the pied-à- terre, for people working at home but wanting somewhere to stay in London.'

Donnell believes that developers will be reluctant to commit themselves to building larger properties because they usually make more money out of putting a larger number of smaller homes on one site.

But Savills says builders should be thinking about features such as cabling for computers. Developers are already focusing on how to be more creative with living space, building in basements, lofts and rooms over garages.

All this suggests that for the owners of larger properties, the four- or five-bedroom homes, the omens are good for the value of their investments.

Increasingly, there may also be a better pay-back for money spent on loft conversions or extensions. In the past, such spending has not always raised the value of a property in proportion to the amount spent.

Ian Perry, national housing spokesman for the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors, agrees: 'Conversions will be a better bet than in the past.'

Andrew Spittle, of estate agent Robert Powell & Co in Edgbaston, Birmingham, goes further: 'If you had, say, a big Victorian semi with four bedrooms and a loft worth £250,000, you could convert the loft for £20,000, and I think it would probably push the value up to £300,000.

'To buy a five-bed house ion the same area you would probably have to pay nearly £350,000.'

He points out that cellars may be suitable for conversion, too.

'There is demand for a decent-sized room for a home office, rather than just a little study.

'PCs take up quite a lot of space, and then there are all the peripherals. When we are designing homes with developers, we say that a study is an important room. It shouldn't just be a 6ft by 10ft thing.'

This trend will make itself felt more quickly in some areas than others. Stuart Harris, a chartered surveyor with agent Carter Jonas in Cambridge - a mecca for computer experts and academics - is accustomed now to clients seeking homes that have scope for plenty of office space.

He is handling a transaction at present on behalf of a family leaving a semi-detached family home in Cambridge for one outside the city that has an annexe for an office.

But the beloved three-bedroom semi should have a lot of life in it yet. Ian Perry says: 'A couple may find a three-bed property ideal, whereas in the past they would have looked for just two bedrooms.'

He believes families are also looking for space for children to spread out their homework and computers. Location will remain an over-riding factor in househunters' choices, but increasingly 'people will have to trade off location against size'.

'We could see a return to a strong market for the pied-à- terre, for people working at home but wanting somewhere to stay in London.' Donnell believes that developers will be reluctant to commit themselves to building larger properties because they usually make more money out of putting a larger number of smaller homes on one site. But Savills says builders should be thinking about features such as cabling for computers. Developers are already focusing on how to be more creative with living space, building in basements, lofts and rooms over garages. All this suggests that for the owners of larger properties, the four- or five-bedroom homes, the omens are good for the value of their investments. Increasingly, there may also be a better pay-back for money spent on loft conversions or extensions. In the past, such spending has not always raised the value of a property in proportion to the amount spent. Ian Perry, national housing spokesman for the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors, agrees: 'Conversions will be a better bet than in the past.' Andrew Spittle, of estate agent Robert Powell & Co in Edgbaston, Birmingham, goes further: 'If you had, say, a big Victorian semi with four bedrooms and a loft worth £250,000, you could convert the loft for £20,000, and I think it would probably push the value up to £300,000. 'To buy a five-bed house ion the same area you would probably have to pay nearly £350,000.' He points out that cellars may be suitable for conversion, too. 'There is demand for a decent-sized room for a home office, rather than just a little study. 'PCs take up quite a lot of space, and then there are all the peripherals. When we are designing homes with developers, we say that a study is an important room. It shouldn't just be a 6ft by 10ft thing.' This trend will make itself felt more quickly in some areas than others. Stuart Harris, a chartered surveyor with agent Carter Jonas in Cambridge - a mecca for computer experts and academics - is accustomed now to clients seeking homes that have scope for plenty of office space. He is handling a transaction at present on behalf of a family leaving a semi-detached family home in Cambridge for one outside the city that has an annexe for an office. But the beloved three-bedroom semi should have a lot of life in it yet. Ian Perry says: 'A couple may find a three-bed property ideal, whereas in the past they would have looked for just two bedrooms.' He believes families are also looking for space for children to spread out their homework and computers. Location will remain an over-riding factor in househunters' choices, but increasingly 'people will have to trade off location against size'.

webTitle: Wrong fit at the right price

fields.headline: Wrong fit at the right price
fields.standfirst: For investors, unwearable clothing is all the fashion, writes  John Windsor
fields.trailText: For investors, unwearable clothing is all the fashion, writes John Windsor
fields.body:
Unwearable clothing is the new art. Impossibly long gowns knitted from human hair, a mini-dress festooned with stuffed fabric phalluses, woollen gloves with too many fingers; they are all taking their place alongside painting and sculpture in art shows in Britain, Europe, the US, Japan and Australia.

Among the unwearables at last month's ART 2000, the big contemporary art show in London, there were white organdie dresses turned into light sculpture. The London gallery Contemporary Applied Arts is selling such works to the public. And on Thursday a selling exhibition dedicated solely to conceptual clothing, as it has become known, opens at Sotheby's.

Daft though it may seem to display in your home an artist-made empty dress or a pair of high-heeled shoes cobbled together from preserved yellow roses, Sotheby's show, titled 'Out of the Closet - Clothes of the Unwearable', is a signal that the new genre has arrived.

Added proof: the howls of outrage in some tabloid newspapers generated by Sotheby's advance press release. The 'Is-it-art?' chatter that greeted young British conceptual art a decade ago was given a second wind. Will the cycle of ridicule followed by buy-up repeat itself? Is the trendy new gear worth investing in?

Although conceptual clothing may appear to have burst suddenly on the art-buying public, hundreds of artists have adopted unwearable clothing as a mode of expression in the past five years - some have done nothing else. They have created a substantial body of work, that is growing all the time.

That's a good investment pointer. Another is that the new genre has art-historical precursors in big-name artists: Joseph Beuys, Salvador Dali, Christo, Lucio Fontana, Jim Dine all made unwearables as art. In the Fifties, Beuys began making men's suits from felt and animal fat: they can fetch around £8,000 at auction. Christo's 'Wedding Dress' was an enor mous fabric-wrapped package harnessed to the unfortunate bride.

So far, prices for work by the new generation of conceptual clothing artists are comparatively low. The few who have gained reputations by conceptual clothing alone may charge upwards of £3,000 a piece, but there are plenty of up-and-comers whose work can be had for under £500.

So what's it all about? Why clothing, instead of paint, or marble, or even formaldehyde? Artists have tumbled to the fact that the most intimate concepts of identity find expression in the thin layer that separates us from the outside world. The way people dress signals how they see themselves and how they want other people to see them. Clothing is everybody's personal art form. Now, as stand-alone art - displayed, not worn - it expresses the way artists see other people. It has acquired a voice of its own.

But as more artists pile in, the knack for collector-investors is to distinguish the resonant voices from the feeble ones. Many works are genuinely witty. Others are vain and trifling.

Among the conceptual clothing at Sotheby's will be work by Britain's leading exponent of the genre, Caroline Broadhead. Her signature work, titled 'Stress' (1993), is an empty translucent cotton dress bulging all over with foot-long carbon-fibre stiffeners. What she says about it exemplifies what artists expect of the new art form.

'"Stress" expresses a woman's tension between inside and outside, private and public, between the self and the rest of the world.' The dress is, she says, trying to force itself back into shape. 'It is resisting the stress emanating from within, trying to conform to the shape expected of it. But there's another shape protruding from inside, trying to break through.'

She says she wanted to make the dress look ordinary, like any dress worn by any woman.

Her latest work plays with shadow and light. Illuminated dresses spread out into the entire room like enlightened souls. Her price range at Sotheby's: £560-£2,385.

Broadhead exhibited at ground-breaking exhibitions of conceptual clothing such as 'Conceptual Clothing' at the Ikon Gallery, Birmingham, in 1986, and 'Conceptual Clothing UK/USA' at the Painted Bride Arts Centre, Philadelphia, in 1989.

In those days, making conceptual clothing tended to be a solitary activity. It needed the sharp eyes of a few exceptionally clued-up curators to bring together the few available examples in a single exhibition space. Now everybody seems to be making it.

The biggest prompt to its burgeoning came from the haute-couture catwalks of New York, London and Paris. The outrageous creations of Issey Miyake and Paco Rabanne seemed to be floating off the catwalk and into the realm of conceptual art. Artists took note.

Paradoxically, now that artists have pushed the boundaries of conceptual clothing still further, the fashion industry is trying to catch up. Last month's haute couture shows in Paris offered the ultimate in the unwearable. The creations of John Galliano, which he describes as art, included a ballerina with her arm in a plaster-cast, lunatics in straitjackets and down-and-out costumes.

Janice Blackburn, curator of Sotheby's show, famous for her annual Contemporary Decorative Arts selling exhibitions at Sotheby's, says: 'Nothing on that catwalk was accessible. It bore no relation to what people put on their backs. This was not art as fashion but fashion as art.'

Emily Bates's dresses, made from human hair and unwearably long, were among the conceptual clothes in Blackburn's show. She used to collect the sweepings from a hairdresser's salon in Glasgow. Her work juxtaposes the eroticism and repulsiveness of human hair, while her elegant but too-thin shapes hint at the constrictions of a notional femaleness dreamt up by male cou turiers. Her prices range from £240 to £3,970.

Freddie Robins makes 'subversive' clothes: pullovers that look jolly but for sewn-up necks, four arms, or elongated sleeves that end in socks; her warm woollen gloves have 14 fingers - or burnt ends. The works, with cosy, punning titles such as 'Leg Room', prompt awkward thoughts about deformity and disablement. Prices start at £400.

Heather Belcher makes seamless garments from rolled felt, one of the oldest textile fabrics, which, like Broadhead's dresses, seem to express a life within. Prices £1,115-£1,270.

At Contemporary Applied Arts, Johanne Mills's white organdie light sculptures are £770 and her organdie slippers £320. A Freddie Robins leg-glove, 'Hand of Good - Hand of God' is £580. Her individual gloves are £230 and knitted 'comfort creatures' £115. A Belcher felt dress is £1,200. ' Out of the Closet - Clothes of the Unwearable' is at Sotheby's, 34-35 New Bond Street, from 10-17 Febru ary (Monday-Friday 10am-4.30pm, Saturday 10am-4pm, Sunday 12am-4pm). Tel: 0171 293 5000.

 Contemporary Applied Arts, 2 Percy Street, London W1. Tel: 0171 436 2344.

webTitle: Time to play your ace card

fields.headline: Time to play your ace card
fields.standfirst: Bulging wallets could become a thing of the past with the advent of the smartcard, says  Tom Bawden
fields.trailText: Bulging wallets could become a thing of the past with the advent of the smartcard, says Tom Bawden
fields.body:
If advocates of smart technology are to be believed, we will soon be able to throw away most of the cards cluttering our wallets and replace them with a single, personalised one, offering exactly the same functions.

The card of the future could double as cash card, travel pass, electronic cash, video shop membership, electronic key and supermarket loyalty card. It could also store more detailed personal information, such as medical records.

This new breed of plastic, known as the multiple application card, is in its infancy, but it could work across the entire range of existing card functions, as well as many new ones. Multiple application cards carry a 'smart' microchip, which can typically store around six A4 pages' worth of data; the magnetic stripes that now occupy the back of our cards store two lines of data.

No wonder the banks are in the process of replacing every magnetic stripe on their cards with a microchip. These have the memory to store complex encryption codes enabling much greater protection from fraud. It still has enough left over to enable it to function in a range of applications. Experts say the absolute security the chip guarantees will make multiple-application cards particularly popular among Internet users, for whom fraud is a major deterrent to e-commerce. You can process information over the Internet by swiping the plastic through a reader connected to your PC.

Big business is still working out how to best to exploit the smartcard's potential. Few projects have gone beyond the pilot stage. But the financial services and transport companies in particular, are keen to push their existing credit, debit, cash and travel cards as multiple-application cards, in part to justify the expense of implementing the costly microchips. The cost of smart chips ranges from 60p to £11.00, compared with 4p-50p for magnetic stripes. Mondex, a consortium including HSBC, NatWest and Royal Bank of Scotland, is running trials on multiple-application cards at Nottingham and Exeter universities.

These function as a stu dent card, a library card, an electronic key to campus buildings, a club membership card and e-cash. This allows smartcards to be loaded electronically with cash and used instead of money at participating shops. VisaCash, a competing initiative set up by Visa, is trying out a similar card at the University of Leeds.

The first nationwide multiple-application smartcard will be launched in Manchester in the spring, backed by bus and train operator Stagecoach. This will eventually target 20 million UK travellers, operating initially as a travel pass and an electronic cash card which can be used at retailers, vending machines, parking meters and telephone boxes. Stagecoach is looking to add further applications as the card gathers momentum.

Experts say that though there is clear demand for a universal smartcard, it could be a while before one emerges, even though the technology already exists.

Richard Poynder, chairman of industry group the smartcard Club, says: 'Initially there will be a host of multiple-application smartcards using a range of different operating systems. This will defeat the object of having one card that does everything. But in time one or two cards will emerge as winners, and they will operate on a single operating system.'

Poynder predicts that people will end up holding three or four multiple-application smartcards which correspond to different parts of their lives. A person may hold cards dedicated to lifestyle, payments, private details and, say, the weekend, says Poynder.

'I think that trusted high street brands such as Vir gin and Boots will in time become the chief suppliers of branded smartcards rather than, say, the banks. But eventually I think we will see shops selling blank, unbranded cards off the shelf, which you go away and fill up with data from American Express, Visa or whoever.'

Ultimately, the mobile phone could become the master multiple-application smartcard. Mobile phones already need a smart id card in order to function and are just begin ning to offer Internet access. It won't be long, for example, before you can access the Internet, find a book at an online bookshop and pay for it securely - all through your smart mobile.

And with IT geeks dreaming up new mobile-phone applications on a daily basis, the potential to exploit the smartcard that powers the handset seems almost limitless.

 Tom Bawden is a financial services reporter for Marketing Week

fields.headline: When you need a counsellor
fields.standfirst: Colin Frier went in search of financial advice and came back empty-handed. But at least no one tried to fleece him...
fields.trailText: Colin Frier went in search of financial advice and came back empty-handed. But at least no one tried to fleece him...
fields.body:
'You need to see a counsellor.' The words take a few seconds to sink in. Have I come to the wrong place? Granted I'm feeling on the edge of a financial breakdown, but I'm hardly a case for the Samaritans - at least not yet. On the other hand, maybe the smartly dressed woman staring quizzically at me across the desk is trying to tell me something.

After all, what type of individual willingly puts himself in the hands of an industry that is paying out billions to cover the cost of mis-sold pension policies? A sector in which visits made by the regulatory body, the Financial Services Authority, at the beginning of 1999, found that sales of endowment mortgages could be justified in only 20 per cent of cases. So maybe she's right and it's my head, not my finances, that need examining.

So why here and why now? Why share my most intimate financial secrets with a stranger? Well my life's changing. I'm about to throw myself on the vagaries of the labour market to work freelance part time. And such seismic shifts, as well as my age, have got me worrying about my financial future - mainly along the lines of whether I have one.

So now I find myself in the offices of one of the UK's largest independent financial advisers, part of Bradford & Bingley building society, determined, above all, not to become just another industry statistic to add to the pile of misinformation and misfortune. The bottom line is that I need expert and impartial financial advice, and this seems as good a place as any to start.

But there are some key questions, such as: what's in it for them? My friendly adviser tells me that the consultation is free; although if I purchase a mortgage or pension policy the commission goes to the company.

As an independent financial adviser rather than an agent tied to a particular insurance company, she is legally obliged to find the product best suited to my needs from across the market. And she must disclose the details of any commission or management charges.

After establishing that my adviser meant I seek debt counselling rather than psychiatric help, we're getting on fine. But it seems that my financial circumstances - a mediocre but steady income becoming a meagre, intermittent and semi-aspirational one - mean I can't afford to purchase any new financial products. And having already cut my costs to the bone, I'm as lean and mean as any man can get without financially evaporating. Apparently I'm downsizing, which I thought only happened to companies.

This search for financial advice could become contagious. Or maybe I'm just not showing free advice enough respect.

So where next? Fashionable Islington, and the offices of Bolt Burdon Solicitors, whose independent financial advisers are among the 15,000 solicitors and accountants authorised by their professional bodies - in this case the Law Society - to give financial advice.

On the wall two Jackson Pollock lookalikes. And then Jason: tall, grey suited, with his dependable deliberate Scottish drawl, financial probity emanating from every buttonhole.

Jason's got my form in front of him containing my minimalist financial circumstances. But what has he got to say? That today's meeting is free because he won't be offering any financial advice. Afterwards he will prepare a report summarising our meeting, and giving a general indication of the typical costs and benefits of products meeting my requirements.

As Jason works in a solicitor's practice, charges are fee-based with any commission belonging to the client, and going into the company's client account. Any such commission is then used to offset fees. If the commission is higher than the fee, Jason could end up paying me money - now there's a thought. But with hourly charging rates between £45 for a clerk and £85 for a partner, the likelihood of this remains to be seen.

The trouble with money is its close relationship with time, and mine's up: or as Jason puts it: 'There's a lot of busy people out there.' So am I any closer to financial peace of mind? Not really.

It's now 2:30am. I'm sitting among the cyberpeople in a West End Internet cafe. I feel I'm making progress: I've found a web site called www.iii.co.uk with 350,000 pages. Eventually I find a page which allows me to e-mail my financial symptoms to a panel of e-advisers. A week later still no reply. Don't they realise I'm going through a financial crisis?

I find myself facing an e-form on the ifadirect.co.uk web site which asks me to complete my financial details. I'm dissuaded by its length and the legal and financial implications of clicking that mouse. I send an email to their contact point.

Two days later I receive a reply outlining the company's terms of business. Perhaps this is the future for independent financial advice, but personally, any financial adviser frank enough to tell me to come back in six months when my life's sorted out has got be trustworthy.

And with talk this cheap, I think I might.

As Jason works in a solicitor's practice, charges are fee-based with any commission belonging to the client, and going into the company's client account. Any such commission is then used to offset fees. If the commission is higher than the fee, Jason could end up paying me money - now there's a thought. But with hourly charging rates between £45 for a clerk and £85 for a partner, the likelihood of this remains to be seen. The trouble with money is its close relationship with time, and mine's up: or as Jason puts it: 'There's a lot of busy people out there.' So am I any closer to financial peace of mind? Not really. It's now 2:30am. I'm sitting among the cyberpeople in a West End Internet cafe. I feel I'm making progress: I've found a web site called www.iii.co.uk with 350,000 pages. Eventually I find a page which allows me to e-mail my financial symptoms to a panel of e-advisers. A week later still no reply. Don't they realise I'm going through a financial crisis? I find myself facing an e-form on the ifadirect.co.uk web site which asks me to complete my financial details. I'm dissuaded by its length and the legal and financial implications of clicking that mouse. I send an email to their contact point. Two days later I receive a reply outlining the company's terms of business. Perhaps this is the future for independent financial advice, but personally, any financial adviser frank enough to tell me to come back in six months when my life's sorted out has got be trustworthy. And with talk this cheap, I think I might.

webTitle: How to pick the league champions

fields.headline: How to pick the league champions
fields.standfirst: In the absence of past performance figures, what should buyers look for in an investment?  Toby Walne investigates
fields.trailText: In the absence of past performance figures, what should buyers look for in an investment? Toby Walne investigates
fields.body:
The league tables of financial product providers that are supposed to protect consumers from city slickers will exclude the information investors rely most heavily on: past performance.

The Financial Services Authority will use charges and ease of understanding in applying the quality benchmark to investments. But it fears consumers place far too much value on how well an investment has done historically, so has decided to accept in practice the adage that past performance is no guide to future success.

However, most of us still cling to historic performance as an important guideline when choosing an investment such as an Isa or a unit or investment trust.

Fund managers appear all too keen to exploit this weakness for figures by offering sparkling statistics in their advertisements highlighting their investments' good points.

But how far can we trust the sugar-coated boasts made in a fund manager's slick ad?

Phil Telford, researcher for the Consumers' Association, publisher of Which? magazine, said: 'We certainly believe the league tables should include past performance because people are always going to be interested in this figure.

'It may not offer an accurate prediction for the future, but the fact is past performance offers a useful indi cator. Other factors, such as charges, should always be considered when making any decision.'

But Telford warns customers to be wary of the way ads brag of past performance successes. He suggests savers look to the financial pages of national newspapers, and specialist money magazines, to compare the boasts of investment houses with more level-headed tables before making a decision. Websites, such as www.micropal.com and trustnet.co.uk, can also offer comparative help.

A favourite trick of fund managers is to manipulate statistics to show they have the best product. Managers may display, as Fidelity Investments did recently, a grid of first-place rankings for a range of funds. Readers who took a second look will have seen that the funds were in the upper quartile among their peers - in the top 25 per cent within a fund sector.

Although a favourable indicator, such information should be greeted with caution. A top-performing fund in a badly performing sector may merely be the best of a bad bunch - and this cer tainly does not guarantee that it will grow well in the future. Fund managers also tend to pick performance over the most favourable timescales as a way of wooing potential customers.

Another practice to be wary of is the comparison of investment funds with other savings. Fleming Asset Management boasted in a recent ad that £1,000 could have grown to £35,598 in an average Fleming Investment Trust over 20 years compared with £6,597 if it had been put into a building society account.

Telford believes it is particularly misleading to compare such investments with building society accounts. Unlike investment trusts, a building society deposit account does not put your capital at risk and you can get at your money easily.

Investors should also be wary of eye-catching growth figures. Invesco appeared to be offering amazing value for money in a recent ad showing a whopping 419 per cent surge in value for its Japan Discovery investment trust for the year ending 5 November. It failed to point out that the price of such incredible growth was a risk of volatility. The previous year the value of Japan Discovery actually fell - plunging 30 per cent in value for the year to 2 November 1998, according to Standard & Poor's Micropal figures.

The figures used in ads are taken from data collectors such as Standard & Poor's Micropal. Any statistics used can generally be trusted, because the financial services industry is highly regulated. But it is the context in which such figures are used that should be treated with caution. Last year, Jupiter attacked Perpetual for claiming that it was the fund management group of the year. Perpetual later pulled the ad, although it says the comments from Jupiter had not influenced this.

Jupiter sales and marketing director Steve Glynn said: 'No one company can be fund manager company of the year. It is like claiming to be the brainiest person in Britain: how do you prove it?'

Glynn admits customers should be wary about marketing, but points out the information given will rarely be inaccurate; rather it offers a biased point of view, so should be treated as such. He adds: 'The vast majority of ads use just a small amount of information to attract the customer's attention - that is the job of the ad. You should then seek advice before deciding what to do.'

The Advertising Standards Authority (ASA) tries to ensure that all ads supply correct information and do not mislead customers.

ASA spokesman Steve Ballinger said: 'In a very competitive market such as fund management, the big companies will only use hard evidence to back up claims because it could be very damaging for them to receive adverse publicity through having used incorrect information.'

He says anyone who feels an advert has overstepped the mark should write to the authority, enclosing a copy of the ad: Advertising Standards Authority, 2 Torrington Place, London, WC1E 7HW.

fields.headline: Could trackers lose the scent?
fields.trailText: Your investments
fields.body:
Which is riskier - to have 10 per cent of your savings in the shares of just one company, or to miss out on the excitement of the latest investment fad?

The question is becoming pertinent as mega-mergers and technology fever create corporate titans. Already, BP Amoco accounts for almost 9 per cent of the FT All-Share index, and Vodafone 7 per cent. The two are on course to account for 20 per cent following Vodafone's takeover of Mannesmann and BP Amoco's planned deal with Arco.

Add a combined GlaxoWellcome and SmithKline Beecham, and just three companies would represent a quarter of the market, and close to a third of the FTSE 100 Index. Individual companies have dominated the index in the past - BP represented 9 per cent of the All-Share in 1979 - but the emergence of a few giants is unprecedented.

Does this matter? It depends on who you talk to. Some investment experts, such as Standard Life and independent adviser Best Investment, say the concentration means supposedly low risk funds designed to track the index have become very risky. An unexpected disaster at BP or a shift in sentiment about the future of telephony could cause huge swings in the indices, and thus in the price of funds tracking them.

The problem is exacerbated by the fact that some of the most fashionable shares, such as ARM Holdings or Energis, have only a limited proportion of their share capital available to the public. Tracker funds have to scramble to buy the few shares available, or invest in similar rivals as a proxy, which push prices up further. Standard Life is concerned that this has driven some shares to extreme, unsustainable, valuations.

Those who run trackers, such as Legal & General or Scottish Widows, say the risk is in being out of these companies. They will be a big part of an investors' portfolio but they are also a big part of the market. It is less risky to have 10 per cent of your funds in something representing 10 per cent of the market than to have 10 per cent of your funds in something which is just 1 per cent of the market - as some actively managed funds do.

For the past few years, the trackers have had the best of the argument. The large and fashionable have powered ahead and the rest have been left far behind - L & G calculated that the top quarter of the FTSE 100 rose by 28 per cent last year while the bottom quarter fell by 33 per cent. Trackers, whose performance should be around average, have been appearing at the top of the league tables while active managers have done badly. If Standard Life is right that the current valuations are unsustainable, that could reverse as prices of some of the fashionable stocks fall.

For investors, there is really only one lesson in this debate: investing in the stock market, through trackers or through actively managed funds, is always risky.

webTitle: More care on the way for carers

fields.headline: More care on the way for carers
fields.standfirst: Funds will be available for breaks, holidays, or mobile phones, says  Neasa  MacErlean
fields.trailText: Funds will be available for breaks, holidays, or mobile phones, says Neasa MacErlean
fields.body:
An hour off a week for a pint and a game of dominoes does not seem much to ask. But for someone caring full-time for a relative, it may be impossible without help.

Ray Slamon, carers' officer for Tameside in Greater Manchester, helped a retired man who looks after his wife. 'We had been providing a helper two hours a week so he can go shopping. When I saw him recently I asked if there was any other help he wanted,' says Slamon. 'He said: "I'd love an extra hour's help for a pint and a game of dominoes." We did that, and it gave him a social life again. It costs us about £6.40 a week.'

Slamon was one of the people Tom Pendry, a local MP, consulted when he drew up his Carers and Disabled Children Bill, launched last week with Government support. The Bill, expected to be law by the end of the year, will make it easier for the country's 6 million carers to get support. According to the Department of Health, help could include 'home helps, fares, and mobile phones or pagers to help them stay in touch'.

The motives are not just altruistic, says Slamon: 'A lot of carers become patients: their own health deteriorates. But the more help you can give them, even in small ways, the longer they can provide that care. By giving that man the extra hour, it's given him a boost that is incalculable in money.'

The Bill introduces the right for a carer to be assessed in their own right by their local authority. At the moment, the carer cannot get an assessment unless the person they are looking after wants one. And frequently the one being cared for does not want an assessment because they do not know how much their carer is suffering, or maybe because they feel there is a stigma attached to help from the local authority.

Help the Aged and the Carers' National Association broadly welcome the Bill, but will lobby hard to have it reworded so that local authorities pay the bills. As it is now, a council will have the discretion to charge for help.

'It was not my intention that carers should be charged,' says Pendry.

Some more imaginative councils are already doing preventative work to help carers. Pendry says: 'The help is very patchy. With the Bill in place, a great deal of moral pressure could be applied.'

Tameside's own Carers' Centre provides - and pays for - holidays for carers, day trips away and Christmas parties. Slamon says social services departments will need to work closely with their clients to get the right package of services: 'Instead of paying for the carer to get away for a fortnight, they may discover that the carer really wants to go on holiday and take Mum with him.'

The Bill will give greater control to carers - whether they are looking after adults or children - to manage the budget for their care package. It allows local authorities 'to make direct payments for carers in respect of carers' services'. So instead of using the home help offered by the council, someone might employ a neighbour who could provide a more flexible service because they live nearby.

Although the Government has dragged its feet in addressing the issues raised by the Royal Commission on Long-Term Care for the Elderly, its support for this Bill is promising, according to Mervyn Kohler of Help the Aged: 'The Government is recognising that it has to do something more for the elderly population.'

 The Carers' National Association helpline is 0808-808 7777.

fields.headline: New order in Auld Reekie
fields.standfirst: Falling sales mean The Scotsman needs a new direction, says  Arnold Kemp
fields.trailText: The party that gathered in Edinburgh's Café Royal on Thursday night had the quality of a wake. Friends had come to say farewell to Alan Ruddock, the affable Irishman who had edited the Scotsman for two years and, on Wednesday, had become the sixth man to leave the chair in as many years.
fields.body:
The party that gathered in Edinburgh's Café Royal on Thursday night had the quality of a wake. Friends had come to say farewell to Alan Ruddock, the affable Irishman who had edited the Scotsman for two years and, on Wednesday, had become the sixth man to leave the chair in as many years.

After watching Ireland play England at Twickenham yesterday, he went home to Dublin, He had been commuting from the Irish capital throughout his editorship, spending Monday to Friday in Edinburgh and heading home for family weekends. Although he maintained a reticent dignity, friends say he was quietly angry.

Ruddock, a former Sunday Times executive, acquired many friends and admirers because of his gentle nature and fair-minded, reflective journalism.

Many among those who said goodbye to him on Thursday were convinced that he was paying the price for the failure of his boss, Andrew Neil, former editor of the Sunday Times and now the grandiosely styled 'publisher' of Scotsman Publications, owned by the Barclay twins.

Friends say the two men have barely spoken to each other for a month. Some go further and assert that Neil, whatever his qualities as a journalist and editor, was a manager who ruled by fear and dogma. He may have lost patience with Ruddock because the Irishman, for all his gentleness, has a stubborn streak and refused to yield on central strategic questions.

The changes announced by Neil last week compounded the uncertainty surrounding the title by saying that although the appointment of Tim Luckhurst, Ruddock's deputy, as editor was provisional he 'hoped' to make it permanent. Luckhurst, with relatively little newspaper experience, is evidently on trial.

The developing estrangement between Ruddock and Neil came to a head in January, when sales figures for December became available. They showed that the Scotsman , which sold almost 100,000 in 1979, was down to 72,000 for the month and 78,000 for the year, a decline of 3.5 per cent against a market fall of 1.5 per cent.

Neil's critics point in particular to his failure until recently to make any significant investment in sales and marketing. Other titles in the house - the Evening News and Scotland on Sunday - are also underperforming a slowly declining market.

Editorially an insider said: 'Andrew Neil is the problem. He appears to loathe his own country.' Under the first years of his leadership, when he was editor-in-chief, the paper took a shift to the right and acquired a sometimes rabid and even vicious tone. Neil is an anguished Unionist who hated devolution, and the paper has sent out confusing signals about the new Scottish parliament, an institution of which Edinburgh wants to be proud.

It reviled core elements in the Scotsman's readership - notably teachers, of whom there are 50,000 in Scotland. A senior staffer, speaking on condition of anonymity, said: 'I meet too many teachers, and lawyers and social workers who have stopped reading the Scotsman .'

But friends of Ruddock say this perception no longer chimes with reality and is essentially a legacy of the brilliant but wayward Martin Clarke's tenure of as editor's in 1997 and 1998. Conflict about the paper's strategic mission led to Ruddock's departure. He wanted to build it over the years into a national and international paper for Scotland - an Irish Times for Scotland, a friend said, but 'not so boring'. Neil is said to want the paper to be like the New York Times - a paper for the city and the world.

Critics say that the Scotsman , in lifting its eyes to wider horizons, neglected its own back yard. A competitor said: 'The Scotsman's agenda has been sub- Daily Mail , even sub- Evening Standard , dominated by metropolitan values. If you wanted to keep up to date with Edinburgh issues, you'd look in vain.'

Like many an editor before him who had a pan-Scottish vision, Ruddock was confronted by the essentially regional nature of the Scottish morning press. Among the broadsheets the Scotsman and the Herald circulate throughout Scotland but are rooted in their cities. The Herald, like the Press & Journal in Aberdeen and the Courier in Dundee, have continued to nourish their roots and fared better.

Under Clarke, now editor of the struggling Daily Record in Glasgow, the Scotsman infamously spent £1 million on a Glasgow campaign that produced an extra sale of 300 copies. Clarke's legacy to the paper was not only the rebarbative tone which it has been trying to live down but, insiders say, a £1m editorial budget deficit.

A colleague said: 'Clarke was groomed on the Daily Mail and is a brilliant newsman. But he has no political sophistication. He is a streetfighter who gets caught up in a perpetual series of brawls.'

Competitors note that the Record under Clarke is sometimes brilliant but uneven - a reflection, they believe, of Clarke's own character. He has mounted a vociferous campaign against the repeal of Section 28 in particular and the Scottish Executive in general. First Minister Donald Dewar is portrayed as a fumbling Dad's Army character.

This sundering of the Record's close and amicable relationship with Labour not only reflects Clarke's right-wing instincts but also his alarm at the rise in sales of the Sun , which flirts with the SNP, and the inexorable decline of the Record , which only a few years ago sold more than 700,000 copies a day.

Neil, it is said, is now determined to press on with his new vision for the Scotsman . An incipient 'metro page' last Monday was the first sign of the impending change of emphasis. Ruddock declined to embrace this new approach, which is to be the theme of the paper's relaunch in the spring.

Compared with the metro section of the New York Times , with its powerful newsroom and team of writers, the metro concept is a puny presence in a paper which in the past seamlessly stitched together its various areas of interest. It was, after all, founded in 1817 specifically as a vehicle to protest against conditions in the local infirmary.

The Barclay brothers have poured millions into the Scotsman . Last month the company moved into 'palatial' new offices near the parliament site at Holyrood.

Now, insiders say the brothers are worried that their investment is producing no return, only mounting costs and falling market share. Neil's own reputation is firmly on the line.

If you wanted to keep up to date with Edinburgh issues, you'd look in vain.' Like many an editor before him who had a pan-Scottish vision, Ruddock was confronted by the essentially regional nature of the Scottish morning press. Among the broadsheets the Scotsman and the Herald circulate throughout Scotland but are rooted in their cities. The Herald, like the Press & Journal in Aberdeen and the Courier in Dundee, have continued to nourish their roots and fared better. Under Clarke, now editor of the struggling Daily Record in Glasgow, the Scotsman infamously spent £1 million on a Glasgow campaign that produced an extra sale of 300 copies. Clarke's legacy to the paper was not only the rebarbative tone which it has been trying to live down but, insiders say, a £1m editorial budget deficit. A colleague said: 'Clarke was groomed on the Daily Mail and is a brilliant newsman. But he has no political sophistication. He is a streetfighter who gets caught up in a perpetual series of brawls.' Competitors note that the Record under Clarke is sometimes brilliant but uneven - a reflection, they believe, of Clarke's own character. He has mounted a vociferous campaign against the repeal of Section 28 in particular and the Scottish Executive in general. First Minister Donald Dewar is portrayed as a fumbling Dad's Army character. This sundering of the Record's close and amicable relationship with Labour not only reflects Clarke's right-wing instincts but also his alarm at the rise in sales of the Sun , which flirts with the SNP, and the inexorable decline of the Record , which only a few years ago sold more than 700,000 copies a day. Neil, it is said, is now determined to press on with his new vision for the Scotsman . An incipient 'metro page' last Monday was the first sign of the impending change of emphasis. Ruddock declined to embrace this new approach, which is to be the theme of the paper's relaunch in the spring. Compared with the metro section of the New York Times , with its powerful newsroom and team of writers, the metro concept is a puny presence in a paper which in the past seamlessly stitched together its various areas of interest. It was, after all, founded in 1817 specifically as a vehicle to protest against conditions in the local infirmary. The Barclay brothers have poured millions into the Scotsman . Last month the company moved into 'palatial' new offices near the parliament site at Holyrood. Now, insiders say the brothers are worried that their investment is producing no return, only mounting costs and falling market share. Neil's own reputation is firmly on the line.

fields.headline: Sound barrier to commercial barrier.
fields.standfirst: Congress tries to keep Concorde out of the Big Apple
fields.trailText: Ooutraged congressmen are calling for a ban on British Airways' supersonic flagship Concorde flying to New York after talks about American access to Heathrow broke down in acrimony last week.
fields.body:
Ooutraged congressmen are calling for a ban on British Airways' supersonic flagship Concorde flying to New York after talks about American access to Heathrow broke down in acrimony last week.

Bud Shuster, chairman of the House of Representatives transport committee, and congressman James Oberstar called on the US government to tear up the aviation agreement with Britain, which restricts access at Heathrow airport to only two US airlines.

They want BA to be prevented from flying to the US, which would require legislation, and Concorde to be banned immediately on the grounds that it is not environment-friendly.

Last week's talks broke down after the UK refused to give any ground that would threaten BA's dominant position in London.

BA is expected tomorrow to announce pre-tax losses of around £90 million for the three months to 31 December, compared with a £42m profit in the third quarter of the previous financial year.
