fields.headline: NatWest faces final clearing house
fields.standfirst: Shareholders will seal the fate of the bank this week, but the choices are not easy, writes Heather Connon
fields.trailText: Shareholders in NatWest, drowning under piles of offer and defence documents, must be desperate for the close of the bid on 14 February. Their irritation is as nothing compared with Bank of Scotland's. Had the issue been settled on 24 September, when it launched its bid for NatWest, it would have romped home with the prize.
fields.body:
Shareholders in NatWest, drowning under piles of offer and defence documents, must be desperate for the close of the bid on 14 February. Their irritation is as nothing compared with Bank of Scotland's. Had the issue been settled on 24 September, when it launched its bid for NatWest, it would have romped home with the prize.

But competition investigations and a late entry by Edinburgh rival Royal Bank of Scotland stretched the already long 60-day bid timetable to an agonising 144 days. That has given all three parties so much time for claim and counter-claim, posturing and muck-spreading that the issues are in danger of becoming obscured. So, it is worth going back to where we stood before Bank of Scotland made its surprise bid four months ago.

Then, NatWest had a well-earned reputation as Britain's worst bank. For years, its managers had embarked on a series of ambitious strategies - build a US banking network, create a top five investment bank, establish itself as a leading fund manager - which quickly unraveled. The result was a dismal record of falling profits and the destruction of billions of pounds of shareholder value.

The final straw for investors was the agreed merger with Legal & General. NatWest had agreed to pay an inflated price for the insurer, to test the concept of bancassurance - always viewed with great scepticism in Britain - and to get its much admired chief executive onto its board.

The result was bang in line with NatWest's record. More than £3 billion was wiped off its market value, and unhappy shareholders were threatening a revolt. That was the catalyst for the Bank of Scotland bid. Nineteen weeks on, the positions of both parties have changed dramatically.

NatWest has made a remarkable recovery, and its defence is seen as sufficiently creditable to give it a chance of escaping the clutches of the two Scottish banks.

Bank of Scotland, on the other hand, has run a lacklustre campaign. Few would dispute its excellent record, but it has failed to convince the City that it can use that record to transform NatWest.

Royal Bank made the most of its late entrance and seemed the more dynamic. However, it has said nothing of substance since it launched the bid, relying on creating an aura of a dynamic, international bank without producing the evidence to support it.

As the battle enters its final week, it is worth examining the position of the three players. NatWest's defence has been built on three planks. First, and most important, it has installed a new management team - it was clearly impossible to conduct a decent defence with Derek Wanless as chief executive. In his place, Sir David brought in Ron Sandler, who helped him push through the restructuring of the Lloyd's insurance market. That was followed with the recruitment of Gordon Pell, from Lloyds TSB, to head the UK retail bank.

Second, it has drawn the City's attention to the fact that, for all the grandiose claims by bidders, the risks of mergers and takeovers are high. A table in its final defence document analysing 10 bank mergers in the US, is telling. All of them failed to meet the profit target implicit in the promise of synergy benefits, and eight of the 10 have underperformed the relevant bank index since the merger.

Third, it has promised more cost cuts and bigger job losses - 15,000 people are to go and 525 million is to be saved. Last week, it said that, had these savings been achieved last year, pro-forma profits of the new NatWest - that is after disposals - would have been £2.3bn, compared with the £1.8bn actually reported.

Then, it is promising to increase revenue. Unlike the Scottish banks, NatWest has not tied itself to a target. Instead, it points out that, if it matched the average of its top six competitors, it would add £217m of income. If it emulated the best performer, that would rise to £612m.

Any of NatWest's shareholders could have told the bank that its problems stem from its inability to generate income and control costs. Whether shareholders should believe NatWest's promise that it will be different this time depends on their opinion of the new management team.

Sir David has certainly been an impressive general, but his record before the bid was hardly impressive. It was clear when he became chairman last April that Wanless was not up to the job as chief executive. But Sir David kept him on, although his role would have been reduced if the L & G deal had gone ahead.

As damaging was the L & G deal itself. That was Sir David's idea, and it has been universally slated. It may, as some suggest, have been a way of sidelining Wanless and attracting a talented boss for the bank. How much easier it would have been to sack him and employ headhunters.

Sandler has been much less prominent during the bid - he has, apparently, been too busy running the bank. Analysts complain that he is not a banker - but Wanless was and that did not help him. More telling is his lack of experience in industry: saving Lloyd's from angry names is an impressive accomplishment but it is not the same as running a clearing bank.

Some suggest that, even if NatWest keeps its independence, Sandler's appointment will end soon after the bid, and Pell will replace him.

On the face of it, Pell would be better suited to the job. He is a banker and Lloyds TSB is the City's favourite bank, with an impressive record of revenue generation and tight cost control. The problem is, everyone attributes that to chairman Sir Brian Pitman - even chief executive Peter Ellwood does not get a look-in. Pell may be able to transfer some of LloydsTSB's magic to NatWest, but we will not know for certain until long after the two Scots bidders have disappeared.

NatWest's real trump card is its warning about the risks of mergers. There have been enough learned studies of the subject to show that the majority of mergers do not live up to their promise, but investors are too often happy to ignore the evidence and vote with the acquiror. The Scottish banks have failed to answer this point other than to say that the quality of their management means this time it will be different.

How good, then, are the management teams? Neither has been involved in a deal anywhere near the size of this one, so their ability to integrate a business twice their size has not been tested.

Royal Bank claims that BoS is simply a Scottish bank with some efficient methods of winning business in England while it is more of a financial conglomerate, with interests in everything from train leasing to US banking and insurance. It even claims a European business, although this is limited to having BSCH as its main shareholder.

It acknowledges that BoS is more efficient but says this is because BoS has no English branches and a different business mix. And it points out that while BoS has a very low cost-income ratio - the measure of banking efficiency - it has stayed that way for years while Royal has been getting more efficient.

It points to its success in with Citizens, through 17 acquisitions in eight years, as well as recent deals such as Green Flag and Angel Trains.

Bank of Scotland's acquisition record is even less extensive. It bought and rather quickly sold a business in New Zealand and looks set to do the same with BankWest in Australia. It points out that neither deal has lost it money, but that hardly enhances its reputation for acquisitions.

Bank of Scotland's case rests on its record of expanding its own income while keeping costs in check. Its performance has been impressive. But its plans for exporting those skills to NatWest came across as muddled. Its strategy is to make NatWest's branches smaller, friendlier and more effective for selling products. But it has failed to convince.

Of NatWest's 1,700 branches, only 274 will be left unchanged. Of the remainder, more than half will be modernised, 523 will be moved elsewhere, 36 will close and a further 125 will be opened to fill gaps in the network.

It has already carried out this exercise with its own network and says that it results in an average increase in revenue of 18 per cent. It has used a more conservative estimate of 10 per cent to calculate the extra income it can generate.

However, there is no guarantee that it will keep its existing customers, let alone attract enough new ones to meet its revenue targets.

Royal's revenue claims are no more certain, relying largely on cross-selling products from within the retail and corporate banking business and from the Direct Line insurance operation.

BoS, Royal and NatWest would need at least a year to demonstrate how well or badly they can fulfil their promises. Shareholders do not have that long. They have to decide this week. NatWest is coming under increasing pressure to recommend one or other bid, but it is in no better a position to judge than its shareholders. Without that guidance, it is impossible to judge which way the battle will go.

webTitle: AA suffers a breakdown over windfall

fields.headline: AA suffers a breakdown over windfall
fields.standfirst: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.trailText: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.body:
I applied for AA membership in February 1998 by telephone, using my credit card, which was debited. A few days later, I received the application form, which showed that a joint membership for my wife named someone completely different at the wrong address.

As my wife was about to make a long journey, I rang to check the temporary membership number I had been given, but it was not recognised. I did not receive my official full membership until October 1999.

Now I have been refused a Centrica windfall payment. When I appealed, I was told that the criteria are clearly set out in the AA's rules, and that its external lawyers have advised that there can be no exceptions. Have I a legitimate claim?
JK, Nottingham

Your case seems clear: you paid for your own membership within the time to qualify for a payout. Not only was the AA in a mess over setting up your membership; it has been equally muddled over your right to a windfall.

It did, though, agree to give your case further consideration and launched what turned out to be a long investigation. The result of taking a closer look at your file is that the AA admits it made a mistake. It agrees that you are entitled to the money, and a cheque for £248.56 is on its way to you.

As to what went wrong at the outset, the AA calls it 'an administrative error'.

Standing order: Fees went on
In February 1997, my husband signed a direct debit form for our joint membership of a local leisure club, payable to a finance company. Last year, the club was taken over. Foolishly, we did not check that we were no longer paying out each month, and the firm continued to take the money until November.

It now refuses to return the overpayment as it says the mandate was signed 'until further notice'. The copy it has sent us shows this to be the case, but the same form says we will pay so much a month for two years, which is confusing.

We asked our bank, HSBC, to help, but the branch said it could only write and request the money back. We know this is due to our own mistake, but can't afford to lose the £350 involved.
HJ, Gateshead

The key point is that your husband did not sign a direct debit mandate, but a stand ing order request. If it had been a direct debit, HSBC would be obliged to sort this out for you because banks have agreed to take responsibility if payees take money they are not entitled to under a direct debit.

But standing orders are under customers' control, so you could stop the payment at any time. HSBC confirms that you were paying 'until further notice' and could cancel at any time. It is unfortunate, though understandable, that you forgot.

As HSBC has had no success getting your money returned and the leisure centre will not co-operate, your last resort is the Small Claims court. Ask your local trading standards department if it has had any complaints from other customers about this firm.

Hire car hassle: Cover surprise
I returned our rented car in the US to be told that we had had no insurance but the minimum State of Arizona cover. Having driven 2,000 miles with my family, I was very upset. We could have had an uninsured accident.

I wrote to ask the firm in Phoenix for compensation, but heard nothing. Should I pursue this?
WD, London

No. This did not spoil your holiday so you should ask yourself what you want compensation for. All the company has to do is make sure you buy the legal minimum amount of cover. Certainly it was scary to realise what might have been but, even if you had had an accident, you are unlikely to have a case for compensation. You have learnt a lesson for next time you hire a car abroad, and without financial loss.

Financial advice: Zero help
I contacted independent financial adviser Towry Law, about investing in an Isa and in zero preference shares. I was advised on the Isa but not on zeroes.

The firm has disclosed the commission it will receive on my Isa investment, and I wonder if it is reluctant to advise on zeroes because they do not attract commission. Who can I ask for unbiased advice on them?
AC, Beckenham

Towry Law confirms that it does not advise on zero preference shares because it is 'not a stockbroker and you have to buy them through stockbrokers'.

A few advisers are qualified to advise on stock market investments, or you can contact a private-client stockbroker. The Association of Private Client Investment Managers and Stockbrokers will send you a list of members with their specialities. Write to 112 Middlesex Street, London E1 7HY.

 Write to Margaret Dibben, Money Writes, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Include a telephone number, but not SAEs or original documents. Letters are selected for publication, and we cannot give personal replies. The paper accepts no legal responsibility for advice.

fields.headline: Railtrack 'to keep safety role'
fields.trailText: Railtrack is expected to remain in charge of safety on the rail network, despite pledges by the Government to strip it of its powers in the aftermath of last year's crash outside Paddington, The Observer has learnt.
fields.byline: by Joanna Walters Transport Business Editor
fields.body:
Railtrack is expected to remain in charge of safety on the rail network, despite pledges by the Government to strip it of its powers in the aftermath of last year's crash outside Paddington, The Observer has learnt.

The Rowlands Report on the company's safety role - handed to Ministers in the last fortnight - is understood to recommend only minor changes to the current regime.

The main thrust of the report is that Railtrack should simply tighten the corporate barriers between its commercial and safety activities and remain in overall charge of day-to-day safety on the network.

The Government is expected to accept the findings, a move which will be interpreted in the City as an important endorsement of the firm's competence and reputation. However, sources close to the Government stress that no final decision had been taken.

But industry observers say that if, as is widely expected, the Government backs down from its tough stance on Railtrack, that would be seen as a reversal of policy.

Louise Christian, of disaster litigation specialists Christian Fisher, the firm acting for victims of the Southall and Paddington rail crashes, said such a decision would be 'absolutely outrageous'. She added that it was clear Railtrack's commercial interests were 'directly opposed' to its safety interests.

It is understood that the Health and Safety Executive (HSE), itself under fire for failing to take a more active stance over safety on the railways, will take over some minor functions from Railtrack.

But the company will keep principal responsibility for safety on the network, provided it hives off its safety directorate into a wholly-owned subsidiary company with its own board of directors.

Industry sources said the safety division would be 'hermetically sealed' from the company's commercial interests.

Roger Ford, editor of Rail Business Intelligence , said: 'The Government is set to do a U-turn on this.' But he added that Railtrack was doing a good job of beefing up its safety role and demanding improvements from the train operators.

These include targets for reducing the number of signals passed at red, and crackdowns on maintenance contractors who leave debris by the tracks that can be used as missiles by vandals.

Ford said: 'John Prescott promised that Railtrack would be stripped of its safety responsibility, but the reality is that Railtrack's safety powers have to grow in order for the railway to get safer.'

Railtrack oversees the safe operation of the passenger and freight network, including signalling, train services and track. Its role is checked by the HSE.

The Rowlands Report on the company's safety role - handed to Ministers in the last fortnight - is understood to recommend only minor changes to the current regime. webTitle: BoS has the edge in NatWest battle

fields.headline: BoS has the edge in NatWest battle
fields.trailText: BIG City shareholders are set to desert NatWest this week in a string of highly public announcements which will see the once mighty English clearing bank fall to a hostile Scots bidder.
fields.byline: by Paul Farrelly and Heather Connon
fields.body:
BIG City shareholders are set to desert NatWest this week in a string of highly public announcements which will see the once mighty English clearing bank fall to a hostile Scots bidder.

Institutions including the Prudential, Mercury, Schroders and PDFM will meet Bank of Scotland and Royal Bank of Scotland in one frantic last round of presentations before taking sides in the £23 billion battle.

By declaring their hands as early as tomorrow or Tuesday, however, the key decision-makers want to create a 'bandwagon effect' to ensure NatWest does not escape through a split vote.

'We're mindful of the need for larger shareholders to give an indication,' one PDFM source said. 'We'll be doing that early next week.'

The top 10 City shareholders control nearly 30 per cent of NatWest shares, with Mercury positioning itself as 'king-maker' through aggressive buying last week. Standard Life and Jupiter are also backing Scots' pleas for NatWest's chairman to recommend one of the bids.

'The situation is very finely balanced. It is important to avoid splitting votes,' said Jupiter fund manager Philip Gibbs.

The bid closes on Valentine's Day after a five-month battle, and this weekend BoS looked to be a nose ahead. Its basic terms were worth £13.80 per NatWest share, against RBS's £13.38 and NatWest's £11.54 closing price last Friday.

The fund managers' decisions will pepper the bid's final week with controversy. RBS's ally, insurer CGU, has already been barred by the Takeover Panel from voting its stake. This week BoS will press for a veto on further share dealing by CGU, which has been a heavy buyer of RBS shares and seller of BoS. Prudential, however, which has struck an insurance deal with BoS, is free to vote.

Mercury, meanwhile, is owned by Wall Street bank Merrill Lynch, one of RBS's advisers. Legal & General also has a grudge against BoS, whose initial hostile bid scuppered its own merger with NatWest.

NatWest refused to be drawn on making any recommendation. 'It is difficult to put a finger on what the institutions want,' said Gordon Pell, its UK banking chief.

RBS has been seen as the favourite throughout, but it disappointed the City with its final bid last Monday by failing to land a knockout blow. Institutions may now give BoS credit for striking first and offering NatWest shareholders a greater stake in the merged group.

fields.headline: Nice to see you, Klaus
fields.standfirst: How an English Gent took the historic Mannesmann surrender.
fields.trailText: FORTRESS Germany fell just before 7pm Central European Time last Wednesday. There were no casualties, and the muted surrender was completed without ceremony. Given the nature of the world's largest hostile corporate takeover - an epic on the scale of Dallas crossed with England's 1966 World Cup victory - it was an anticlimax.
fields.body:
FORTRESS Germany fell just before 7pm Central European Time last Wednesday. There were no casualties, and the muted surrender was completed without ceremony. Given the nature of the world's largest hostile corporate takeover - an epic on the scale of Dallas crossed with England's 1966 World Cup victory - it was an anticlimax.

As Vodafone chief executive Chris Gent walked into Mannesmann's Düsseldorf HQ that night, he could reflect that he was close to making history. No German company had ever fallen to a hostile takeover by a foreign rival.

The effects of what Gent was doing would resonate around the business world and high up in the political stratosphere. Even German Chancellor Gerhard Schröder had publicly supported Mannesmann's independence when he said hostile bids destroyed the culture of companies.

And the fact that Vodafone's prey was Germany's second-largest company, with more than 116,000 employees, and a symbol of the country's industrial heritage made the deal more incredible.

Founded in 1885, Mannesmann started by making steel tubes, and diversified into a number of industries, including chemicals, electronics, and, crucially for Vodafone, telecoms. Its place in German industrial folklore dwarfed that of BMW or Volkswagen.

It was dark when Gent walked into the massive building beside the Rhine to talk to his counterpart Klaus Esser. Few people were around. Esser's office is on the twenty-first floor of the elegant Twenties building, which dominates the skyline. 'Hello Klaus, nice to see you,' Gent said. As they shook hands and started to talk they could see industrial barges on the river below, symbols of Germany's industrial heritage.

Several of Gent's key advisers from Goldman Sachs and Warburg Dillon Read had already been in the building for hours. Mannesmann's advisers, who had plotted through the previous night, sustained by takeaways of Westphalian chicken and potatoes, were cordial in their greetings. 'The negotiations we had were very courteous and professional. Klaus has a good sense of humour and we get on well,' Gent told journalists.

Esser had phoned him the previous day inviting him to the Mannesmann fortress to discuss terms. The deal values the combined company at around £228 billion, fractionally ahead of the value of AOL's merger with Time Warner. Negotiations between Vodafone and Mannesmann advisers reopened at the start of last week following three weeks' silence.

These talks went on until early on Thursday morning and resumed the following day, although some advisers worked all night. Gent himself left the talks to appear on a German television show. He spoke from a small room in the Steigenberger Parkhotel, which was his base. Gent drummed home his belief in the deal's logic, as his advisers thrashed out its framework.

Mannesmann's supervisory board met last Thursday afternoon to discuss the terms, but took no decision. Esser assured Gent that the board would ratify the deal the following day.

Insiders say the main terms were fleshed out almost immediately. The stumbling blocks were minor. One demand was for the Mannesmann name still to be used in Germany; they also worried about how their company's surrender was to be painted. They were keen to highlight Esser's success in securing a much higher price for shareholders than Vodafone had originally offered. As one Mannesmann supporter claimed: 'Esser has created an extra €11.5 billion (about £9bn) in three months. That's not bad going.'

When Vodafone made its original offer just before Christmas, Mannesmann was valued at around £84bn. By the time Esser agreed terms, the value of the all-paper offer had risen to £113bn. Mannesmann's value had risen from €154 a share to €353 a share.

As the minutiae were picked over throughout the following day, Gent left the Mannesmann HQ to visit its Eurokom subsidiary. Throughout Thursday the international press gathered outside the HQ, and his every move was beamed around the world. 'It was like a journalists' Woodstock out there,' said one insider. As Gent stooped to get into a waiting car he paused and, with understated hubris, told the press pack: 'It's nice to be in Düsseldorf.'

Considering the roller-coaster nature of the campaign, there may have been times when Gent considered this visit to Germany unlikely, times when Mannesmann looked like slipping out of his grasp. Earlier this year speculation about a Mannesmann merger with the French utility giant Vivendi had threatened to spoil the Vodafone party. But Gent had acted quickly to break up the potential marriage. Within days Vodafone had teamed up with Vivendi to create an Internet portal, killing Esser's hopes of a white knight defence.

By the start of this month, Esser knew the game was up. His main advisers at Morgan Stanley continued to argue the case for holding out until the last minute of the Vodafone offer period, which would have closed tomorrow. But he came under mounting pressure to cede a deal. As the value of the takeover continued to rise, so did the chances of a lawsuit from disgruntled shareholders if the German boss continued to hold out. As Vodafone agreed to increase its offer marginally, giving Mannesmann's shareholders 49.5 per cent of the company, compared with the original 47.2 per cent, Esser was able to retain a degree of satisfaction at the outcome.

Indeed the whole nature of the takeover campaign could provide a textbook example of the rules of corporate conduct in the future. Gent said: 'It's been a long run, but it's been a pretty friendly hostile takeover.'

However, the relationship between Esser and Gent is damaged. Esser will be an executive director of the new company only until the summer. His main brief will be to oversee the disposal of Mannesmann's engineering and automotive divisions, a task he was to carry out even before the Vodafone deal. After that Esser will switch to being a non-executive deputy chairman; there are doubts over how long he will stay.

The relationship between the two men reached rock bottom early in January when cricket-mad Gent, who was watching England play a Test match against South Africa, mocked his counterpart's love of poetry and chess in preference to sport. Gent's advisers say he was horrified to see the off-the-record remarks in print. However they exemplify Gent's cocksure attitude to the deal. 'We wouldn't have attempted this if we weren't certain that we were going to get a majority,' he said repeatedly.

But for three crucial days last autumn Vodafone's future hung in the balance. Gent was at a conference retreat, Brocket Hall in Welwyn Garden City, when he heard that Mannesmann was negotiating to buy UK rival Orange. The Vodafone chief head had gathered all the heads of his company's global subsidiaries to hear his strategy for creating an Internet platform to link them together. Mannesmann, Gent had always felt, would eventually end up as part of Vodafone. The Orange link-up changed everything.

For three days Gent and his advisers crunched the numbers. Could Vodafone pull off such an audacious coup, one which would eventually make it the world's fourth-largest company after Microsoft, General Electric and Cisco Systems? The eventual decision to launch the bid evolved from a feeling that if Vodafone didn't attempt the impossible it would end up being swallowed by a US predator. For Gent, who had been with Vodafone since 1985, this was unthinkable.

But as he and his army of advisers, who have earned around £400m in fees for their work, toasted their success last Friday night, the enormity of what they had achieved had only just begun to sink in. Perhaps Gent will be mindful of the present given to Olivetti chief executive Roberto Colaninno following his firm's acquisition of Telecom Italia. It was a construction worker's belt, complete with a hammer, wire cutters and a screwdriver. The point is that the hardest work - transforming the new company from a business which allows people to talk into one which offers them a wealth of new media services - starts now. On Friday a cheerful Gent said: 'My diary is filled up with people who want to do deals with us.'

To the victor, the spoils.

It was good to talk

IT WAS a tale of two companies. The grinning face of Vodafone boss Chris Gent on the financial pages last Friday contrasted with the pensive mugshot of BT chief executive Sir Peter Bonfield the day before. In the same week that Vodafone had just completed the world's largest merger, BT shocked the City with interim results at the bottom of expectations. It unveiled plans to axe 3,000 jobs - the latest in a long line of cutbacks. Over the past decade BT has cut its workforce from 245,000 to 137,000.

Vodafone, meanwhile, has moved at breakneck speed securing alliances (Vivendi last week), concluding mergers (AirTouch and Bell Atlantic in the US last year) as well as taking stakes in numerous subsidiaries around Europe and the Far East in a bid to become a global player. It has also been quicker and more forceful in communicating its Internet strategy. All of which has helped drive the value of Vodafone's stock north at a galloping pace, giving the company the firepower to do mega-deals.

BT, meanwhile, is viewed as slow to embrace new technologies. Once it could have been forgiven for not focusing too much on the Internet. After all, its core fixed-wire voice telephone business in the UK was a fantastic earner. But there is much more competition around now, not to mention intervention by watchdog Oftel to keep the costs down. These factors mean BT's staple source of income is under threat, hence the need to embrace new technologies and services, chiefly mobile telephony and the Internet, which will create new earnings streams. Its mobile arm, BT Cellnet, gets the thumbs-up from analysts, but it doesn't have anything like the global reach of a combined Vodafone/Mannesmann. After all, if telecoms is about anything now it's about providing seamless global communication links.

And while other operators have embraced the Internet with gusto, the jury's still out on BT. The problem is, of course, that as this credibility gap widens the value of BT's stock plummets, limiting its ability to do deals. The conventional wisdom is that it needs a merger, and fast. It held exploratory talks with Telefónica late last year, but these fell through. Merger plans with both Cable &Wireless and MCI fell through in 1996. 'BT is cheaper than the sum of its parts,' said Paul Sharma, analyst with JP Morgan. Indeed, BT's share price has risen by only 154 per cent over the past decade, compared with Vodafone's 845 per cent. The question now is: how long before a predator turns on BT?

Jamie Doward and Ben Laurance

webTitle: Now Gent closes on Spanish prey

fields.headline: Now Gent closes on Spanish prey
fields.trailText: Vodafone AirTouch is close to following its historic merger with German conglomerate Mannesmann with a majority holding in Airtel of Spain - a vital piece in its pan-European jigsaw.
fields.body:
Vodafone AirTouch is close to following its historic merger with German conglomerate Mannesmann with a majority holding in Airtel of Spain - a vital piece in its pan-European jigsaw.

This new success would be another setback for British Telecom, which wants to increase its stake in Spain's second-largest mobile phone operator. Airtel has around 2.1 million customers. BT's share price fell 18 per cent last Wednesday after it reported disappointing results.

Vodafone, the UK's largest mobile phone operator, owns nearly 22 per cent of Airtel, but is negotiating for a 30 per cent holding owned by a cluster of Spanish institutional shareholders.

Vodafone chief executive Chris Gent said: 'We expect to announce something in the next month. We understand the Spanish shareholders' preference is a deal with us.'

In addition to securing a majority interest in Spain, Gent hinted that a number of other deals were in the pipeline. 'My diary is full of people who want to do deals with us,' he said.

The merger with Mannesmann, which will create the world's fourth-largest company and see the German firm's shareholders owning 49.5 per cent of the combined business, leaves a question mark over the future of Orange, the UK's third-largest mobile phone operator. Orange is part of Mannesmann, but under competition rules it will have to be sold off.

Vodafone is looking to demerge Orange, but it is unlikely to stay independent for long. Several companies, including KPN of Holland, France Télécom and SBC Ameritech of the US, are known to be circling.

Analysts have speculated about what the mega merger means for other telecoms companies, notably BT. 'It undoubtedly means more consolidation in the sector. Other organisations are going to have to respond' said Mike Grant, of telecoms consul tancy Analysys.

'The issue for BT is that it's got lots of minority stakes. People are looking for BT to reassert itself,' said Paul Sharma at JP Morgan.

BT held exploratory talks with Spain's Telefónica late last year, and the City is betting that these will be reactivated. Another option would be for BT to increase its holding in Viag Intercom, the German telecoms firm in which it holds a 95 per cent stake.

webTitle: Storming ICI aims for returns in the top four

fields.headline: Storming ICI aims for returns in the top four
fields.trailText: Imperial Chemical Industries does not have a reputation of pulling rabbits out of hats to get itself out of scrapes - much as its shareholders may wish that it could - so it seems likely that the storming performance in the fourth quarter of last year was really because customers were buying more.
fields.body:
Imperial Chemical Industries does not have a reputation of pulling rabbits out of hats to get itself out of scrapes - much as its shareholders may wish that it could - so it seems likely that the storming performance in the fourth quarter of last year was really because customers were buying more.

The question is, can such growth continue? Even the ebullient Brendan O'Neill, chief executive, is not promising that he can carry on increasing pre-tax profits at the 90 per cent rate seen in the last quarter. But he says that, so far, there is little sign of the slowdown that would suggest last year's growth was largely due to millennium bug stockpiling.

What is certain, however, is that the company will have to produce a lot more good results if its senior executives are ever to get the benefits of its new performance scheme.

Like rivals such as Unilever, chairman Charles Miller Smith's alma mater, it has decided to benchmark its performance against 16 of its its peers - excluding former rivals such as Du Pont and BASF, now much more heavily in bulk chemicals than ICI, but including specialists such as Clariant and Henkel.

Its aim is to produce shareholder returns above the average for the group and, ideally, in the top four. If it succeeds, shareholders will be richly rewarded. It estimates that, if it achieves this for the next five years, an above-average performance will produce £2 billion extra value; if it gets to the top four, that will rise to £3bn.

If past performance is anything to go by, it will struggle. Over the last five years, its returns have been just 2 per cent against 12 per cent for the best-in-class, although last year, it was well ahead.

Boosting shareholder returns that much will, of course, be even harder if the dividend is cut. It was maintained, as expected, last year but the inference from O'Neill's comments is that a cut is on the cards. As a long-term average, his aim is to have the dividend covered 2.5 times by profits. That has been a rarity in the past 10 years.

A historic yield of more than 6.5 per cent shows that a cut is firmly factored into the calculations - indeed, confirmation could actually spark a rise, particularly if it means ICI has more available to invest. The only complaint is that it was not done earlier.

Take a cruise

DEMERGERS have had a bit of a bad press recently as splits such as Thorn EMI and BAT have failed to unlock a great store of hidden value. P&O's proposal to hive off its cruise business could be one of the exceptions.

Lord Sterling and his colleagues chant the usual mantra of giving the two businesses freedom to develop on their own, and it is certainly true that the only thing owning ports, ferries and container ships has in common with cruise liners is the sea. But the real reason for the demerger is that, no matter how hard it has tried, P&O has failed to get its share rating anywhere near that of US rivals Royal Caribbean and Carnival. And it hopes that an independent cruise business - working title P&O Princess, although the name has yet to be decided - will finally get the rating it deserves.

The leap in its share price following the announcement goes some way towards achieving that. There could be further to go. The more bullish analysts suggest that the cruise business, with £0.5 billion of debt, could be worth £6.2 billion or 930p a share - 100p above P&O's price before the demerger. Add, say, £2.5bn for the other businesses and the two halves could easily be worth 1,300p.

There are caveats. A dive in the US economy - and more especially a stock market correction - could hit demand for cruises. The pace of expansion in capacity has also stepped up from an average of 9 per cent a year to 12 per cent a year. So far, that is easily being absorbed by increased demand. That cannot continue forever.

Do not underestimate the remaining business. P&O's restructuring has made it highly efficient and effective and it could reap more benefits from further restructuring in the industry. The shares already reflect some of the demerger gains but it is still worth tucking them away.

Jam today

WHAT DOES Invensys have to do to boost its share price? Last week's presentation was as impressive as anyone could have wished, yet the shares were largely unmoved. This is a classic case of investors ignoring value now in their frenzied quest for growth in the future.

Chief executive Allen Yurko spelled out the case for investing pretty clearly. Invensys is promising to improve productivity by 5 per cent a year, and annual sales by a similar amount, even without acquisitions. Costs will also fall as it continues its policy of shifting operations to cheaper countries, such as Malaysia and the Czech Republic - it already has 20 per cent of its workforce in such areas and that will rise to 28 per cent within two years.

The result is that operating profits will grow by at least 10 per cent a year, and the business will generate at least 5 per cent of that growing profit stream in cash.

Of course, promising is not delivering. The sceptics are more concerned about the pace and proceeds of disposals and the competitive position of the businesses that are left. These concerns are unjustified. About 80 per cent of the businesses earmarked for disposals when BTR and Siebe merged to create Invensys have been sold, at slightly more than book value. They have been replaced by five acquisitions, which contribute more than four times the profit and, Invensys believes, can grow by at least 10 per cent a year.

It may surprise those who are obsessed with the latest dot.com, but Invensys has considerable claims to being an internet stock. Already, 20 per cent of its sales are related to e-commerce and, as the pace of change accelerates, the network of customers already using its automation technology are likely to come back for more.

Harry Philips, engineering analyst with West LB Panmure, points out that Invensys already has a bigger customer base in these areas than any of its competitors, so Invensys's claim that half its business could be e-commerce-related in five years does not look unrealistic.

Of course, much of the promises are of jam tomorrow. But there is also plenty of jam today. Based on forecasts of £1.06bn profit for the year to March, the shares trade on less than 16 times earnings. That is a bargain.

Buy.

webTitle: Hold on to your reputation, Burt

fields.headline: Hold on to your reputation, Burt
fields.trailText: THE worst thing about the battle for NatWest is that someone has to win it.
fields.body:
THE worst thing about the battle for NatWest is that someone has to win it.

Whichever of the three protagonists emerges as victor, the risk of it going horribly wrong is high.

The Scottish banks are both small and face a real challenge integrating a bank of NatWest's size. Both have proved adept at using their Scottish base as a platform to expand their business elsewhere, but the skills required to do that are very different from the skills needed to turn around and run a bank of NatWest's size. Their history of organic growth bolstered by small acquisitions means that neither can claim to have more such skills than the other.

Both banks say that it is not their staff but NatWest's which will turn the bank around. Their faith is touching, but it may be seriously misplaced. Years of poor management, chaotic systems and underperformance have sapped morale and sent the brightest stars looking for challenges elsewhere. NatWest's decision to accelerate redundancies as part of its defence will not have helped.

That is one of the reasons why NatWest should not keep its independence. Its workforce has been so badly shaken by this bid that it needs an outside catalyst, like a new owner, to recover. NatWest's management may have put up a good defence, but they are untested at running a clearing bank, let alone turning it around.

Managements at the two Scottish banks, by contrast, have at least demonstrated that they can run a banking business - and well. That gives them the edge over Sir David Rowland and his team. The Royal Bank of Scotland is hungriest for a deal. It made overtures to Barclays, Birmingham Midshires and Halifax before launching this bid. Its campaign has been far slicker than that run by Bank of Scotland, which seemed to find the whole business of explaining itself an irritation.

But Bank of Scotland is simply a better retail bank than the Royal. It is the banking business of NatWest that needs fixing. BoS, with its superior record of income generation and cost control, is the best placed to fix that. Peter Burt and his team must just pray that it does not cost them their reputation.

fields.headline: Toy queen is toppled
fields.standfirst: New York
fields.trailText: THE fall from grace of one of the few women chief executive officers to run a Fortune 500 company was as long as it was hard. So when Jill Barad, a former actress and beauty consultant, was last week pushed from the helm of Mattel, the world's biggest toy maker, after failing to revive falling sales and profits, it came as little surprise.
fields.body:
THE fall from grace of one of the few women chief executive officers to run a Fortune 500 company was as long as it was hard. So when Jill Barad, a former actress and beauty consultant, was last week pushed from the helm of Mattel, the world's biggest toy maker, after failing to revive falling sales and profits, it came as little surprise.

Barad, 48, took over the reins of the company three years ago after successfully transforming Mattel's famous Barbie doll into a major brand, with her name - and shocking pink colour - imprinted on all manner of little-girl accessories. Barbie was turned from a tired, $200 million product line into one of the most recognised brands of all time, with $1.9 billion in sales last year.

But having helped build Mattel into a corporate powerhouse, Barad fell victim to an illness that is sweeping corporate America - caught up in the euphoria of the economy, overpaying for acquisitions and underestimating the costs of integration.

Barad's undoing came with last year's $3.6bn acquisition of The Learning Company, the children's software firm known for 'Reader Rabbit' and 'Where in the World is Carmen Santiago?'. The acquisition, which was part of an effort to expand from traditional toys into the fast-growing world of software and electronic toys, was supposed to add to the company's bottom line.

However, the price of The Learning Company proved far too high and not only failed to meet sales projections but served to drag Mattel down.

Sales for the last quarter of 1999 were $1.77bn, down from $1.82bn a year ago, and Barad's departure came on the day the company announced losses of $18.4m. That compares with profits of $59m for the same period a year earlier. Financial analysts had predicted that fourth-quarter earnings in 1999 would rise year on year.

Mattel had come under increasing pressure from investors after consistently overestimating earnings. In October, for example, the company said that earnings for the fourth quarter of last year would be 70 to 80 cents a share. Instead, it lost 4 cents a share.

'Each time, it was the last time, and it wasn't going to happen again,' said Martin Romm, an analyst for Credit Suisse First Boston. 'Lo and behold, it did happen again. Unfortunately, Jill went to the well a couple of times too many.'

Barad joined Mattel 20 years ago as a product manager and rose through the ranks. In 1982, she was named marketing director for Barbie and began expanding the line into one that featured an entire universe of cars, houses, pets and siblings for the perpetually cheerful plastic doll.

Largely on the strength of her success with Barbie, she was elevated to chief execu tive in 1997. She was one of just four women heading major American corporations, the others being Andrea Jung at Avon, Carly Fiorina of Hewlett-Packard and Marion Sandler of Golden West Financial.

Barad was celebrated as a keen marketer and brilliant presenter, but criticism of her volatile management style - which led several key Mattel executives to resign over what one called 'the Jill Factor' - her grasp of financial matters and her overweening attention to detail - monitoring doll designs down to minor details on their faces - began as soon as sales began to falter in the mid-1990s.

As Beanie Babies and other toys began to eat away at Barbie's market share, Mattel began producing thousands of Barbies from its collectors' line - angering collectors who had paid $50 to $100 for the dolls, believing that they were limited editions.

Despite her success with Barbie and other divisions such as Fisher-Price and Hot Wheels toys, Barad's tenure will be remembered for the software débcle. Although Mattel maintains the Learning Company's poor sales reflected slowing sales in the CD-rom business in general, many analysts say the problem is a lack of new offerings.

'They overpaid severely for a company that they felt was on the way up, and it really wasn't,' says Jim Silver, publisher of the Toy Book , an industry journal. Many predict Mattel will now return to its core business of selling toys, particularly over the Internet where toys with such strong brand names can be easily sold, and profit margins maximised by bypassing traditional retailers.

'There is nothing I can say to gloss over how devastating the Learning Company's results have been to Mattel's overall performance,' Barad said after her departure. 'Because there must be accountability, I and the board agree that I must resign.'

For many investors, the departure of the ambitious glamour queen, known for her mane of black hair, Chanel suits and high heels, has not come a moment too soon. 'There's blood dripping off fangs over this,' said one analyst. 'There's no love lost.'

fields.headline: Media diary
fields.trailText: Sick slickers | Horse dealing | Castaway execs
fields.body:
Sick slickers

The share-dealing scandal which enveloped the Mirror last week reminds us of an absolutely delightful lunch the Media Diary had with the charming Trinity Mirror chairman Victor Blank many moons ago. The subject of the Mirror 's 'City Slickers' was raised and Blank, himself a respected City grandee with an excellent record in banking, shook his head woefully. He was, he said, a bit tired of his major advertisers arriving in his office brandishing their outsized fake P45 forms which had been dispatched by the jovial Slickers for poor performance. Never one to meddle editorially, Blank did say that he was considering pulling his own prank and sending the Slickers - Anil Bhoyrul and James Hipwell - a fake P45 from the chairman's office. Maybe this is one of the weeks when Mr Blank has wondered to himself whether he should have followed through with his 'joke'.

Horse dealing

One of the beautiful relationships in British media took a further battering last week when Channel 4 committed a 'significant act of war' against BSkyB for the second time in a few weeks. After paying a nose-bleedingly high amount for first run rights for Friends and ER , cheeky C4 went on to bid against Sky - successfully - for horse-racing rights.

Now, there are two ways of looking at this - one is that Sky is furious for being two-time losers; or, more controversially, Channel 4 is a bit worried that it has bid up two sets of rights for squillions of pounds only to have Sky unexpectedly back out of the bidding, leaving the Horse ferry Road mob holding a couple of very expensive babies.

Whatever. Things could get interesting bearing in mind that Channel Four will be looking for space on Sky's race card for its new sports and entertainment pay-TV channels. Watch out for the river of fire mark2.

Castaway execs

This is the ongoing saga of the 'Cast Off' TV programme where telly executives are sent to drink bog water and eat limpets on the hitherto deserted but rapidly filling Island of Talentfree. We hear that over at Channel 4, director of programmes Tim Gardam last week bundled Phil Redmond (creator of Brookside ), Waheed Ali (responsible for the Big Breakfast ) and Chris Evans ( TFI Friday ) on to his self-inflate dinghy and rowed them off to the wild shores of the island, hoping that a quick blast of the elements will clear the cobwebs and raise the ratings. One hopes they can survive the gruelling conditions; Gardam was vague about when he might be able to get back to pick them up. Meanwhile, Andrew Flanagan, the chief exec of Scottish Media, which recently paid £225 million for Evans's Ginger Media Group, was last seen furtively puncturing the aforementioned dinghy.

Spot the mistake

Last week we set a complex test for staff by suggesting that the name of the Guardian Media Group's new chairman was Ian Myners when it is, of course, Paul Myners. We are delighted that so many senior people in our own company spotted the 'test', and many have spent the intervening week phoning to congratulate us on our ingenuity. In the meantime, we'll get our coats.

fields.body:
I SPENT my last night on the Observer 's expense account at the Groucho Club killing a £30 bottle of claret. I had convinced the editor I needed a wad of dosh to maintain my cover as a grasping yuppie. But my mark, a young New Labour lobbyist, was in no mood for good vintage. 'It's appalling,' he moaned, head in hands. He was horrified that competitors, former aides of Messrs Blair, Brown and Mandelson, had passed confidential Government information to me and to their clients, US power companies.

The Americans, who owned seven of England's 12 regional electricity companies, and their British comrades in water, gas and telecoms, were concerned about the new Government's tough plans to end the windfall profits and fat-cat pay-outs that marked the Tories' befuddled regulation of utilities. That was June 1998. Last week, the feared reform plan, the Utility Bill, debuted in the Commons.

In Opposition, Labour had no shortage of tales to tell of Tory regulation buffoonery. In 1994, Ofwat director Ian Byatt authorised water companies to collect £3 billion a year that the utilities claimed they needed to maintain the nation's rotting pipe network. The companies duly collected the repair surcharge - then diverted the cash to pay dividends and bonuses. In this past year alone, underspending on operations hit £420 million.

Rather than thunder at the companies for 'gaming' (the industry's term for fiddling the system), Byatt poured praise on them for maintaining the system at a lower-than-expected cost. As their just reward, Byatt let shareholders keep what he oddly called 'efficiency gains'. But the companies did not maintain the system, they merely dumped workers off the payroll. Meanwhile, nearly a third of the nation's water simply bleeds out of leaky pipes.

Over the 10 years of Byatt's watch, the amount of money shifted from operations and upgrades to shareholders easily topped £4bn. Operating profits now eat up an eye-popping 45p out of each pound charged on a water and sewer bill. 'We're still on the learning curve,' says Byatt. The public has spent quite a lot on his education.

Byatt was not alone in his amateur act. In 1996, when the electricity regulator Professor Stephen Littlechild was asked how he distinguished capital expenditures from operating expenditures, he replied: 'Does it make a difference?' Answer: Only to the customers who pay the bill for his loosey-goosey accounting rules.

The basis of Keystone Kops regulation is the strange, cabbalistic system of price setting Professor Littlechild designed for Margaret Thatcher.

Regulators determine prices in secretive, closed hugger-mugger with utility chiefs and their accountants. Consumers are barred from looking at company accounts. If the regulator, a virtual hostage to industry data, fails to do the utilities' bidding, companies may appeal to the Competition Commission. But consumers have no right to appeal against higher prices. Shareholders get the gold mine, customers get the shaft.

Labour promised radical change. In its Utility Bill, the Government does not back away from its commitment. It performs a complete flip. Consumers' right to appeal? Forget it. And if a customer wants to eavesdrop on meetings of the regulator and regulated? Scram, Sam.

To give the bill a little PR panache, the Government gives the organisation a spin. Out go the single regulators, in come panels. To watch over each new Regulatory Panel, hand-picked by the Department of Trade & Industry Minister, the Government will set up a Consumer Panel, also picked by the Minister.

What if real live bill-paying consumers want to look at the utility accounts seen by either the Tweedle-Dee panel or the Tweedle-Dum panel? 'That,' sniffed a DTI spokesman, 'will be taken care of under Mr Straw's Freedom of Information Bill.'

Indeed it will. The proposed FOI Act bars regulatory agencies from releasing information given to them, 'in confidence' or which may be 'commercially sensitive' or which 'may affect share prices'. In the utility regulation game, that's just about everything.

In case some information leaks through, the Bill provides for the Minister to issue a blacklist of additional items banned from public inspection.

Back in the mists of time - 1996 - Labour proposed that consumer groups, trade unions, industrial customers and environmental organisations have the right to take part in price reviews. The Bill now reads: 'The Secretary of State shall consult the holder of the Licence [the utilities] and such other persons as he considers appropriate.' I suppose that's better than democracy.

Lord Neill's just-released report on corruption and influence in government is the Utility Bill's well-timed companion. While the proposed utility law slams the front door of government to the public, the Neill Committee holds open the back door for lobbyists and corporate chiefs.

The committee's report dedicates an entire chapter to the Observer 's Lobbygate investigations. But after hearing from influence peddlers and their clients protesting their innocence, Neill concluded there is no need to register nor regulate lobbyists nor the business fixers who glide in and out of Downing Street. However, Neill boldly recommended that ministers and special advisors meeting with businessmen record these policy swap-fests in their official diaries. These are sealed for 30 years. 'The Circle', as Blair's advisoreRoger Liddle calls it, remains unbroken. From Ofwat to the Downing Street Policy Unit, the secrecy industry is back in business.

Yet, despite this Government's best efforts, some information leaks out. US State Department memos obtained by Guardian reporters Rob Evans and David Hencke under America's Freedom of Information Act confirm what the lobbyists told me last June, that US utilities knew the timing and content of UK Cabinet deliberations on energy policy that month. This intelligence permitted the US Secretary of Commerce to quietly, and quite successfully, lobby the Blair Government on its legislative programme.

So there you have it. The proposed Utility Bill will keep Britain's consumers out of the decision loop, but rest assured British policy is in good hands: Bill Clinton's, or rather, corporate America's.

You can put your head in your hands and say it's appalling, but concede that Labour's shift from consumer friend to foe is amazing. It only took 1,000 days.

webTitle: This Express rush into oblivion can be halted

fields.headline: This Express rush into oblivion can be halted
fields.trailText: The headline, slipped on to page two of the Daily Mail the other day, had a nicely anguished ring. 'Concern growing for future of Express ' it said - over an appropriately concerned tale by an anonymous author quoting equally anonymous 'newspaper industry sources'. The spirit of the old Pravda lives, scenting death at the old Izvestia .
fields.body:
The headline, slipped on to page two of the Daily Mail the other day, had a nicely anguished ring. 'Concern growing for future of Express ' it said - over an appropriately concerned tale by an anonymous author quoting equally anonymous 'newspaper industry sources'. The spirit of the old Pravda lives, scenting death at the old Izvestia .

What's up, doc? Well, Express sales were down again in December (a 5.3 per cent drop year on year). The Daily Telegraph, at 1,022,000, sold 12,000 more. From Monday to Friday, those sources claim, Express circulation is now well under a million. There are 300,000 fewer Express readers than there were a year ago. Can an advertising rate cut be long delayed? Is a drastic move to cheaper out-of-town offices in the wind? Could 'even closure' be an emerging option?

Such solicitude from the Express 's ancient rival must, naturally, be taken with a jumbo packet of salt. The future of the daily - and its two United sisters, the Sun day Express and the Star - is obvious gossip fodder anyway as Lord Hollick and Carlton's Michael Green conclude their media mergings. But the facts that feed the speculation are really pretty miserable - and that doesn't help.

It's nearly two years since Rosie Boycott moved to Blackfriars Bridge and began, at Clive Hollick's urging, to transform the rickety shell of the traditional Tory Express into a younger, smarter title which New Labour could be proud of. She has achieved a good deal in that time. The Rosie Express may not always be homogenised to a reassuring consistency but, in the abrasive pairing of Peter Hitchens and Andrew Marr, it is never less than interesting. There's life in Beaverbrook's old dog yet - just as there is an engaging energy to the Sunday version. What there is not yet, though, is any reward to show for it.

Let's be a touch more historical than the Mail 's 'concerned' sources. Four decades ago, the Daily Express was the monarch of the middle market - routinely selling well over four million copies and easily shrugging off anything the Daily Mail could throw at it. The gap was around 1.5 million copies, not so far off the Mail lead today.

The decline since then has been bitter and inexorable. Goodbye to four million for the last time in 1967, to three million in 1975, to two million in 1984. And now the million itself hangs by a thread. What's gone wrong? Ownership mostly.

While the staunch family Harmsworth hung on to the Daily Mail and helped it reinvent itself, the frail family Aitken abandoned its flagship to a succession of businessmen who wanted cash flow and lordly glory. The two Express titles were produced to a stale, hand-me- down formula and left critically short of investment or creative belief.

The legacy of those years lingers balefully in, for example, the proportion of over-65s taking the Express . At 28 per cent, it's the greyest profile around - worse, even, than the Telegraph . These readers are, literally, dying.

Boycott is being asked to achieve something never attempted in Fleet Street - not to revive a flagging brand by modernising it, updating its essential image, but to change that brand entirely in mid-stream. Exeunt crusty conservatives reared on Empire; enter swinging young Tonies prepared to love the EU. And all the time she must keep circulation high enough to survive and provide a tolerable profit.

It is the tallest of orders, one only worth contemplating with a rich, settled ownership prepared, over decades, to spend and promote unwaveringly. Even then, results may be mixed. (The Telegraph 's less ambitious drive for a younger image has seen its readership profile age markedly over the past five years, so that 63 per cent of its readers today are over 45). Rosie would probably find it easier to start and succeed with an entirely new paper - say the Daily Clive? - than try to warm her branding irons in these embers.

Does Hollick realise the immensity of the task he's set her? Perhaps, but the staff cuts have come again and promotion cash doesn't stretch to helping the Sunday as it 'finds its natural level' way under a million.

Concerned of Kensington would have us believe that ad revenue will flake way almost mechanically as the benchmarks of falling readership become apparent.

That isn't, in fact, quite how it works. This is art, not science, but no less cruel in it functionings. The spectre haunting the Express is one of peripheralisation and then irrelevance as the ad agencies find other ways of covering that sliver of the market.

And yet there's a perverse sense in which all this gloom is potty stuff. Could Hollick and Green, if they wished, still pull the resources trick?

Of course. Are newspapers, in logic, part of the equipment that every vertically integrated media giant will need to pull its Net and digital tricks for the future?

Absolutely: call Rupert Murdoch. The dynamic duo have something valuable under their noses; but do they realise as much? United, who stands?

I inadvertently aged Nigel Dempster by 12 months in my last column. He's not 60 until next year. Apologies and happy (deferred) returns.

fields.headline: Fighting the odds on decline
fields.standfirst: Jamie Doward on the steely 'five-foot nothing northerner' who's set to head Camelot should it beat Branson to the Lottery licence
fields.trailText: The wily property developer who owns Camelot's headquarters was on to a good thing back in 1994. Not one, not two, but three of the consortia looking to run the National Lottery desperately wanted the Watford site. So the owner could play one off against the others and negotiate a fat rent.
fields.body:
The wily property developer who owns Camelot's headquarters was on to a good thing back in 1994. Not one, not two, but three of the consortia looking to run the National Lottery desperately wanted the Watford site. So the owner could play one off against the others and negotiate a fat rent.

The property firm in question could be looking forward to another payday soon. The seven-year licence to run the lottery from autumn next year is up for grabs, and the Camelot building, complete with a traffic roundabout which boasts a flowerbed in the shape of the company's crossed fingers logo, could end up in new hands. Parties interested in running one of the world's biggest lotteries, which has sold more than £25 billion-worth of tickets, have 23 days to submit their bid.

All of which makes it a curious time to be appointed the next chief executive of Camelot: the company may not exist this time next year.

'It's very strange. We're a strange organisation in that sense,' agrees Dianne Thompson, Camelot's chief executive-designate. Thompson believes Camelot will produce a 'knockout bid', but suggests there is a chance of the company continuing to exist even if it loses the licence. 'There are other options. We've built great centres of expertise like our call centres. But at this stage we haven't considered what we would do.'

Thompson is currently Camelot's commercial operations director, responsible for looking after the needs of players and retailers. She will step up to the top job next year if Camelot wins the new licence. But to do this, Camelot needs to beat off Richard Branson's People's Lottery consortium. Branson, of course, wanted to run the lottery last time around. So this time it's personal.

There have been suggestions that because of the Virgin chief's perceived ability to exploit the public's concern over 'fat cat' directors, Camelot last week decided to cut its directors' pay packets. Thompson, for instance, will receive around £340,000 a year, compared with current chief executive Tim Holley's £482,000.

'It's nothing to do with the People's Lottery,' said Thompson. 'The whole fat cat thing shows how stories grow legs of their own. The people who set Camelot up left good jobs and had no guarantee that they would get the licence.

'The bonuses that caused all the fuss were, I think, a very fair reward. They took a big risk, but the situation is different now. I don't have to go through the start-up phase. I think it's only right that I don't get the same, because I'm not taking the same risk.'

Camelot's biggest problem is not winning the next licence, but deciding what it will do if it does. Lotteries, as Camelot knows only too well, attract huge interest from the public in their infancy, but lose their shine as they get older.

Take Camelot's last set of sales figures. Sales for the six months to 12 September this year were down around 7 per cent on the same period the previous year. Offsetting this sort of decline by introducing rafts of new games to stimulate public interest will be Thompson's main task, as will be managing the public's perception of the game.

'There are quite a few myths surrounding the lottery in the public's minds,' she says. 'More than 30 per cent of people still think we decide where the money goes. The vast majority of people think we make much more than 1 per cent profits [just over the actual figure]. Then people say the jackpot should be capped, or that more people should share the prizes. But look at what happens when you have a rollover. You sell £64 million-worth of tickets on a Wednes day draw, compared with £26m in a normal week.'

Thompson knows something about the fickleness of the public. After a stint heading Woolworths' marketing department she moved to Signet, the jewellery chain then run by Gerald Ratner. This was in 1994, not long after Ratner made his famous gaffe by saying that a Marks & Spencer sandwich would last longer than some of his company's jewellery.

'Gerald's remarks had just about destroyed the business. At the end of January 1991 the company made about £125m profit. He said his remarks in the April and at the end of January 1992 the business made a loss of £122m .'

As marketing director, Thompson had to make a key decision. 'Could we save Ratners? The answer was no. It was a tough decision to make because it put several thousand people out of a job.'

When she was offered the Camelot job, Thompson was unsure whether to take it. 'I like to go to places where there's a job for me to do. But when I got talking to Holley [Camelot's chief executive, who will next year become chairman of its putative overseas lottery division] about how it's easy to launch a lottery but the real success is keeping it driving forward, I was up for it.'

Thompson's career might have been very different. Having graduated from Manchester University with a degree in French and English, she worked in the marketing department of the Co-operative Wholesale Society on the recommendation of a careers adviser. 'I'd no clue what marketing was,' she confesses.

Prior to her stint at Signet she worked for a Swedish steel company as its UK managing director, a job which will have prepared her well for the goldfish-bowl nature of her new position.

'It was unheard of in those days to be female in the steel industry. It amuses me, looking back. Being female was totally advantageous. People who would be too busy to see you normally were intrigued. They were all shocked. They expected somebody tall with permed hair and a handbag and there I was, five foot nothing and northern.'

That sort of scrutiny will intensify now Thompson is to head Camelot. And, as with the steel industry, fighting decline will be Thompson's main task.

Profile

Dianne Thompson

Job title: Chief executive-designate, Camelot

Born: 31 December 1950

Other directorships: None

Hobbies: Watching Harlequins Rugby Union Football Club; cooking; theatre

fields.headline: Stockwatch
fields.trailText: Believe your Ears
fields.body:
Believe your Ears

CHORION, owner of nightclubs and Big Ears' best friend, Noddy, has been trying to disassociate itself from the Trocadero centre since it excised the Piccadilly white elephant from its name two years ago. Finally, last week, it managed a financial exit too - and on terms better than the City had expected.

More importantly, Chorion's escape deal with Burford frees it to focus on the rest of its business - where news should be encouraging when it reports next month. Noddy is still in the costly development phase, but reaction to the TV programmes has been excellent. Two more Poirots have also been made. Chorion, indeed, makes more from its characters than HIT Entertainment, which is using its high-rated shares to stalk Britt Allcroft.

Nightclubs, too have been storming ahead, and expansion should keep profits moving. Brokers are forecasting £6 million profit for 1999 and £10.5m this year, putting the shares on a rating of 35 times. As in all fashion-driven businesses, the trick is knowing when to sell, but there could be substantial upside in Chorion yet.

Berisford converts

THE CITY has been waiting for Berisford to convert its outstanding £94m of unsecured loan stock ever since the shares reached a level to make it worthwhile. Why, then, when it finally announced the move, have the shares slumped from a high of 359p to 292p - particularly as the City agrees conversion is a 'good thing'.

The main reason is that conversion will mean shares in issue rise by a whopping 25 per cent, a lot for the market to absorb, when investors are more concerned with finding the nextgreatidea.com than picking out value stocks.

Conversion will mean higher income for loan stock holders and better interest cover for the Magnet DIY-to- Welbilt kitchen equipment group. There is, however, no guarantee loan stock holders will want to hold on.

Fundamentally, though, Magnet is benefiting from the housing boom, while the addition of Scotsman freezers to Welbilt's ovens should give further growth. The shares will stay unsettled until after conversion, but - at 292p - could be worth buying in anticipation of recovery.

3i's on the prize

HOW HIGH can venture capital group 3i go? Already the shares stand at a premium of almost 40 per cent to net asset value - but broker Dresdner Kleinwort Benson thinks that still understates the value of its portfolio of unlisted shares. 3i has always been very conservative about valuing its investments, and DKB reckons the last reported net asset value - 645p at end September - could be little more than half its true worth.

Adding in 228p per share for the fund management business, 189p for technology stocks and 128p uplift for realisation on the rest of the portfolio, gives a total of 1190p. And on top of that comes the potential from reinvestment of disposal proceeds. All in all, DKB still rates the shares - at 998p - a strong buy.

Avoid Premier

PREMIER Farnell, the distributor of electronic components, has sharpened up its act considerably since overpaying for its expansion into the US and botching the integration of the deal.

The first phase of the turnaround started last year, and the shares have nearly doubled as a result. Phase two, however, involving changes to IT systems and logistics, carries far more risks over the next couple of years, and investors should therefore be on their guard. So thinks broker Merrill Lynch, which has just downgraded its stance on Premier Farnell because of to these risk and the likely impact on earnings. Avoid for the moment.
