webTitle: Roll up, roll up for the MBA Oscars

fields.headline: Roll up, roll up for the MBA Oscars
fields.standfirst: There's a new ethical side to this year's prizes, says  Jonathan Gregson
fields.trailText: A new 'ethical' category has been created for business and management students planning to enter the Association of Business Schools' Award Scheme this year. Called the Business and Society Award, it is intended to highlight contributions by students - undergraduates and postgraduates - at more than 100 UK business schools, towards ethical and environmental initiatives.
fields.body:
A new 'ethical' category has been created for business and management students planning to enter the Association of Business Schools' Award Scheme this year. Called the Business and Society Award, it is intended to highlight contributions by students - undergraduates and postgraduates - at more than 100 UK business schools, towards ethical and environmental initiatives.

This is the third year that the ABS has run the awards scheme, in partnership with Clerical Medical and the Guardian and Observer . Previously, there were just two categories of award - one for undergraduates to demonstrate the benefits of their placement year and the other for MBA and other postgraduate students to show how their programme helped them to develop entrepreneurial skills.

According to the Association's chief executive, Jonathan Slack, the rationale of setting up an award focused on the ethical side of business is clear enough. 'The ABS takes social and environmental responsibility in the workplace very seriously,' he says, 'and we give advice on teaching such issues in our MBA guidelines, and benchmarking standards for undergraduate business programmes.'

The aim of the new award is to focus the minds of busi ness students - the future generation of corporate leaders - on the social and environmental responsibilities of the organisations they have contact with. 'Nowadays,' says Slack, 'with more mergers and global corporations earning larger revenues than many smaller countries, it's more necessary than ever to have an understanding of the real implications that businesses have on society at large.'

On the other hand, he notes that 'more companies - including some mega-companies - are taking their social responsibilities to heart. They are looking at new areas of concern and how they can best generate an ethical image of themselves at the global level and many run schemes to ensure that society benefits from their activities and not just the company concerned.'

For students who have been involved with such initiatives, the Business and Society Award offers an opportunity for wider recognition of their ideas and methods. The range of qualifying initiatives has deliberately been kept open-ended .

'They could be in and around environmental issues,' says Slack, 'or they could be in different ways of pursuing an ethical line. They should show awareness of the impact a business has on the communities in which they're operating, whether it's at the production end or distribution - basically, any stage in the supply chain.'

The award is not limited to how the private sector operates. 'It's open to students working in disaster areas or urban regeneration projects, for instance, where some of the funding comes from private companies as well as the public sector. The student may have been involved in improving job opportunities, in training schemes for young people, or in developing and implementing schemes in and around the social exclusion agenda. Or it could arise out of involvement in one of the mentoring schemes, like those being developed by the Institute of Directors, whereby more larger or sophisticated companies pass on their expertise in ethical or environmental areas to fledgling companies. We're taking a very broad view,' says Slack.

The undergraduate Benefits of Work Placement Award and the MBA prize for entrepreneurship still stand as before. Indeed, the runner-up for last year's MBA Prize, Ian Holland, might have qualified for the new Business and Society Award. For in his role as Community Development Manager, he spearheaded the foundation of a new company to tackle social and economic problems on one of Europe's largest housing estates in Stoke-on-Trent.

The initiative, known as the Villages Community Company, was set up as a partnership between three economic development agencies and representatives of five local communities with the aim of creating new companies and work opportunities. On receiving his award, Holland said that 'the creation of the new company was inspired by my MBA [part-time at Manchester Business School]. Modules of the course, for example strategy, marketing, accounting, management of change and statistics, have all been used over recent months to bring partners together and to forge the new company's vision, aims, staff and cash flow.'

But the winner of last year's MBA award for entrepreneurship was Richard Downs, who spent the latter part of his two-year MBA programme at the London Business School setting up Iglu.com, a website that handles bookings for ski chalets and other winter sports accommodation.

'Doing an MBA helped me tremendously,' says Downs, whose company now employs 38 people and 'is doubling in size every three months'. And while he admits that 'you hear counter-views on whether the MBA is synergistic with entrepreneurship, I found it very useful to step back and study different markets and business models.' He particularly benefited from an exchange scheme that took him to the University of Berkeley in California, right on the doorstep of Silicon Valley. 'What some of the companies are doing there is awesome. It gave me an insight into the future.' Which to Downs means the breathtaking rise of e-commerce (a subject now taught as an elective at many UK business schools).

The undergraduate award focuses on the benefits of work-placement schemes. Typically, these take up a full year in the latter part of a four-year programme and, as Slack points out, students can now expect to be paid £10-£12,000 by their employers as rates have increased in line with graduates' starting salaries.'

Last year's winner was Emma Blake, a BA student at Cheltenham and Gloucester College of Higher Education. Her placement with British Aerospace Defence Systems soon found her with financial control over eight projects; while her guidelines to assist staff fill in BAe's 'Achieving Customer Excellence' evaluation forms were adopted by the company.

Commenting on her work placement, Blake says: 'It has been absolutely brilliant. I have learned so much in only 12 months and acquired skills and knowledge that will help my progression through the rest of my life.'

How to enter

Students are invited to enter now for this year's competition, which is open to 2 May.

The Business and Society Award is open to both undergraduates and postgraduates. Entrants should describe an initiative or project they have been involved in which has benefited the environment or communities in which their business operates. First prize is £1,250, second £700, third £300. (Students taking part in this section can also enter the work placement or entrepreneurship categories.)

For the Entrepreneurship Award, MBA students will be invited to show how their programme will help them launch their own company or develop a new division or product area for their current employer. First prize is £2,000, second prize, £1,000.

For the Benefits of Work Placement Award, undergraduates must show what they have learned during their placement year and explain the benefit to their employer and how it will enhance their career prospects. First prize is £1,250, second £700, third £300.

Further information

Contact the ABS Hotline on 0800 779090. Entry forms can also be obtained on the Internet at www.the-abs.org.uk

webTitle: Too many chips could spoil the next course

fields.headline: Too many chips could spoil the next course
fields.standfirst: Where can the semiconductor industry go next?  Oliver Morgan investigates
fields.trailText: 'Chips with everything'. 'Wafer thin margins.' The headlines are enough to give you indigestion.
fields.body:
'Chips with everything'. 'Wafer thin margins.' The headlines are enough to give you indigestion.

But it is not simply the bad puns using semiconductor industry jargon (chips are made from sheets of silicon called wafers) that encourage investors in the sector to reach for the indigestion tablets. The industry itself is bulimic, bingeing on growth before purging in periods of sharp downturn.

Semiconductors may be the vital ingredient that has powered the information revolution - without them dot.com mania would not exist - but while Internet company valuations have defied gravity on jam-tomorrow earnings projections, semiconductors have become staple commodities, demanding huge initial investment and huge demand to make returns.

The rewards for investors can be large and, unlike with Internet stocks, there are real profits from real products. Growth in the past 40 years has averaged 15 per cent a year. Last year, the industry turned over $148 billion.

But as Andrew Griffin, semiconductor analyst at Merrill Lynch, points out, the prices are on a roller-coaster. 'Everything is governed by the three- to five-year cycle. It starts with overcapacity and weak demand following a previous cycle. Then new, hitherto uneconomic applications come along - mobile phones and digital set top boxes are now viable, because prices have fallen.

'Demand soars, capacity is taken up, and the industry responds by creating more. Then there is overcapacity again, prices fall, and demand tails off until new applications trigger it again.'

The early Nineties saw an upturn, before a slump in 1995, and another in 1998. In slump years, revenue growth slows to below 10 per cent. At the moment, things are recovering.

The huge cost (£2bn) of building a chip fabrication plant or 'Fab' is what drives this volatility. Companies can spend 25 per cent of their revenues on new capacity. Griffin says: 'The problem is not only expense, but the time it takes to build plants. Companies are trying to plan two years ahead, but they can only see two months.

'Depreciation is a huge cost for companies that build Fabs. This is a direct charge against profits, and it drives the need to find markets for output.'

Rapidly advancing technology helps the process. As the transistors and circuits in chips become smaller and faster, they become cheaper, which reduces production costs. But then prices go down, so volume is the key.

The figures are dramatic - the cost of producing a chip falls up to 90 per cent in five years. Margins stay the same, and so prices fall equally. This phenomenon is known as 'Moore's Law'.

The last slump in 1998, which saw world chip prices slashed and industry rev enues fall 7.5 per cent - the loss of 1,800 jobs at Siemens and Fujitsu on Tyneside was a direct result - held deeper significance than most. It marked the end of personal computers being the engine of semiconductor expansion.

According to Jean Philippe Dauvin of Italian-French manufacturer STMicroelectronics: 'In the Sixties and Seventies the industry was driven by major corporations' demand for mainframe computers.' This was the era of IBM and the first generation of chip suppliers - Texas Instruments, Motorola and so on.

'By the early Eighties you move to improving the productivity of small companies, and that meant personal computers. For the past 15 years the semiconductor industry has been PC-driven.'

The growth of global industry leader Intel, maker of the Pentium microprocessors in PCs, along with the largely Asian manufacturers of computer memory (known as DRAM), has been hitched to 20 per cent annual growth in PC sales.

In 1999, says Dauvin, there were 600 million PCs at work in the world, while 120 million new ones were sold.

But the end of the line is coming. Analysts believe PC markets are now near saturation.

Of course, Dauvin would say this because STM is hoping to be in pole position to gain from the emergence of mobile technology.

But the immediate question is: what does this all mean for the mighty Intel? Intel currently accounts for 16.7 per cent of the world market - more than 10 per cent per cent ahead of the number two, NEC - and turns over $22bn a year. How does it stop being the IBM of the 2000s?

Joe Osha, Intel watcher at Merrill Lynch, says the com pany's strength has so far has been its ability to defy the cycle through innovation. 'Intel has been on its own growth curve, and was not affected by the downturn in the mid-1990s,' he says.

Osha says Intel's success goes back to the 1980s, when it realised that microprocessors rather than DRAM memory would give greater growth prospects.

It found the ideal partner in Microsoft, which has added functions and upgrades to its Windows operating system throughout the 1990s.

But, says Osha, the big problems started in 1998, in the second 'dip' of a double-dip slump. This was partly to do with poor sales of Microsoft's Windows 98 operating system - sales of Windows 95 had helped Intel through the first trough.

But there are more fundamental economics at work. Osha says: 'Intel has been driven by people's demand for greater processing speed and more PC applications. Now it is getting harder to understand why they need more Microsoft buttons on their PCs.'

So what does it do next? Jump on to the Internet, of course. Analysts believe the biggest opportunity for Intel will be in providing processors for servers - the massive computers which are the backbone for the Internet.

International IT consultant IDC estimates that Intel will make strong moves into the small, medium and large server market. For larger servers, it estimates that Intel's market share will move from 14 to 48 per cent; for intermediate size from 27 to 62 per cent; and at the smallest end from 89 to 96 per cent.

As a sign of its determination to break into this new market, Intel has been working with Linux, a major software provider for servers.

Closer relationships with Linux will, it hopes, also help it break into the mobile and digital markets, perhaps the biggest new growth areas.

Griffin says: 'There are two new paradigms affecting the industry - mobile phones which allow access to the Internet and allow huge new applications for communication; and broadband home access, which allows home shopping, real-time pausing of TV and so on.'

It could also mean a shift in the base of manufacturing.

Griffin says: 'The companies that are at the forefront on these new applications are often Europe-based: Nokia, Ericsson and so on.'

He believes manufacturers such as Philips, Infinion and Dauvin's STM, which have good relationships with customers and are at the leading edge of technology, will be among the leaders.

'America is waking up to this,' says an industry expert. 'Five years ago, when STM went to the US, people in Silicon Valley would say "Who are these guys with the silly Italian accents?" They don't say that any more.'

Dauvin says: 'This is the third great advance - after the big corporation with mainframes, and the small companies, it is now time for individuals with mobiles.'

Dauvin says there are three conditions for success: very close relationships with customers such as Nokia; the ability to provide the whole processing solution through one system rather than specialising in one component as in PCs; and being a big manufacturer. STM, he points out, has 10 Fabs.

This may be true to an extent.

But there are other ways in. Some 'Fabless' companies design chips and sub-contract manufacture to 'foundries'. And then there are 'chipless' players, which do not even design whole chips, but only parts of them.

These companies, the UK's Arm is one, trade on their intellectual property. Arm provides the control part of mobile phone chip systems, and was one of the UK stock market's darlings last year. Its revenue comes from licensing its designs to manufacturers such as Texas Instruments, Sony, Philips and STM. It currently has about 30 licences.

Jamie Urquhart, Arm's chief operating officer, says the company has been able to ride the cycles well. 'We don't have high capacity problems. People come to us even when times are difficult, and buy a licence.'

STM and Arm are looking for Intel-style growth. Griffin believes they have 15 years to do it in. By then, be believes, Moore's law will have run its course.

'It will come to the stage where you can't get the electrons down the circuits,' he says. Sounds like indigestion for chips. For the industry, it will mark the coming of maturity.

The days of adolescent binge-bust disorder will be over for good.

This was partly to do with poor sales of Microsoft's Windows 98 operating system - sales of Windows 95 had helped Intel through the first trough. But there are more fundamental economics at work. Osha says: 'Intel has been driven by people's demand for greater processing speed and more PC applications. Now it is getting harder to understand why they need more Microsoft buttons on their PCs.' So what does it do next? Jump on to the Internet, of course. Analysts believe the biggest opportunity for Intel will be in providing processors for servers - the massive computers which are the backbone for the Internet. International IT consultant IDC estimates that Intel will make strong moves into the small, medium and large server market. For larger servers, it estimates that Intel's market share will move from 14 to 48 per cent; for intermediate size from 27 to 62 per cent; and at the smallest end from 89 to 96 per cent. As a sign of its determination to break into this new market, Intel has been working with Linux, a major software provider for servers. Closer relationships with Linux will, it hopes, also help it break into the mobile and digital markets, perhaps the biggest new growth areas. Griffin says: 'There are two new paradigms affecting the industry - mobile phones which allow access to the Internet and allow huge new applications for communication; and broadband home access, which allows home shopping, real-time pausing of TV and so on.' It could also mean a shift in the base of manufacturing. Griffin says: 'The companies that are at the forefront on these new applications are often Europe-based: Nokia, Ericsson and so on.' He believes manufacturers such as Philips, Infinion and Dauvin's STM, which have good relationships with customers and are at the leading edge of technology, will be among the leaders. 'America is waking up to this,' says an industry expert. 'Five years ago, when STM went to the US, people in Silicon Valley would say "Who are these guys with the silly Italian accents?" They don't say that any more.' Dauvin says: 'This is the third great advance - after the big corporation with mainframes, and the small companies, it is now time for individuals with mobiles.' Dauvin says there are three conditions for success: very close relationships with customers such as Nokia; the ability to provide the whole processing solution through one system rather than specialising in one component as in PCs; and being a big manufacturer. STM, he points out, has 10 Fabs. This may be true to an extent. But there are other ways in. Some 'Fabless' companies design chips and sub-contract manufacture to 'foundries'. And then there are 'chipless' players, which do not even design whole chips, but only parts of them. These companies, the UK's Arm is one, trade on their intellectual property. Arm provides the control part of mobile phone chip systems, and was one of the UK stock market's darlings last year. Its revenue comes from licensing its designs to manufacturers such as Texas Instruments, Sony, Philips and STM. It currently has about 30 licences. Jamie Urquhart, Arm's chief operating officer, says the company has been able to ride the cycles well. 'We don't have high capacity problems. People come to us even when times are difficult, and buy a licence.' STM and Arm are looking for Intel-style growth. Griffin believes they have 15 years to do it in. By then, be believes, Moore's law will have run its course. 'It will come to the stage where you can't get the electrons down the circuits,' he says. Sounds like indigestion for chips. For the industry, it will mark the coming of maturity. The days of adolescent binge-bust disorder will be over for good.

fields.headline: Muddy water
fields.standfirst: Rare and brilliant? Or mediocre and over-priced? The truth about Cloudy Bay?
fields.trailText: Rare and brilliant? Or mediocre and over-priced? The truth about Cloudy Bay?
fields.body:
'I've got some under the counter,' my local wine merchant told me with a conspiratorial wink, 'but for God's sake don't tell anyone where you bought it.' Great dope? Beluga caviar? A ticket to the Wimbledon final? No, just a bottle of Cloudy Bay Sauvignon Blanc, that most cultish of cult wines.

There may be people out there who have never heard of Cloudy Bay - just as there are allegedly GIs, lost in the Vietnamese jungle somewhere, who think that Richard Nixon is still president of the United States - but I doubt it. Few wines have received such attention over the last decade. Cloudy Bay is an international phenomenon, as famous in London as it is in New York, Sydney and Tokyo.

When Aussies David Hohnen and Kevin Judd made the first Cloudy Bay Sauvignon in 1985, using cool-climate grapes from Marlborough at the tip of the South Island, they created an exciting new style of white wine and transformed the image of New Zealand in the process. It was Sancerre on steroids, or as someone put it at the time, 'a bungee jump into a gooseberry bush'. No one had ever tasted Sauvignon Blanc like it.

If the wine was brilliant, the marketing campaign was doubly so. Cloudy Bay, more than any other New World wine, managed to convey an image of rarity and exclusivity - and still does. 'That stuff is like gold dust,' cooed a friend when I opened a bottle over dinner recently. 'Where did you find it?'

In the days when Cloudy Bay Sauvignon was produced in small quantities, some time back in the 1980s, this was quite true. These days, however, it's owned by a French Champagne house which has boosted production to 40,000 cases; that's an awful lot of bungee jumps. It isn't an industrial quantity of wine, but when you contrast it with the tiny amount of, say, top red and white Burgundy on the market, you wonder who is kidding whom.

Is it just me, or has Cloudy Bay lost its way in recent years? The 1998 was mediocre (but then so was most Kiwi Sauvignon in that vintage); the 1999 is more impressive, but it is no longer several furlongs ahead of its peers. If anything, Cloudy Bay has been overtaken by the likes of Palliser, Neudorf, Villa Maria, Seresin, Lawson's Dry Hills, Forrest and Isabel Estate.

Only on price does Cloudy Bay continue to lord it over its rivals. At £10.99, it's at least £1 more expensive than its competitors on retail shelves. In a restaurant, you can pay as much as £40 for a bottle (thank you, Marco Pierre White). Some restaurateurs claim that they deliberately keep the price high so that the wine stays on the list longer. Ho hum.

If Cloudy Bay wants to reclaim its position as a producer of top-class New Zealand Sauvignon Blanc, it has the vineyards and the winemaker to do it. But first its French owners have to acknowledge that there's a problem. As long as the wine is considered a precious rarity, sold to gullible label worshippers with in-growing taste buds, why should they care?

fields.headline: Pulis perfect play
fields.trailText: On a horses-for-courses theory, a valuable away win for new manager Tony Pulis was always on the cards. Not only do Portsmouth nearly always get some reward here but Steve Claridge regards journeys to the West Yorkshire town with the anticipation of a dog seeing a particularly juicy bone.
fields.byline: Peter Keeling at the McAlpine Stadium
fields.body:
On a horses-for-courses theory, a valuable away win for new manager Tony Pulis was always on the cards. Not only do Portsmouth nearly always get some reward here but Steve Claridge regards journeys to the West Yorkshire town with the anticipation of a dog seeing a particularly juicy bone.

Claridge, whose goal came from a Ceri Hughes free-kick in the 74th minute, was told as an apprentice at Fratton Park he was not good enough; but has returned as a hero, scoring the hat-trick that beat Barnsley last week, and was match-winner again to take Pompey out of the bottom four.

'We worked so hard today and a free-kick was exactly what we had been practising in training this week. It was great to see it work,' Pulis said. 'Claridge took his chance well with a beautiful glancing header - and at 34, he is a marvel covering so much ground and always looking for an opening.

'We are starting to believe in our ability now, but with an extremely tough fixture list ahead the vital thing is to keep the run going.'

Eager to show home supporters that he can become a credible replacement for Marcus Stewart, sold to Ipswich in midweek, Martin Smith made a useful debut without scoring the goal that would have made him a hero or looking as aware, incisive or eager as Claridge.

Smith had almost a dream start at his new club when in the sixth minute he caught Adrian Whitbread in possession and beat Hoult with a low drive only to see his shot a couple of feet wide.

He was desperately close to putting Huddersfield ahead in the 60th minute with a lovely strike on the half-turn, only for his shot to rebound to safety off the right post.

Their best chance fell to Ben Thornley, just before Claridge's winner. After a superb pass by Dennis Gorre, he had an outstanding chance from 18 yards but ballooned it wastefully over the bar. 'When that chance was lost I realised it was not going to be our day,' admitted the Huddersfield manager Steve Bruce. 'But it was a cruel blow to see Claridge score because our keeper did not have a save to make throughout the match'.

Nobody could say, however, that Portsmouth did not deserve the points. Claridge said happily: 'We are turning things round. There are too many positive elements at Fratton Park for us to go down.'

fields.headline: A Little lift for Clarets
fields.trailText: A magnificent solo goal from Glen Little gave 10-man Burnley an eighth successive home win in a pulsating match, enhancing the Clarets' promotion challenge while knocking Rovers off the top of Division Two in the process.
fields.body:
A magnificent solo goal from Glen Little gave 10-man Burnley an eighth successive home win in a pulsating match, enhancing the Clarets' promotion challenge while knocking Rovers off the top of Division Two in the process.

Little's 70th-minute effort would have graced any Premiership game and rightly overshadowed the other major talking point, the 27th minute sending off of Burnley's leading scorer Andy Payton for violent conduct.

Ironically, it was a mistake by Rovers' own leading scorer, 17-goal Jason Roberts, which led to the goal. Little picked up the ball after the subdued Roberts had given it away and, with three defenders surrounding him in the centre circle, threaded his way between all of them before breaking free in the box and chipping the advancing keeper.

'I'd loved to have passed it, but there was no one around,' said Little afterwards, 'so I just got on with it and went off on my own. It has to be the best goal I've ever scored.'

'It was a sensational goal,' said Burnley's boss Stan Ternant, 'absolutely world-class, and would deserve to win any match. But the result was not just about the goal, it was a magnificent team performance in which we showed tremendous spirit against massive adversity.'

Clearly anticipating a late onslaught, Ternant replaced Little with an extra defender for a frantic final quarter of an hour in which Rovers deployed four strikers and forced six corners in quick succession. But, thanks in large part to the agility of keeper Paul Crichton, they failed to find a way through.

Rovers manager Ian Holloway said: 'It was a magnificent goal, but I have to be disappointed, we came to win. But we are still on target - one defeat against a very good Burnley side isn't going to change that. There is still a lot of football to be played this season and we'll just go back to work and get on with it.'

Neither manager chose to comment on the sending off of Payton, which came as Rovers prepared to defend a free-kick into the box. Payton appeared to head-butt defender Trevor Challis. The referee missed it but, following consultation with his linesman, showed the striker the red card.

Ternant said: 'I didn't see the incident but I know it takes two to tango and I felt we were on the wrong end of a lot of decisions today.'

fields.headline: The top 10 film moments
fields.standfirst: The top 10 film moments as voted for by Observer readers
fields.trailText: The top 10 film moments as voted for by Observer readers
fields.body:
1: The Usual Suspects - Kujan realises that he has been conned...

(Bryan Singer, US, 1995)

"It was one of those rare occasions when you could lie to an audience and because there were so many aspects to the film the audience would accept lies - it made the ending all the more exciting and powerful."


Reading on mobile? Click here to watch the scene from The Usual Suspects.

That is how director Bryan Singer remembers the scene that tops the Observer poll. "The film won two Academy Awards but in a way this is more significant because then we were up against the best films of 1995, while this survey is comparing a moment in The Usual Suspects to all the great moments in film history." The nature of the list also appeals to Singer: "Films to me are great lines and great moments - it is amazing to me that we should come out top. It is a testament to how much people like to be tricked: if you trick them the right way, they will love you forever; if you get it wrong, you will never work again."

The whole film is built on lies. Five criminals meet at a police line-up, plan and execute a successful robbery. And they are then approached by the arch criminal Keyser Soze via his henchman, the lawyer Kobayashi, played by Pete Postlethwaite. He makes them an offer - work for the devil or die. The tale is told in flashback by Kevin Spacey's character, the crippled Verbal Kint - already granted immunity from prosecution - as he is interrogated by customs officer Dave Kujan, played by Chazz Palminteri.

But this revelation scene is not the original. Singer screened the first version for two friends - his agent and his lawyer - before realising that it was, "too flat?it was confusing and just kind of died". It had the crashing coffee cup falling out of Kujan's hand, the bulletin board and the fax with the face of Keyser Soze, which seems to take forever to come off the machine. But after that first screening, Singer introduced the visual flashbacks as Kujan scans the board and finally realises that he has been conned by Spacey's Kint - aka Keyser Soze - who is shuffling out of police headquarters after being released by Kujan.

Singer added audio flashbacks. So in hindsight we hear from disembodied voices, with Spacey's saying: "It's all there, I'm telling it straight, I swear," as Kujan scans the board and finds references to some of the places and characters from Spacey's elaborate lie staring down from the board.
"It works because of the way Kevin carries the moment, the choice of music - how it shifts gear and takes a completely different rhythm from the rest of the film," says Singer. "There are all kinds of scenes and pieces of the film being played out before your eyes - the images are flooding down from the bulletin board. The coffee cup goes crashing in slow motion and all the time you are seeing images from the film that you thought meant one thing but you now realise mean something completely different. We pulled together every bit of sound which hinted that Kevin was Keyser Soze. The flashbacks and audio were all keenly placed to sit with certain images and then we stuck all the magnetic tape together and waited to see the result." The scene was the idea of screenwriter Christopher McQuarrie. He and Singer had made a low-budget film, Public Access, in 1993 that won an award at the Sundance film festival. The duo was seeking a new project and McQuarrie came up with the idea of five criminals meeting at a police line-up. The bulletin board scene was the second he wrote and the film was then effectively written in reverse. "It is one of the few times I can watch something that I have done. Obviously I am biased, but I think it was a successful surprise, and it had been a long time since a surprise ending had actually caught people by surprise."

2: Psycho - The shower scene

(Alfred Hitchcock, US, 1960)


Reading on mobile? Click here to watch the scene from Psycho.

"Mary started to scream, and then the curtains parted further and a hand appeared, holding a butcher's knife. It was the knife that, a moment later, cut off her scream. And her head." Bang. End of chapter three.
The most famous screen murder of all time is over in a flash in Robert Bloch's original novel: three lines, in fact.

In Joseph Stefano's screenplay, 'Mary' became Marion, her head stayed mercifully on, and this goreless, staccato passage was transformed by Hitchcock, 'pictorial consultant' Saul Bass, editor George Tomasini and composer Bernard Herrmann into a landmark of postwar cinema and one of the most imitated and parodied sequences ever committed to film. What's more, on a non-academic level, it's as intensely powerful today as it ever was.

Famously shot on an $800,000 shoestring in six weeks with a crew from Hitchcock's TV series, Psycho was dismissed by the critics on its release - partly because there were no preview screenings - but it made $15 million in its first year, earned four Oscar nominations and accidentally kickstarted the slasher movie genre (not to mention three mediocre sequels of its own). It has since been listed by the National Film Registry at the Library of Congress, slowed down and turned into an art installation, sent up in The Simpsons and remade, shot for shot, by Gus Van Sant (proving, if nothing else, that colour ruins it).

The 45-second shower scene, shot in seven days using 70 separate camera set-ups, is not just the most memorable in the film, it is the plot pivot, the unexpected - and unexpectedly vicious - dispatch of the leading lady (Janet Leigh) halfway through. Indeed, Marion Crane's spontaneous theft of $40,000 from her realtor boss and subsequent paranoid flight from Phoenix is a lengthy MacGuffin - it is her murder by motelier Norman Bates (Anthony Perkins) dressed as his dead mother that signals the 'beginning' of the story. As such, the shower is unique in that it can legitimately be viewed and appreciated in isolation as a bravura example of the filmmaker's art, or enjoyed as the narrative masterstroke in a very clever movie. (It's easy to see why Hitchcock banned exhibitors from letting in audiences once Psycho had started.)

The trivia of Hitchcock's most celebrated and raked-over scene sometimes threatens to overtake its visual power, but nuggets like these are hard to resist: for instance, Marion could have been played by Eva Marie Saint, Shirley Jones, Lana Turner or Hope Lange. The silhouetted 'Mother' behind the shower curtain was played by Ann Dore (one of five different uncredited actresses responsible for creating Mrs Bates - three for her physical scenes, plus two for her voice, spliced with that of Paul Jasmin, an actor pal of Tony Perkins). The censors demanded the removal of one shot in which they believed Leigh's nipple was visible, but in actual fact, only her head, feet and arms are seen - the rest is stand-in Marli Renfro, a nude model, whose dignity was preserved through judicial use of moleskin patches and glue.

The blood that swirls downs the plughole is chocolate sauce, the stabbing sound effects were created by violating a Turkish melon, Janet Leigh postponed the filming twice due to a cold and then her period, and for the final shot of her inert form, she wore contact lenses to create the dilated pupils.Perhaps the scene's biggest talking point down the years has been the contention that graphic supremo Saul Bass, having storyboarded the scene, also directed it. He made this claim himself in 1973, presumably sore that Hitchcock had written his contributions to this and the Arbogast murder scene out of the story. (Bass had not only storyboarded both, he actually shot and assembled a montage to prove that the shower scene would work). However, Janet Leigh has since put the records straight: "Saul Bass was there for the shooting, but he never directed me."Whatever. When Francois Truffaut interviewed Hitchcock in 1962, the director said that his 'main satisfaction' regarding Psycho was that it 'had an effect on the audience' - a desire more than realised by the shower scene's continuing legacy. "It wasn't a message that stirred the audience,' commented Hitchcock. 'Nor was it a great performance?They were aroused by pure film."

3: The Third Man - Harry Lime appears

(Carol Reed, UK, 1949)


Reading on mobile? Click here to watch the scene from The Third Man.

It nearly wasn't him. Noel Coward could have made the most famous entrance in cinema history. Then producer David O. Selznick wanted Robert Mitchum to play legendary racketeer Harry Lime. That particular star put paid to his chances after being arrested and imprisoned for marijuana possession in 1948. So Welles it would be then. Selznick initially resisted the Hollywood maverick: Welles's box-office appeal had slumped disastrously.

In reality Welles's appearance was so late in the film his star billing could seem undeserved. He didn't appear in The Third Man until an hour into the film. And even then he didn't speak. Naive American writer, Holly Martins (Joseph Cotten), was in ravaged post-war Vienna trying to unravel the mystery of his best friend Lime's apparent death. Up to this point moviegoers had been entranced by Reed's noir-ish vision of a city near breakdown. Incidentally, Observer readers found more moments to savour in The Third Man than any other film. Harry Lime's cuckoo clock speech narrowly failed to make it on to the final list. But there was no doubt about the film's most treasured scene. As is often the case, an odd twist of fortune played a part in the circumstances leading to the film's pivotal scene.

Characteristically, Welles was less than committed when working for another director. He'd often disappear, trying to raise funds for his Othello adaptation from financiers across Europe. On one occasion he was in Rome while needed on set. In desperation Reed often ordered assistant director Guy Hamilton to take his place so he could shoot an ominous figure running thorough the streets. "He made me dress up in a big black coat with padded shoulders because I was rather skinny," he recalled.

Fortunately Welles was around for his most famous close-up. The night scene had been smartly set up. Moments after Lime's former girlfriend, Anna Schmidt, told Martins her cat 'only likes Harry', it had stolen outside and snuggled against the shoes of a mysterious man hiding in a doorway. When a drunk Martins leaves her flat, he is aware of a man on the other side of the street. Martins taunts him: "Cat got your tongue? Come on out! Come out, come out, whoever you are." He rouses an indignant Frau who switches on a light above the door illuminating Lime's face.

At the realisation that his plans to disappear have been undone by chance, Lime smiles enigmatically. His face is mischievous, not malicious. The film's villain clearly likes a joke. For all the Third Man's virtues - a British Film Institute poll saw it voted the best British film ever - the scenes with Welles dominate. Whether he is hiding in a doorway or philosophising on a Ferris wheel, Welles is the film's iconic motif.

At a time when independent sensibilities seem to be encouraged in Hollywood, Welles is the patron saint of pigheadedness. It's hardly surprising contemporary left-fielder Tim Robbins' latest film The Cradle Will Rock is based on one of Welles's early artistic struggles in the theatre. Welles displayed little humility on the set of The Third Man; he frequently offered directing tips to Reed and rewrote his own lines, improvising the cuckoo clock speech. "It's true that Orson suddenly produced it while on set," says Hamilton. "Carol said: 'It's a goody, let's use it.'" On screen, as in life, he cut a larger-than-life figure. A decade later he emerged as a grotesque villain in his own creation Touch of Evil, but in The Third Man he played the most appealing of characters: a charismatic baddie.

More Third Man moments and the strange case of Citizen Kane
Naturally, many films received votes for more than one moment. Casablanca and Jaws both did themselves no favours in terms of the final list by throwing up so many memorable scenes. Citizen Kane (below) suffered more than any other film from this effect, votes for which were so varied that no one moment made the final 100. (By contrast, the greatest beneficiary was our poll topper, The Usual Suspects which, beyond the winning moment, barely received a mention.) Of our 100, The Third Man elicited the greatest variety. Here's a few of the nearly list.

•The final scene. Anna Schmidt (Alida Valli) ignores Holly Martins by walking past him after Harry Lime's funeral.

•Harry Lime defends himself to Martins on a Ferris wheel ride. "In Italy for 30 years under the Borgias they had warfare, terror, murder, and bloodshed, but they produced Michelangelo, Leonardo da Vinci and the Renaissance. In Switzerland they had brotherly love - they had 500 years of democracy and peace, and what did that produce? The cuckoo clock."

•Orson Welles's hands appear through the grating at street level, grasping the air, after being shot trying to escape the police in the sewers.

•A mournful Anna Schmidt lies in bed wearing Harry Lime's pyjamas shortly before a visit from Martins.

•A moon-faced boy, holding a ball, shouts at Holly Martins and Anna Schmidt as he chases them away from the murder scene of the vital witness, provoking suspicion from on-lookers that Martins was responsible.

4: 2001: A Space Odyssey - From flying bone to space ship

(Stanley Kubrick, UK, 1968)


Reading on mobile? Click here to watch the scene from 2001: A Space Odyssey.

Kubrick's beautiful but baffling sci-fi opus billed itself as The Ultimate Trip, spanning many, many thousands of years, from the dawn of man to the first, futuristic steps into space and, with typically Kubrick hubris, 2001 announces this with one simple, majestic cut.
Having introduced us to a jabbering community of ape-men, Kubrick reveals a mysterious, coal-black and clearly alien totem that seems to exert a strange influence over this primitive race. Ape-gangs clash, tempers fray, and when their leader thwacks down his club into a pile of bones, he sends them flying into the air - which Kubrick seamlessly matches with a jump-cut that shows a spaceship seeming to follow its graceful trajectory into the starry void of space, accompanied by the triumphant strains of Also Sprach Zarathustra. This wordless leap is typical of Kubrick's open-ended, psychedelic movie: although it lasts some two hours and 20 minutes, there are only 40 minutes of dialogue, and the significance is left to the viewer's imagination.

The film's co-creator, Arthur C Clarke, claimed that the film was meant to be unsolvable, going so far as to claim that "if you understand 2001 completely, we failed. We wanted to ask more questions than we posed". Kubrick was never happy with this explanation and claimed that Clarke was speaking 'facetiously'. However, he did believe in preserving the film's mystery, asking Playboy magazine, "How much would we appreciate La Gioconda today if Leonardo had written at the bottom of the canvas: 'This lady is smiling slightly because she has rotten teeth' or 'because she's hiding a secret from her lover'? It would shut off the viewer's appreciation and shackle him to a 'reality' other than his own. I don't want that to happen to 2001."
View from the stalls
"The moment is special because it manages to encompass the entire evolution of the human race in one graceful visual metaphor. The ape has used a weapon for the first time and this sets the course of development that culminates in the nuclear bomb". Robert West, Oxford

5: Apocalypse Now - Dawn helicopter attack

(Francis Ford Coppola, US, 1979)

Apocalypse Now was method filmmaking: the film that was as insane as the war itself. And never more so than during the making of the film's showpiece: the scene where insanely gung-ho Colonel Kilgore (Robert Duvall) and his Air Calvary helicopters swarm out of the dawn light to flatten a Vietcong village, speakers blasting out Wagner's 'Ride Of The Valkyries' as they go (the great film critic Pauline Kael bizarrely tried to dissuade Coppola from using the music on the grounds that it had already been used in a European arthouse movie).

Having already set up the hugely expensive scene, Coppola tried to bully the US secretary of defence into providing a lifting helicopter for the scene. The helicopters they did have were borrowed from Filipino dictator Ferdinand Marcos, and were called away in the middle of the shooting of the scene to be used in a real war against Communist guerrillas. "We just heard they're taking away five of our helicopters," Coppola rages in the documentary Hearts Of Darkness, clearly no longer able to realise he was only making a film about a war. When he did have the choppers, all he could do was complain about the incompetence of the Filipino pilots.

But the result is stunning, the craziness and the appeal of war brought together. "Men play strange games to break up the boredom of being in the war," Duvall once said, explaining Kilgore, the man who insists on having his troops surf in the middle of battle. But the real genius of the scene comes not from the grandiose explosions, or even the strange beauty of the attack helicopters, but from some subtle acting: the incredulous expression on Martin Sheen's face as he watches Kilgore in action.

6: Blade Runner - Batty's dying speech in the rain

(Ridley Scott, US, 1982)


Reading this on mobile? Click here to watch the scene from Blade Runner.

"I've seen things you people wouldn't believe. Attack ships on fire off the shoulder of Orion. I watched c-beams glitter in the dark near the Tanhauser Gate. All these moments will be lost in time. Like tears in rain. Time to die."

After Rutger Hauer (Batty) delivered his final soliloquy, the surrounding crew applauded and a few even cried. It wasn't just the replicant's final poignant words that stirred them. Finishing the rain-sodden scene marked the end of an arduous shoot. The exhaustion on Harrison Ford's face as he watches his man-made adversary's demise isn't just acting. He was knackered. Originally Hauer's speech was much longer but the actor persuaded Scott to cut the dialogue saving the audience another protracted death scene. "His batteries are going. He has no time to say good-bye, except maybe to briefly talk about things he'd seen. 'Life is short' - boom!"

With Scott's permission he cut out the beginning and improvised the last lines. Although Hauer crafted the speech to suit himself, he paid tribute to screenwriter David Peoples for doing 'a really beautiful job'. "I loved those images he came up with - 'c-beams glittering near the Tanhauser gate, attack ships off the shoulder of Orion'. I thought they were really interesting, even if you didn't understand them."

7: The Great Escape - The Cooler King escapes on his motorbike

(John Sturges, US, 1963)


Reading this on mobile? Click here to watch the scene from the Great Escape.

Hot off the back of The Magnificent Seven but basically still a TV actor, Steve McQueen almost turned down The Great Escape ("I just did two WWII flicks and they both died in the stretch", he told director Sturges, referring to Hell Is For Heroes and The War Lover). In the end, he took it on the proviso that he was allowed to ride a motorcycle - a typically brattish, macho McQueen demand, but one which sealed his iconic fate, for the climactic two-wheeled leap over a six-foot barbed-wire fence remains the defining image of the film.
McQueen, playing loner POW Hilts ('the Cooler King') breaks out of the prisoncompound, steals a motorbike from a German soldier using piano wire across a road, and dons his uniform. It is actually McQueen in the saddle during the resulting chase - in fact, he also doubled for a German soldier in pursuit ("With exceptional cutting," commented Sturges, "Steve could've played the entire German motorcycle corps"). The famous jump over the wire was achieved by McQueen's stunt double, long-time pal and bike shop owner Buddy Ekins, on a souped-up Triumph. With the cameras rolling, he cleared it in one take ("Nothing like that had ever been done before," said Ekins).

Ironically, the heroic jump does not lead to Hilts' escape - he falls at the next fence - but the scene made McQueen. In Britain, mods and rockers went to see the film over and over again for the jump; they stood up and cheered every time.

8: Casablanca - Rick and Ilsa part at the airport

(Michael Curtiz, US, 1942)


Reading this on mobile? Click here to watch the scene from Casablanca.

By all accounts, it drove Ingrid Bergman (Ilsa) crazy. As scriptwriter Howard Koch recalled, "The ending of the film was in the air until the very end. We thought of many possibilities and finally decided on the one that was in the film." Of course, any other ending would have ruined the film, both as a tragic love story and as a great piece of anti-fascist propaganda. As it was, these were the words Warner Bros's squad of writers cobbled together for Rick (Humphrey Bogart) and Ilsa to say as they stood on the runway:
Rick: Inside of us, we both know you belong with Victor. You're part of his work, the thing that keeps him going. If that plane leaves the ground and you're not with him, you'll regret it. Maybe not today. Maybe not tomorrow, but soon and for the rest of your life.
Ilsa: But what about us?
Rick: We'll always have Paris. We didn't have, we lost it until you came to Casablanca. We got it back last night.
Ilsa: When I said I would never leave you.
Rick: And you never will. But I've got a job to do, too. Where I'm going, you can't follow. What I've got to do, you can't be any part of. Ilsa, I'm no good at being noble, but it doesn't take much to see that the problems of three little people don't amount to a hill of beans in this crazy world. Someday you'll understand that. Now, now... [He wipes away her tear] Here's looking at you kid.

9: Planet of the Apes - Taylor finds the Statue of Liberty

(Franklin J Schaffner, US, 1967)

For all the recent talk about stunning twists in movies from Sixth Sense to Fight Club, none has the impact of the end of Planet Of The Apes. This is one surprise ending that strengthens, rather than undermines, the meaning of what's gone before. It still sends a shiver up the spine - and it rejuvenated the career of Charlton Heston (Taylor), leading to the similarly minded Soylent Green and The Omega Man and making him the most improbable icon for nuke-hating hippies.
All the way through the film, stranded astronaut Taylor believes he is on an Earth-like planet. But having escaped into the Forbidden Zone, he comes across a strange object on the beach and as we begin to see it is the Statue Of Liberty, it slowly dawns on Taylor where he is and what has happened:

"You did it, didn't you...You maniacs! You blew it up! Damn you! God damn you all to hell!"

In the original script, Taylor just says 'My God!' Heston claims that he wrote the speech used in the film. But as Heston's diaries record, in 1967 'goddamn' was still banned by the Hollywood Production Code. Fortunately, Heston successfully argued that he was using the expression precisely: "It's surely acceptable in the context of this speech; Taylor is literally calling on God to damn the destroyers of civilisation." It was one of the last stands that old Hollywood morality would make.

View from the stalls
"Charlton Heston finds the Statue of Liberty buried in the sand and screams at the sky, 'God damn this world to hell.' I often shout that at Waterloo station when my train has been cancelled again." Karen Gilchrist, Middlesex.

10: Some Like It Hot - 'Well, nobody's perfect'

(Billy Wilder, US, 1959)


Reading this on mobile? Click here to watch the scene from Some Like it Hot.

"It's always very difficult for me to say 'this is mine and this is his' said Wilder recently. "Always except, of course, I have to give [longtime co-screenwriter] Diamond credit for 'Nobody's Perfect.'
The late I.A.L. Diamond deserves ample praise for penning one of the movies' greatest payoff lines: Joe E. Brown's sanguine response to cross-dressing Jack Lemmon's revelation that 'she' is actually a he: 'You don't understand, Osgood! Aaah? I'm a man!'

Lemmon and Tony Curtis shared plenty of sparkling, Wildean wit in Some Like It Hot, playing a couple of musicans who, having witnessed the St Valentine's Day Massacre, flee for their lives disguised as the newest members of an all-girl band.

Ironically, the film's best line went to Brown, by then a forgotten silent movie journeyman. It also nearly didn't make it. Diamond originally suggested the line as a temporary solution when the pair failed come up with a final flourish. After a test audience 'exploded' at a preview screening, they kept it. "I was asked by many people, 'What is going to happen now?' And I always said, 'I have no idea. Leave it up there on the screen. You cannot top that.'"
fields.bodyText: 1: The Usual Suspects - Kujan realises that he has been conned... (Bryan Singer, US, 1995) "It was one of those rare occasions when you could lie to an audience and because there were so many aspects to the film the audience would accept lies - it made the ending all the more exciting and powerful." Reading on mobile? Click here to watch the scene from The Usual Suspects. That is how director Bryan Singer remembers the scene that tops the Observer poll. "The film won two Academy Awards but in a way this is more significant because then we were up against the best films of 1995, while this survey is comparing a moment in The Usual Suspects to all the great moments in film history." The nature of the list also appeals to Singer: "Films to me are great lines and great moments - it is amazing to me that we should come out top. It is a testament to how much people like to be tricked: if you trick them the right way, they will love you forever; if you get it wrong, you will never work again." The whole film is built on lies. Five criminals meet at a police line-up, plan and execute a successful robbery. And they are then approached by the arch criminal Keyser Soze via his henchman, the lawyer Kobayashi, played by Pete Postlethwaite. He makes them an offer - work for the devil or die. The tale is told in flashback by Kevin Spacey's character, the crippled Verbal Kint - already granted immunity from prosecution - as he is interrogated by customs officer Dave Kujan, played by Chazz Palminteri. But this revelation scene is not the original. Singer screened the first version for two friends - his agent and his lawyer - before realising that it was, "too flat?it was confusing and just kind of died". It had the crashing coffee cup falling out of Kujan's hand, the bulletin board and the fax with the face of Keyser Soze, which seems to take forever to come off the machine. But after that first screening, Singer introduced the visual flashbacks as Kujan scans the board and finally realises that he has been conned by Spacey's Kint - aka Keyser Soze - who is shuffling out of police headquarters after being released by Kujan. Singer added audio flashbacks. So in hindsight we hear from disembodied voices, with Spacey's saying: "It's all there, I'm telling it straight, I swear," as Kujan scans the board and finds references to some of the places and characters from Spacey's elaborate lie staring down from the board. "It works because of the way Kevin carries the moment, the choice of music - how it shifts gear and takes a completely different rhythm from the rest of the film," says Singer. "There are all kinds of scenes and pieces of the film being played out before your eyes - the images are flooding down from the bulletin board. The coffee cup goes crashing in slow motion and all the time you are seeing images from the film that you thought meant one thing but you now realise mean something completely different. We pulled together every bit of sound which hinted that Kevin was Keyser Soze. The flashbacks and audio were all keenly placed to sit with certain images and then we stuck all the magnetic tape together and waited to see the result." The scene was the idea of screenwriter Christopher McQuarrie. He and Singer had made a low-budget film, Public Access, in 1993 that won an award at the Sundance film festival. The duo was seeking a new project and McQuarrie came up with the idea of five criminals meeting at a police line-up. The bulletin board scene was the second he wrote and the film was then effectively written in reverse. "It is one of the few times I can watch something that I have done. Obviously I am biased, but I think it was a successful surprise, and it had been a long time since a surprise ending had actually caught people by surprise." 2: Psycho - The shower scene (Alfred Hitchcock, US, 1960) Reading on mobile? Click here to watch the scene from Psycho. "Mary started to scream, and then the curtains parted further and a hand appeared, holding a butcher's knife. It was the knife that, a moment later, cut off her scream. And her head." Bang. End of chapter three. The most famous screen murder of all time is over in a flash in Robert Bloch's original novel: three lines, in fact. In Joseph Stefano's screenplay, 'Mary' became Marion, her head stayed mercifully on, and this goreless, staccato passage was transformed by Hitchcock, 'pictorial consultant' Saul Bass, editor George Tomasini and composer Bernard Herrmann into a landmark of postwar cinema and one of the most imitated and parodied sequences ever committed to film. What's more, on a non-academic level, it's as intensely powerful today as it ever was. Famously shot on an $800,000 shoestring in six weeks with a crew from Hitchcock's TV series, Psycho was dismissed by the critics on its release - partly because there were no preview screenings - but it made $15 million in its first year, earned four Oscar nominations and accidentally kickstarted the slasher movie genre (not to mention three mediocre sequels of its own). It has since been listed by the National Film Registry at the Library of Congress, slowed down and turned into an art installation, sent up in The Simpsons and remade, shot for shot, by Gus Van Sant (proving, if nothing else, that colour ruins it). The 45-second shower scene, shot in seven days using 70 separate camera set-ups, is not just the most memorable in the film, it is the plot pivot, the unexpected - and unexpectedly vicious - dispatch of the leading lady (Janet Leigh) halfway through. Indeed, Marion Crane's spontaneous theft of $40,000 from her realtor boss and subsequent paranoid flight from Phoenix is a lengthy MacGuffin - it is her murder by motelier Norman Bates (Anthony Perkins) dressed as his dead mother that signals the 'beginning' of the story. As such, the shower is unique in that it can legitimately be viewed and appreciated in isolation as a bravura example of the filmmaker's art, or enjoyed as the narrative masterstroke in a very clever movie. (It's easy to see why Hitchcock banned exhibitors from letting in audiences once Psycho had started.) The trivia of Hitchcock's most celebrated and raked-over scene sometimes threatens to overtake its visual power, but nuggets like these are hard to resist: for instance, Marion could have been played by Eva Marie Saint, Shirley Jones, Lana Turner or Hope Lange. The silhouetted 'Mother' behind the shower curtain was played by Ann Dore (one of five different uncredited actresses responsible for creating Mrs Bates - three for her physical scenes, plus two for her voice, spliced with that of Paul Jasmin, an actor pal of Tony Perkins). The censors demanded the removal of one shot in which they believed Leigh's nipple was visible, but in actual fact, only her head, feet and arms are seen - the rest is stand-in Marli Renfro, a nude model, whose dignity was preserved through judicial use of moleskin patches and glue. The blood that swirls downs the plughole is chocolate sauce, the stabbing sound effects were created by violating a Turkish melon, Janet Leigh postponed the filming twice due to a cold and then her period, and for the final shot of her inert form, she wore contact lenses to create the dilated pupils.Perhaps the scene's biggest talking point down the years has been the contention that graphic supremo Saul Bass, having storyboarded the scene, also directed it. He made this claim himself in 1973, presumably sore that Hitchcock had written his contributions to this and the Arbogast murder scene out of the story. (Bass had not only storyboarded both, he actually shot and assembled a montage to prove that the shower scene would work). However, Janet Leigh has since put the records straight: "Saul Bass was there for the shooting, but he never directed me."Whatever. When Francois Truffaut interviewed Hitchcock in 1962, the director said that his 'main satisfaction' regarding Psycho was that it 'had an effect on the audience' - a desire more than realised by the shower scene's continuing legacy. "It wasn't a message that stirred the audience,' commented Hitchcock. 'Nor was it a great performance?They were aroused by pure film." 3: The Third Man - Harry Lime appears (Carol Reed, UK, 1949) Reading on mobile? Click here to watch the scene from The Third Man. It nearly wasn't him. Noel Coward could have made the most famous entrance in cinema history. Then producer David O. Selznick wanted Robert Mitchum to play legendary racketeer Harry Lime. That particular star put paid to his chances after being arrested and imprisoned for marijuana possession in 1948. So Welles it would be then. Selznick initially resisted the Hollywood maverick: Welles's box-office appeal had slumped disastrously. In reality Welles's appearance was so late in the film his star billing could seem undeserved. He didn't appear in The Third Man until an hour into the film. And even then he didn't speak. Naive American writer, Holly Martins (Joseph Cotten), was in ravaged post-war Vienna trying to unravel the mystery of his best friend Lime's apparent death. Up to this point moviegoers had been entranced by Reed's noir-ish vision of a city near breakdown. Incidentally, Observer readers found more moments to savour in The Third Man than any other film. Harry Lime's cuckoo clock speech narrowly failed to make it on to the final list. But there was no doubt about the film's most treasured scene. As is often the case, an odd twist of fortune played a part in the circumstances leading to the film's pivotal scene. Characteristically, Welles was less than committed when working for another director. He'd often disappear, trying to raise funds for his Othello adaptation from financiers across Europe. On one occasion he was in Rome while needed on set. In desperation Reed often ordered assistant director Guy Hamilton to take his place so he could shoot an ominous figure running thorough the streets. "He made me dress up in a big black coat with padded shoulders because I was rather skinny," he recalled. Fortunately Welles was around for his most famous close-up. The night scene had been smartly set up. Moments after Lime's former girlfriend, Anna Schmidt, told Martins her cat 'only likes Harry', it had stolen outside and snuggled against the shoes of a mysterious man hiding in a doorway. When a drunk Martins leaves her flat, he is aware of a man on the other side of the street. Martins taunts him: "Cat got your tongue? Come on out! Come out, come out, whoever you are." He rouses an indignant Frau who switches on a light above the door illuminating Lime's face. At the realisation that his plans to disappear have been undone by chance, Lime smiles enigmatically. His face is mischievous, not malicious. The film's villain clearly likes a joke. For all the Third Man's virtues - a British Film Institute poll saw it voted the best British film ever - the scenes with Welles dominate. Whether he is hiding in a doorway or philosophising on a Ferris wheel, Welles is the film's iconic motif. At a time when independent sensibilities seem to be encouraged in Hollywood, Welles is the patron saint of pigheadedness. It's hardly surprising contemporary left-fielder Tim Robbins' latest film The Cradle Will Rock is based on one of Welles's early artistic struggles in the theatre. Welles displayed little humility on the set of The Third Man; he frequently offered directing tips to Reed and rewrote his own lines, improvising the cuckoo clock speech. "It's true that Orson suddenly produced it while on set," says Hamilton. "Carol said: 'It's a goody, let's use it.'" On screen, as in life, he cut a larger-than-life figure. A decade later he emerged as a grotesque villain in his own creation Touch of Evil, but in The Third Man he played the most appealing of characters: a charismatic baddie. More Third Man moments and the strange case of Citizen Kane Naturally, many films received votes for more than one moment. Casablanca and Jaws both did themselves no favours in terms of the final list by throwing up so many memorable scenes. Citizen Kane (below) suffered more than any other film from this effect, votes for which were so varied that no one moment made the final 100. (By contrast, the greatest beneficiary was our poll topper, The Usual Suspects which, beyond the winning moment, barely received a mention.) Of our 100, The Third Man elicited the greatest variety. Here's a few of the nearly list. •The final scene. Anna Schmidt (Alida Valli) ignores Holly Martins by walking past him after Harry Lime's funeral. •Harry Lime defends himself to Martins on a Ferris wheel ride. "In Italy for 30 years under the Borgias they had warfare, terror, murder, and bloodshed, but they produced Michelangelo, Leonardo da Vinci and the Renaissance. In Switzerland they had brotherly love - they had 500 years of democracy and peace, and what did that produce? The cuckoo clock." •Orson Welles's hands appear through the grating at street level, grasping the air, after being shot trying to escape the police in the sewers. •A mournful Anna Schmidt lies in bed wearing Harry Lime's pyjamas shortly before a visit from Martins. •A moon-faced boy, holding a ball, shouts at Holly Martins and Anna Schmidt as he chases them away from the murder scene of the vital witness, provoking suspicion from on-lookers that Martins was responsible. 4: 2001: A Space Odyssey - From flying bone to space ship (Stanley Kubrick, UK, 1968) Reading on mobile? [He wipes away her tear] Here's looking at you kid. 9: Planet of the Apes - Taylor finds the Statue of Liberty (Franklin J Schaffner, US, 1967) For all the recent talk about stunning twists in movies from Sixth Sense to Fight Club, none has the impact of the end of Planet Of The Apes. This is one surprise ending that strengthens, rather than undermines, the meaning of what's gone before. It still sends a shiver up the spine - and it rejuvenated the career of Charlton Heston (Taylor), leading to the similarly minded Soylent Green and The Omega Man and making him the most improbable icon for nuke-hating hippies. All the way through the film, stranded astronaut Taylor believes he is on an Earth-like planet. But having escaped into the Forbidden Zone, he comes across a strange object on the beach and as we begin to see it is the Statue Of Liberty, it slowly dawns on Taylor where he is and what has happened: "You did it, didn't you...You maniacs! You blew it up! Damn you! God damn you all to hell!" In the original script, Taylor just says 'My God!' Heston claims that he wrote the speech used in the film. But as Heston's diaries record, in 1967 'goddamn' was still banned by the Hollywood Production Code. Fortunately, Heston successfully argued that he was using the expression precisely: "It's surely acceptable in the context of this speech; Taylor is literally calling on God to damn the destroyers of civilisation." It was one of the last stands that old Hollywood morality would make. View from the stalls "Charlton Heston finds the Statue of Liberty buried in the sand and screams at the sky, 'God damn this world to hell.' I often shout that at Waterloo station when my train has been cancelled again." Karen Gilchrist, Middlesex. 10: Some Like It Hot - 'Well, nobody's perfect' (Billy Wilder, US, 1959) Reading this on mobile? Click here to watch the scene from Some Like it Hot. "It's always very difficult for me to say 'this is mine and this is his' said Wilder recently. "Always except, of course, I have to give [longtime co-screenwriter] Diamond credit for 'Nobody's Perfect.' The late I.A.L. Diamond deserves ample praise for penning one of the movies' greatest payoff lines: Joe E. Brown's sanguine response to cross-dressing Jack Lemmon's revelation that 'she' is actually a he: 'You don't understand, Osgood! Aaah? I'm a man!' Lemmon and Tony Curtis shared plenty of sparkling, Wildean wit in Some Like It Hot, playing a couple of musicans who, having witnessed the St Valentine's Day Massacre, flee for their lives disguised as the newest members of an all-girl band. Ironically, the film's best line went to Brown, by then a forgotten silent movie journeyman. It also nearly didn't make it. Diamond originally suggested the line as a temporary solution when the pair failed come up with a final flourish. After a test audience 'exploded' at a preview screening, they kept it. "I was asked by many people, 'What is going to happen now?' And I always said, 'I have no idea. Leave it up there on the screen. You cannot top that.'"

webTitle: Fulham make a move for Gullit

fields.headline: Fulham make a move for Gullit
fields.trailText: Ruud Gullit is poised for a surprise return to English football, as manager at ambitious Fulham.
fields.body:
Ruud Gullit is poised for a surprise return to English football, as manager at ambitious Fulham.

Gullit resigned as Newcastle manager at the end of August after a dreadful start to the Premiership campaign and a public rift with Alan Shearer. Now Gullit, who admitted he was uneasy at being the centre of press attention in a football-crazy provincial city, could return to London where he enjoyed his best times in management with Chelsea between 1996-98.

Fulham, who began their First Division campaign under manager Paul Bracewell in fine style, have struggled recently, dropping down the table and going out of both cup competitions. They won yesterday, but Bracewell's future at the club is thought to be in doubt.

New PR adviser Max Clifford has dismissed speculation about a move for Eric Cantona but sources in Holland say Gullit has been earmarked for a major role. Fulham are believed to have sounded out the former Wimbledon manager Joe Kinnear too, but Mohamed Al-Fayed, the club's owner, wants a high-profile manager and is ready to increase his spending at the club - currently £30 million - to get his man.

A respected source in Holland, to where Gullit has returned since leaving Tyneside, told Observer Sport, 'It looks like a serious move. Ruud could be ready to make a move back into the game.'

At Craven Cottage, Bracewell's mood is said to be subdued and, according to a senior player, the team are expecting a change.

A move for Gullit will need to be persuasive. When he left Newcastle his British agent, Jon Smith, said he would be unlikely to work in the English game again. Gullit had become disillusioned by his public falling-out with Ken Bates at Chelsea, then his life in a goldfish bowl at success-starved Newcastle, where he was unable to setlle.

Fayed must convince Gullit that he can be rehabilitated in west London. If it comes off, Gullit would again be following a path trodden by England coach Kevin Keegan, Bracewell's predecessor and Newcastle's manager between 1992 and 1997.

fields.headline: Glory Hunt continues
fields.trailText: Hunt the hat-trick hero for Charlton on a day of emphatic away-day performances.
fields.body:
Andy Hunt, Charlton's FA Cup scoring hero at Coventry, again stood out by scoring a hat-trick to give his team a 3-1 win at Stockport and enable them to maintain their four-point championship lead.

Hunt also scored a hat-trick in the home match against Stockport, and his latest treble was his third of the season. More intimidating for Charlton's remaining opponents is that this was their ninth win in succession, and their ninth of the season in the First Division away from home. It is the best record on enemy territory in the entire league.

What is their secret? Charlton's first-team coach, Mervyn Day, explains: 'A lot of it is down to confidence, but the key factor is that we have quite a bit of pace in our side, especially with Shaun Newton and John Robinson down the flanks. So it does suit us to play a counter-attacking game.'

To Day, another reason for Charlton's high number of away wins concerns their experience of losing 1-0 at home to Manchester United 13 months ago.

United got their goal through Dwight Yorke in the last minute and Day recalls: 'Even at that stage in the game, when most teams would have settled for what they had, United were going flat out for victory.

'Alan Curbishley and I spoke to Alex Ferguson about it afterwards, and he said: "Well, in our position [at the top of the Premiership], a point was not that much use to us."

'That's the way we are looking at it in the First Division. Years ago, when it was two points for a win and one for a draw, it was acceptable to be negative away from home. This is not so much the case now.'

As it happened, Charlton were forced to go for it at Stockport by the home side taking the lead. But, as their manager Andy Kilner pointed out: 'Hunt was the difference between the two teams.'

Curbishley added: 'A lot of chances have fallen to him this season, but on this occasion, he made two of the goals himself. When you have someone like him, you know that you always have a chance.'

There were similarly emphatic away-day performances from second-placed Manchester City, who also came from behind to win 3-1 at Nottingham Forest, and Ipswich, who had a 2-0 victory at Barnsley - a result which lifted them above the Yorkshire club into third position.

The highlight of Ipswich's success was a brilliant goal by Marcus Stewart, their £2.5 million signing from Huddersfield. It came via a run from the half-way line, in which he beat two Barnsley defenders and then dribbled the ball around the keeper, Kevin Miller.

On a day when only four First Division teams were able to make their home advantage count fully, even the likes of Grimsby and Crewe, who appear to get nosebleeds when it comes to asserting themselves on opponents' grounds, had cause to be in a happy mood on their return journeys.

Grimsby won 1-0 at Swindon (who have not won anywhere since October and are nine points adrift at the bottom) and Walsall got a 1-1 draw at Norwich.

Though Walsall were outplayed for long periods, they might easily have collected all the points. That they did not do so was down to their scorer Michael Ricketts wasting the easiest of chances to get his second in the dying minutes.

'He admits he should have scored,' said Walsall manager Ray Graydon.

'Unfortunately, he tried to toe-poke the ball home when he should have sidefooted it. But you won't hear me complaining about him.'

As for the home winners, Wolves' 2-1 success against Crystal Palace has hardly helped ease the latter's relegation fears. The view of Palace's situation from their manager Steve Coppell was nothing if not graphic: 'The big monster called relegation is there, ready to bite us on the arse.

'Until we get the 50-odd points that I think we need, that relegation fear is right in my vision. We are so fragile. In terms of players, we are right down to the bare bones. Every week has been like a cup final for us and now we have 18 cup finals left to play.'

Fulham's Paul Bracewell is another manager who has been under pressure, which explains why he seemed so relieved by their 1-0 win over West Brom, even though his team did not perform well.

Having not scored since 26 November, and lost their previous four matches, Fulham at last came good with a 48th- minute penalty by Karlheinz Riedle after a foul by Graham Potter on Barry Hayles. From that point, West Brom came alive, and were unlucky not to get an equaliser.

Still, as Bracewell said: 'Although we can play a lot better than that, the important thing was the result.'
