A mysterious figure whose personal background is shady and possibly criminal, Ethan vows revenge when his brother and sister-in-law are butchered by Indians and their youngest daughter, Debbie, is kidnapped. Ethan begins a five-year quest to find her, but when he does, he finds to his disgust that the child is now a young woman and acclimatised to 'her' people. Ethan is forced to confront his racism through Debbie's part-Cherokee brother Marty, who persuades her to return, and after a tense scene in which his rage suggests that he's more likely to kill her than save her, Ethan safely delivers Debbie to her father's neighbour. He doesn't, however, enter the house, silently returning to his frontier world, a wandering loner who doesn't belong in the stable world of family and relationships. And as the screen fades to black, there's a reprise of the opening music: 'A man will search his heart and soul, go searchin' way out there, his peace of mind he knows he'll find, but where, O Lord, oh where? Ride away, ride away.' 72: There's Something About Mary - The unusual hair-gel (Bobby and Peter Farrelly, US, 1998) When drag terrorist Divine ate poodle excrement in John Waters' 1972 arthouse shocker Pink Flamingos, it was a milestone of sorts in cinema. At the time, it was seen by a comparatively small crowd - students, druggies, drop-outs - and reviled by the critics, which makes the mainstream success of There's Something About Mary all the more remarkable. The key point finds Ted Stroehmann (Ben Stiller) facing a date with his longtime fantasy girl Mary (Cameron Diaz). He's nervous, but a friend recommends masturbation as a relaxation technique. So Ted tries it, but at the crucial point he finds no sign of his issue - and Mary is at the door. Giving up his search for the missing semen, Ted goes to meet her but is horrified when she spots the errant seed swinging from his earlobe. fields.headline: Explain... The Gold Cup
fields.trailText: For a long time, the competition that we now call the Gold Cup didn't quite know where it stood. The premier international tournament of North and Central America has, at various times since the first Concacaf championship in 1941, been held at intervals of one, two, three and four years. It has recently settled on two - great for football, bad for Premiership managers.
fields.body:
For a long time, the competition that we now call the Gold Cup didn't quite know where it stood. The premier international tournament of North and Central America has, at various times since the first Concacaf championship in 1941, been held at intervals of one, two, three and four years. It has recently settled on two - great for football, bad for Premiership managers.

Costa Rica were the region's original powerhouse, winning seven of the first 10 tournaments - although the area's natural superpowers, Mexico and Colombia (who have since joined the South American football association), didn't bother turning up. The roll-call of former winners, which includes El Salvador, Panama, Guatemala and Honduras, only proves how lightly it has been taken in the past. Mexico won on their first attempt, in 1965, and have won the last three tournaments.

While even the locals didn't bother turning up to the old-style Concacaf championship (it was even used as a World Cup qualifying event in an effort to bully nations to sign up), the new Gold Cup, launched in 1991, now attracts high-profile guest teams. In 1998 Brazil played as part of their World Cup preparations (they won't want to be reminded of it, though - they drew with Jamaica and Guatemala and lost to America), and this year Colombia, South Korea and Peru have signed up.

It all kicks off on Saturday, with America v Haiti and Colombia v Jamaica in Miami, and lasts for 15 glorious days. The likes of Nolberto Solano, Dwight Yorke (left), Marcus Gayle and Paulo Wanchope will all be there, much to the displeasure of their managers. Still, none of the British-based stars plays for any of the good teams, so they should be back home soon.

fields.headline: 100 top film moments: 81 to 90
fields.standfirst: The top film moments as voted for by Observer readers
fields.trailText: The top film moments as voted for by Observer readers
fields.body:
81: Edward Scissorhands - Ice sculptures

(Tim Burton, US, 1991)

It's an annual event, Hollywood crowning 'This year's hottest director'. In 1990, Tim Burton, 31, held the honour. Fresh from the success of Batman, a textbook late Eighties blockbuster - big stars + big bangs = big bucks - he could do anything. He opted to make Edward Scissorhands, based on an idea he had cherished since childhood. Warner Bros, understandably, wanted a sequel. They would have to wait.

Despite Burton's hip status, only one studio, 20th Century Fox, wanted to make the film. The dark fairytale, set in an identikit, pastel suburbia, looked askance at Reagan's middle-America filled with smiling jocks and Avon ladies. The hero (Johnny Depp) was a reed-thin enigma, not unlike Burton himself. Destined never to score a winning touchdown, he would puncture the ball just by picking it up. But Edward inspired affection for his noble heart and imagination. He transformed the local gardens into a gallery of topiaries, from dolphins to dinosaurs. It won him friends among the neighbourhood watch brigade. Gaining the heart of cheerleader Winona Ryder was trickier. Unable to touch her, creating ice sculptures while she danced through the snow to Danny Elfman's overwhelming score became his love token.

82: Babette's Feast - The old general tastes the food

(Gabriel Axel, Denmark, 1987)

The sight of an old man enjoying his dinner doesn't immediately suggest itself as one the greatest moments in cinema. But what a spread: foie gras, turtle soup, quail stuffed with truffles, followed by baba au rhum and washed down with champagne. It's enough to make a man sit back and re-evaluate his life, which is exactly what happens to General Lowenhielm (Jarl Kulle) in this scene.
The film tells the story of a mysterious French emigrée Babette (Stephanie Audran) who is taken in by two elderly spinster sisters in 1871. Over the years, an unlikely bond grows between the Frenchwoman, who works as their housemaid, and her pious, yet kindly benefactors. When Babette wins the lottery, she decides to cook a fabulous feast for the dour villagers. By agreeing, the sisters risk the wrath of their puritanical fellow parishioners. The seven-course delight is politely received until the memories stirred by the culinary magnificence prove too much for Lowenhielm, leading to the revelation of old secrets and a measure of catharsis.

83: The Jungle Book - Mowgli meets Baloo

(Wolfgang Reitherman, US, 1967)

The 17th and last animated feature personally produced by Walt Disney seemed in synch with the Swinging Sixties. Four years since the last Disney feature, The Sword in the Stone, the studio's panoramic animation was largely absent, relying on catchy jazz-inspired songs and the interaction of memorable characters. Rudyard Kipling's stories about a boy raised by wolves had been liberally adapted by the filmmakers. When jovial Baloo meets Mowgli, 'Well, what have we here then?' it marks the start of one of the film's central relationship and was another excuse for a song, 'The Bare Necessities'. Bandleader and radio star Phil Harris, who voiced Baloo, was a household name in the States, with Bruce Reitherman as Mowgli. He was the son of director Wolfgang Reitherman, Disney's favourite animation director. He was one of the 'nine old men', the original group of animators who worked on Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs.

84: Henry V - Henry carries away his dead page

(Kenneth Branagh, UK, 1989)

Arguably Hollywood's favourite screenwriter during the Nineties, the Bard's resurgence owed much to the efforts of Branagh, Oscar-nominated here in his directorial debut. Branagh retained period costumes but updated the play with a modern sensibility. No longer was Hal purely a two-dimensional war-monger driven by staunch patriotism. Lawrence Olivier's famous adaptation was aimed at boosting British spirits during World War II. Over 40 years later in peacetime, Branagh had no such constraints, bringing greater realism and violence to his version. Audiences familiar with Olivier's version were in for a surprise. Of course, the 'Once more unto the breach' speech was delivered with customary rigour, but Branagh's battleground was a muddy hellhole. There was little place for vainglory in this world. Therefore Observer readers were stirred by a less obvious moment of heroism and leadership. It takes place after the battle, when Henry staggers across the fields, strewn with corpses, carrying the youthful body of his dead page on his shoulders. The warrior king goes on to eventual victory but the terrible cost of battle is an indelible memory.

85: La Dolce Vita - The frolic in the fountain

(Federico Fellini, It/Fr 1960)

Fellini's classic marked a highpoint of European cinema, supporting the auteur theory of filmmaking beloved of contemporary French critics. The film lambasted the decadent values of post-war Rome and views the city's landmarks with a sardonic eye. From the opening scene, when a statue of Christ is carried above Rome by a helicopter, the director's iconoclastic vision is set. For much of the film, Mastroianni's handsome yet dissolute tabloid reporter chases stories and women, often in tandem, as in the film's most memorable scene. Covering the arrival of a buxom movie star (Anita Ekberg), he follows her across the the city spectrum, from the top of St Peter's to a dingy nightclub. He is smitten despite her obvious shortcomings: earlier asked the secret of her success, she points to her chest, proudly declaring: 'Because I've discovered I've got great talent.' The passionate pursuit ends at dawn, as he follows her into the Trevi fountain. By now he has elevated the actress to the epitome of her sex, but is still unable to reach her.

86: Cabaret - Tomorrow belongs to them

(Bob Fosse, US, 1972)

By 1972, Bob Fosse had an enviable reputation as a Broadway producer and choreographer - talents that were showcased impressively in his 1969 film debut, Sweet Charity. Fosse's flair was better served by Cabaret, however, which allowed him more leeway with his often underrated dramatic sensibility although it irritated many of the original stage musical admirers, who felt Jay Presson Allen's script owed far too much to Christopher Isherwood's source play I Am A Camera.

Set in Thirties Berlin, the film stars Liza Minnelli as Sally Bowles, an ex-pat American singer who performs lewd routines in the seedy Kit Kat Club. Sally meets Brian (Michael York), a genteel British writer, and together they meet Maximillian (Helmut Griem), a suave, rich Berliner who romances them both with no apparent preference.

Against this decadent backdrop, Fosse plays out the rise of Nazism, using the song and dance routines as an eerie reflection of its methods and doctrine. Most chilling of all, however, is the scene in a rural Biergarten, where an angelic young blond boy in his early teens stands up and begins to sing the plaintive 'Tomorrow Belongs To Me'. It starts as a gentle, childish song of hope but, slowly, more and more of the people around him join in. The elephantine clatter of a traditional oompah band picks up the beat, until the song reaches a powerful, marching crescendo - every man, woman and child is in thrall to the tempo, making all Brian's philosophical musings redundant and hammering home the growing support for Adolf Hitler with the simple revelation of a single swastika on the original boy's clothing.

87: Un Chien Andalou - Eye-slicing

(Luis Buñuel and Salvador Dali, Sp, 1928)

In 1928, Luis Buñuel made cinema history with a simple trip to the butcher's. As a student at university in Madrid, Buñuel had made friends with aspiring artist Salvador Dali, and together they conceived what would become famous as the first true Surrealist movie. The opening was designed to shock, showing a man (played by Buñuel himself) sharpening his razor until it glistens. Next we see him standing behind a woman, who is sitting nonchalantly on a chair, and prising her eyelids apart with his fingers. The next scene is the clincher, showing the razor slicing through the aqueous humour, a horribly realistic effect achieved by using a cow's eye for the close-up. The random, frequently hilarious scenes that follow 'a man dragging two grand pianos stuffed with dead donkeys, another man staring in horror at the colony of ants living in his hand' make even less sense over the course of the next 17 minutes, but the film achieved its aim and the pair teamed for a second Surrealist classic, L'Age D'Or (1930). This time the subject was religion, and its scurrilous nature threatened to damage Buñuel's career.

After a slack period during the Thirties, Buñuel moved to Los Angeles and later, in the Forties, to Mexico, partly inspired by right-wing dictator General Franco's success in the Spanish Civil War, although he returned to Spain in 1961 at Franco's personal request. His first film back in his homeland, Viridiana, was a religious satire culminating in an irreverent recreation of The Last Supper. Franco was not impressed.

(Mike Newell, UK, 1994)

Never mind the Weddings, the Funeral was the narrative masterstroke of Richard Curtis's five-act comedy of manners, in that it tied a counterweight to the otherwise gossamer larks. 'Splendid bugger' Gareth (Simon Callow) has suffered a fatal heart attack at the previous wedding, and at his funeral, his partner Matthew (John Hannah) says 'a few words'. It is a moving speech, not least for Curtis's inclusion of W. H. Auden's 'Song IX'.

Perhaps unsurprisingly, the poem was republished and snapped up by people who had never bought a poetry book in their lives. This illustrates the power of the scene, the credit for which remains a dead heat between Auden and Hannah (who also benefited, in that he turned into a leading man). 'Perhaps you will forgive me,' he says, 'If I turn from my own feelings to the words of another splendid bugger, W. H. Auden.

'Stop all the clocks, cut off the telephone. Prevent the dog from barking with a juicy bone. Silence the pianos and with muffled drum / Bring out the coffin, let the mourners come?'

He continues, 'Pour away the ocean and sweep up the wood; for nothing now can ever come to any good.'

89: Great Expectations - Pip meets Magwitch in the graveyard

(David Lean, UK, 1946)

These days, Dickens seems to be an excuse for TV prop departments to show off and for the BBC's better-paid stars to indulge in scenery munching cameos. But David Lean's Great Expectations is something else entirely: an often terrifying Gothic tale that had a marked influence on Sunset Boulevard.
It starts with young Pip (Anthony Wager) running across truly bleak, dead marshes, with the wind howling, and a pair of gallows the only sign of human habitation. He climbs a wall into a crumbling graveyard, with a loud creaking in the background. He visits his parents' grave, but the creaking has made him nervous, and he keeps looking round. He starts to run away but his throat has been seized by a vast, ugly man with a huge bulbous nose.

'Keep still, you little devil, or I'll cut your throat.' Magwitch (Finlay Currie) lifts Pip up, turns him upside down and shakes his pockets out. Then he interrogates Pip about his family.

'Get me a file and vittles or I'll have your heart and liver out.' Pip believes him: equally importantly, so do we. There are few scarier moments in British cinema.

90: Happiness - The, er, climax

(Todd Solondz, US, 1998)

Billy Maplewood has it tough. First, the kids at school tease him because he hasn't managed to 'come' yet - in fact, he doesn't know what 'coming' means, until he asks his obliging father Bill, a psychiatrist. Worse is to come when it is revealed that Maplewood Snr is a closet paedophile who has been drugging and raping Billy's playmates. Billy's mother takes him back to live with her parents, and at a family meal, Billy masturbates for the first time and earnestly tells the horrified diners: 'I came!' Those familiar with director Solondz's debut, school-year cringe comedy, Welcome To The Dollhouse, will recognise his trademark black comedy, but Happiness certainly pushes the envelope.
'Many people have walked out of Dollhouse and said, "Oh, that was me",' says Solondz. 'I don't anticipate anyone walking out and saying, "That was me, I was Bill Maplewood." But for me the tragedy of Bill Maplewood is his family: he loves his wife, he loves his son. He's not a monster but struggles with a monster within, and he succumbs to this demon, so to speak.'
fields.bodyText: 81: Edward Scissorhands - Ice sculptures (Tim Burton, US, 1991) It's an annual event, Hollywood crowning 'This year's hottest director'. In 1990, Tim Burton, 31, held the honour. Fresh from the success of Batman, a textbook late Eighties blockbuster - big stars + big bangs = big bucks - he could do anything. He opted to make Edward Scissorhands, based on an idea he had cherished since childhood. Warner Bros, understandably, wanted a sequel. They would have to wait. Despite Burton's hip status, only one studio, 20th Century Fox, wanted to make the film. The dark fairytale, set in an identikit, pastel suburbia, looked askance at Reagan's middle-America filled with smiling jocks and Avon ladies. The hero (Johnny Depp) was a reed-thin enigma, not unlike Burton himself. Destined never to score a winning touchdown, he would puncture the ball just by picking it up. But Edward inspired affection for his noble heart and imagination. He transformed the local gardens into a gallery of topiaries, from dolphins to dinosaurs. It won him friends among the neighbourhood watch brigade. Gaining the heart of cheerleader Winona Ryder was trickier. Unable to touch her, creating ice sculptures while she danced through the snow to Danny Elfman's overwhelming score became his love token. 82: Babette's Feast - The old general tastes the food (Gabriel Axel, Denmark, 1987) The sight of an old man enjoying his dinner doesn't immediately suggest itself as one the greatest moments in cinema. But what a spread: foie gras, turtle soup, quail stuffed with truffles, followed by baba au rhum and washed down with champagne. When Babette wins the lottery, she decides to cook a fabulous feast for the dour villagers. By agreeing, the sisters risk the wrath of their puritanical fellow parishioners. Rudyard Kipling's stories about a boy raised by wolves had been liberally adapted by the filmmakers. When jovial Baloo meets Mowgli, 'Well, what have we here then?' it marks the start of one of the film's central relationship and was another excuse for a song, 'The Bare Necessities'. Branagh retained period costumes but updated the play with a modern sensibility. No longer was Hal purely a two-dimensional war-monger driven by staunch patriotism. Lawrence Olivier's famous adaptation was aimed at boosting British spirits during World War II. Of course, the 'Once more unto the breach' speech was delivered with customary rigour, but Branagh's battleground was a muddy hellhole. There was little place for vainglory in this world. Therefore Observer readers were stirred by a less obvious moment of heroism and leadership. It takes place after the battle, when Henry staggers across the fields, strewn with corpses, carrying the youthful body of his dead page on his shoulders. The warrior king goes on to eventual victory but the terrible cost of battle is an indelible memory. 85: La Dolce Vita - The frolic in the fountain (Federico Fellini, It/Fr 1960) Fellini's classic marked a highpoint of European cinema, supporting the auteur theory of filmmaking beloved of contemporary French critics. The film lambasted the decadent values of post-war Rome and views the city's landmarks with a sardonic eye. From the opening scene, when a statue of Christ is carried above Rome by a helicopter, the director's iconoclastic vision is set. For much of the film, Mastroianni's handsome yet dissolute tabloid reporter chases stories and women, often in tandem, as in the film's most memorable scene. Covering the arrival of a buxom movie star (Anita Ekberg), he follows her across the the city spectrum, from the top of St Peter's to a dingy nightclub. He is smitten despite her obvious shortcomings: earlier asked the secret of her success, she points to her chest, proudly declaring: 'Because I've discovered I've got great talent.' The passionate pursuit ends at dawn, as he follows her into the Trevi fountain. By now he has elevated the actress to the epitome of her sex, but is still unable to reach her. 86: Cabaret - Tomorrow belongs to them (Bob Fosse, US, 1972) By 1972, Bob Fosse had an enviable reputation as a Broadway producer and choreographer - talents that were showcased impressively in his 1969 film debut, Sweet Charity. Fosse's flair was better served by Cabaret, however, which allowed him more leeway with his often underrated dramatic sensibility although it irritated many of the original stage musical admirers, who felt Jay Presson Allen's script owed far too much to Christopher Isherwood's source play I Am A Camera. Set in Thirties Berlin, the film stars Liza Minnelli as Sally Bowles, an ex-pat American singer who performs lewd routines in the seedy Kit Kat Club. fields.headline: Said & Done
fields.trailText: Emmanuel Petit loses patience; Zambian fans vent their anger on prostitutes; Reuters man gets his kit off.
fields.body:
Le Petit blank

Emmanuel Petit has lost patience with the press. How, he asked last week, can reporters worry about whether or not he spat at John Hartson while at the same time a war is being fought in Chechnya? 'To know whether or not I spat at him,' said Petit, 'or to do half a page on me the moment - I sneeze, frankly. With the war in Chechnya, I think there are better things to do.'

Petit, increasingly profound, played for Arsenal against Bradford yesterday before cold-shouldering a media pack he now regards as irredeemably frivolous. 'This is why I no longer speak to the English press. Football and business do have need of each other, but these exchanges must never sink into tuppenny squabbles'.

Petit was speaking at length to European Monthly Sport and Business magazine on the subject of protecting his public image from incidents such as that with Hartson, and from association with inferior products or journalists.

'I can refuse astronomical sums of money so as not to soil my image,' he confides. 'Credibility can quickly be lost. Partly for that reason and partly because I do not have enough time, I will wait further to launch my own product-line. I am thinking of it though, for when I stop playing.' Tomas Brolin - be warned.

Prostitutes 'cost us the game'

Furious Zambian fans vented their anger on prostitutes last Tuesday after their side went out of the African Nations Cup after a 2-2 draw with Senegal. According to local paper the Independent Post ', the fans, wielding sticks and empty bottles, rounded up the ladies and then 'beat them up, stole their handbags and chased them around'.

One of the fans was quoted as claiming the 'sex workers' were a source of bad luck and might have contributed to the team's poor performance. They should, he said, have been indoors watching the game instead of lining the streets: 'These people should be taught a lesson,' said one as he charged at the group. 'Not only do they spread diseases, but they are bad luck when such important tournaments are taking place. We shall not leave until the streets are clean.'

Zambia crashed out of the championship having lost 2-0 in the opener against Egypt, drawn 1-1 against Burkina Faso - and lost 7-1 to Honduras in a warm-up game. The team are now in hiding.

Shower power

Reuters news agency has found a new hero after one of its journalists discovered a bold way round a dressing-room ban. The incident happened after the African Champions Cup final between Shooting Stars of Nigeria and Zamalek of Egypt - a 1-0 defeat for Zamalek. After the game, as is standard practice in the region, Reuters man Eniwoke Ibagere went to the losers' dressing room to collect quotes - only to be told to get lost by the miserable, naked players. 'We've lost, we're unhappy, and anyway we've got no clothes on, so we can't talk to you.' Unfazed, Ibagere stripped off his suit and strode nude into the changing room - lifting the mood and bagging all the quotes he needed. Man of the week, by far.

fields.headline: 100 top film moments: 91 to 100
fields.standfirst: The top film moments as voted for by Observer readers
fields.trailText: The top film moments as voted for by Observer readers
fields.body:
91: Braveheart - The battle of Stirling Bridge

(Mel Gibson, US, 1995)

Although the Oscar-winning film became a rallying point for Scottish Nationalists, most of the filming took place in Ireland. The Irish government offered tax incentives, the use of five castles and hundreds of Irish defence force soldiers at Gibson's disposal, which paid off when they came to film the battle of Stirling Bridge. The filming required 30 days' shooting, 10 cameras and 3,000 extras. He concentrated on capturing the violence of the conflict, zooming in on the brutal hand-to-hand fighting and the carnage. During editing, Gibson worried that some battle scenes were too strong, and was proved correct when people walked out of a preview screening, causing him to cut some of the gore. 'You don't want to gross people out,' he admitted at the time, 'but I think they have to feel what a 13th-century battle was like. It can't be a comfortable experience, people slugging each other with blunt weapons.'

92: High Noon - Will Kane realises he is alone

(Fred Zinnemann, US, 1952))

Having had his call for volunteers rejected in both the saloon and the church, sheriff Will Kane (Gary Cooper) returns to his office and has to tell his one temporary deputy, Herb, that they're going to have to stand alone.
'You and me against Miller and all the rest of 'em?...I'm ready now, but this is different, Will. This ain't like what you said it was gonna be. This is just plain committing suicide and for what? Why me? I'm no lawman. I just live here. I got nothin' personal against nobody. I got no stake in this? There's a limit how much you can ask a man. I got a wife and kids.'

Kane lets Herb go and lets his weary head rest against his desk. A teenage boy tries to help Kane, but it's clear he'll have to stand alone. When the clock turns to noon, he gets up and walks out into the street. But even then he's no fighting machine: he's an anxious, ailing middle-aged man, glancing nervously around. And all the more heroic for it.

93: Ice Cold In Alex - 'Four ice-cold lagers'

(J. Lee Thompson, UK, 1958)

The title comes from a pledge that (alcoholic) British officer Captain Anson (John Mills) makes to the crew of his ambulance as they brave the Germans, the Sahara and the spy they have in their ranks, trying to get from Tobruk to Alexandria: if they make it, they'll have the best beer in the world.
Battered, dusty, weary and expectant, the survivors: Anson, the sergeant (Harry Andrews), Diana, the nurse (Sylvia Syms) and the Nazi spy (Anthony Quayle) who has actually saved them, troop into Anson's favourite bar and take their stools.

'Set 'em up Joe,' Anson requests, as if he'd been in the day before.
'Set what up?' the barman asks.
'Four ice-cold lagers.'
The quartet look tense as the barman pours the drinks.
'You've kept your promise,' Diana says.
'Let's hope the beer is all I said it was.'
The barman lines up four glasses of frothy lager. Anson looks at his for a long time, thinking back on the long, shambolic and dangerous trip across the desert. He picks up the glass, sinking it in one. 'Worth waiting for.'

94: Les Diaboliques - He rises from the dead

(Henri-Georges Clouzot, Fr, 1955)

'Don't be devils. Don't ruin the interest your friends could take in this film. Don't tell them what you saw.' (Henri-Georges Clouzot's post-film voiceover.)
Is this the one film Alfred Hitchcock wished he had directed himself? In retrospect, he probably regretted turning it down. Instead, Henri-Georges Clouzot stepped in to direct the classic pot-boiler. The resulting film was the first art-house hit in America, inspiring round-the-block queues. The appeal: dark humour, a hint of supernatural mystery, a foreboding atmosphere topped off with a memorable twist lured many mainstream moviegoers to their first foreign language film.

Ironically, Hitchcock was inspired by the film when he came to direct Psycho in 1960, Les Diaboliques' marketing ploy, urging people not to reveal the ending, proved wise both times.

After being drowned by his long-suffering wife, Christina (Vera Clouzot), and vengeful mistress Nicole (Simone Signoret), callous headmaster Paul Meurisse (Michel Delasalle) is spotted around the school. A botched job or something more sinister? Nothing is quite as it seems, of course. At the end of the film, the headmaster rises again out of the tub, soaked but unapparently unharmed, although his pupils are missing from his eyes. His slow ascent is terrifying, deepening the mystery about his mortality. Is he man or monster? The Hitchcock link continued after the release of Psycho when he received a letter from a distraught fan. 'Sir, After seeing Diabolique [sic], my daughter was afraid to take a bath. Now she has seen your Psycho and is afraid to take a shower. What should I do with her?' Hitchcock replied: 'Send her to the dry cleaners'.

95: Schindler's List - The girl's red coat

(Steven Spielberg, US, 1993)

This heartbreaking sequence relates to the earlier 'Rosebud' moment in Schindler's List. During the Krakow ghetto clearance, the girl in the red coat had dodged through the carnage, ignored by everyone, as Oskar Schindler (Liam Neeson) watched in growing horror. In the film it marked a turning point for the industrialist, pushing him to risk his life and fortune rescuing potential camp victims. The red coat, conspicuous in an otherwise black and white film, draws our attention to the anonymous girl. At the end of the sequence she slips into an empty house and hides under a bed. However, her ultimate fate is still tragic. Later, we catch a glimpse of the coat in a cart piled high with corpses.

Apparently the arc of this particular story caused a stir between Spielberg and screenwriter Steven Zaillian who worried the sequence was too sentimental. The film was released to almost universal praise but prominent Jewish American critics were not won over. Writing in the Village Voice, J. Hoberman thought the film focused too heavily on Schindler's heroics relegating Jews 'to supporting parts in their own cataclysm, hanging around the Krakow ghetto'. The film, he argued, was 'a feel-good entertainment about the ultimate feel-bad experience of the 20th century'.

96: Cool Hand Luke - The egg-eating contest

(Stuart Rosenberg, US, 1967)

Non-conformist convict Lucas 'Luke' Jackson (Paul Newman) is a good ole Southern boy whose spirit can't be broken. He arrives in prison and becomes a messiah figure in the eyes of his peers, earning their respect by challenging the prison establishment and, in the film's signature scene, scoffing boiled eggs to win a wager.

Luke's pal Dragline (George Kennedy) makes a bet with the other prisoners that he can eat 50 eggs in an hour. The men are confident Luke can't do it. 'Fifty eggs gotta weigh a good six pounds? A man's gut can't hold that. They'll swell up and bust him open?'

'They're gonna kill him,' says one as he throws his money down. Following a couple of humorous eating exercises, stretching his stomach's skin, Luke is ready. After eating 32 eggs rapidly, he looks beat. But his feeding fatigue is a ploy to drum up more betting interest. 'I wanna hear from some big money men. Where's all the high rollers?' asks Dragline. 'I believe you've got it all, Dragline. Every cent in camp is riding,' comes the reply.

Luke eventually reaches the target, but the punters aren't happy he swallowed the last egg within the time limit. They examine his mouth before laying the exhausted victor on a table covered in egg shells. An overhead camera looks down, Luke's arms are outstretched, his legs are crossed and his head is tilted in a crucifixion pose. The deification is complete.

'Do you play?' Crown asks.
'Try me.'
For a while, they concentrate on the game. Then Vicki starts stroking her arms.

(Michael Mann, US, 1995)

Hanna: I don't know how to do anything else.
McCauley: Neither do I.

'There was a real rapport between them; yet both men recognised one would probably kill the other. And subsequently Chuck was called out to an armed robbery and shot him six times,' says Mann. 'But it was the intimacy and mutual rapport that became the nucleus of the film.'

fields.headline: Battle for Lakeland Poets' soul
fields.standfirst: Wordsworth and Coleridge kindled their genius far from Grasmere, say West Country devotees
fields.trailText: It has been pushed off the literary map for 200 years, but now Somerset is fighting back. It is about to wage a campaign to reclaim the Romantic poets, Samuel Taylor Coleridge and William Wordsworth, from the Lake District.
fields.body:
It has been pushed off the literary map for 200 years, but now Somerset is fighting back. It is about to wage a campaign to reclaim the Romantic poets, Samuel Taylor Coleridge and William Wordsworth, from the Lake District.

Galvanised by a new film about the two radical writers, which has just been shot on location in the area, the West Country is feeling bullish. 'I suppose it is surprising that we have not made this link clear before,' said Elaine Ford, one of those working for recognition of Somerset's stake in the so-called 'Lakeland Poets'.

'We certainly have a very special story down here, and I believe people will find it fascinating to come and see some of the places that really inspired these poems. It is something that will be particularly interesting to visitors from overseas.'

In a concerted attack on the accepted idea that Dove Cottage in Grasmere is the true birthplace of the Romantic movement, West Country historians and tourist officers are pointing out that the two great poets of the late eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries actually met and wrote some of their best known lines in the South West, and not in the Lake District.

'The Rime of the Ancient Mariner', the haunting story of the curse of the albatross, and the fantastical poem 'Kubla Khan' were both composed by Coleridge after long walks near his Somerset home. He also plotted out the shape of the Lyrical Ballads with his friend and neighbour Wordsworth during walks they took together on the Quantock Hills in 1797 and 1798.

Cumbria and the Lakes have benefited for far too long, Ford and her colleagues in the Somerset tourist industry believe, from an interna tional literary association which turns out to be debatable.

Coleridge was born in Ottery St Mary, Devon, and lived in Nether Stowey at the foot of the Quantocks. Wordsworth, who was born in what is now Cumbria, moved to Alfoxton in Somerset with his sister Dorothy in the late 1700s. They went back to the Lake District at the turn of the century and spent the remainder of their lives up there, but the time the young poets spent together in the West Country was arguably their most productive and influential period.

Last summer film stars Linus Roache and John Hannah went to the Quantocks to shoot Pandemonium , a film version of the turbulent friendship. They shot one key sequence inside Wookey Hole, the vast cave network Coleridge visited, along with the nearby Cheddar Gorge, just before he created his mysterious Xanadu with its 'caverns measureless to man'.

While it is true the poet also took three grains of opium to ease the creative process, literary historians agree the caves and gorge are the geographical features that sparked his imagination. The poet was famously prevented from completing this work when a 'person on business' from the nearby village of Porlock disturbed him.

Coleridge's longer, ghostly poem 'The Rime of the Ancient Mariner' begins as a seafarer tells his story in a harbour that must be that at Watchet, on the edge of the Somerset Levels. So far the coastal town celebrates its claim to fame with a single, faded window display. In October things are due to change.

'Our booklets and new tours for small groups will highlight all the important places to visit,' said Ford, for whom the project has become a crusade.

Her fellow tourist officer on the other side of the county, Martin Woods, is more resigned about the way the Lake District has stolen a march on Somerset.

'The trouble is we have concentrated on the traditional coastal resorts like Minehead, and rather assumed the Lakes had already got the Romantic poets for good,' he said.

But for Marc Haynes, who runs a museum near Yeovil, the problem is that the county has been disorganised. 'We have had too many different district officers working on their own. Somerset is not a big county and we really should have been working together to get our message across.'

The Wordsworth Trust, based in Dove Cottage, Grasmere, is confidently waiting to knock back the West Country challenge.

'This is where Wordsworth grew up and it is where he returned in 1799 and lived for most of his life,' said Dr Robert Woof, who is the trust director. 'It is true that the period they spent in Somerset was perhaps the most vital vortex in English literature. It was a crucible, but it was not the whole story.

'Much of Wordsworth's work there in his Lyrical Bal lads was a reflection on his childhood years up here.'

This week the trust is running a winter school to mark 200 years since Coleridge and Wordsworth went to the Lakes together. 'We want to celebrate their amazing friendship and I hope this new film will do the same. I believe they did shoot some scenes up here as well.'

Woof has two concerns about Pandemonium ; first, the story may be used to champion the importance of Somerset over Dove Cottage and, second, Wordsworth may be portrayed as a traitor to the friendship, even as a spy. 'The relationship between them was symbiotic and so, of course, it was a difficult one. Coleridge's growing addiction to opium obviously caused them problems.'

Woof also suspects that the story will be simplified - yet, despite the coincidence that his daughter, the actress Emily Woof, will be playing the part of Dorothy Wordsworth, he was not consulted on the film.

'These men had a very close friendship and they only fell out for a short time. I would like their work to be celebrated all over Britain.'

fields.headline: Professor Richard Dawkins
fields.standfirst: Scientist, author
fields.trailText: I love the great lawyer scene in Jurassic Park. It is a moment of pure, sublime happiness, even though only one lawyer is eaten. Perhaps it would have been slightly more artistic if the tyrannosaur had tossed the lawyer in a graceful parabola straight to the back of its throat, as a toucan deals with a nut. But there's a lot to be said for the scene as it stands, and it has surely given much innocent pleasure to a great many people.
fields.body:
I love the great lawyer scene in Jurassic Park. It is a moment of pure, sublime happiness, even though only one lawyer is eaten. Perhaps it would have been slightly more artistic if the tyrannosaur had tossed the lawyer in a graceful parabola straight to the back of its throat, as a toucan deals with a nut. But there's a lot to be said for the scene as it stands, and it has surely given much innocent pleasure to a great many people.

During the scene when Dudley Moore, dressed as a nun, joins the nuns on the trampoline in Bedazzled I came nearer to dying of laughter than on any other occasion not involving John Cleese. I was helpless, winded from laughing, struggling to breathe.

I was also very impressed by the astounding liberty taken by Baz Luhrmann at the end of his terrifyingly futuristic Romeo And Juliet. The whole film is amazing enough: no West Side Story this, but real Shakespeare, shatteringly real. I was completely sceptical until I saw it, car chases, gunfights, helicopters and all. It works. But most memorable of all is the end, the main place where the plot significantly departs from Shakespeare. Juliet stirs awake before Romeo takes the poison. The audience sees it, but Romeo doesn't - until it is too late. When it came to tragedy, Shakespeare brooked no half measures, and one feels that he would have done it this way if he had thought of it.

Perhaps it would have been slightly more artistic if the tyrannosaur had tossed the lawyer in a graceful parabola straight to the back of its throat, as a toucan deals with a nut. But there's a lot to be said for the scene as it stands, and it has surely given much innocent pleasure to a great many people. During the scene when Dudley Moore, dressed as a nun, joins the nuns on the trampoline in Bedazzled I came nearer to dying of laughter than on any other occasion not involving John Cleese. I was helpless, winded from laughing, struggling to breathe. I was also very impressed by the astounding liberty taken by Baz Luhrmann at the end of his terrifyingly futuristic Romeo And Juliet. The whole film is amazing enough: no West Side Story this, but real Shakespeare, shatteringly real. I was completely sceptical until I saw it, car chases, gunfights, helicopters and all. It works. But most memorable of all is the end, the main place where the plot significantly departs from Shakespeare. Juliet stirs awake before Romeo takes the poison. The audience sees it, but Romeo doesn't - until it is too late. When it came to tragedy, Shakespeare brooked no half measures, and one feels that he would have done it this way if he had thought of it.

fields.body:
The opening scene of The Sound Of Music is always a thrill. The great panning shot across the mountains to the lovely Julie Andrews, one of Britain's greatest stars, about to burst into song, is a rollercoaster start to one of the most popular singalong movies in the gay community.

Battleship Potemkin, Eisenstein's modernist classic, defines the vertiginous image of the individual swept aside by blind social forces as an innocent child hurtles down the Odessa steps, a powerless victim of the struggle against tyranny and oppression.

Dumbo is Disney's most brilliant cartoon. A film all about difference and the hurt others can cause. Keeps sentimentality at bay with powerful animation and a great score. The moment when Dumbo falls from the top of the big tent and starts to fly is triumphant.

fields.headline: Tony Benn
fields.trailText: My first scene is from a film called The Life And Death Of Colonel Blimp, from 1943. Young Blimp is in a restaurant in Berlin. A band is playing. He sees a German, who was imprisoned in South Africa, and asks the band to play a tune which used to be played in the South African prison. The German is enraged and pays the band to stop. Blimp buys them beer, and they play the tune again. This continues until Blimp and the German are almost spitting at each other.

He sees a German, who was imprisoned in South Africa, and asks the band to play a tune which used to be played in the South African prison. The German is enraged and pays the band to stop. Blimp buys them beer, and they play the tune again. This continues until Blimp and the German are almost spitting at each other.

The second scene is from a film called Proud Valley, with Paul Robeson. A black Pennsylvanian man starts work in a South Wales mine. The other miners are not too happy that he is black until they realise that they are also blackened. In my favourite scene a choir is singing at the eisteddfod, but the lead singer is not present. The conductor is about to sing the solo part when they hear Robeson singing outside and are spellbound.

My final moment is from The Railway Children, when the children see their father again through the steam on the station platform. I am always terribly moved by that moment and so are my children.

fields.headline: Chris Cunningham
fields.standfirst: Director of music videos and new film William Gibson's Neuromancer
fields.trailText: My all-time favourite film moment is the love scene from Blade Runner, with Harrison Ford and Sean Young. It's about 10 minutes long and within it are all the things I love most about film.
fields.body:
My all-time favourite film moment is the love scene from Blade Runner, with Harrison Ford and Sean Young. It's about 10 minutes long and within it are all the things I love most about film.

The scene begins in Deckard's apartment. Rachel has just saved Deckard's life. The minimal and awkward exchanges between the two are in perfect harmony with the music and sound design. Waves of sound and light bleach out the frame randomly and fill the spaces in the scene with a rich ambience. Rachel watches Deckard clean himself up whilst Vangelis's music becomes progressively more abstract. This moment has an ambiguity to it that is impossible to describe, but gives me goosebumps every time.

Second to this is the scene in The Elephant Man where John Merrick (John Hurt) has escaped from the circus and the brutal clutches of Bytes (Freddie Jones), and is making his way back to London. On arrival at the station, cloth sacking covering his face, he is harassed by an oik who keeps asking "'ere mister, why is your 'ead so big?" Merrick tries his hardest to evade the rapidly growing posse of nosey people who eventually drive him down into a public toilet. Cornered, his sack is whipped off and the onlookers gasp. At his wit's end John Merrick cries, "I am not an animal!" It is difficult to pick a best scene from The Elephant Man, because in my opinion it is a perfect film. What I remember most about this scene is how desperately I wanted to jump into the TV set and machine-gun down all those people who were busting his balls. I can't watch it too often as it always makes me sob.

fields.headline: Peter Greenaway
fields.standfirst: Director
fields.trailText: In Boyar's Plot by Eisenstein the moment when the film changes from black and white to colour is very important. The change and contrast in language, from black and white to colour, reflects the move from the past to the future.
fields.body:
In Boyar's Plot by Eisenstein the moment when the film changes from black and white to colour is very important. The change and contrast in language, from black and white to colour, reflects the move from the past to the future.

I also love the moment in Abel Gance's Napoleon when it goes from one screen to three screens for similar sorts of reasons. Again there is a huge dynamic change and contrast from a single vision to multiple visions.

Finally I think that the moment in Resnais' Last Year In Marienbad, when the organ music begins, introduces the most intelligent piece of filmmaking ever.

fields.trailText: Two of my favourite films are Les Enfants Du Paradis and The Seven Samurai and I really couldn't pick out any individual scenes from them - they're all wonderful. But there is an extraordinary moment from another Kurosawa film, Ran, when one of the daughters-in-law commits a murder. She was played by a fantastic Japanese actress, Mieko Harada, who lets out an incredible, blood-chilling scream. It comes from absolute tranquillity, and this actress is in a beautiful kimono, in an empty castle. Another moments is from the end of The Sting when Newman says, "It isn't everything," and Redford replies, "But it's close." It isn't just the dialogue, but the little laugh Newman gives.

fields.headline: Joan Bakewell

fields.trailText: I love the encounter in the desert between Peter O'Toole and Omar Sharif in Lawrence of Arabia. It is a truly cinematic moment, a moment impossible to recreate on the television screen. I like the idea of cinema as an epic experience.
fields.body:
I love the encounter in the desert between Peter O'Toole and Omar Sharif in Lawrence of Arabia. It is a truly cinematic moment, a moment impossible to recreate on the television screen. I like the idea of cinema as an epic experience.

In Eisenstein's Alexander Nevsky there is the scene of the knights' advance across the frozen lake. It is black and white, obviously, and you can see this frozen lake, but no people. Then a great throbbing sound begins to build and eventually a huge, charging army appears over the horizon. Leading with just the sound can be very chilling and threatening.

The scene in The English Patient, when Juliette Binoche swings up to look at the frescos is wonderful. There is such sheer pleasure in the camerawork and [director] Anthony Minghella really draws the scene out, revelling in it.

fields.trailText: The last scene in Failsafe, a film about a nuclear stand-off , depicts the last 10 seconds of life in New York before the Bomb goes off. Ordinary people, about to end their lives in a nuclear flash, are shown doing ordinary things. I love the scene in Goodfellas when Joe Pesci challenges Ray Liotta for apparently laughing at him. A tremendous moment of Scorsese interplay. In John Carpenter's Dark Star, there's one of the funniest sci-fi scenes ever. A spaceship crew member tries to entertain his dour friend with a box of tricks that includes a funny nose, glasses with eyes on springs, and other hopelessly tired visual gags.

fields.headline: At last, at moment 65...
fields.standfirst: Cuban novelist and former film critic G. Cabrera Infante waits a long time for our list's first foreign-language film
fields.trailText: Cuban novelist and former film critic G. Cabrera Infante waits a long time for our list's first foreign-language film
fields.body:
Let's face it: English is the language of the movies. It was so even before the pictures began to talk, as D. W. Griffith's The Birth Of A Nation (1915) established the pattern for epics. Remember Cecil B. DeMille's saying about God being the Great Producer in Heaven? That meant, of course, a God speaking the Gospel in the King's or Queen's English. And, later on, in Californian or Brooklynese.

That said, you've missed some great moments from non-Anglophone masterpieces. Think simply of Japan. How about something from Akira Kurosawa's Seven Samurai (1954) or Ran (1985), Mizoguchi's Ugetsu Monogatari (1953), or Ozu's Tokyo Story (1953); more recently, you might have mentioned something from Takeshi Kitano (Sonatine, Hana-Bi etc).

Think Mexico and you might think actor Gold Hat Alfonso Bedoya telling Bogart: 'I know whoo ju are' in the Treasure Of The Sierra Madre. But how about, instead, exiled Spaniard Luis Buñuel assembling a razor blade, some needle and thread and putting them in the hands of the madly jealous bourgeois husband (Arturo de Cordova) as he prepares to carry out an improptu infibulation of his wife (Delia Garces) in Buñuel's Mexican-made El (1952).

Turn to France, and where's the boarding house pillow battle from Jean Vigo's Zéro De Conduite (1933)? Or any of several scenes from Marcel Carné's Les Enfants Du Paradis (1945)? Jean-Louis Barrault miming the pickpocket that he has seen picking the fat man's watch to exonerate Arletty, for instance. From the German cinema, you might have chosen Fritz Lang's masterpiece M (1951), and the moment when child murderer Peter Lorre discovers a big M drawn in chalk on his back.

Indian cinema first made a mainstream impact in the west with Satyajit Ray's Pather Panchali (1955). This and Ray's subsequent films, Aparajito and Apur Sansar became known as The Apu Trilogy. From this, Apu's reading of the poem of his life stands out. As for Italy, I would choose the white peacock landing on the square as a winged snowball in Federico Fellini's Amarcord (1973).

It always helped, of course, for the non-Anglos to change the language in which they worked. A lesson Fritz Lang learned very well. My favourite 'outsider-turns-insider moment' is from Lang's Scarlet Street, the director now working in Hollywood and helping to shape film noir. The moment is when Edward G. Robinson's obsessive cashier/Sunday painter paints prostitute Joan Bennett's toes - a scene lifted toe by toe in Kubrick's Lolita, where Humbert Humbert is definitely not a Sunday painter!

fields.headline: Beg, borrow or steal
fields.standfirst: Tom O'Sullivan on the fine line between plagiarism and pastiche in advertising's film moments
fields.trailText: Tom O'Sullivan on the fine line between plagiarism and pastiche in advertising's film moments
fields.body:
'People came up and asked me what HE was like to work with,' says Paul Street who, in 1997, literally brought Steve McQueen back to life by re-creating his finest moments from the film Bullitt in an ad for the Ford Puma car. 'They didn't realise that he was dead.' In fact McQueen had been dead for 17 years. And the closest Street got to the screen legend was via a hefty dollop of editing equipment. The ad put McQueen back on the streets of San Francisco, back on our television screens and, I suspect, Bullitt on this list.

Rather than just pinching a scene and re-creating a pale pastiche, the makers shot new footage, spliced them together with the original film and hired Bullitt cinematographer William Fraker as a consultant to make sure we couldn't see the join.

With visual references back to other McQueen films including The Great Escape and The Thomas Crown Affair - which also make this list - the ad is more a homage to the actor than a simple device to use him to sell cars, although there is no doubt that it also did that. But it is the exception. Advertising has stolen from film and not always treated it well. The Sound Of Music, The Great Escape, Ben Hur, Singing In The Rain, Casablanca, Star Wars, Ice Cold In Alex, Thelma And Louise, The Birds and numerous other films mentioned in this list have been lifted to sell everything from beer to cough sweets to cars. Especially cars where, because of either the epic nature of the sell or the fact that there are big budgets available, advertisers seem to find the movies irrestistible.

'I quite liked the ad,' says Peter Yates who directed Bullitt back in 1968. 'My only complaint is that they didn't ask me to direct it. It was very well made and nicely exploited McQueen's intriguing persona. In principle I don't object to that sort of plagiarism when it's done well. But I've seen ads in the past using stars like Fred Astaire and John Wayne which were just terrible. It was really quite flattering.'

For advertising agencies, the attraction is clear. If there is no creative idea for the ad, it is much simpler to re-create a scene with which people feel comfortable. It is immediate. There is no need to explain the meaning of certain iconic images. But most of it is cheap plagiarism.

However, it is not just advertisers who pinch from film, but also other filmmakers. The red coat in Schindler's List looks remarkably like the red coat in Nicolas Roeg's 1973 Don't Look Now. The fact that the coat then cropped up in a 1997 Peugeot ad confirms the idea that a good image is never too old to be resuscitated.

But it is a simple formula that doesn't always work. In the same year that Ford ran the Bullitt ad it also ran a campaign which it would rather forget. It was a skit on The Full Monty where a team of male strippers used a Ford Escort for getting to gigs. But the ad featured five white strippers and was immediately accused of racism for omitting the black character Horse. The ad was pulled. Ford apologised.

That only leaves the likes of Renault for its awful Sound Of Music rip-off, Tunes for Star Wars, and numerous other advertisers to apologise for their small screen 'borrowing' from their big screen cousins.

fields.headline: Are effects really that special?
fields.standfirst: Some of our moments result from technological advance. But we seem more interested in the human than the  technology argues  Rob Kenner
fields.trailText: Some of our moments result from technological advance. But we seem more interested in the human than the technology argues Rob Kenner
fields.body:
More than any other art form, cinema is inextricably intertwined with technology. But the $10 billion-a-year industry is in for a big shock when, in the not-too-distant future, movies can be streamed or downloaded on demand - and we will be able to view any movie ever made on our internet-ready telescreens.

And while many may still prefer a night out at the movies to the pauseable, rewindable, less magical small-screen VCR experience, this highlights the fact that the distribution monopolies are crumbling.

And as that accelerates, the big boys and the young upstarts will be separated by a mere mouse-click. But it is not just how we will view films in the future that is influenced by technological change. It has already changed what we see - and not always for the better. Steven Spielberg may have been proud of his big robotic shark - he named it Bruce, after his lawyer - but what made Jaws so terrifying was that he kept Bruce submerged in the audience's imagination for the first two-thirds of the film. Such restraint is almost unimaginable today. Directors want to show us everything because they can.

Movies like The Matrix and Toy Story are primarily showcases for expensive digital effects, all paid for by an overabundance of corporate-sponsored product placement. It is significant in this Observer list that even with moments from the likes of Star Wars and 2001, it is not the effects which are remembered but the imagery or dialogue. Ironically the conditions created by the likes of The Matrix paved the way for The Blair Witch Project. Made for 'the price of a nice car', it became the most profitable film in recent history by sticking to the fundamentals of storytelling. But the real promise of high-tech is the widespread availability of cheap desktop editing suites and affordable image-capturing devices. Digital tape, which costs much less than film, provides superior sound and increasingly better visual resolution. The effect has been to demystify and democratise the art and science of movie making. Ten years ago, a very jaded Francis Ford Copolla made a pre-Blair Witch prediction: 'One day, some little fat girl in Ohio is going to be the new Mozart and make a beautiful film with her father's camcorder and the so-called professionalism about movies will be destroyed forever.' Bring on the fat girl.

Rob Kenner is a writer on technology for Wired magazine

fields.headline: How to get a moment to sound good
fields.trailText: Composing soundtracks was a kind of accident for me - I never thought I would ever compose for film. Merry Christmas Mr Lawrence was my debut score, but I was actually brought in as an actor first by the director, Nagisa Oshima, though my principal career had been in pop music, with the Yellow Magic Orchestra. So at our first meeting I just asked him if I could compose the music. And so it began
fields.body:
Composing soundtracks was a kind of accident for me - I never thought I would ever compose for film. Merry Christmas Mr Lawrence was my debut score, but I was actually brought in as an actor first by the director, Nagisa Oshima, though my principal career had been in pop music, with the Yellow Magic Orchestra. So at our first meeting I just asked him if I could compose the music. And so it began

Many of the films I've scored since are based in very different and specific cultures: Peter Kosminsky's Wuthering Heights, Bernardo Bertolucci's The Sheltering Sky, Pedro Almodovar's High Heels. That's one of the reasons I take them. Every time is a good learning experience, a good education. I'm lazy, so I have to be given a challenge! It's also a good way to learn about different cultures and, of course, it's fascinating to work with different cultural artists. Before accepting a commission, I always check a director's reputation or existing films. If he or she is a new director, I trust my intuition, but of course the subject matter is important. I try to get the script, if I'm allowed to read it, but I have to be interested in the subject.

Another important factor is how big the budget for music is, or how much time I have. If it's two days, I won't do it. I normally like eight weeks for each project, which is a long time in the Japanese film industry, although it might be a little more normal here and in the US. I usually start working after the director puts together a rough edit, at the beginning of post-production. I don't touch the edit. With each director I work in a different way. Bertolucci, for example, has strong views, so he might not need so many suggestions. I've worked with him three times now - The Last Emperor, The Sheltering Sky and Little Buddha - and we're talking about working again , so I'm glad our relationship is still. The first time I was a little too shy, but by the third time I made sure I was not too shy! He can be very precise about music, and he'll sometimes give strict instructions about the instrumentation: 'I need to hear a solo violin here', for instance. He also has a desire to hear something he's never heard before. The director and the composer need to talk a lot - yell a lot! - but, naturally, the composer has the weaker hand. I try to protect my corner but, again, the director will win - it's his film!

What's more, success often depends on developing this sort of strong relationship with the director. I recently worked with Mr Oshima again on his new movie Gohatto, which means 'forbidden' or 'taboo'. In Japanese cinema, there's a certain musical sub-category - the Samurai movie. You always hear this stereotypical music, and I hate it! So the first thing I told Mr Oshima was that I would not compose that kind of music, and he understood completely.

People ask me which scores I'm proudest of. The strongest melody is perhaps the music for The Last Emperor. Or maybe Merry Christmas Mr Lawrence. Each piece of music has a different character -they're like your children - different colour eyes, different colour hair, different colour skin. But you know, we musicians get carried away.

Sakamoto's soundtracks include 'Merry Christmas Mr Lawrence', 'The Last Emperor', 'The Sheltering Sky', 'High Heels', 'Little Buddha' and 'Love Is The Devil'.

fields.headline: Words and pictures
fields.standfirst: Britain's finest young filmmaker, Lynne Ramsay, director of last year's Ratcatcher, ponders the competing claims of 'verbal' and 'visual' moments
fields.trailText: Britain's finest young filmmaker, Lynne Ramsay, director of last year's Ratcatcher, ponders the competing claims of 'verbal' and 'visual' moments
fields.body:
Overheard in a pub:
Man 1: 'Open the pod bay door now, Hal.'
Man 2: 'I'm sorry Dave, I can't do that.'
(from 2001: A Space Odyssey)

There's something fascinating about record collector minds, hoards of quotes shared and dealt like cards, lines traded, images bought. It's a more private and difficult thing to describe complex emotions; easier to slip into character: 'Are you looking at me?' The line, proffered by Travis Bickle, in Martin Scorsese's Taxi Driver, is shorthand for a psyche much more difficult to articulate.

Through this shared experience we can spar, compete, bond, identify, even threaten. We can be De Niro for a moment (right). This line has become one of the definitions of cool machismo (as so many of Scorsese's lines have). Yet we forget all the great lines from the bad films. We also forget the sound, the ghosts that pulled us sideways but we remember all the songs from The Wizard Of Oz.

Whatever we take from a film - personal, public, private, subconscious - a list can only contain moments that are often a key to the recognition of something more complex. This is the case with the above quote from 2001. The monotonous dialogue is not the most interesting thing about the scene. More menacing is the ingenious use of silence - there is no sound in space. I find it difficult to write with reference to the most memorable moments in film, when for me the best moments in films are truly irreducible. I walked out from the last film I saw, sat down somewhere, had coffee, and I'd already forgotten where I'd been for the previous two hours. When I walk into a cinema, I want to leave with an experience unrepeatable, unquotable and indescribable. For this to happen at all is a small miracle and the measure of a great film is how long that feeling will last.

For example, the final scene in Mouchette by Robert Bresson (which is one of my most memorable moments) carries a vast emotional power. In the film, 14-year-old Mouchette, burdened by responsibilities beyond her age, becomes more and more of an outcast in a small village full of petty-minded hypocrisy.

In the final scene we see her for the first time as a little girl playing a simple game of rolling down a grassy verge. Then we realise she is at the edge of a lake. Three times she rolls down the hill towards the water. What is playful to start with quickly becomes unnerving. She rolls out of frame. We hear the sound of her slipping into the lake without struggle. We see a shot of the still water. No words can really describe how it makes you feel. It has no dialogue. It's so simple, compelling, dreamlike.

Lynne Ramsay is currently working on an adaptation of Alan Warner's novel 'Morvern Callar'.

fields.headline: The triumph of craftsmen
fields.trailText: Perhaps it's not surprising that the directors who come out on top are strong visual stylists. In fact, those most frequently cited in the poll - Steven Spielberg (six moments), Stanley Kubrick (four), Alfred Hitchcock (three), David Lean (three) and Ridley Scott (three) - are storyboard directors noted for the time they spend in pre-production and their precision on the set. The presence on the list of the last three gives the lie to the sneering mot of François Truffaut (a surprising absence from the list, incidentally) that 'British cinema' is a contradiction in terms - especially as Kubrick and Spielberg have done much of their best work in this country.
fields.body:
Perhaps it's not surprising that the directors who come out on top are strong visual stylists. In fact, those most frequently cited in the poll - Steven Spielberg (six moments), Stanley Kubrick (four), Alfred Hitchcock (three), David Lean (three) and Ridley Scott (three) - are storyboard directors noted for the time they spend in pre-production and their precision on the set. The presence on the list of the last three gives the lie to the sneering mot of François Truffaut (a surprising absence from the list, incidentally) that 'British cinema' is a contradiction in terms - especially as Kubrick and Spielberg have done much of their best work in this country.

Most of the sequences by these five are skilfully edited and/or involve special effects. Only two arose serendipitously during shooting - the mirage-like first appearance of Omar Sharif in Lawrence Of Arabia, the product of an optical discovery on location, and Harrison Ford's Indiana Jones suddenly pulling a gun on an Arab swordsman in Raiders Of The Lost Ark, a happy invention on the set. With the exception of the football sequence from Ken Loach's Kes, the cinema's celebrated improvisers (eg Andy Warhol, John Cassavetes, Derek Jarman, R.W. Fassbinder) haven't made the top 100 list.

Of the 19 moments from our top five directors, only the confrontation between Indiana Jones and the Arab is designed to elicit laughter, and it involves a death. Revealingly, the scene from Four Weddings And A Funeral is the film's one stab at seriousness, and in fact less than a fifth of the 100 moments chosen by readers are comic. Missing from the list are the cinema's great comedians - Charlie Chaplin, Buster Keaton, Harold Lloyd, the Marx Brothers, Laurel and Hardy, W.C. Fields, Mae West, Will Hay and George Formby. Nor is there any moment from an Ealing Comedy or a Carry On picture. In France no such list would have omitted the name of Jerry Lewis, even if the editors had been forced to rig the votes to retain their boulevard cred. Maybe because comedy is so much a matter of taste, there was too wide a spread of choices.

Immediately after the five directors with three or more citations are five directors named for two films each - Sergio Leone, Brian De Palma, Martin Scorsese, Quentin Tarantino and Francis Ford Coppola. Interestingly, the oldest of these was Italian, while the others are Italian-Americans and still very active. Is there something cultural there?

TV directors must grab audiences at the outset, then hold them with dramatic hooks that precede every commercial. Cinema directors, having persuaded their patrons to part with their money at the box office, can conduct themselves in a more teasingly sophisticated fashion. They can puzzle, disturb or even bore in the first scene, though only the commercially reckless would do that in the finale - Welles, for instance in Citizen Kane (though by 1979 this conclusion was so celebrated that Spielberg paid homage to it in Raiders Of The Lost Ark). In fact only six moments on the list occur in opening sequences - the D-Day assault in Private Ryan, the razored eye in Buñuel's Un Chien Andalou (one of the few silent moments), Pip meeting Magwitch in Lean's Great Expectations, the vulnerable girl swimmer in Jaws, Woody Allen's constantly revised tributes to New York in Manhattan, David Niven's bomber pilot coming in on a wing and a prayer in A Matter Of Life And Death. However, 21 unforgettable moments - a fifth of the total - figure in final sequences, those images and lines of dialogue that are most vivid as you leave the cinema. Incidentally, is there any great movie that ends ineffectually or unmemorably?

webTitle: What will top the list in 2010?

fields.headline: What will top the list in 2010?
fields.standfirst: Andrew Collins looks ahead and imagines some memorable moments from the future. (We can but hope.)
fields.trailText: Andrew Collins looks ahead and imagines some memorable moments from the future. (We can but hope.)
fields.body:
Okay, You've had your say, and the best 100 moments of the first century of film have been handsomely collated. But what now? Which classic moments will imprint themselves on our collective cinema-going imagination in the decades to come? Will technological advance or emerging trends in celebrity megalomania and writer-empowerment affect what turns a length of celluloid (or a less-romantic fistful of digital noughts and ones) into a magic moment? Or will it be the same old collection of murders, courtroom speeches and Mexican standoffs? Here are our 10 movie moments of the near-future.

The astonishing 20-minute sequence in Lars Von Triers' My Arse when he leaves his camera rolling in a flight case in the back of his car while he drives to the airport. Twenty minutes of total darkness accompanied only by the sound of a car engine and some bumping encapsulates everything Dogme 2005 stood for.

The denouement of Quentin Tarantino's remake of Gone With The Wind in which Laurence Fishburne, playing Rhett Butler, takes Scarlet (Juliette Lewis) in his arms and utters the immortal line, 'Frankly, bitch, I don't give a fuck.'

Roberto Benigni's devastating balloon-folding routine in his controversial, award-winning comedy about genocide in Rwanda, It Could Be Worse.

Vinnie Jones, plays a maverick environmental health inspector, triumphing over the giant cow that has been terrorising London in Moo, with the much-quoted wisecrack, 'No milk today, fanks.' Ker-boom!

The knife fight between Leonardo DiCaprio and a completely computer-generated James Dean at the Griffith Observatory in Gus Van Sant's 50th-anniversary remake of Rebel Without A Cause.

'It tastes good.' Bill Clinton (a heavily made-up Billy Bob Thornton) enjoys that special cigar moment with Monica Lewinsky (Christina Ricci) in Oliver Stone's uncompromising biopic, WJC.

Tom Cruise's pivotal courtroom speech in Cameron Crowe's Coming Clean. Cruise plays a huge Hollywood star who risks all by admitting his homosexuality at a libel hearing on the eve of release of his latest film. (Anne Heche plays his wife.)

The first half-hour of Spielberg's Gulf War epic The Desert And Private Hope. The rest is sentimentalised propaganda, but that realistic carpet bombing sequence

Robin Williams' head explodes in David Cronenberg's Scanners II. Not a great film, but at least Williams shuts up.

The tear-jerking death of the first goat (voiced by James Van Der Beek) in Disney's back-to-basics animated adaptation of The Three Billy Goats Gruff. The Troll is voiced by George Clooney. Songs by Randy Newman.

fields.headline: Director's Cut
fields.standfirst: The scene they wish they had directed
fields.trailText: The scene they wish they had directed
fields.body:
Spike Lee

The greatest closing shot is in Billy Wilder's Ace In The Hole, where Kirk Douglas drops dead in front of the camera. Billy Wilder! His work is amazing. Another scene is Elia Kazan's On The Waterfront where Brando has to walk to the line-up. I'm very glad that I'm friends with Waterfront screenwriter Budd Shulberg. And then there's the 'Tonight' quartet in West Side Story

Bryan Singer

Close Encounters Of The Third Kind when the alien mothership lands. It's one of the great commercial art movies of all time. The scene tells a magnificent story while at the same time not really telling us what is going on. It is speaking through music. You don't know why the spaceship has taken the people, why it is returning them. You don't know who the aliens are. You don't understand any of those things, but for some reason it all seems to make sense. You feel an experience rather than being told what it is you should think or feel. But I have to admit that it is partly born out of my love of special effects and a fascination with life on other planets.

Michael Mann

I'd like to have done the war room scenes with those spectacular sets in Dr Strangelove and I would change nothing. I especially like all the stuff with Peter Sellers. I just crack up whenever I see it. I just marvel at it. It's a brilliant combination of a sense of doom and foreboding and dark comedy at the same time. It's so extreme and out there. There's such spectacular invention happening. I'd also probably have liked to do the last scene in Casablanca and again I'd have changed nothing.

fields.headline: Just a moment?
fields.standfirst: Philip French analyses the fast and loose way you have interpreted a 'moment'. It might be a second or half an hour.
fields.trailText: Philip French analyses the fast and loose way you have interpreted a 'moment'. It might be a second or half an hour.
fields.body:
You, Observer readers, have been versatile in your interpretation of what constitutes a moment. A good many which make the list are those moments you can almost freeze in time - such as the one in first place on the list, the blinding flash when Kujan (Chazz Palmintieri) gets the plot in The Usual Suspects, or the 46th moment when, in The Crying Game, Fergus (Stephen Rea) discovers that he hadn't quite known Dil (Jaye Davidson) as well as he thought. They are shocking revelations we have shared with the characters.

But several selections correspond to the loose definition of 'I'll be with you in a moment' which could be anything between the five minutes Gene Kelly takes to sing and dance in the rain (or the milk, as pedants will have it) or the 25 minutes it takes Captain Miller (Tom Hanks) and his company to get from the landing craft to the cliffs on Omaha Beach. But not even this last epic can compete with perhaps the longest 'moment' in the final list, the peepshow booth encounter from Paris Texas as the former lovers, played by Harry Dean Stanton and Nastassja Kinski, meet.

However you have chosen to define a 'moment', detailing a list of favourites is a very different exercise from asking for a series of favourite films. It's likelier to elicit a more interesting and honest response. More interesting because voters will be less inclined to produce a balanced, thoughtful list that will attest to their education, intelligence and good taste - the usual suspects, as it were. (As opposed to The Usual Suspects.) Readers, we thought, would be more tempted to vote for a scene from a film that normally doesn't make it on to 'sanctioned' lists - and so it occasionally proved. (The Princess Bride, for instance, chosen for its unconventional sword fight.). Put on the spot, you are forced to be specific in describing the key images and scenes that have remained lodged in the mind's eye. For more than just a moment.
