fields.headline: Listless Celtic sunk
fields.trailText: Celtic surpassed even their own moderate standards with probably their most pathetic performance of the season, their appalling lack of backbone allowing an initially poor Hearts team to worry them out of a two-goal lead. As declarations of inadequacy go, this was a work of art.
fields.body:
Celtic surpassed even their own moderate standards with probably their most pathetic performance of the season, their appalling lack of backbone allowing an initially poor Hearts team to worry them out of a two-goal lead. As declarations of inadequacy go, this was a work of art.

Yet, if the majority of Celtic supporters took their seats with mild apprehension over the composition of their team - some valuable regulars missing because of injury - it would have been dispelled by their quickly formed impression of Hearts.

The Tynecastle side for some time evinced the kind of lifelessness that comes from general unhappiness. Hearts appeared ill at ease with themselves and by the time they were two goals behind, it was clear that their self-belief, their inclination towards any resistance, had been diminished to the point of non-existence.

Celtic, not overly impressive themselves, were so far ahead in possession and in goals that the image of rampaging Hearts fans demanding changes at their club began to form in the mind. This made the goal with which Colin Cameron halved the deficit a genuine shock.

The visitors had shown neither the capability nor even the urge to bother Celtic in their own half when the ball arrived at the feet of Dar ren Jackson on the left. As Cameron began his run through the middle, Jackson quickly realised that there was not a green-and-white shirt keeping him company.

The rest was fundamental, the pass rolled into Cameron's path, allowing the diligent little midfielder to run towards the unprotected Jonathan Gould and clip the ball shoulder high into the net behind him.

The effect that had on the middle third of the game said as much about Celtic's character as it did about Hearts' resurgence. Instead of shrugging off the moment as an aberration and resuming their dominant role, John Barnes's players allowed the goal to affect them to such an extent that it was not difficult to imagine Hearts contriving an equaliser.

Lubomir Moravcik contributed more than anyone to the restoration of some composure, quite fitting in that he had done so much to help establish the authority which had taken his team into their two-goal lead. The opening goal from the Slovakian midfielder was characteristically stunning.

Stilian Petrov gathered the ball from what had begun as a throw-in and pushed the ball forward to Moravcik, who had his back to goal. He held it until he could turn into a shooting position and simply rooted Antti Niemi to his line as his right foot sent the ball hurtling and dipping away to the goalkeeper's left from 18 yards.

Moravcik's contribution to the second was as valuable as if he had actually scored it. Receiving Petrov's pass on the left, his left-foot shot was blocked by Niemi. As he gathered the rebound, he located Viduka making his way between two defenders and simply placed the ball on the big Australian's forehead, allowing him to send it over the line from only three yards out.

But the impetus from Cameron's goal not only suffused the Hearts players with a new urgency, but seemed to induce in Celtic a paralysing anxiety. The latitude their defence allowed the visitors made Gary Naysmith's equaliser seem inevitable.

It was Fitzroy Simpson who held the ball in midfield as Naysmith made his run into the left side of the area, timing the pass perfectly to give Naysmith the chance to thunder a left-foot shot high past Gould.

What followed - an unmissable cluelessness among the Celtic as to how to cope - made Hearts's winner almost an inevitability. It was left to substitute Tommy Johnson to provide the ammunition, conceding a penalty by pushing Jackson as he moved towards Simpson's cross. Cameron's penalty conversion was touched over the line by Gould.

fields.headline: Running off at the mouth
fields.trailText: Roy Keane's 'bullying' of referee Andy D'Urso is an open and shut case... isn't it?
fields.body:
We've all seen the pictures: it's an open and shut case isn't it? Here's big bad Roy Keane, with his bulging veins and invincible bank account, bullying poor little Andy D'Urso over the first league penalty to be awarded against Manchester United at Old Trafford in six years.

Recognising that the two-minute hiatus in last weekend's victory over Middlesbrough looked unsavoury, Sir Alex Ferguson just about managed to apologise a couple of days later, although it is hard to imagine the United manager giving his captain the hairdryer treatment over an incident which showed just how well the pupil has learned his master's technique. There is not a manager in the league who does not want his players to perform with passion, and though Keane and Co might have overstepped the mark to give all the club's regular detractors a chance to air their prejudices and complain that Manchester United get away with murder, the fact remains that Ferguson's boys are the leading team in England, quite possibly in Europe, at playing each match as if their lives depended on it.

Which is precisely why everybody hates them. Jealousy, pure and simple. Apart from the staggering number of people on radio phone-ins expressing dissatisfaction with United's arrogance or Ferguson's one-eyed views, the most regular theme is the fan disenchanted with his own team. 'They just don't care,' is the common lament. 'They get paid more in a week than we earn in a year, and they are happy to collect their money whatever the result.'

No one has ever said this about Manchester United. It is practically written into football's constitution that wealth and achievement quickly lead to complacency and dissipation, so it was perfectly reasonable to ask Ferguson after last year's Treble whether he thought it might be difficult to keep his players focused and motivated. 'Nah,' he replied tersely. 'We've still got the hunger. I've no worries at all on that score.'

Last weekend's events bore this out, as well as conforming to Ferguson's long-held philosophy. 'Football is played by creatures of flesh and blood and feeling,' he wrote in his autobiography. 'Tactics are important but men win football matches. The best teams stand out because they are teams . There is a constant flow of mutual support among the players, and a manager should engender that sense of unity.'

Well, Ferguson has certainly been doing that. It might not be pretty, may indeed be reprehensible, but United's sense of unity is frightening. Those rushing to condemn Keane's gang-slanging should first ask themselves whether they would like him in their side and then consider what they expect for £52,000 a week. A headshake and a few Irish curses?

If United wanted a player who would react to a dubious decision by standing open-mouthed with his hands on his hips they could have got one much more cheaply, since the league is full of them. What you get for the money with Keane is the single best embodiment of the champion's mentality that runs through Old Trafford. It has a lot to do with the manager and the huge crowds, but is mostly due to the organic process by which members of a consistently winning team come to believe in each other, refusing to accept weakness in themselves and becoming intolerant of failings in others. This is what top-level professional sport leads to. Corinthianism is an amateur concept.

Which brings us neatly to the man at the centre of the row, Mr D'Urso of Essex and his measly £700 match fee. If it is unfair that millionaires like Keane should be able to terrorise officials on a relative pittance, then the only answer is to upgrade referees' pay and improve their perceived status to somewhere approaching that of the players. At the moment referees get it in the neck because players and managers regard them as bumbling amateurs and therefore fair game. There was widespread sympathy for Mr D'Urso last week because he looked out of his depth and in some danger, yet appearances are often deceptive.

Patrick Mortimer, a project leader in sports science at Edinburgh University, is currently investigating stress and conflict management on behalf of the Rugby Football Union's referees. He claims D'Urso handled last week's pressure well, and may not have been anywhere near as agitated as might be imagined.

'I would love to have had a heart monitor on him,' Mortimer said. 'Looking at TV and newspaper pictures only gives you a two-dimensional image. You can see how the situation developed, but you don't know how the individuals were relating to each other. What we have found when using heart monitors with referees is that they run about 180 beats per minute during the normal course of a match, which is pretty respectable. When conflict arises you would expect the heart rate to increase, and sometimes it does, but only with less experienced referees who let the situation get to them. With good referees, and this is a reliable performance indicator, the heart rate actually stabilises. They recognise a situation and are ready to deal with it; they have strategies for taking control.'

Mortimer has identified five broad strategies - accommodating, avoiding, collaborating, competing and compromising - and says D'Urso was using the first last Saturday. 'He withdrew himself from the point of contact and went to where he could see the whole pitch, all the time keeping his eye on Keane as the major threat,' he explained. 'He was patient and he appeared calm, although possibly he forgot Jaap Stam could have been sent off. It is not easy to remember the whole rulebook when players crowd you out, that's why managers instruct players to do it. But standing still and confronting Keane might have inflamed the situation. I think he coped quite well, though it's clear to me that referees in general need a lot more support.

'Managers only want professional referees for accountability, so they can be sacked like they can, but I can think of many more constructive reasons than that.'
fields.bodyText: We've all seen the pictures: it's an open and shut case isn't it? Here's big bad Roy Keane, with his bulging veins and invincible bank account, bullying poor little Andy D'Urso over the first league penalty to be awarded against Manchester United at Old Trafford in six years. Recognising that the two-minute hiatus in last weekend's victory over Middlesbrough looked unsavoury, Sir Alex Ferguson just about managed to apologise a couple of days later, although it is hard to imagine the United manager giving his captain the hairdryer treatment over an incident which showed just how well the pupil has learned his master's technique. There is not a manager in the league who does not want his players to perform with passion, and though Keane and Co might have overstepped the mark to give all the club's regular detractors a chance to air their prejudices and complain that Manchester United get away with murder, the fact remains that Ferguson's boys are the leading team in England, quite possibly in Europe, at playing each match as if their lives depended on it. Which is precisely why everybody hates them. Jealousy, pure and simple. Apart from the staggering number of people on radio phone-ins expressing dissatisfaction with United's arrogance or Ferguson's one-eyed views, the most regular theme is the fan disenchanted with his own team. 'They just don't care,' is the common lament. 'They get paid more in a week than we earn in a year, and they are happy to collect their money whatever the result.' No one has ever said this about Manchester United. It is practically written into football's constitution that wealth and achievement quickly lead to complacency and dissipation, so it was perfectly reasonable to ask Ferguson after last year's Treble whether he thought it might be difficult to keep his players focused and motivated. 'Nah,' he replied tersely. 'We've still got the hunger. I've no worries at all on that score.' Last weekend's events bore this out, as well as conforming to Ferguson's long-held philosophy. 'Football is played by creatures of flesh and blood and feeling,' he wrote in his autobiography. 'Tactics are important but men win football matches. The best teams stand out because they are teams . There is a constant flow of mutual support among the players, and a manager should engender that sense of unity.' Well, Ferguson has certainly been doing that. It might not be pretty, may indeed be reprehensible, but United's sense of unity is frightening. Those rushing to condemn Keane's gang-slanging should first ask themselves whether they would like him in their side and then consider what they expect for £52,000 a week. A headshake and a few Irish curses? If United wanted a player who would react to a dubious decision by standing open-mouthed with his hands on his hips they could have got one much more cheaply, since the league is full of them. What you get for the money with Keane is the single best embodiment of the champion's mentality that runs through Old Trafford. It has a lot to do with the manager and the huge crowds, but is mostly due to the organic process by which members of a consistently winning team come to believe in each other, refusing to accept weakness in themselves and becoming intolerant of failings in others. This is what top-level professional sport leads to. Corinthianism is an amateur concept. Which brings us neatly to the man at the centre of the row, Mr D'Urso of Essex and his measly £700 match fee. If it is unfair that millionaires like Keane should be able to terrorise officials on a relative pittance, then the only answer is to upgrade referees' pay and improve their perceived status to somewhere approaching that of the players. At the moment referees get it in the neck because players and managers regard them as bumbling amateurs and therefore fair game. There was widespread sympathy for Mr D'Urso last week because he looked out of his depth and in some danger, yet appearances are often deceptive. Patrick Mortimer, a project leader in sports science at Edinburgh University, is currently investigating stress and conflict management on behalf of the Rugby Football Union's referees. He claims D'Urso handled last week's pressure well, and may not have been anywhere near as agitated as might be imagined. 'I would love to have had a heart monitor on him,' Mortimer said. 'Looking at TV and newspaper pictures only gives you a two-dimensional image. You can see how the situation developed, but you don't know how the individuals were relating to each other. What we have found when using heart monitors with referees is that they run about 180 beats per minute during the normal course of a match, which is pretty respectable. When conflict arises you would expect the heart rate to increase, and sometimes it does, but only with less experienced referees who let the situation get to them. With good referees, and this is a reliable performance indicator, the heart rate actually stabilises. They recognise a situation and are ready to deal with it; they have strategies for taking control.' Mortimer has identified five broad strategies - accommodating, avoiding, collaborating, competing and compromising - and says D'Urso was using the first last Saturday. 'He withdrew himself from the point of contact and went to where he could see the whole pitch, all the time keeping his eye on Keane as the major threat,' he explained. 'He was patient and he appeared calm, although possibly he forgot Jaap Stam could have been sent off. It is not easy to remember the whole rulebook when players crowd you out, that's why managers instruct players to do it. But standing still and confronting Keane might have inflamed the situation. I think he coped quite well, though it's clear to me that referees in general need a lot more support. 'Managers only want professional referees for accountability, so they can be sacked like they can, but I can think of many more constructive reasons than that.'

fields.headline: Ruud Gullit, parks player
fields.trailText: PSV, Milan, Chelsea, Newcastle... next stop the Amsterdam amateurs' fifth team.
fields.body:
A confused old man remarks to another spectator: 'Do you know, that could be Ruud Gullit's brother.'

'It is Ruud Gullit,' the spectator replies.

'Are you kidding me?' demands the old man.

'It's true. He plays for the AFC fifth team now.'

The old man takes another look at the large, dreadlocked sweeper in the red shirt, and exclaims: 'He was in the Dutch team!'

We are in a sports park just outside Amsterdam, two miles down the highway from the Ajax stadium, on a glorious, still, winter Saturday. In the canteen beside the ground old men play cards and ignore the football. OSDO third XI v AFC fifths has drawn 20 spectators, most of them the toddler offspring of the players, who have joined in the warming-up.

They have caught Gullit on a bad day. Even as the Felliniesque figure performs his unmistakable broad-shouldered jog on to the muddy pitch, his team are falling apart. Before kick-off, the pygmy woman referee dispatches several AFCers to find shinpads.

The AFC coach, a bad-tempered man with a mobile phone, confides that, because of holidays, he has had to call up reinforcements from lower teams. Granted, his sweeper is the European Footballer of the Year 1987, still only 37 years old and not given to Maradonaesque dietary excesses. But having Gullit in your park side is apparently a mixed blessing.

'AFC 5 is not AFC 5 any more,' one player has told me. 'Now the boys are nervous in the changing room. No one dares to sit next to him.'

The former manager of Chelsea and Newcastle, enjoying a 'rest' from professional football, made his AFC debut in September, soon after getting kicked out of St James's Park. A couple of his friends, fifth team regulars, got him to play in a friendly against ABN-Amro sixth XI, who had been threatening to field a ringer named Marco van Basten.

That game kicked off with Gullit but without his former team-mate at Holland and Milan, who had fallen asleep on the sofa at home. However, woken by a phone call, Van Basten tore to the ground, where he was immediately brought on as a substitute. Eleven seconds later he had scored. He got another later, but Gullit's team won 6-2.

Gullit also scored twice, enjoyed the game and decided to join AFC. He paid the membership fee of £120 a year; high by Dutch standards, because this is a chic club. Chelsea, the last team he played for, consented to the transfer.

And so he became the sweeper of AFC fifths, much to the delight of a friend of mine who plays for AFC fourth team and had always known that he was a better player than Gullit.

He could be right. Against OSDO, the AFC defence marshalled by Gullit concedes two goals in the first five minutes. Gullit, who for several games had maintained an uncharacteristic silence, has recently begun expressing his views.

'Inside! Inside! Inside!' he tells one of his defenders. Then, sighing: 'I said inside.' One of his enduring themes is that his team-mates must learn to mark on the inside.

It is to no avail. The AFC defence is what Johan Cruyff would call 'goats' cheese' and when an OSDO forward next sweeps into the penalty area, an exasperated Gullit stands aside and lets him score.

'The cream has gone,' comments the confused old man.

It would be wrong to say that Gullit is playing, as he would phrase it, 'like a turd'. Several times he sweeps a 50-yard pass on to his outside-left's left toe, an eerie sight in this setting. 'Good ball!' the AFC coach shouts reflexively.

However, the winger can never control the ball. Several times Gullit overhits. If you had to guess which of today's players had 65 Dutch caps, you would probably pick one of the OSDO forwards.

A spectator tells his son that Ruud Gullit is playing. 'Does he play for OSDO?' the boy asks.

The father is shocked. 'Ruud Gullit, who played in Italy and for the Dutch team! You know him, don't you?'

'Yeah, yeah, you're kidding me,' says the boy.

Finally AFC get a cross into the box and Gullit, hurtling in, almost heads it into the top corner. Except that he misses the ball. The coach turns to me, beaming hugely, 'It almost makes you think of old times!'

OSDO make it 4-0. By now AFC have begun the running commentary of mutual criticism traditional in a losing Dutch football team.

'Goddammit! What was that?' shouts a forward.

'Well do something up front!' suggests a defender.

'Referee, that man always has his flag up!' says another forward.

Gullit tries to be positive. He does not want to destroy anyone's confidence for life. After an AFC shot sails 20 yards over the bar, and some OSDO players joke about going home early, he laughs and shouts: 'They're getting tired!'

Half-time comes with the score 5-0, and an OSDO striker walks up to shake Gullit's hand. 'I was thanking him for all the pleasure he's given me,' 40-year-old Thieu Heuijerjans reveals later. 'That man meant so much for Dutch football.'

Heuijerjans and Gullit walk off arm in arm, chatting. Like Cruyff, Van Basten and Rinus Michels, Gullit has become a very nice guy by the simple expedient of retiring from top-class football.

Walking back out for the second half, he throws a glance at the men playing cards in the canteen. They don't look back. They should have, though, because in the second half AFC are transformed. Is it creatine? In any case, the outside-right Alfons soon creates a goal with a brilliant solo run.

'Alfie!' bellows Gullit. 'He is fit, he is sharp!'

AFC win a penalty. Not Gullit, but Guido, the centre-forward, takes it. He scores.

Then Guido makes it 5-3. Gradually, however, the AFC revival stalls. As the end approaches, the OSDO players' wives start singing the club song:

'OSDO is our club,

We have won!'

Then, with only a minute to go, a cross from Guido reaches Ruud Gullit alone in front of an empty goal. This is his moment. But he is caught flat-footed. He tries to jump, cannot get off the ground, and as he contorts his body the ball sails over his head. Ruud Gullit has become a parks footballer.

The pygmy ends the game, AFC have lost 5-3, and Ruud goes around shaking hands. He congratulates the pygmy at length, and to no one in particular he exclaims: 'The second half was better!'

He pops into the canteen afterwards wearing a grey woollen Italianate coat: the Best Dressed Man in Britain 1996. He has a drink with his team-mates (not alcohol, never alcohol) and after five minutes says goodbye and is off in his people-carrier (the new thing among continental footballers, who are emerging from the Sports Car Age) which has what looks like a small boat strapped to the roof. From the canteen there is nary a backward glance.

It is not that the Amsterdammers have forgotten Gullit, just that they don't go in for idols. This is a town where if you spotted Jesus Christ having a drink with Nelson Mandela at the next café table it would be uncool to notice. Rembrandt was declared bankrupt here, Spinoza expelled from the synagogue, Cruyff nicknamed the Money Wolf, and when John Lennon and Yoko Ono left town after their bed-in for peace at the Hilton, they had to return their honorary white bicycles to the local hippies. So nobody mobs Gullit. An Amsterdammer himself, he says he likes that about the place.

He could easily slip into former celebritydom. He is no longer even the most famous Ruud in Holland, having been outstripped by the brilliant young goalscorer Ruud van Nistelrooy (who should command the biggest transfer fee in Europe this summer) and Ruud, the character in the real-life soap opera Big Brother , who vomited on national television and coined the phrase , 'Come on! A nice cuddle.'

fields.headline: Throw book at snarling United
fields.trailText: Watching five fearsome United players surround referee Andy D'Urso was disturbing and distasteful. Throw the book at them.
fields.body:
The season stands at a turning point. In midweek, Manchester United moved ominously to the top of the Premiership; now it depends on whether rivals are intimidated or inspired by playing catch-up. The same might be said of referees officiating United games now - will they be intimidated or inspired?

Watching five fearsome United players, vein-bulging faces contorted with arrogant, angry self-righteousness, surround the hapless referee Andy D'Urso after he had given Middlesbrough a penalty last week was indeed disturbing and distasteful. The very fact that even Sir Alex Ferguson condemned it means that it must have been. It might also have been counter-productive to their cause.

For now United's conduct is in the spotlight, now a pattern of behaviour is out in the open. Referees and their assistants may more clearly discern what is happening on the field and be willing to address it, feeling that they will be backed by the right-minded majority outraged by the sight of Roy Keane and Co in Mr D'Urso's face.

A prevaricating FA, who laughably oversaw a conference concerned with improving a ref's lot two days after the episode and came up with an eight-point plan but no action against United, may even have to respond to public sentiment and do the just thing. United themselves, to their detriment, may be forced to douse a fiery part of their game.

Mr D'Urso said that he was forced to step backwards by the Old Trafford five because he felt he would be pushed over if he did not. From now on - and certainly if Paul Alcock is in charge of a United game - it can be assumed that referees will stand their ground and be in a position to check if David Beckham's roots need doing. United had literally better back off if last week's episode is not to backfire on them.

The tactic of a cluster of players surrounding a referee to try and influence him is by no means a new one in the professional game. The idea is that a referee is confronted by a group of faces and, not knowing which to book, cautions none of them. The Arsenal of George Graham were fond of that one. The aim is that, wearied by the pressure, he gives in to whatever demands are made.

Then there is another approach to achieve the same aim; take it in turns to berate the referee so that although he may issue a yellow card - a price worth paying if you get the right decision from him at a key moment - he cannot issue a red for two offences. It was said that a cuter Liverpool of the 70's and 80's preferred this one.

Linesmen do not escape. At Arsenal, Graham would instruct Lee Dixon and Nigel Winterburn to 'work' their men, especially early on. Then, a short, sharp shout of 'lino' might well produce a trigger reaction of raising the flag for a tight offside.

Some of it can be seen in Leeds United, who are currently earning a reputation within the game for moments of spite and gamesmanship, though their youngsters still have much to learn. At Tottenham earlier this season, Alan Smith spent the afternoon tiresomely swearing at a linesman and went too far. When Smith committed an offence, the official was only too happy to recommend his sending-off.

It is all very well for a side to seek to emulate United's intense attitude to the game, admirable in the pace, passion and panache they can exhibit when play is flowing. It is quite another for that intensity to overspill and become a standard that teams feel they must match if they are to be successful. Heaven help us if more players start trying to get the opponents sent off, as Gary Neville and Beckham did with Stefan Schnoor at Derby last November.

One reason that United appear so awesome at Old Trafford, quite apart from any stoking of the furnace that Sir Alex may do in the dressing room, is their crowd - but for the opposite reason than might be thought. As the capacity reaches 65,000, some 20,000 more than nearest rivals, we might expect the intimidation would get worse. Instead, development has hitherto dissipated the noisier support. Often, United have to generate their own atmosphere initially, until the crowd is whipped up.

Then, the stadium can simply assume things. I once sat next to an Italian at a World Cup game and at one point, exasperated by a referee's decision, he demanded: 'Where is our penalty?' It was almost his team's right, he believed. Manchester United supporters can seem similar. At the other end, Lennie Lawrence's comment when he was manager of Charlton Athletic springs to mind: 'The last time we got a penalty against them, Christ was a carpenter.'

It used to be thus at Liverpool, where 'an Anfield penalty', became part of the language of the game. The home side seemed to get them if a defender looked at one of their players the wrong way while the visitors appeared to feel like a boxer trying to get a decision in a foreign land. It felt that you had to have been kicked, punched and trodden on at least. And then it was outside the area.

The evidence of midweek at Sheffield Wednesday was that United were on best behaviour, and the lesson for them was that a 1-0 win could be achieved with rather more composure, which, after all, is what they will need as the silverware season approaches. It did look as if Sir Alex had reminded them of the need to retain coolness and discipline.

He may have his volatile side but Ferguson is also fiercely aware of his responsibility as manager of Manchester United and the effect his stewardship can have on youngsters, those who support his club and play for it. It was noticeable, too, at Hillsborough that he was self-restraint itself, realising that the lead came from him.

He is also canny enough to realise that while they have to retain their fire to be true to their own expansive game, unless they also show some ice, United will abuse the current climate of leniency - only Keane was booked in the Middlesbrough incident - and may indeed single-handedly put an end to it.

They could well then attract the yellow and red cards that will bring suspensions at crucial periods as referees adopt a new clampdown to prove how strong they can be in handling games involving them. Any repeat of their mob rule and Manchester United will certainly deserve to have the book and the bookings thrown at them.

It did look as if Sir Alex had reminded them of the need to retain coolness and discipline. He may have his volatile side but Ferguson is also fiercely aware of his responsibility as manager of Manchester United and the effect his stewardship can have on youngsters, those who support his club and play for it. It was noticeable, too, at Hillsborough that he was self-restraint itself, realising that the lead came from him. He is also canny enough to realise that while they have to retain their fire to be true to their own expansive game, unless they also show some ice, United will abuse the current climate of leniency - only Keane was booked in the Middlesbrough incident - and may indeed single-handedly put an end to it. They could well then attract the yellow and red cards that will bring suspensions at crucial periods as referees adopt a new clampdown to prove how strong they can be in handling games involving them. Any repeat of their mob rule and Manchester United will certainly deserve to have the book and the bookings thrown at them.

fields.headline: Ex hex on vexed fans
fields.trailText: Examining the abuse players get when they return to old haunts.
fields.body:
In Italy they have a football saying for nearly everything. 'La regola immutabile del ex' is the immutable law of the ex. This law states that it is inevitable that a returning player will score a goal. And so it was last week when Alan Shearer returned to Blackburn .

Since his poor performances for England, especially against Scotland, fans have given Shearer plenty of stick. Bobby Robson even lost his marbles over it and told us that it was a disgrace to boo the England captain. Shearer has now answered all his critics in the only way he knows, by scoring goals.

What was strange about Newcastle's FA Cup tie with Blackburn was that the home fans were still so nasty to Shearer. You would have thought that they would be grateful to him for his part, five years ago, in helping them to their first league title since 1914. He was popular with the fans and had turned down the chance to join bigger clubs than Blackburn when he left Southampton.

Despite this all they did during the game was boo and taunt him. This clearly upset Shearer because for the first time in memory he changed his goal celebration. Instead of the more modest one-arm raised salute he did a Klinsmann and then pointed to the Blackburn fans with one hand while holding his Newcastle badge with the other. Fair enough we all thought, but Shearer didn't think it was. He has since apologised and admitted it was a stupid thing to do, and that he would never do it again.

Blackburn fans don't seem to have the same sense of humour as the Geordies, who had a totally different reaction to one of their own ex-players, John Beresford, when he turned out against them recently for Southampton. He was cheered by the Newcastle fans when he came out to warm up but when he first touched the ball in play he was roundly booed and everyone laughed, including Beresford.

I expect the Italians have lots of different rules to determine fans' reaction to 'ex' players. They will involve a whole number of factors.

The most obvious reason to boo a returning player is that he has gone to play for your local rivals, which appears to be unforgivable. So when Pat Jennings first returned to White Hart Lane as an Arsenal player you might not have expected him to get a very warm reception. In fact he got a standing ovation. This was because other factors were involved, the main one being that he was forced out of the club: he was also a great goalkeeper and the fans liked him.

Fans of the top teams hate it when a player goes to a rival big club so Sunderland fans will never forgive Michael Bridges for going to Leeds. They made their feelings very clear on his recent return to the Stadium of Light. Unfortunately for them La regola immutabile del ex came into play.

The fans reserve their most venomous abuse for players who are deemed guilty of betrayal. Gazza was never given a welcome back by Newcastle fans because he left them for a flashy London team and then told the press how much better things were in the capital. But the biggest act of betrayal was that of Paul Ince. He is still hated by West Ham fans because he posed in a Manchester United shirt while still a West Ham player: an unforgivable sin.

Age can be an important factor in fans' reaction to an ex. If a player has given the best days of his life to a club and leaves in his early thirties he will be treated well on his return. So Bryan Robson was more than welcomed on his return to Old Trafford with Middlesbrough. Supporters from a lower division side also don't object too much if a player with great talent goes to join the best team in the league. So when John Barnes left Watford for Liverpool the fans may have been upset but they never booed him on his return. Fans will also not boo an ex who has gone to play for an inferior team, so when Perry Groves returned to Highbury with Southampton the North Bank gave him a very warm reception. Indeed Perry, although useless, was a bit of a cult hero and cult heroes are always welcome back.

No doubt the Blackburn fans who gave Shearer such a hard time last week will have their reasons for doing so. He has in their view broken one of the rules for a returning ex, though I'm not sure which one it is. It could simply be that they think he's a tosser. They would be better off displaying more of a sense of humour in their attempts to put Shearer off his game. They could take a leaf out of Chelsea fans' book; they always give Frank Sinclair a rousing reception on his return to Stamford Bridge and cheer his every move. And why not? He has scored nearly as many goals for Chelsea in a Leicester shirt as he did when he was at Stamford Bridge.

fields.headline: Killies sink to bottom
fields.trailText: Struggling Kilmarnock had a double dose of misery yesterday. Apart from being held to a goalless draw by Alloa in the Scottish Cup, they also replaced Aberdeen at the bottom of the Premier League.
fields.body:
Struggling Kilmarnock had a double dose of misery yesterday. Apart from being held to a goalless draw by Alloa in the Scottish Cup, they also replaced Aberdeen at the bottom of the Premier League.

Aberdeen got out of that unenviable position, for the first time this season, by coming from behind to beat St Johnstone.

The visitors took the lead through John O'Neil after 14 minutes, following excellent build-up work by Miguel Simao. Their lead was short-lived, however, as Aberdeen hit back from the penalty spot six minutes later through Arild Stavros, following a disputed handball decision against Danny Griffiths.

Hicham Zerouali, whose brilliant free-kick earned his side a Scottish Cup replay against St Mirren, wasted a good chance to make himself an Aberdeen hero again; but not Robbie Winters. The striker, brought into the side as a replacement for the injured Eoin Jess, scored Aberdeen's winner in the 50th minute.

The first half of the Motherwell-Dundee clash was so poor that at the interval, the teams were booed off the field. Motherwell's Lee McCulloch and John Spencer had worked hard enough to penetrate Dundee's defence, but it says much about their struggle that even when Spencer set up a great chance for Martin Corrigan, the Motherwell defender blasted the ball over. How he must have regretted it when Dundee took the lead in sensational fashion after 49 minutes.

Hugh Robertson picked up a pass from Gavin Rae and the midfielder thundered home a glorious 35-yard shot. Robertson then turned scorer himself to make it 2-0.

Clydebank's embarrassing distinction as the only team in Britain without a win continued against Dunfermline - even after they had been given the boost of taking the lead with an own goal from Andy Tod. Dunfermline, clearly motivated by the prospect of being Clydebank's first victims, hit back with a goal from Lee Bullen and two more from Steve Crawford,

Airdrie, having gone into provisional liquidation last week, were confronted with another problem when their match at home to Inverness CT was put in jeopardy by a bomb scare.

Shortly before 1pm. Strathclyde Police received a report that a device had been hidden in Airdrie's ground. A search revealed the report to be groundless - but less encouraging for Airdrie was that they conceded a Dennis Wyness goal after 14 minutes and ended up losing 4-1.

fields.headline: Unbeatable - and now unbackable
fields.trailText: Betting on the outcome of the Scottish Premier League championship will be suspended until next August, or until Rangers have an accident that equates to falling down a manhole, whichever comes sooner. Given the present situation, the odds compilers will surely have to busy themselves with other matters until the leaves start changing hue.
fields.body:
Betting on the outcome of the Scottish Premier League championship will be suspended until next August, or until Rangers have an accident that equates to falling down a manhole, whichever comes sooner. Given the present situation, the odds compilers will surely have to busy themselves with other matters until the leaves start changing hue.

The reigning champions have become unbackable for the 1999-2000 title, not only because they established a nine-point advantage over their closest pursuers, Celtic, last Wednesday, but because they have exhibited such convincing form that a collapse is virtually impossible to envisage.

Before the 4-0 whipping of Dundee United at Tannadice last midweek, Dick Advocaat and some of his players had expressed the potential difficulties presented by the month of February, during which they are scheduled to play four successive league games and one Tennents Scottish Cup tie away from home.

It is the kind of programme that would cause managers of lesser teams to speculate that they would be satisfied at securing half the number of points available and a replay in the cup. That level of ambition is set several notches below that embraced by Advocaat and his side.

The Dutchman is also perfectly entitled to expect maximum returns from these travels. During the past decade of dominance, Rangers - with the exception of 1998, when Celtic won the title - have demonstrated a characterful firmness of purpose in these 'trials' that has proved beyond all challengers.

It is, indeed, the Ibrox side's ability to cope with away games that has proved decisive in jousts with their greatest rivals for the championship in recent seasons. The 'road' series they began so persuasively at Tannadice four days ago is unlikely to leave them numbed by apprehension.

John Barnes, the Celtic manager, has been saying since the Old Firm match on 27 December ended 1-1 that his team now have to rely on others inflicting damage on the leaders, as even victory in each of the two remaining games against Rangers would not be sufficient to regain the championship as long as Advocaat's team won elsewhere.

That claim pre-supposes that Celtic would maintain a winning streak while their rivals were dropping points. There is enough evidence to surmise that this is unlikely. On their first outing after the winter shutdown, Celtic drew 1-1 at Kilmarnock, allowing Rangers the opportunity to increase a potential seven-point lead by two points.

Having dispatched Dundee United mercilessly at Tannadice, Advocaat's squad now square up to visits to Hibs at Easter Road tonight, then St Johnstone and Dundee before the month is out. If there is a squeak of a chance that they could drop points in this period, it is most likely to be found during their trip to Edinburgh.

While Hibs have shown a destructive inferiority complex when playing the Old Firm in Glasgow, where they have been easily dismissed, Alex McLeish's team - promoted at the end of last season - have been altogether more difficult back at base.

McLeish and his players still regard the 1-0 defeat by Rangers on 28 August as their unluckiest match of the season so far and their self-belief in tonight's renewal is likely to run much deeper than it does on sojourns to Ibrox.

They have had a rewarding association with Sunday night matches televised by BSkyB, each of their three ventures having yielded victory. In the process, they have scored 10 goals and conceded five, suggesting that the supporters at the Rangers game are unlikely to wilt from boredom.

Those previous triumphs in front of the numerous cameras deployed by the satellite broadcasters include a 3-0 thumping of neighbours Hearts, a 3-2 win over Dundee United and a 4-3 victory over Dundee. It is not difficult to imagine that McLeish and his men anticipate these occasions with some relish.

'We would all love to make Rangers and Celtic work a little harder in the Premier League,' said McLeish, 'and it is our aim to ensure that Rangers leave here realising they have been in a game. Having said that, Rangers really are formidable.

'We've watched them since their return from the winter break and, if anything, they seem fresher and stronger. But I'm certain we will be much better at Easter Road than we were at Ibrox, where we seemed not to get started. We have some very good young players here, like Ian Murray and Kenny Miller, and I hope they can experience how victory over the Old Firm feels.

'One of the advantages of the younger guys is that they seem to be totally free of apprehension about occasions like this. They don't have the mental barrier of some older players, who sometimes go into these games with trepidation.

'We have a good mix of youth and experience, of skill and will, with quality players like Russel Latapy and Frank Sauzee well supported by those around them. There's no doubt Rangers are a very good team. They are quality, with great movement and interchanging.

'They have terrific balance down the left, with players like Giovanni van Bronckhorst, Arthur Numan and Jorg Albertz, all left-footed. It's something that makes me very envious. Having said that, I also know that they are human and that means the possibility of mistakes under pressure.

'We have to make sure we put them under that pressure, but I think the most important thing for us will be to defend properly in the opening exchanges. We've noticed that Rangers in recent matches have scored a few first-half goals, taking advantage of slackness.

'That's all they need to make them relaxed and confident. We saw that at Tannadice, where the self-assurance was oozing out of them after they had scored a couple of early goals. But I never stop believing that, in a single game, we are capable of beating them.'

fields.headline: No one likes them...so what?
fields.trailText: The accusation levelled against Manchester United that they can intimidate referees, as we saw last week, brings into focus the fine line between motivating your players to the maximum and going over the top.
fields.body:
The accusation levelled against Manchester United that they can intimidate referees, as we saw last week, brings into focus the fine line between motivating your players to the maximum and going over the top.

There can be no doubt that United's players are a highly-motivated bunch - you have only to look at the number of trophies they have won in recent years. United, like the Arsenal side of a few years ago, have a 'siege mentality', which makes them all the stronger for thinking, rightly or wrongly, that the world is against them.

It is perhaps not surprising how much this sort of mentality can bond players and bring out the fighting spirit in them, but it is not always easy to do this successfully without going too far.

I have stressed repeatedly in this column the need for managers at all levels to be properly qualified in coaching, but I recognise that of equal importance in this most demanding of roles is an ability to motivate players. The best managers are certainly the best motivators.

Sir Alex Ferguson has it at United, George Graham did at Arsenal and Wimbledon were always famous for their amazing team spirit under Dave Bassett and then Joe Kinnear.

More recently, we have seen David O'Leary at Leeds and Martin O'Neill of Leicester becoming very defensive of their players in the light of what they perceive to be persecution by the opposition and sections of the media, even if it is not the case.

I'm sure Ken Bates's recent criticism of Leicester inadvertently galvanised Martin O'Neill's team and, being the excellent psychologist he is, Martin would have used this to maximum advantage.

When I took over from O'Neill as manager of Wycombe Wanderers, there was talk in the boardroom and among players about his darker side and mood changes. One player who had been a journeyman footballer throughout his career was reduced to tears by O'Neill's criticism.

I was told he closely followed Brian Clough's maverick style of management in being unpredictable, so that you never knew which Martin O'Neill you were likely to encounter on any given day. But one thing was unquestionable: when his players ran out on to the pitch, they gave their all for him. This was shown by Wycombe gaining entry to the Football League, promotion from Division Three and a Wembley appearance in the Zenith Data Trophy. Since he left Adams Park the team have never really been the same and now are planted firmly in mid-table in Division Two.

I would mention here that in Martin's first season at Leicester, when things were not going so well for him, some fans boycotted games in protest. I hope those fans can be honest with themselves as to what they thought of Martin's football at the time.

The great motivators are not always so successful - sometimes it takes all their efforts just to keep a club alive. Steve Coppell is doing a remarkable job at Crystal Palace, which speaks volumes for his powers of motivation and ability to survive on a shoestring.

It has been a similar story over the years at Wimbledon, who have gone from non-League to Wembley and the Premier League in a relatively short time. When I was a youth coach at Wimbledon, Dave Bassett became manager and took the side from the lower divisions through to the old First Division.

Dave, now at Barnsley, is one of the best motivators I have ever worked with and has been known to lecture businessmen in the art of management. Joe Kinnear carried on in a similar vein at Wimbledon, always quick to blame outside sources for any mistakes and building a fantastic team spirit.When he was composing his pre-match team-talk, he would seize on any negative references to Wimbledon's style of play or the size of their crowds, and this was as important to him as tactics and teamwork.

Sir Alex Ferguson does the same at United, where he uses any anti-United talk to stoke up his players. On the continent, coaches and managers spend much less time on building an 'us and them' mentality, and possibly this is why the football is more clinical or cynical, and that our games tend to have so much more passion. You would always expect British players to show more commitment when the chips are down. The ideal situation is to find the balance between good coaching and the power to get players to play for you. It may sound easy, but it is not.

Dave, now at Barnsley, is one of the best motivators I have ever worked with and has been known to lecture businessmen in the art of management. Joe Kinnear carried on in a similar vein at Wimbledon, always quick to blame outside sources for any mistakes and building a fantastic team spirit.When he was composing his pre-match team-talk, he would seize on any negative references to Wimbledon's style of play or the size of their crowds, and this was as important to him as tactics and teamwork. Sir Alex Ferguson does the same at United, where he uses any anti-United talk to stoke up his players. On the continent, coaches and managers spend much less time on building an 'us and them' mentality, and possibly this is why the football is more clinical or cynical, and that our games tend to have so much more passion. You would always expect British players to show more commitment when the chips are down. The ideal situation is to find the balance between good coaching and the power to get players to play for you. It may sound easy, but it is not.

webTitle: Ridley's wrong: There's a lot to admire about Leicester team

fields.headline: Ridley's wrong: There's a lot to admire about Leicester team
fields.trailText: As a Leicester fan I was forced to concede that, however cross Ian Ridley's article 'O'Neill's Blight on Wembley' (30 January) made me feel, much of it was based on essentially sound arguments. As a fan I have been gripped recently by my club's recent exploits and the drama of sudden-death finishes, but am the first to admit that the quality of football in several of the games has been far from entertaining for the fans.
fields.body:
As a Leicester fan I was forced to concede that, however cross Ian Ridley's article 'O'Neill's Blight on Wembley' (30 January) made me feel, much of it was based on essentially sound arguments. As a fan I have been gripped recently by my club's recent exploits and the drama of sudden-death finishes, but am the first to admit that the quality of football in several of the games has been far from entertaining for the fans.

However, the arguments put forward were weakened by a consistent level of vitriol that ignored the basic facts. Leicester have produced some exceptionally entertaining games this season. The home games against Liverpool, Chelsea, Aston Villa and the away matches at Spurs, in particular, were full of open attractive football exhibiting the best features of the game. But the well-publicised injury crisis that has blighted Leicester over recent months has shorn them of, at times, their entire midfield creativity of Guppy, Izzet, and Lennon. Many sides like Leicester are plunged into crisis during these spells as they do not have the financial clout to afford the big names, nor the glamour status to attract these players without guaranteeing them first team football each week.

This in itself does not wholly excuse an apparent lack of enthusiasm for playing good football. However, the simple truth, often ignored, is that when a side is facing opposition who man-for-man are of a higher ability than themselves, it often makes little difference whether an attacking or defensive formation is planned, they are invariably forced on to the back foot.

Finally, it is worth noting that Leicester, even with their current unattractive football, by and large avoid the many other unattractive aspects of Premiership play that similarly undermine Premiership football, that is to say diving, shirt-pulling, requesting the referee to card opposition players, chasing the referee around the field, denying local talent the chance to progress through the ranks and pricing local fans out of the ground. Without clubs like Leicester we will surely have a Super League format made up of expensive stars from all over the world with no local or club passion, and the English game will have died.

Steve Smith

North Chingford, Essex

In my imagination I can see the look of horror on Ian Ridley's face as he arrives at Stamford Bridge last Sunday, flicks through his programme and realises just quite what a catastrophic error he has made. It must surely be the journalist's worst nightmare; to see one's opinions on football echoed in print by Ken Bates.

The fact that a journalist who seems to stop at Arsenal more often than the Piccadilly Line felt it appropriate to write the piece was unfortunate. Not nearly as unfortunate, however, as the absence of any sense of balance, impartiality or research.

No one who supports Leicester City has always enjoyed the quality of some of the football we have produced in recent weeks, but we are certainly not embarrassed by it. On the contrary, most of us feel extreme pride at our ability to get results under exceptionally trying circumstances. While it might be easy to write a knocking piece lamenting the negativity and boredom of LCFC a little homework would have made a lot of difference.

At the end of November Martin O'Neill won the manager of the month award. Leicester City were fifth in the Premiership and winning plaudits for their exciting attacking football. Journalists were talking of automatic qualification for Europe. Then the club suffered its worst injury crisis in 20 years. Would Manchester United have won the treble last year if they had been denied the services of Peter Schmiechel, Gary Neville, Dennis Irwin, Ryan Giggs, David Beckham, Roy Keane and Dwight Yorke for eight weeks?

In a footballing world that appears to grow more cynical and homogenised each week, Leicester City stand out as a club which refuses toaccept the status quo. The fact that we survive - and win trophies - is not just good for us but good for every other team in English football.

So next time you visit Filbert Street, Mr Ridley, I'd advise you to take your own refreshments. Humble pie might suffice, as you may find our cakes have been made with sour cream, especially for you.

Ben Fletcher,

London N22

It was a wind-up, wasn't it? If Ian Ridley spent less time tucking into Filbert Street's 'guilt-inducing' cream cakes and more trying to understand the difficulty of staying in the Premiership for clubs living on a shoestring (now that is worth debating) he would not be in the running for the Most Bollocks in One Piece Award. Leicester's patched-up tramp streamer may offend those who live in awe of the luxury liners in the same harbour, but for us loyal fans it looks lovely.Thank goodness Gordon Strachan knows what he is talking about.

Chris Lymn,

Leicester

Leicester headed the Fair Play League last season, and despite the recent sending-off of Steve Walsh, still have an excellent disciplinary record under O'Neill. Give O'Neill and the Leicester players the credit they are due, as does Gordon Strachan in his perceptive piece. Strachan knows his subject; Ridley seems to be an expert on cream cakes.

D. Thompson

via email

Here's a newsflash, Ian; success by any club outside the 'big six' is positively good for the game. I am a Manchester United fan and I have Arsenal fans telling me how it would be bad for the game if United win the Premiership this season - and they have a point. Not that I don't want to see my team succeed, but I don't begrudge 'smaller' clubs their achievements, even if they do come at the expense of open football. I don't expect to see teams try to take on the 'top' clubs at their own way of playing the game. I would like to nominate Martin O'Neill for Manager of the Year - his passion for the game is a tonic.

Peter Murphy.

via email

Ian Ridley's article was not only insulting but also ignorant. Izzet, Guppy and Elliott, for example, have become far more capable and creative players since joining Leicester. Elliott has surely developed better footballing skills than most other central defenders in the Premiership (note his lovely goal against Chelsea at the weekend). Football as a whole, rather than the handful of super-rich clubs, is about making the most of what you have. May Leicester continue to shake elitist managers, chairmen and journalists and ensure football remains an unpredictable mix of both passion and skill.

Peter Johnson,

Bath

Oh dear. What is one to make of Ian Ridley's spiteful criticism? Explanation 1: Apply conspiracy theory. All fans have a tendency to subscribe to this view that 'they' are against them. Explanation 2: Apply discourse analysis. Situation: Leicester are successful. Problem: They are not supposed to be. They have outgrown their plucky-losers position and are causing severe embarrassment to cash flows along the way. Solution: Hope they lose and patronise their supporters. Evaluation: The talent is sold, as it should be, and Filbert Street becomes a provincial pleasure garden once more. Explanation 3: Punishment: Use posi tion to denigrate in media. Crime: Beating Arsenal.

Steve Issitt

London WC1

Whoops! We've been found out at last. Ian Ridley has spotted that Leicester City pass the ball to Emile Heskey to wreak havoc in opposition defences, that we work hard to deprive the opposition of the ball, that we depend on Tony Cottee to do what he does best, snaffling the half-chance, and that we try to score from set pieces. Now this intrepid journalist has revealed the truth, we promise to do better. In future we will not pass the ball to a striker whose athleticism and power strike fear in to the hearts of defenders, and when the opposition have the ball, we will politely stand aside and let them play their pretty passing game. Above all, when we have a corner or a free-kick, we will not put the ball anywhere near the danger area, but immediately give away possession to the opposing team - particularly if they are from London, so that they are more easily able to demonstrate their superiority. Only a couple of things in Mr Ridley's article spoiled his demolition of Leicester City. First, that the food laid on for the benefit of him and other journalists is the best spread in the Premiership. Second, his strange notion that at Leicester the fans are 'civilised and fair-minded'. Can't comment on the cream-cake scenario, but civilised and fair-minded? I have never been so insulted!

Paddy Casswell

Markfield, Leicester

Ian Ridley's feature was extremely interesting. Leicester City's style of football is just dreadful - watching them perform in the Worthington Cup first leg at Villa Park on 25 January was just like watching the Wimbledon of old. Hoof the ball up the pitch, shove your elbow into your opponent's face and that's that.

Horrible, horrible, horrible!

The only section of your feature that we disagree with is your description of the fans - 'civilised and fair-minded' they are not. They are arrogant, many of them are just yobs and they probably still bear a grudge against us for poaching a former manager of theirs - Brian Little, who resigned a very long time ago. And Robbie Savage seems to get glorified in every other newspaper you read - he's one of those players who disguises his footballing inability with cynical and dangerous tackles.

But thanks for your feature - it was joy to read and it's about time that the country was told about this wolf in sheep's clothing.

Michele Platman

Birmingham

fields.headline: Slickers fuel the casino culture
fields.standfirst: Share tipping explained
fields.trailText: Racing share prices, insider-dealing scandals and City bonuses of Lottery winner proportions - the madness of the Eighties is back. When Piers Morgan and his City team of Slickers were put under scrutiny last week for alleged share dealing impropriety, it was as though we were caught in a time warp.
fields.body:
Racing share prices, insider-dealing scandals and City bonuses of Lottery winner proportions - the madness of the Eighties is back. When Piers Morgan and his City team of Slickers were put under scrutiny last week for alleged share dealing impropriety, it was as though we were caught in a time warp.

The very fact that a popular tabloid newspaper felt it needed a City page in the first place is symptomatic of how the collision of prosperity, advances in technology and growing interest in personal finance has fuelled a boom in share dealing with more than a touch of madness about it.

In the past year, claim the Mirror's City Slickers, Anil Bhoyrul and James Hipwell, their average share tips have yielded a rise of 154 per cent. The brash promotion of companies, accompanied by a 'fill yer boots' bravado, hit a nerve with a new type of investor. The availability of cheap share trading through online and telephone broking houses, plus a boom in highly volatile Internet and technology shares, have encouraged small private investors to pile into the stock market.

Everywhere you look, there are new media aimed at this market , all striving to capture the attention of Britain's burgeoning share-trading community. No one would have turned a hair 30 years ago if the City editor of the Times had recommended a share he owned - because the business of share tipping was arcane, largely for those already in the know, who would have retained their own stockbroker. Shares might have made a stately ascent - but they would not have risen 2800 per cent in one day, as Oxygen Holdings, the latest Internet hot stock, did when it launched on Friday.

In this febrile atmosphere the business of buying and selling shares purely for profit has meant that prices often wildly exaggerate the real value of a company - which can often be close to nothing. It has ushered in the casino culture where share tips and price rises became self-fulfilling prophecies. It was into his Zeitgeist that the Slickers tapped brilliantly. But over-hyped shares will come down and people less well-off than national newspaper editors are the most likely casualties.

webTitle: Burning merrily with plenty of O

fields.headline: Burning merrily with plenty of O
fields.trailText: AT THE height of punk, Malcolm McLaren coined a brilliant phrase: 'It's cash from chaos,' he said, as kids with tin ears and drug habits attracted adoring hordes who paid for the privilege of being spat at.
fields.body:
AT THE height of punk, Malcolm McLaren coined a brilliant phrase: 'It's cash from chaos,' he said, as kids with tin ears and drug habits attracted adoring hordes who paid for the privilege of being spat at.

Well bring on Malcolm as the Lord Mayor of London, because the great Rock 'n Roll Swindle is back. This time in a Savile Row suit.

Oxygen Holdings, a small company with some big names behind it, came to the market on Friday at 2p. By the close of trading it was 57p. So that would be as close as you're going to get to a 3,000 per cent increase in a day.

As we say in the East Midlands, it caps hen racing.

Oxygen Holdings is principally famous for attracting the talents of Elisabeth Murdoch and Matthew Freud as directors. It is financially interesting because it is yet another Michael Edelson vehicle - the man who brought you Knutsford - and fashionable because it proposes to perform that most desirable of functions: to be an incubator for Internet companies.

Now in a week when it has been clear to anyone with a thimbleful of cerebellum that the Internet goldrush is about to turn into a bloodbath, it may seem slightly curious that Oxygen is causing such breathlessness. But then so did Knutsford, which we now know will be losing its key executive, in the form of Archie Norman, to the grim moonscape of the shadow cabinet, and has failed at the first attempt to buy something of value as its talks with Wassall collapsed.

Murdoch and Freud (junior varieties) are no mugs in their respective fields of TV and PR. But I'm not convinced that they, or indeed anyone, can really be expected to spot the next Amazon.com or Yahoo! with the kind of certainty that would deserve a 3,000 per cent rise in share values. In fact when one scans the roster of bright young things piling into Internet start-ups, it is clear that the Net has taken over from the wine trade, or even tea plantations, as the repository for upper class children of average intelligence.

Talk to anyone who has traipsed round the City recently with a dot.com business and they will tell you that in the past six months there has been a perceptible shift in attitudes: the bankers now want a schedule for return on investment; a year ago they had a more relaxed attitude.

Boo.com, or Boo.Hoo as it's cattily called, the overhyped site for 'urban streetware' has slashed jobs; Amazon.com is still walking a thin line between world domination and spectacular failure. And I can think of at least half a dozen companies spending millions on advertising which very probably won't be here in 12 months' time.

As interest rates inch up, the Dow has fallen to below 11,000 and the FTSE 100 is at its lowest since October, the institutions are shifting their investments out of equities. But at this high-energy end of the market, the small investment community - which seeks to hold for days or weeks at the most and behaves irrationally at the best of times - it must be clear that we are reaching cut-and-run time.

Those who have been swept up in the casino culture of day trading and quick profits will be fine so long as they recognise the difference between a gamble and an investment. There will of course still be casualties, apart from the dozens of companies which will suddenly find those understanding venture capitalists getting edgy.

The gravy train is reaching the end of the line and this spring will find the fetid London air scented even more heavily than usual with the whiff of carbon as a number of entrepreneurial ideas are turned to toast.

All of this is just part of a predictable market cycle. However, one should hope that once a line has been drawn under the sorry business which has turned commerce into a lottery, and made monkeys out of investors, that we can return to a world where shareholding regains its democratic appeal and becomes a way of sharing growth rather than losing your shirt.

emily.bell@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Our minor miracle
fields.standfirst: Last Sunday, Ian Ridley's criticism of Martin O'Neill's Leicester sparked a furore. Here is the dressing room response
fields.trailText: People used to use words like 'plucky' and 'commitment' about Leicester and we found that patronising. When backhanded complements turn into bitter criticism that's a different matter altogether. Martin O'Neill called Ian Ridley's article the most vitriolic attack on one team he has seen. Talk about twisting the knife. We were incredulous. We talked about it. We couldn't ignore it. It brought us closer together.
fields.body:
People used to use words like 'plucky' and 'commitment' about Leicester and we found that patronising. When backhanded complements turn into bitter criticism that's a different matter altogether. Martin O'Neill called Ian Ridley's article the most vitriolic attack on one team he has seen. Talk about twisting the knife. We were incredulous. We talked about it. We couldn't ignore it. It brought us closer together.

We've come through a lot and the criticism only steels us even more. It all boiled over on Wednesday night in the Worthington Cup semi-final against Aston Villa. We knew it was make or break, our season hinging on that game, and the performance we put in with our best players back was very satisfying. That was us. That was what this squad of players is all about.

There was a moment in the first half when Villa couldn't get the ball off us and the fans were singing 'Boring, boring Leicester'. The perfect response.

I haven't seen us that fired up for a game for a long, long time.The dressing room beforehand burned with the desire to ram the taunts back down people's throats. It gives you inner strength and makes you feel invincible.

There's not just great spirit here, there is ability too. That's why we feel such a sense of injustice. Apparently we represent ugly football. There are a few who aren't the best looking but I'll leave Robbie Savage out of it. We make no apologies for not always being good to watch because ultimately we are trying to win games. With the exception of Steve Guppy and Muzzy Izzet, Ridley actually described us as the 'preponderance of dross' which I find incredible.

I'm the current Player of the Year in the Midlands which doesn't say a lot about the rest of the players in the Midlands when I'm described as the preponderance of dross.

What seemed particularly unfair was launching these assaults when we had such a crippling injury list. At full strength we were sixth in the League and unbeaten at home. When we lost myself, Muzzy, Guppy, Tony Cottee, Andy Impey and Steve Walsh the heart of the team was ripped out. We were down to the bare bones, calling on players who hadn't had much first team experience or hadn't played much this season and they were fantastic. But if you lose quality players it's very hard to replace the qualities they bring.

Take out half Manchester United's best players and obviously they will miss some class. Everyone wants to play champagne-style football but you can't always do it that way. Nobody wants Matt Elliott to play up front, least of all Matty, but with Cottee and Ian Marshall injured he is the next best option. If he is playing up front you have to hang it up for him to get knock downs for Emile. You can only play to your strengths.

I don't find playing for Leicester boring at all. When I'm in the team I don't think we lump the ball. I certainly don't want to be tagged as a kick-and-rush player and I'm sure Muzzy, Guppy, Emile and Matt Elliott don't.

Okay, sometimes it can be frustrating if you find yourself camped in your half and you have to defend. Mind you, it's funny how when we get players behind the ball we're playing for penalites yet when Arsenal do it it's called good defending.

Ridley called us 'Wimbledon with fewer excuses'. What sort of line is that? We don't want to make an issue about how well we've done on a shoestring but sometimes we are competing against teams who have one player on the pitch who costs more than our whole team. We brought in Darren Eadie for £3 million but we haven't spent much compared to other clubs. Getting crowds of under 20,000, in terms of the Premier League is on the low side. We are a provincial club. But we've beaten most of the Man Uniteds and Arsenals, and it's a credit to the players that a club of this size has reached three cup finals in four years. The Worthington Cup might be looked upon as the third trophy to go for but once we walk out at Wembley a lot of clubs will be very envious.

The manager has been magnificent about the whole thing. I expect the attack on the team hurt him more than anything directed at him personally. He surprises me because he gets better all the time with each little crisis. I look at his team selections sometimes and think 'what is going on here?' Then the boys go out and produce something like beating Arsenal on penalites with two youth team players sitting on the bench. I hold him in the highest esteem. He has worked minor miracles with this club.

We'd all love to have £10m so he could bring in a bit more quality and push on but for now we do our best with what we have. On a limited budget he's bought well_ players high on ability and character.

What we've got in terms of hunger, resolve, resilience and camaraderie is very special. We've a lot of players who came from the lower leagues and we are hungry. We're not spoilt here. We genuinely appreciate being in the Premiership. I had five great years at Crewe but I was yearning for the big time and now that I'm here, I lap it up.

I don't want to hear any more of this kick and rush nonsense. In fairness all teams want to be loved. But you only get that by what you do on a football pitch. I think we are loved and there's a healthy respect for us in the football fraternity. Looking down the fixture list everyone thinks Leicester are a dark horse and make for a tricky game.

And I think we've earned that.

Neil Lennon was talking to Amy Lawrence.

webTitle: I stand by what I wrote

fields.headline: I stand by what I wrote
fields.trailText: Leicester City: An apology. This correspondent may have given the impression last week that he does not often enjoy watching Leicester City play. Following the reaction of their fans, and the expansive, self-vindicating response of their team in crushing Aston Villa 1-0 to reach the Worthington Cup final, he now accepts that he was completely wrong and that the fantastic Foxes are the most entertaining team in the English game.
fields.body:
Leicester City: An apology. This correspondent may have given the impression last week that he does not often enjoy watching Leicester City play. Following the reaction of their fans, and the expansive, self-vindicating response of their team in crushing Aston Villa 1-0 to reach the Worthington Cup final, he now accepts that he was completely wrong and that the fantastic Foxes are the most entertaining team in the English game.

Not.

In fact, he stands by most of his column, though he accepts they did have a good 45 minutes. That was due largely to the return of Neil Lennon (see elsewhere on this page), who may not be the paciest of players but does give them a thoughtful option to their long-ball game with the way he sits in front of his defence and frequently makes himself available for a pass, before ferrying the ball on tidily. He did go overlooked here last week.

Martin O'Neill claimed that in that first period they might have had three or four goals, but the likelihood is that had one come earlier, they might then simply have sat on the lead sooner, as they did in the second half. Far from being vindication, it seemed mostly confirmation of criticism.

'Emile Heskey all on his own here,' the television commentary seemed to say more than once in the second half, informing us also of the damning statistic that Muzzy Izzett was still joint top scorer despite having missed seven of the last eight games. Radio 5 Live also informed us that their back three moved effortlessly into a back five or even, mischievously, 10.

But then they have had injuries, although somebody tell me a Premiership club who haven't. Also, they claim they don't have the resources to bolster the squad. Curious, that, given the revenue from three trips to a sold-out Wembley in four years.

All this is London bias against a small, provincial club, they claim. One suspects, however, that if a London club, or any big-city club for that matter, were playing the same way and had the same record of indiscipline - the latest example being Steve Walsh's elbow to the throat of Chris Sutton at Chelsea last Sunday - they would come in for some fearful abuse.

O'Neill is clearly a good manager, given that the criterion for such is getting the best out of a group of players and his handling of Stan Collymore, due to arrive tomorrow, will tell us more. We wait to see whether he is a great one, though, when he either takes the chance to move to a bigger club or is given to spend at Leicester the £10 million that the sale of Heskey will yield in the near future.

In the meantime, apart from all the apologists and actual supporters of the club - and bearing in mind that they have scored one goal in three-and-a-half hours during their last two Wembley appearances - hands up those who are looking forward to seeing Leicester City in the Worthington Cup final.
