fields.headline: Football's Bonfire of the Vanities
fields.trailText: There is a slew of football movies about to be released - The Match, about a couple of Scottish pub teams; Mad About Mambo, in which football and dance collide; and two called The Cup , one set in Bhutan and the other starring Ally McCoist. All these films are to be welcomed, but all of them are rather small-scale (see the hiring of McCoist). It is time for a footballing blockbuster that addresses the issues spewed up by the world's most popular game.
fields.body:
There is a slew of football movies about to be released - The Match, about a couple of Scottish pub teams; Mad About Mambo, in which football and dance collide; and two called The Cup , one set in Bhutan and the other starring Ally McCoist. All these films are to be welcomed, but all of them are rather small-scale (see the hiring of McCoist). It is time for a footballing blockbuster that addresses the issues spewed up by the world's most popular game.

If you were forced to pitch the film to a movie executive with a coke-ravaged attention span you might label it The Bonfire of the Vanities with a soccer - they're American - spin. It should be stressed that it is a work of fiction. All characters are fictitious and any resemblance to real persons, living or dead, is purely coincidental.

Here's the plot. Striker A and Winger B are out celebrating a 2-1 home win against Villa that keeps their team top of the League. They are high-profile, millionaire, internationals playing for one of the most illustrious sides in England. They go out with babes from competing girl bands. Life is large.

After a succession of lagers there is an altercation outside. No one can be sure what happens or who is to blame, the only certainty is that an Asian man is so severely injured that he ends up on a life-support machine. The football stars are arrested. What becomes interesting is not their guilt or innocence but the reactions of others.

The victim's family employ a high-profile lawyer and he ensures that the case becomes front-page news.

The football club knee-jerkingly attempt to brush everything under the carpet, but the victim's family refuse their offer of a million, cash, and the local police, while keen to help out their old muckers at the club, are under colossal pressure to play this one by the book.

The club become increasingly agitated. They are concerned not only about their stake in the two players, conservatively estimated at £30 million, but also the $200 million deal with a German internet/television/mobile phone company that has gone all wobbly on them. They fall back on the presumption of innocence and continue to select the two players. This backfires on them. Every game becomes a flash-point with demonstrations inside and outside the ground. In the end, the players ask to be dropped for their own protection.

The football press do not cover themselves in glory. Some representatives appear regularly on All-Sport Radio to argue that the fact that the victim is Asian rather than white is not strictly relevant. Their insistence in continuing to focus entirely on foot balling issues - How will the case affect the club's championship challenge? What will England do for width if Winger B can't play in the 2002 World Cup Finals? Are these demos wrecking the beautiful game? - rather misses the prevailing mood in the country.

The football authorities fare even worse. The sports minister of the day appears on Newsnight to fret about how all this hubbub will damage England's chances of hosting the 2010 World Cup. The next day he appears on the Today programme and promptly resigns. The FA and the PFA, are completely bewildered. The Bosman ruling was difficult enough, but this is truly complicated.

For many fans, the case and its implications serve to crystallise the disenchantment they feel for the sport. Football's response to the issues raised is so self-serving, so blinkered, so wrong-headed that in their droves supporters turn away from the national game.

And so to the trial, which lasts for many a month. It is screened live and exclusive on Sky Box Office and draws audiences far bigger than for a top Premiership match or even the recent Lewis v Tyson re-match. From this moment, LawTV rather than LiveFootball will be the biggest income generator for the company.

Britain, finally, has its OJ trial. Have we got a deal?

fields.headline: Fifa at fault over record
fields.trailText: When Hossam Hassan runs out for Egypt against Tunisia in the quarter-finals of the African Nations Cup in Kano, Nigeria, tomorrow, he will be making his 140th official international appearance, putting him within touching distance of Lothar Matthaus' world record of 143 caps.
fields.body:
When Hossam Hassan runs out for Egypt against Tunisia in the quarter-finals of the African Nations Cup in Kano, Nigeria, tomorrow, he will be making his 140th official international appearance, putting him within touching distance of Lothar Matthaus' world record of 143 caps.

That's how Fifa, football's governing body, would have it, for Hassan's record is potentially embarrassing to them at a time when the international game - at least in Europe - has been celebrating Matthaus' longevity.

In truth, Hassan is playing a world record 152nd time for Egypt, but 12 of his caps have been summarily disqualified because of a 'lack of evidence'. In reality it is more because the state of international record-keeping is in disarray, even in this technological age. Hassan is a victim, too, of Africa's poor sports administration where keeping statistics is as alien as paying wages on time.

It was late last year that the Egyptian FA belatedly decided to submit documentary proof to Fifa that the Al Ahli striker, who has also played in Greek and Swiss football, had a legitimate claim to being the world's most capped international.

The Egyptians claimed a total of 155 games for Hassan, but Fifa chopped this back to 133, disqualifying eight matches as non-internationals and leaving out a further 15 because of lack of evidence.

Two 'disqualified' caps came in Olympic qualifiers 13 years ago, when the tournament was not, as now, restricted to under-23s. They should be counted. Hassan can claim another 10 caps, but Fifa cannot verify them because the process of recording international matches remains flimsy and relies on national federations.

Under the rules, associations must report all internationals and send accompanying documentation to Fifa, along with a small share of the gate money. African associations have made a habit of conveniently forgetting this... and they get away with it.

It means Hassan, and a bevy of other African footballers, have been robbed of a legitimate right to more caps, among them Roger Milla.

'Africans don't keep records,' Ndumiso Gumede, secretary-general of the Zimbabwean FA, told me when I asked for a list of his country's caps, which only go back to independence in 1980. 'Ours is an oral history.' There are no records in his office, nor in other federation headquarters.

Hassan, 33, first played for Egypt in 1985 as a teenager, picked by the former Wales manager Mike Smith for a 3-0 defeat in Norway. His hundredth cap went unnoticed in 1996 when he scored the last two goals in a 7-1 win over Namibia in the World Cup.

webTitle: Cheap imports alert as quotas are slam dunked

fields.headline: Cheap imports alert as quotas are slam dunked
fields.trailText: In a week when the Football Association has discussed imposing quotas on foreign players from outside the European Union, a French court, basing its judgement on Community law, has said that the move would be illegal if it were applied to eastern bloc nationals.
fields.body:
In a week when the Football Association has discussed imposing quotas on foreign players from outside the European Union, a French court, basing its judgement on Community law, has said that the move would be illegal if it were applied to eastern bloc nationals.

In a landmark case that fleshes out the Bosman ruling, Polish basketballer Lilia Malaja has won an appeal which effectively recognises the right of associate members of the European Union to be regarded in the same light as EU nationals.

The consequences of the Malaja case for European sport - and football in particular - are enormous. The list of countries - 23 - which have similar agreements to Poland is extensive: Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Bulgaria, Czech Republic, Estonia, Georgia, Hungary, Kazakhstan, Kirgistan, Latvia, Lithuania, Moldova, Romania, Russia, Slovenia, Slovakia, Ukraine and Uzbekistan.

But it does not end in Europe because the north African countries of Algeria, Tunisia and Morocco fall into the same category. But a major footballing power like Yugoslavia is excluded.

Edward Grayson, UK expert on sport and the law, said: 'For professional sport this decision is dynamite. This is good law to which the whole of the EU is subject.'

Serge Pautot the Marseilles lawyer who fought the case for Malaja said: 'This is Bosman to the power of 23. It is going to have enormous and spectacular consequences for professional sport. We are going to witness the explosion of the frontiers of sport in Europe.'

But perhaps not quite yet. The initial application of the Malaja judgment will apply to nationals from the 23 countries who already ply their trade within the EC - it will not allow sportsmen (or indeed other workers) to come to EC countries such as Britain to begin employment. Those already here, however, will enjoy exactly the same post-Bosman freedom to cross borders once their existing contracts come to an end.

A spokesman for the FA insisted that quotas was only in the discussion stage but added that in the event of a legal challenge 'we would confront that as and when it arises.'

Gordon Taylor of the PFA was not available for comment but when the Malaja case first surfaced last year he said: 'It would create enormous problems for us if she wins. It could have serious repercussions. We could become a dumping ground for world football.' The ruling in the Malaja case handed down by the Nancy court of appeal on Thursday was based on article 37 of EU law concerning associate status. Under this law no worker from any of the 23 states can be discriminated against because of their nationality.

A spokeswoman for the DEE said: 'It depends on the grounds she had her case overturned on. We're not sure it would affect us. Each country has its own work permit scheme and that would be still the same.'

In the past eastern bloc nationals, once in the country, have still been subject to restrictive criteria which are reviewed on an annual basis. If the players have not met the criteria they are obliged to leave. In 1993 Hungarian Istvan Kozma was obliged to leave Liverpool because he did not play enough games. The French court found however that according to Community law once these nationals are legally employed in the country they must be viewed in the same light as EU nationals and must be allowed to work and move about freely in the countries of the EU without discrimination.

Grayson added: 'Malaja is a logical extension of Bosman. We're in a different legal system now, we are Europeans. This is the umbrella under which all European legal systems operate. You can't do anything about it and sport is no different. It thinks it's above the law but it isn't. It's all part of the logical unfolding of the development of industrial relations in the sporting world.'
fields.bodyText: In a week when the Football Association has discussed imposing quotas on foreign players from outside the European Union, a French court, basing its judgement on Community law, has said that the move would be illegal if it were applied to eastern bloc nationals. In a landmark case that fleshes out the Bosman ruling, Polish basketballer Lilia Malaja has won an appeal which effectively recognises the right of associate members of the European Union to be regarded in the same light as EU nationals. The consequences of the Malaja case for European sport - and football in particular - are enormous. The list of countries - 23 - which have similar agreements to Poland is extensive: Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Bulgaria, Czech Republic, Estonia, Georgia, Hungary, Kazakhstan, Kirgistan, Latvia, Lithuania, Moldova, Romania, Russia, Slovenia, Slovakia, Ukraine and Uzbekistan. But it does not end in Europe because the north African countries of Algeria, Tunisia and Morocco fall into the same category. But a major footballing power like Yugoslavia is excluded. Edward Grayson, UK expert on sport and the law, said: 'For professional sport this decision is dynamite. This is good law to which the whole of the EU is subject.' Serge Pautot the Marseilles lawyer who fought the case for Malaja said: 'This is Bosman to the power of 23. It is going to have enormous and spectacular consequences for professional sport. We are going to witness the explosion of the frontiers of sport in Europe.' But perhaps not quite yet. The initial application of the Malaja judgment will apply to nationals from the 23 countries who already ply their trade within the EC - it will not allow sportsmen (or indeed other workers) to come to EC countries such as Britain to begin employment. Those already here, however, will enjoy exactly the same post-Bosman freedom to cross borders once their existing contracts come to an end. A spokesman for the FA insisted that quotas was only in the discussion stage but added that in the event of a legal challenge 'we would confront that as and when it arises.' Gordon Taylor of the PFA was not available for comment but when the Malaja case first surfaced last year he said: 'It would create enormous problems for us if she wins. It could have serious repercussions. We could become a dumping ground for world football.' The ruling in the Malaja case handed down by the Nancy court of appeal on Thursday was based on article 37 of EU law concerning associate status. Under this law no worker from any of the 23 states can be discriminated against because of their nationality. A spokeswoman for the DEE said: 'It depends on the grounds she had her case overturned on. We're not sure it would affect us. Each country has its own work permit scheme and that would be still the same.' In the past eastern bloc nationals, once in the country, have still been subject to restrictive criteria which are reviewed on an annual basis. If the players have not met the criteria they are obliged to leave. In 1993 Hungarian Istvan Kozma was obliged to leave Liverpool because he did not play enough games. The French court found however that according to Community law once these nationals are legally employed in the country they must be viewed in the same light as EU nationals and must be allowed to work and move about freely in the countries of the EU without discrimination. Grayson added: 'Malaja is a logical extension of Bosman. We're in a different legal system now, we are Europeans. This is the umbrella under which all European legal systems operate. You can't do anything about it and sport is no different. It thinks it's above the law but it isn't. It's all part of the logical unfolding of the development of industrial relations in the sporting world.'

fields.headline: Women on the verge
fields.standfirst: This season, women provide much of the movies' creative firepower, argues  Mark Morris. But forget cosy 'chick flicks'. As  Boys Don't Cry  suggests, these films have a sharp edge
fields.trailText: This season, women provide much of the movies' creative firepower, argues Mark Morris. But forget cosy 'chick flicks'. As Boys Don't Cry suggests, these films have a sharp edge
fields.body:
There can't have been a more memorable - or more grating - movie ad campaign than the Sliding Doors World Cup poster. In the summer of '98 it seemed as if every Tube station wall and every bus shelter had been taken over by the image of Gwyneth Paltrow holding up a referee's red card.

The theory went that all men were glued to the World Cup, and, conversely, all women were football-haters who needed to take refuge in alternative reality comedy- dramas. Thus the ads insulted pretty much everybody. And, almost inevitably, the film was depressingly successful.

You would have to be blindly dogmatic to deny that the cinema audience often splits down gender lines. Traditionally, women like fewer guns, fewer car crashes and more roles for actresses beyond token girlfriends, wives, secretaries, hookers or crones. But what is promising about this spring's batch of films tilted towards a female audience is that not one of them aspires to be this year's Pretty Woman . These are films directed by women (Holy Smoke, Boys Don't Cry, Mansfield Park), or co-adapted by women from books by women (Tumbleweeds and Girl, Interrupted). They are films in which actresses get to play tired, battered, drunk and even mentally ill women. There is a pleasing complexity to the characters.

It would be nice to hail it as a breakthrough, but we have been here before. In the late Thirties and Forties the combination of writers such as Anita Loos and Dorothy Parker and sympathetic directors like George Cukor made for classics such as The Women.

And in the late Seventies and early Eighties, modern feminism belatedly arrived in Hollywood, and the likes of Sissy Spacek, Jessica Lange and Meryl Streep were let loose in Coal Miner's Daughter, Frances and Sophie's Choice. But no matter how far things seem to have come at any given point, the anguished cries of actresses remain as loud. For every Kathy Bates able to make a living as a star/character actress, there are a dozen silicone-pumped 19-year-old blondes.

But let's look on the bright side, and the obvious place to start is Boys Don't Cry, which could be the first film to earn someone the best actress Oscar for playing a swaggering stud. Kimberly Peirce's directorial debut is based on the bizarre life of Teena Brandon (aka Brandon Teena), a Midwestern teenager who not only felt she was a man, but managed to convince dozens of people - including his many girlfriends - that she was.

Peirce takes this extraordinary piece of Jerry Springer-fodder and turns it into a grounded, plausible American tragedy. The little known Hilary Swank is fantastic as the doomed, cocky Romeo taking too many chances in impoverished smalltown America - and by most accounts is a rather more convincing male than Brandon really was. But the performance goes far beyond male impersonation, and Swank is well matched by the excellent Chloë Sevigny as the girl who wanted to run with Brandon. Sevigny puts her New York It Girl tag far behind her: she's a substantial actress.

The same desperate, drifting working-class-in-decline world is also the backdrop to Tumbleweeds, which has turned veteran British stage and TV actress Janet McTeer into a surprise film star. Part of the thrill for the US critics who raved about McTeer's performance seems to have come from the sheer distance between her status as a 'proper' British actress and her role as a white trash single mom. Based on model-turned-actress Angela Shelton's memoirs, Tumbleweeds is the story of Mary Jo Walker (McTeer) who drags her daughter round the country in flight from disastrous relationships. There's nothing too original about the plot, but McTeer is terrific.

The other showboating, award-snagging performance coming our way is Angelina Jolie in Girl, Interrupted . Jolie has already picked up a supporting actress Golden Globe. This adaptation of Susanna Kaysen's account of her time in a psychiatric hospital film is Winona Ryder's long-nurtured pet project. Ryder is the executive producer and plays Kaysen, but Jolie hogs the movie as Kaysen's best friend, a liberating and destructive influence on all around her. At times she slips over the top, but there is a vivid glee in Jolie's performance.

Girl, Interrupted is an actress's movie: the men are few and far between, and they only exist in relationship to the female characters. The tables are thoroughly turned on poor Jared Leto, who turns up as the pretty, ineffectual and soon out of the picture boyfriend. (Leto seems to be carving out a strange career as the sensitive male bimbo: in Fight Club his face was smashed to a pulp for being too good-looking). The cast of Girl, Interrupted ranges from Vanessa Redgrave and a restrained Whoopi Goldberg to the excellent young actresses Brittany Murphy (from Clueless) and Clea DuVall (from Faculty). For all the star-power on offer, Murphy and DuVall are the best things about the film.

But if Girl, Interrupted is too obvious a bonding-in-misery flick, there are a couple of more eccentric films on offer. The first is Mansfield Park. That there would be an adaptation of Jane Austen's dourest novel was pretty inevitable: the Austen canon has been thoroughly plundered in recent times. But Miramax boss Harvey Weinstein's choice of director was Patricia Rozema, a typically off-beat Canadian best known for the sweetly meandering lesbian comedy I've Heard The Mermaids Singing .

Rozema's Mansfield Park merges Fanny Price (Frances O'Connor) and Austen herself. Then she chucks in laudanum-addiction, a hint of lesbianism... and points out that the basis of elegant nineteenth century country life was the slave trade. Austen addicts have been up in arms, but alongside all the more chocolate boxy adaptations there is plenty of room for this reinterpretation.

Mansfield Park looks very straight compared to Jane Campion's impressively odd Holy Smoke, which is worth cherishing if only for the scene in which Kate Winslet, driving through the outback, bellows along to Alanis Morissette. You'll never think of Winslet as a corset girl again.

The most surprising performance by an actress this spring comes from the almost unrecognisable Cameron Diaz in Being John Malkovich, and her scenes with Catherine Keener are brilliant. And as for the unwittingly annoying Gwyneth Paltrow? Thoroughly outclassed by Cate Blanchett in The Talented Mr Ripley.

fields.headline: Disarming Martin McGuiness [ii]
fields.standfirst: Martin McGuiness's recent appointment to the Stormont Assembly in Northern Ireland completes a 30-year journey from Provo poster boy to IRA Chief of Staff and, finally, to Crown minister. But in a week in which the decommissioning issue once again threatens to make or break the peace process, the man who was once dubbed 'Britain's number one terrorist' is showing a touching faith in politics.
fields.body:
In 1961, Martin McGuinness failed the 11-plus, adding to a litany of deprivations that marked a childhood tailor-made for a future career as revolutionary/terrorist. His family was poor, his home overcrowded, his neighbourhood a marginalised, Catholic slum. His bronchial father's health was eroded even further by a lifetime's work in an iron foundry.

In 1969, McGuinness witnessed his friends and neighbours batoned off the street by a brutish, sectarian police force. And then, the coup de grace, a man shot dead by British soldiers, his body brought to the end of McGuinness's street in sight of the 19-year-old butcher's assistant. The road McGuinness would choose began, perhaps, with the 11-plus failure. Instead of the high-achieving St Columb's College, he was 'selected' for the school next door, the Christian Brothers' technical school, long since demolished, but known at the time as the 'Brow o' the Hill'.

A former St Columb's pupil, Dermot Byrne, recalled in a letter to The Guardian the awfulness of that neighbouring school: 'On days when the windows were open, we could hear the ranting and screaming of the teachers and the sound of punishment being administered.' A former St Eugene's classmate, Paul McGill wrote: 'When they [the Christian Brothers] weren't beating you, they were glorifying the historic struggles of the Irish against the English oppressors... It is interesting to speculate how differently life might have been if Martin had passed the 11-plus and gone to St Columb's, where, by the way, he might have been taught history by the leader of the SDLP.

'As it was, he joined the IRA as many other disadvantaged young people did, in which he served for many years before embarking on the path of peace which led to his post as minister for education.' It's a tidy analysis and one that McGuinness rejects. Yes the Christian Brothers beat him, 'but they didn't make me a republican; the Brits made me a republican.' A former teacher at the school, Don O'Doherty, describes the teenage McGuinness: 'Martin was a very disciplined and industrious student and I never had any trouble with him. He was not outstanding in any way; however, he was extremely courteous and well-mannered.'

McGuinness quit school at 15, moving through a series of low-paid, unskilled jobs. His first experience of sectarianism came when he was rejected for a job as a mechanic on the grounds of his religion. In 1971, then working as a butcher's assistant, 'events' began to utterly transform the quiet, obedient Bogside boy into a ruthlessly focused, lethally angry IRA activist. If his life up until then had lacked meaning, the republican struggle gave him an education and a direction that slum life in the Bogside never could. The deaths of Seamus Cusack and Desmond Beattie (shot by British soldiers in disputed circumstances on 8 July 1971) had the greatest impact.

'I was at my front door and I heard roaring and shouting at the bottom of the street. It seemed that Dessie Beattie had brought in a car from the Leckey Road area. And I remember walking down to the bottom of the street seeing the body and the blood in the car and it scared the living daylights out of me. I was 19 years of age at the time and it had a powerful effect on me. I couldn't believe that anybody could be shot dead on the streets. For what? For throwing stones? I don't even know that Dessie Beattie was throwing stones'

McGuinness then launched into what was probably his most intensive period of IRA activism. The Bogside became a no-go area for the security forces until Operation Motorman in 1972 moved to crush the no-go areas in Derry and Belfast. After that, McGuinness fled south to the Republic, evading capture until December 1972. McGuinness's early activism would become the foundation of his 'stellar' career within the republican movement. While others threw stones and petrol bombs, launched sniper attacks on British soldiers, planted bombs and sacrificed personal lives for the cause, he did it all to Olympic standards.

During that period, the IRA in Derry launched a ferocious commercial bombing campaign. Just 20 of the city's 150 shops were finally left intact. 'It was a cleaner, less messy campaign than the one in Belfast,' said one Derry source. 'It was the IRA versus the Brits and there were no civilians killed during the campaign. There was almost something honourable about it. The campaign in Derry also avoided the purely sectarian hits that you had in Belfast. McGuinness also managed to keep republicans out of the clubs and the rackets.'

The British army then became the primary target. Between August 1971 and December 1972, 26 British soldiers were killed by the Provisional IRA in Derry. Five were still in their teens, the youngest, Angus Stephen and William Raistrick, just 18-years-old. The majority were killed by IRA snipers. McGuinness has since acknowledged the working-class ties that could have bound the British squaddies and IRA men. But in those days, the soldiers' humanity was visible only in the brief paragraphs that marked their deaths and fleshed out their lives, the unborn children they would never get to see, the wives left weeping in English towns.

By early 1972, the 21-year-old McGuinness had become an IRA superhero within the Bogside community. His personal bravery, his success is reviving the moribund Derry IRA into a strikingly effective force, his lack of affectation, all allied to an undeniable charisma, gave him an enduring iconographic status in the north's republican ghettos. 'He used to give us his bullet clips,' recalled Paul McGavigan, a former IRA activist in The Cook Report: 'He was a hero. You'd see him sniping, shooting around corners.' His reputation grew. Bogside women would goad the British soldiers: 'McGuinness will be out tonight. McGuinness will be out tonight...' He also induced fear among his own, alluded to in The Cook Report: 'You had to fear,' said one IRA activist, 'someone who had the power of life and death over you.'

Musing about McGuinness's hold over the movement, Sean O'Callaghan wrote: 'McGuinness is a strict disciplinarian who possesses, nevertheless, a degree of integrity in his dealings with IRA volunteers. Almost universally respected within the movement, he is a hard militant with a proven track record of operational experience. A British Army officer who served in McGuinness's home town of Derry, once referred to him as, "Excellent officer material".' His first appearance at a press conference in April 1972 caused US TV producers to swoon. 'Jeez,' one such is reported to have said, 'that boy would be hot on the coast. Can you see him, 6ft tall, in a dinner jacket, raising funds.'

'He had the looks,' recalled a Derry friend of McGuinness's. 'A lot of young girls used to find him gorgeous. A lot of them became republicans just because of him; they were like a fan club.' McGuinness's status did not go unnoticed. On 7 July 1972, he was part of a seven-man IRA delegation airlifted to London to meet with the then Northern Ireland Secretary of State, William Whitelaw. The talks came to nothing. In 1973 and 1974, McGuinness served two short prison terms for IRA membership. He has never faced charges in a British court. By the time the informer Sean O'Callaghan made his revelations, McGuinness was snug inside the peace process and no one was going to touch him.

The one serious blow to his 'deadly but honourable' image was an interview in The Cook Report with 81-year-old Rose Hegarty, mother of Frank Hegarty, an alleged IRA informer, who was shot dead in 1986. Rose Hegarty told of how her son had returned from England after McGuinness had given repeated assurances of his safety to his mother. When Hegarty did return, Rose Hegarty claimed that McGuinness said he would have to attend a meeting across the Irish border, but that 'nothing would happen to Frank. McGuinness said he'd bring him home himself.' In her annual memorial notice to her son, Rose Hegarty alludes to an unnamed 'Judas goat'.

McGuinness issued a blanket denial to every allegation in The Cook Report, yet he did support the murder of IRA informers. In a Panorama interview with Peter Taylor some time earlier, McGuinness said that if republican activists 'go over to the other side, then they more than anyone else are totally aware what the penalty for doing that is'. 'Death,' asked Taylor? 'Death, certainly,' McGuinness replied. On another occasion, speaking about the shooting dead of an alleged informer, a young woman, he said: 'To a republican soldier, she is a British agent... and she deserves to be executed.'

He added that the IRA volunteer who had carried out her killing would have carried on with his day-to-day business 'without any [emotional] problem whatsoever'. From his prison release until his emergence under the Sinn Fein electoral umbrella in the early 1980s, McGuinness largely disappeared from media view. It is widely accepted that he was the IRA's Chief of Staff from 1978 until 1982, when he ceded the position to Kevin McKenna in the run up to the Assembly elections in which he secured a seat.

The IRA killed 327 people during that period, which also witnessed three of the most high-profile IRA atrocities of the Troubles. On 17 February 1978, 12 people, seven of them women, were killed when an IRA firebomb devastated the La Mon Hotel on the outskirts of Belfast. On 27 August 1979, the Queen's cousin, Lord Louis Mountbatten, was killed by an IRA bomb on board a boat off the County Sligo coast. On the same day, 18 soldiers were killed when the IRA exploded two 800lb bombs at the Warrenpoint army base. If McGuinness was, as is widely believed, Chief of Staff at the time, it is clear that his reputation was further bolstered within the movement by the latter two 'spectaculars'.

Shortly after his 1974 release, he married Bernadette Canning, in a private church ceremony in Donegal. Vast sums of money were offered for photographs of the occasion, but no one obliged. The couple's first child was born in 1976, and the family was complete by 1986. That year the McGuinness family appeared in the BBC's Real Lives documentary, 'At the Edge of the Union', a programme promptly banned by the British government. The portrayal of McGuinness as a deeply committed, and loving father and husband, was more than Margaret Thatcher could stomach. Pure evil is a hard concept to push when the evil one is bouncing a fat, dribbling baby on his knee. In one scene, McGuinness walks on a Donegal beach with his wife and children; in another he is at the kitchen table coaxing alternate spoonfuls of what looks like shepherd's pie into his then baby son Emmet and the next in line, Fiachra.

Yet from a distance of more than 14 years, it is McGuinness's irresolute support of the IRA that comes across most strongly. It is inconceivable that McGuinness would now allow himself to be filmed in the centre of a republican mob chanting, 'Up the Ra, Up the Ra, Up the Ra', or to stand, ramrod stiff in front of a camera and state that it would be the armed campaign of the IRA that would eventually get the Brits out.

'We don't believe,' he said, 'that winning elections and any amount of votes will bring freedom in Ireland. At the end of the day, it will be the cutting edge of the IRA that will bring freedom.' Fourteen years later, in the Union Hall in Manhattan, McGuinness would ask his audience to: 'Help us become the largest political party in the north and south.' Sinn Fein and the IRA's evolution from the mid-1980's is well charted. By 1990, McGuinness was leading secret talks with the British government.

While history will sort out who cajoled whom to do what, it is clear that the decision to allow the ballot box to override the Armalite was a tactical one and not the conversion of a middle-aged IRA grandfather who likes Bran Flakes, and fly-fishing and Ali G, to the virtues of pacifism.

'The IRA stopped,' says McGuinness, 'because people put a political analysis to them which in their judgement was a project worthy of support.' On a late Friday afternoon, McGuinness takes me through Stormont Castle. He's in his shirtsleeves, utterly cool, walking through the corridors with an ease that belies that this man fought for almost three decades to raze this structure to the ground - if only metaphorically.

When visitors gape, he doesn't even notice. When an usher shuffles to attention as he passes, he beams and shakes his hand. Downstairs in the canteen, he eats battered fish and boiled potatoes, politely asking if I'd like a 'cappuccino'. An attendant lifts a tasselled rope to allow us to enter the Assembly chamber. 'That's where I sit and that's where Big Ian [Paisley] sits,' he says. 'He has an office just down from us, you know. I always say hello when I pass. It drives him mad. There was one time I went into the loo and he was standing outside in the corridor with someone. When I came out he was on his own. I think he wanted to say something, but he just couldn't bring himself to do it.'

Upstairs, in the green wing, the Sinn Fein office is awash with parliamentary detritus - New Year calendars and commercial diaries, picked over by staff and Assembly members . fields.bodyText: In 1961, Martin McGuinness failed the 11-plus, adding to a litany of deprivations that marked a childhood tailor-made for a future career as revolutionary/terrorist. His family was poor, his home overcrowded, his neighbourhood a marginalised, Catholic slum. His bronchial father's health was eroded even further by a lifetime's work in an iron foundry. In 1969, McGuinness witnessed his friends and neighbours batoned off the street by a brutish, sectarian police force. And then, the coup de grace, a man shot dead by British soldiers, his body brought to the end of McGuinness's street in sight of the 19-year-old butcher's assistant. The road McGuinness would choose began, perhaps, with the 11-plus failure. Instead of the high-achieving St Columb's College, he was 'selected' for the school next door, the Christian Brothers' technical school, long since demolished, but known at the time as the 'Brow o' the Hill'. A former St Columb's pupil, Dermot Byrne, recalled in a letter to The Guardian the awfulness of that neighbouring school: 'On days when the windows were open, we could hear the ranting and screaming of the teachers and the sound of punishment being administered.' A former St Eugene's classmate, Paul McGill wrote: 'When they [the Christian Brothers] weren't beating you, they were glorifying the historic struggles of the Irish against the English oppressors... It is interesting to speculate how differently life might have been if Martin had passed the 11-plus and gone to St Columb's, where, by the way, he might have been taught history by the leader of the SDLP. 'As it was, he joined the IRA as many other disadvantaged young people did, in which he served for many years before embarking on the path of peace which led to his post as minister for education.' It's a tidy analysis and one that McGuinness rejects. Yes the Christian Brothers beat him, 'but they didn't make me a republican; the Brits made me a republican.' A former teacher at the school, Don O'Doherty, describes the teenage McGuinness: 'Martin was a very disciplined and industrious student and I never had any trouble with him. He was not outstanding in any way; however, he was extremely courteous and well-mannered.' McGuinness quit school at 15, moving through a series of low-paid, unskilled jobs. His first experience of sectarianism came when he was rejected for a job as a mechanic on the grounds of his religion. In 1971, then working as a butcher's assistant, 'events' began to utterly transform the quiet, obedient Bogside boy into a ruthlessly focused, lethally angry IRA activist. If his life up until then had lacked meaning, the republican struggle gave him an education and a direction that slum life in the Bogside never could. The deaths of Seamus Cusack and Desmond Beattie (shot by British soldiers in disputed circumstances on 8 July 1971) had the greatest impact. 'I was at my front door and I heard roaring and shouting at the bottom of the street. It seemed that Dessie Beattie had brought in a car from the Leckey Road area. And I remember walking down to the bottom of the street seeing the body and the blood in the car and it scared the living daylights out of me. I was 19 years of age at the time and it had a powerful effect on me. I couldn't believe that anybody could be shot dead on the streets. For what? For throwing stones? I don't even know that Dessie Beattie was throwing stones' McGuinness then launched into what was probably his most intensive period of IRA activism. The Bogside became a no-go area for the security forces until Operation Motorman in 1972 moved to crush the no-go areas in Derry and Belfast. After that, McGuinness fled south to the Republic, evading capture until December 1972. McGuinness's early activism would become the foundation of his 'stellar' career within the republican movement. While others threw stones and petrol bombs, launched sniper attacks on British soldiers, planted bombs and sacrificed personal lives for the cause, he did it all to Olympic standards. During that period, the IRA in Derry launched a ferocious commercial bombing campaign. Just 20 of the city's 150 shops were finally left intact. 'It was a cleaner, less messy campaign than the one in Belfast,' said one Derry source. 'It was the IRA versus the Brits and there were no civilians killed during the campaign. There was almost something honourable about it. The campaign in Derry also avoided the purely sectarian hits that you had in Belfast. McGuinness also managed to keep republicans out of the clubs and the rackets.' The British army then became the primary target. Between August 1971 and December 1972, 26 British soldiers were killed by the Provisional IRA in Derry. Five were still in their teens, the youngest, Angus Stephen and William Raistrick, just 18-years-old. The majority were killed by IRA snipers. McGuinness has since acknowledged the working-class ties that could have bound the British squaddies and IRA men. But in those days, the soldiers' humanity was visible only in the brief paragraphs that marked their deaths and fleshed out their lives, the unborn children they would never get to see, the wives left weeping in English towns. By early 1972, the 21-year-old McGuinness had become an IRA superhero within the Bogside community. His personal bravery, his success is reviving the moribund Derry IRA into a strikingly effective force, his lack of affectation, all allied to an undeniable charisma, gave him an enduring iconographic status in the north's republican ghettos. 'He used to give us his bullet clips,' recalled Paul McGavigan, a former IRA activist in The Cook Report: 'He was a hero. You'd see him sniping, shooting around corners.' His reputation grew. Bogside women would goad the British soldiers: 'McGuinness will be out tonight. McGuinness will be out tonight...' He also induced fear among his own, alluded to in The Cook Report: 'You had to fear,' said one IRA activist, 'someone who had the power of life and death over you.' Musing about McGuinness's hold over the movement, Sean O'Callaghan wrote: 'McGuinness is a strict disciplinarian who possesses, nevertheless, a degree of integrity in his dealings with IRA volunteers. Almost universally respected within the movement, he is a hard militant with a proven track record of operational experience. A British Army officer who served in McGuinness's home town of Derry, once referred to him as, "Excellent officer material".' His first appearance at a press conference in April 1972 caused US TV producers to swoon. 'Jeez,' one such is reported to have said, 'that boy would be hot on the coast. Can you see him, 6ft tall, in a dinner jacket, raising funds.' 'He had the looks,' recalled a Derry friend of McGuinness's. 'A lot of young girls used to find him gorgeous. A lot of them became republicans just because of him; they were like a fan club.' McGuinness's status did not go unnoticed. On 7 July 1972, he was part of a seven-man IRA delegation airlifted to London to meet with the then Northern Ireland Secretary of State, William Whitelaw. The talks came to nothing. In 1973 and 1974, McGuinness served two short prison terms for IRA membership. He has never faced charges in a British court. By the time the informer Sean O'Callaghan made his revelations, McGuinness was snug inside the peace process and no one was going to touch him. The one serious blow to his 'deadly but honourable' image was an interview in The Cook Report with 81-year-old Rose Hegarty, mother of Frank Hegarty, an alleged IRA informer, who was shot dead in 1986. Rose Hegarty told of how her son had returned from England after McGuinness had given repeated assurances of his safety to his mother. When Hegarty did return, Rose Hegarty claimed that McGuinness said he would have to attend a meeting across the Irish border, but that 'nothing would happen to Frank. McGuinness said he'd bring him home himself.' In her annual memorial notice to her son, Rose Hegarty alludes to an unnamed 'Judas goat'. McGuinness issued a blanket denial to every allegation in The Cook Report, yet he did support the murder of IRA informers. In a Panorama interview with Peter Taylor some time earlier, McGuinness said that if republican activists 'go over to the other side, then they more than anyone else are totally aware what the penalty for doing that is'. 'Death,' asked Taylor? 'Death, certainly,' McGuinness replied. On another occasion, speaking about the shooting dead of an alleged informer, a young woman, he said: 'To a republican soldier, she is a British agent... and she deserves to be executed.' He added that the IRA volunteer who had carried out her killing would have carried on with his day-to-day business 'without any [emotional] problem whatsoever'. From his prison release until his emergence under the Sinn Fein electoral umbrella in the early 1980s, McGuinness largely disappeared from media view. It is widely accepted that he was the IRA's Chief of Staff from 1978 until 1982, when he ceded the position to Kevin McKenna in the run up to the Assembly elections in which he secured a seat. The IRA killed 327 people during that period, which also witnessed three of the most high-profile IRA atrocities of the Troubles. On 17 February 1978, 12 people, seven of them women, were killed when an IRA firebomb devastated the La Mon Hotel on the outskirts of Belfast. On 27 August 1979, the Queen's cousin, Lord Louis Mountbatten, was killed by an IRA bomb on board a boat off the County Sligo coast. On the same day, 18 soldiers were killed when the IRA exploded two 800lb bombs at the Warrenpoint army base. If McGuinness was, as is widely believed, Chief of Staff at the time, it is clear that his reputation was further bolstered within the movement by the latter two 'spectaculars'. Shortly after his 1974 release, he married Bernadette Canning, in a private church ceremony in Donegal. Vast sums of money were offered for photographs of the occasion, but no one obliged. The couple's first child was born in 1976, and the family was complete by 1986. That year the McGuinness family appeared in the BBC's Real Lives documentary, 'At the Edge of the Union', a programme promptly banned by the British government. The portrayal of McGuinness as a deeply committed, and loving father and husband, was more than Margaret Thatcher could stomach. Pure evil is a hard concept to push when the evil one is bouncing a fat, dribbling baby on his knee. In one scene, McGuinness walks on a Donegal beach with his wife and children; in another he is at the kitchen table coaxing alternate spoonfuls of what looks like shepherd's pie into his then baby son Emmet and the next in line, Fiachra. Yet from a distance of more than 14 years, it is McGuinness's irresolute support of the IRA that comes across most strongly. It is inconceivable that McGuinness would now allow himself to be filmed in the centre of a republican mob chanting, 'Up the Ra, Up the Ra, Up the Ra', or to stand, ramrod stiff in front of a camera and state that it would be the armed campaign of the IRA that would eventually get the Brits out. 'We don't believe,' he said, 'that winning elections and any amount of votes will bring freedom in Ireland. At the end of the day, it will be the cutting edge of the IRA that will bring freedom.' Fourteen years later, in the Union Hall in Manhattan, McGuinness would ask his audience to: 'Help us become the largest political party in the north and south.' Sinn Fein and the IRA's evolution from the mid-1980's is well charted. By 1990, McGuinness was leading secret talks with the British government. While history will sort out who cajoled whom to do what, it is clear that the decision to allow the ballot box to override the Armalite was a tactical one and not the conversion of a middle-aged IRA grandfather who likes Bran Flakes, and fly-fishing and Ali G, to the virtues of pacifism. 'The IRA stopped,' says McGuinness, 'because people put a political analysis to them which in their judgement was a project worthy of support.' On a late Friday afternoon, McGuinness takes me through Stormont Castle. He's in his shirtsleeves, utterly cool, walking through the corridors with an ease that belies that this man fought for almost three decades to raze this structure to the ground - if only metaphorically. When visitors gape, he doesn't even notice. When an usher shuffles to attention as he passes, he beams and shakes his hand. Downstairs in the canteen, he eats battered fish and boiled potatoes, politely asking if I'd like a 'cappuccino'. An attendant lifts a tasselled rope to allow us to enter the Assembly chamber. 'That's where I sit and that's where Big Ian [Paisley] sits,' he says. 'He has an office just down from us, you know. I always say hello when I pass. It drives him mad. There was one time I went into the loo and he was standing outside in the corridor with someone. When I came out he was on his own. fields.headline: Strange days and odd jobs
fields.standfirst: Films with a weird streak are not obvious box-office. Why then, wonders  Damon Wise,  is movie surrealism in vogue this season?
fields.trailText: Films with a weird streak are not obvious box-office. Why then, wonders Damon Wise, is movie surrealism in vogue this season?
fields.body:
After his brush with an Oscar last year for The Truman Show, it seemed Jim Carrey was on the threshold of being taken seriously as an actor. For his role in Milos Forman's Man On The Moon, he beat off some serious opposition to play the part of doomed, demented stand-up comic Andy Kaufman.

Hollywood gossip says the director was swamped with audition tapes from the very best actors available and was so overwhelmed by the choice that he left it to the studio to decide.

The film's release was bumped to the all-important end-of-year slot to keep it fresh in the Academy's mind when the voting slips went out. But when it was finally released in the States, the public failed to react. Even though The Truman Show had breezed past the $100 million mark - and despite almost a year of hype that suggested Man On The Moon was Carrey's best work to date - it opened on Boxing Day to a surprisingly subdued take of a little over $7m. Carrey went on to take a Golden Globe for his perfor mance and stands a very good chance of making the Oscar short list, but the paying public's lack of affection for this remarkably honest and moving biopic was conveniently brushed under the carpet.

The truth is that Andy Kaufman, respected and revered as he was by his peers, was not terribly popular with the rest of America. After peaking as the endearingly bumbling foreigner Latka in the hit sitcom Taxi, he set about destroying his new-found fame with a series of mind-bending pranks and jokes that the public never really got.

Abandoning traditional comedy altogether, Kaufman pioneered a strain of surrealism that tested people's patience. When he 'forgot' his lines, was he joking? When he stood up onstage and read The Great Gatsby for three hours, was he joking? When he insulted women and invited them to wrestle him, was he joking? And when he died of cancer, at the age of 35, was he still joking?

The public's threshold for surrealism has never been strong. Although he made his name with the surrealist classics Un Chien Andalou and L'Age D'Or , Luis Buñuel went without work for most of the Thirties and arrived penniless in New York at the end of the decade. In the 60 years since, surrealism has largely been the province of the art movie, and even though certain figures (David Lynch, Terry Gilliam and David Cronenberg especially) are able to entice some of America's most respected actors off the beaten track, the box office figures tell their own story.

A case in point is last year's Fight Club, which peaked at $36m despite a wealth of hype and the presence of pretty boy Brad Pitt. The violence turned off his female fanbase, and many more were baffled by the film's ambiguous setting and far-fetched plot twists. Similarly, Martin Scorsese's visually stunning Bringing Out The Dead died a premature death of its own, with many bemoaning its seemingly pointless scenes of pyrotechnic excess without realising that this sensory pile-up was part of the film's point.

The treatment of these films would suggest public indifference to movies that bend reality - if it weren't for a couple of films that have sneaked under the wire lately. The first is American Beauty, which managed to capture the public's imagination even though its lead character is quickly established as telling his story from beyond the grave. The film is also punctuated by beautiful, wordless scenes of aesthetic indulgence that are there only because of the raw connections they spark. The film's success, plus the early reception afforded Paul Thomas Anderson's decidedly offbeat Magnolia seems to suggest the American public are a little more open to surrealist interludes when they find their place within a standard narrative. (A different kind of weird - also within a fairly straightforward narrative - is the very idea of Mike Leigh, whose films tend to scrutinise present-day Britain, moving onto a biopic of Gilbert and Sullivan!)

But this doesn't explain the incredible appeal of Being John Malkovich, a seemingly ridiculous outsider by promo director Spike Jonze that squeezed into Variety 's Top 100 of 1999 with a year-end take of $18m, just 14 places below the much-vaunted and ostensibly much more commercial Man On The Moon at $24m.

Man On The Moon, after all, is about a man the American public once took to their hearts and it features one of their favourite stars. Being John Malkovich, in contrast, stars John Cusack as a failed puppeteer who gets a job as a filing clerk on the seven-and-a-halfth floor of a major New York building. By accident he drops an important document behind the back of a filing cabinet and, on retrieving it, uncovers a portal that leads directly into John Malkovich's brain. And then he starts selling tickets.

Bearing in mind that David Cronenberg's eXistenZ, an entertaining but pretentious take on computer games in the new millennium, took less than $3m, the success of Being John Malkovich is no small achievement. Yet the makers themselves are not convinced that the public is necessarily warming to the genre, seeing it as more a case of people being bludgeoned into submission by the film's lack of compromise. 'Maybe it's because it's so relentlessly that way,' says writer Charlie Kaufman of his film's success. For Kaufman, the superficial strangeness of the story masks an oddly human love triangle that makes up the strange emotional core of the film: the puppeteer, his forlorn wife and the dazzling female workmate who comes between them.

'The reality is in the characters' reaction to their circumstances, and also to what it is they're desperate about,' he says. 'I was interested in that as a way of grounding it, so it wasn't just being weird for weird's sake.'

The film may yet signal something of a watershed in American cinema history, and already Patricia Arquette has signed up for a role in Kaufman's follow-up, Human Nature, in which she'll play the world's hairiest lady. He also has another script being made, adapted from a non-fiction book, which seems to astonish even him. It's about orchids, the natural history of orchids, and orchid collectors. There's a character who steals an orchid from a Florida swamp, but he disappears halfway through. There is, Kaufman says quite freely, no story.

Meanwhile, the forthcoming adaptation of Bret Easton Ellis's American Psycho -in which Manhattan yuppie Patrick Bateman (Christian Bale) may or may not be a hideous misogynist serial killer - looks set to take Fight Club 's mindgames into a controversial new dimension. But anyone expecting a new surrealist revolution to happen overnight may be in for a long wait. In November a letter appeared in the New York Times complaining about a scene in Kaufman's film in which John Cusack's puppeteer locks his wife in her pet monkey's cage so he can enter John Malkovich's body and make love to another woman. The writer claimed that, in terms of feminism, this was not a progressive movie. Says Kaufman - and he should know -'It's bizarre.'

fields.headline: Golden Globe winner Janet McTeer
fields.trailText: There was an interloper among the showbiz royalty at the recent Golden Globes awards. It was no surprise to see Hollywood blue-bloods Tom Cruise and Denzel Washington collect gongs, but many of the 50 million television audience probably reached for their celebrity Who's Who, B-list section, when Janet McTeer went up on stage.
fields.body:
There was an interloper among the showbiz royalty at the recent Golden Globes awards. It was no surprise to see Hollywood blue-bloods Tom Cruise and Denzel Washington collect gongs, but many of the 50 million television audience probably reached for their celebrity Who's Who, B-list section, when Janet McTeer went up on stage.

The 38-year-old Brit had, against the odds, walked away with the Best Actress award for her role in the bittersweet comedy, Tumbleweeds. McTeer's Mary Jo is a gregarious single mother; a happy-go-lucky Southern gal who drags her adolescent daughter around the country fleeing from dead-end jobs and boyfriends. Mary Jo is sexy, and effortlessly seductive to both sexes, but her trials and tribulations wouldn't look out of place in a daytime soap. The script and McTeer's irresistible performance make the film a warm-hearted little gem.

Given her Rada background, it's McTeer's impeccable Southern accent that has attracted most attention in the States. After last year's Sundance Film Festival, one fan was particularly taken with her performance. 'You're the sweetest Southern girl I ever seen,' he shouted. 'Ain't you my cousin?'

'I rather think not,' McTeer replied tartly, 'unless you mean the south of England.' In fact she was born and raised in York.

She spent three months in North Carolina listening to the local vernacular to prepare for the part. Her preparations left her out of pocket since she was paid a relative pittance for her performance. But it was worth it. The success of Tumbleweeds has made her a hot property. She now shares the same agent as Calista Flockhart.

It's not the first time McTeer has been the one to watch. The ink on her Equity card had barely dried when she was chosen to play Beatrice in Much Ado About Nothing. The classical roles piled up. By 27, she was exhausted. 'I used to look in the mirror and think, I look terrible.' Her unrelenting schedule eventually took its toll. She was struck down by a mysterious infection, which plagued her with migraines and poor sight for six months. It also made her reassess her career.

In 1996 she came to popular attention as a prison governor in Lynda La Plante's typically hard-boiled TV series, The Governor . At 6ft 1in she cut an imposing figure as she patrolled the institution.

The move to Hollywood wasn't a natural career progression. Her Tony-winning performance in the Broadway revival of Ibsen's A Doll's House , the role she had first played in the West End, alerted Americans to a new talent.

'I'd never even been to America,' she told Entertainment Weekly . 'As far as I was concerned, I was coming to do my little play and go home.' With a probable Oscar nomination on the cards, she can afford to discard her return ticket.

McTeer's Mary Jo is a gregarious single mother; a happy-go-lucky Southern gal who drags her adolescent daughter around the country fleeing from dead-end jobs and boyfriends. Mary Jo is sexy, and effortlessly seductive to both sexes, but her trials and tribulations wouldn't look out of place in a daytime soap. The script and McTeer's irresistible performance make the film a warm-hearted little gem. Given her Rada background, it's McTeer's impeccable Southern accent that has attracted most attention in the States. After last year's Sundance Film Festival, one fan was particularly taken with her performance. 'You're the sweetest Southern girl I ever seen,' he shouted. 'Ain't you my cousin?' 'I rather think not,' McTeer replied tartly, 'unless you mean the south of England.' In fact she was born and raised in York. She spent three months in North Carolina listening to the local vernacular to prepare for the part. Her preparations left her out of pocket since she was paid a relative pittance for her performance. But it was worth it. The success of Tumbleweeds has made her a hot property. She now shares the same agent as Calista Flockhart. It's not the first time McTeer has been the one to watch. The ink on her Equity card had barely dried when she was chosen to play Beatrice in Much Ado About Nothing. The classical roles piled up. By 27, she was exhausted. 'I used to look in the mirror and think, I look terrible.' Her unrelenting schedule eventually took its toll. She was struck down by a mysterious infection, which plagued her with migraines and poor sight for six months. It also made her reassess her career. In 1996 she came to popular attention as a prison governor in Lynda La Plante's typically hard-boiled TV series, The Governor . At 6ft 1in she cut an imposing figure as she patrolled the institution. The move to Hollywood wasn't a natural career progression. Her Tony-winning performance in the Broadway revival of Ibsen's A Doll's House , the role she had first played in the West End, alerted Americans to a new talent. 'I'd never even been to America,' she told Entertainment Weekly . 'As far as I was concerned, I was coming to do my little play and go home.' With a probable Oscar nomination on the cards, she can afford to discard her return ticket.

webTitle: Rising tides threaten ageing nuclear stations

fields.headline: Rising tides threaten ageing nuclear stations
fields.trailText: Government scientists and experts in the nuclear industry are preparing for a doomsday scenario caused by rising tides around Britain's ageing atomic power stations.
fields.body:
Government scientists and experts in the nuclear industry are preparing for a doomsday scenario caused by rising tides around Britain's ageing atomic power stations.

As British Nuclear Fuels prepares to close down some of the oldest reactors, nuclear engineers are worried that abandoned plants will be inundated by the sea. The nuclear waste discharged in a flood would contaminate much of the coastline for decades to come.

Consultant nuclear engineer John Large, who advises central government and local authorities about safety issues, told The Observer : 'This is a catastrophe waiting to happen. Over the next 100 years there will be significant sea rises and no one has prepared for this.

'Conventional sea defences are not designed to withstand the combination of a rise in the sea level, an increase in inclement weather and bouts of flash flooding.'

All but one of Britain's nuclear plants is on the coast and many were intentionally sited on low-lying ground to give access to sea water for cooling without the need for expensive pumping systems. But even the designers of Britain's newest nuclear power station, commissioned at Sizewell in East Anglia in 1994, did not consider the effects of global warming.

Last week The Observer revealed that Britain's coastline is being eroded at a rate that could lead sea levels to rise by up to 60 centimetres during the next 50 years.

The areas predicted to be underwater by 2025 by Dr Edward Hill of the Proudman Oceanographic Laboratory coincide with key nuclear installations.

Hinkley Point on the Somerset levels, Dungeness and Sizewell in the South East, and the BNFL reprocessing plant at Sellafield would all be affected.

An emergency flood caused by global warming is a nightmare scenario associated with the older generation of Magnox reactors.

The Government has had to decommission plants at Hunterston in Scotland, Trawsfynydd in North Wales and Berkeley in Gloucestershire after inspectors raised concerns about safety issues. Bradwell in Essex and Hinkley Point in Somerset are to be closed for safety checks.

Scientists are also worried about the build-up of 'Wigner energy', a by-product of the nuclear reaction that can lead to the ignition of the graphite core.

Even after decommissioning, plants are to be be left as radioactive hulks for 150 years before being dismantled, by which time sea levels could have risen by a metre.

BNFL is so worried about older power stations built between 1956 and 1971 that it has called emergency meetings between its scientists, local campaign groups and anti-nuclear organisations.

Greenpeace will launch a campaign in spring to coincide with public consultation by the Environment Agency on the future of Magnox stations. Campaigners may focus on Hinkley Point A station in Somerset, shut since last autumn after a radioactive leak contaminated the Severn estuary. Campaigners want Hinkley A to be closed altogether, but BNFL hopes to reopen the plant in April after repairing the reactor and getting safety clearance from the Nuclear Installations Inspectorate. However, BNFL apparently has contingency plans for closure.

The Stop Hinkley campaign is spearheaded by Jim Duffy, an anti-nuclear activist, and his wife Karalina Matsukevich, who grew up near Chernobyl in Ukraine, the site of the world's worst nuclear accident in 1986.

Matsukevich was 18 at the time and is now on the British cancer register as a result of ovarian and thyroid cysts caused by radiation from the plant. She lives in West Quantoxhead, 10 miles from Hinkley Point, and fears a similar accident here if BNFL reopens the reactors.

'It's a sad irony for me,' she told The Observer , 'I know too well what's it's like when an accident happens and it's terrible. I am always conscious of the presence of Hinkley Point and I am scared to take my daughter to the beach.'

A spokeswoman for the Environment Agency said the report on the consultation over the Magnox stations would be published at the end of the year after a series of public meetings. She added that global warming was a serious issue and the agency had allowed for a six-millimetre annual rise in sea levels in its plans for sea defences.

Colin Bennett, of BNFL Magnox Generation, said no special preparation had been made to protect decommissioned reactors from flooding and added that sea water was already used in the cooling process.

'In the highly unlikely event that water got into a plant,' he said, 'the sea water itself would be an economic loss, but there would be no major safety issues.'

webTitle: Archer and Grisham plc to merge?

fields.headline: Archer and Grisham plc to merge?
fields.trailText: Robert McCrum reveals the secret behind the new John Grisham novel
fields.body:
The new John Grisham arrived here at the World of Books under heavy embargo. But if there is a secret contained within these 360-odd pages that the publisher does not want the wider world to know about in advance, it must be how thin and uninteresting Grisham's work has become, how lazy and utterly putdownable, every line marked with the unmistakable taint of 'soon to be a major motion picture'.

A close reading of The Brethren (Century £16.99 pp366) does, however, clear up one mystery of interest to British bestseller readers: Jeffrey Archer watchers in the world of books, who have noted his absence from the ceaseless turmoil of literary endeavour, have been wondering what the disgraced peer has been up to these past several months.

Now, for the first time, and on the exclusive basis of this embargoed text, I can reveal that he has gone into creative partnership with his bestselling American cousin.

Just as nifty British multinationals make strategic alliances with worldbeating Yankee competitors, so in the cut-throat arena of bestselling fiction, brand is well advised to make deals with rival brand. The Brethren demonstrates that Archer plc has made a stunning reverse takeover of Grisham Inc. Nothing but Lord Archer's fabled command of narrative technique could explain the novel here issued under Grisham's name.

At first, for devotees of The Firm and The Pelican Brief, all seems well. We open in familiar Grisham territory, in a low security federal prison in the north Florida boondocks. Three disgraced former judges, styling themselves 'The Brethren' in homage to the US Supreme Court's archaic moniker, are dispensing prison justice, and operating a simple mail-scam successfully designed to blackmail prominent (and wealthy) closet homosexuals. So far, so Grisham. It's by no means the most gripping plot in the world, but it will serve, and with a bit of work it could have been made into a perfectly plausible legal yarn 'by the author of'.

At this point (I imagine) the American courtroom bestseller king e-mailed some work-in-progress to his new British partner and got a distinctly dusty answer from Archerworld HQ. 'These old jailbirds aren't sexy !' cried Jeff. 'Politics! You've gotta mix in some politics. It's 2000. Give them an election-year cliffhanger!

'And dammit, John, give them' - his voice dropped an octave as he uttered the words that had have made him millions in 15 languages - 'give them the CIA!'

And suddenly there it is: in chapter two, and on page 20 no less, before the Brethren have even had time to take a turn around the exercise yard, the narrative swerves up to Washington DC. We are introduced to the unknown Congressman, scandal-free Aaron Lake, who has been chosen by the head of the CIA to be the intelligence agency's home-grown candidate for the Presidency, the man who will stand up to resurgent Russians and put a bit of stick about in the Arab world.

It's a preposterous story that more properly belongs in the pages of conventional airport tosh, but by page 48 everything's settled, at least to Archer-Grisham's satisfaction. 'We promise to get you elected,' says the CIA's wheel-chair-bound (Jeff, please!) Mr Big. 'And you promise to double defense spending and get ready for the Russians.'

'You have a deal,' says Lake. If only the reader was so lucky. Books of this kind depend on 'the willing suspension of disbelief'. With The Brethren most readers would need a crane to achieve this feat.

The novel now becomes fatally divided between the absolutely unbelievable account of Aaron Lake's run for the White House (in the week of the McCain-Bush High Noon, a candidate who says 'Who needs New Hamphire, I'll take the rest of the country' sounds at best out of touch, at worst from central casting at Archerworld) and the almost equally implausible unfolding of the Brethren's jailhouse scamming.

I suppose that in Archer-Grisham's mind these two tales were supposed to mirror each other, nailed together by the intervention of villains from the CIA with names like Deville (thanks, Jeff!). In the end, surprise surprise, it turns out that empty suit Aaron Lake has been ensnared by the Brethren's mail-scam, and then, as blurbs like to say, the book moves to its shattering conclusion.

Except that it's about as shattering as tea and scones in Grantchester Meadows. On page 332 the President of the United States utters the leaden words: 'This is a bit confusing.' He is not alone.

Not to mince words, The Brethren is truly dreadful: misconceived, uninteresting and quite deadly. If it did not bear the Grisham logo it would not even deserve our notice.

The only good thing about it is that it appears to have been composed in an approximation of the English language.

So perhaps it wasn't anything to do with Lord Archer, after all.
