fields.headline: Life with the Teflon toff
fields.standfirst: He's lived through a royal marriage, his mistress's suicide and unexpected fatherhood at 68. Yet Lord Snowdon remains unscathed
fields.trailText: He's lived through a royal marriage, his mistress's suicide and unexpected fatherhood at 68. Yet Lord Snowdon remains unscathed
fields.body:
Our meeting is scheduled for 4 o'clock, but Lord Snowdon's assistant rings me late morning, asking if it would be possible for us to meet for lunch instead. Actually, it's not at all convenient, so I lodge some objections, but then - after a little muffled conferring - she says Snowdon would like a word. 'I was thinking,' says an elderly voice, mildly but firmly, 'that it might be fun to talk over lunch, wouldn't it?' and of course, after that, there is no point in arguing.

An hour or so later, we are making our way to the restaurant closest to his Kensington house. As we walk - very slowly, for he's a few weeks short of his seventieth birthday, and has had a limp since a teenage brush with polio, and in any case his manners are so painfully exquisite that he pulls back whenever we approach lampposts so that I can go on ahead - we see a crocodile of smart little London schoolgirls approaching, a battalion of Emilys and Jessicas in blue and grey blazers, paired off like Noah's cargo. When they've passed, Snowdon turns to me and asks, 'Do you think they might all be related?'

Beneath all the whimsical twinkling, Snowdon is a man of secrets: his appetite for the frivolous is entirely compatible with his cast-iron discretion when it comes to more serious matters. As a result, he has never talked about his first wife, Princess Margaret, or the suicide of a long-term mistress four years ago, or the recent separation from his second wife, Lucy, or the affair which resulted in the birth of a son called Jasper in 1998 (all the things, in other words, that anyone might want to ask him about); yet even when he's deflecting a parry into his personal life, he does so with immense amiability. Consequently, he is a nightmarish interview subject. When he's not being vague or forgetful, he's being evasive. Yet somehow, his charm renders him untouchable: the Teflon toff.

Having shed his Margaret Howell overcoat and a duck-egg scarf - a relic of Cambridge days, half a century ago - Snowdon is shown to his customary table ('I like to see who's coming around the corner') and sits down to consider the menu, juggling two sets of spectacles. His remarks to the waiter are characteristic: half-apologetic, in the way of the well-mannered top-drawer set, and half-bracing.

He orders duck liver, followed by roast chicken, although the description of the gravy appears to irritate him slightly: 'What's the tarragon "jus"?' he asks, with a little bit of an edge. Though Snowdon accepted the life peerage offered to him in the new-look House of Lords, whereas the Duke of Edinburgh and his sons all refused theirs, he says he is not one for fancy titles. Talking about his forthcoming show at the National Portrait Gallery, he says, 'I hate the word "portraits". Portraits to me means something that is rather grand and old-fashioned, in oils. It's better to say photographs.' Then he adds, 'Hate the word "retrospective", too. It's a bit pompous. I didn't want it to be called a retrospective, but they wanted to, so I said, "Well, call it an obituary then." ' He snuffles a bit.

The NPG exhibition probably says more about Snowdon than he ever will. In it, you can see traces of his society background, his interest in the arts, his royal connections, as well as his social conscience (he is reported to be staying on in the Lords to continue his campaigning work for the disabled).

Perhaps it's modesty, or that posh trait of pretending not to take anything seriously, but he is relentlessly offhand about photography. 'When I started out, you only took photographs because you drew badly. It was a very lowly profession,' he says, and, 'It has all got too grand. It's pretty rubbish, they should just get on with it. We're reporters.'

He can't resist asking whether I've seen a particular feature in a recent Tatler, a Mario Testino promotion for a mackintosh manufacturer, masquerading as the wedding album of Kate Moss and Lord Frederick Windsor. 'Have you seen those latest things, taken by Mario, which are very bizarre? No, I couldn't possibly comment on Mario's work... I am very fond of him, I know him a little bit.' His daughter from his second marriage, Frances, now in her early twenties, worked with Testino before moving on to be one of Paolo Roversi's assistants.

Like the Great Wall of China seen from space, a Testino fashion spread is utterly distinctive, whereas Snowdon's work - like the earl himself - is altogether more difficult to pin down. When I ask him to describe its hallmarks, he looks horrified. 'I hope nothing,' he says, spooning bread sauce on to his plate. 'If I have a recognisable style, that's my failing. It would just mean that I'm repeating myself. I just want to capture something that relates to the [subject].' Later, he backtracks on this as well, as if it was too ambitious (I can't help feeling that his words have a bearing on our meeting, too). 'It's not always trying to get to the truth, it's trying to amuse as well. A lot of the time I'm playing games, and a lot of it's theatre, and a lot of it's cheating, in every possible way.'

So which line to take on Snowdon? Some facts, at least, are unarguable. He was born in 1930, to a barrister and an heiress who divorced when he was five. He and his elder sister Susan spent their childhood at their father's estate in Caernarvonshire and with their mother - who swiftly remarried the Earl of Rosse - in Ireland and Yorkshire. He was sent to Eton and then, excused National Service because of the polio, studied architecture at Cambridge. He left without a degree but with a blue, having coxed the victorious side in the 1950 Boat Race.

By then, he'd already begun to be interested in photography - or more accurately in cameras. (He's fascinated by mechanics. 'I walk around like a ferret,' he says, explaining how, on a recent visit to Paris, he was so transfixed by a water sculpture on the Champs Elysées that he laboriously tracked down its bewildered Greek creator. They had lunch together a few weeks ago. 'My Greek's not very good, and really it was so complicated, but I adored him because he was absolutely obsessed by his fountain. It drove me absolutely mad until I found out how it worked.')

At school, he'd founded a photographic society, 'mainly because I wanted to go somewhere quiet', and invented an underwater camera: 'You had to surface every time you wound it on, so it only took one picture at a time. That's quite good training.' After Cambridge, his father paid for him to study at Baron's photographic studio, and then helped him rent his own in Pimlico. You might think this showed extreme tolerance, but the family had bohemian connections: a great-uncle was a Punch cartoonist, and Anne's brother, Oliver Messel, was a celebrated set-designer.

During the Fifties, young Armstrong-Jones successfully reconciled the roles of snapper and debs' delight (he was a very popular walker) and won his first royal commission, taking the 21st birthday photographs of the Duke of Kent. In 1958, he met Princess Margaret and, in order to muffle the relationship as much as possible, rented an apartment in darkest Rotherhithe, where they ate fish and chips straight from the wrapper.

They had two children and divorced in 1978. There's little doubt that Snowdon's career was partly inhibited by the match; after all, he was now as famous as anyone he was commissioned to photograph. So he returned to design: an electric wheelchair, and a collaboration with an architect and an engineer which led to the the aviary ('that funny old birdcage') at London Zoo, for which he was paid £145, 'and that included the model'.

Snowdon has finished his glass of white wine, so I offer him another.

'No darling, let's have a red wine. A bottle. Can they afford it?'

The matre d' is there in the blink of an eye. 'The house claret? Or would you prefer something fuller-bodied?'

'Ah, I wonder. No, no. I think that ordinary one.'

The matre d' starts to ask whether I'd like another glass of white, but Snowdon is too quick. 'No, we'll have a bottle of the red, I think.'

'You'll have a bottle of it?' repeats the matre d', with emphatic neutrality.

'Well, don't sound so surprised,' says Snowdon, rather crossly.

'No, that's fine, it's just that you usually drink it by the glass, sir.'

Snowdon subsides, like a balloon that has been left too close to the radiator. 'Oh, alright. We'll try it by the glass.'

'I'm happy to do whatever you prefer, sir,' the waiter offers, but Snowdon has given up. 'We'd better have it by the glass,' he repeats dispiritedly. When we're about to leave, he notices I haven't finished mine - 'Might drink that. Are you going to leave it?' - and polishes it off.

After lunch, we walk back up the street to the house where he has lived since his first marriage ended, and where he now lives alone, surrounded by clocks, and mechanical toys, and a clutch of elegant scarlet chairs which he designed for the Prince of Wales's investiture at Caernarvon in 1969.

Of course, I'd like to ask why he hasn't yet divorced from his second wife, Lucy; and whether he ever sees his son, Jasper, the result of a brief affair with a commissioning editor at Country Life which preceded the separation; and what went on with poor Anne Hills, who took an overdose on New Year's Eve 1996 after a 20-year on-off relationship with the earl; but instead, Snowdon is telling me about a trip to the cinema with Frances last week to see the new Scorsese film, which was awful, and about how he has converted her Paris bathroom into a darkroom, and how he's forever nipping over on Eurostar with his toolbox, and how he wishes the train would just shoot off the end of Brighton Pier with a great splash instead of slinking underground.

This prompts another thought entirely, which leads to another, and to another: 'It's wonderful when you go to Moscow or St Petersburg - there are no railings in the parks or squares. It's all open, everyone can walk in. Why do we have to have these awful prissy little keys to go into a park? We should pull all the railings down. Get rid of them, open it all up, green grass, and make everyone welcome. It would be wonderful. It was like that during the war when all the railings were melted down. Unfortunately, they melted them up again. Why do you say "melt down" but not "melt up"? I was thinking about this the other day. You don't say, "It's trying not to rain," do you? But you'd say, "It's trying to rain." All these weather forecast things I love to listen to before I go to sleep. Don't you? The latest news from Fred Astaire and Rockall... We were going to do a film, John Betjeman and I. It was called Cloudy Bright, which used to be printed on packets of photographic film, I don't think it is any more. A lovely title, don't you think? Peter Sellers was going to be in it, and we had one meeting at the RAC Club in Pall Mall, for lunch, and we were stopped at the door because Peter didn't have a tie on, so he put one on, but inside the collar... those kind of rules drive me so mad. I remember once not being allowed into the dining room of the Mandarin hotel in Hong Kong because I wasn't wearing a tie, so I went out and bought a Mao jacket, and put it on, and they had to allow me in then because I was in the national costume.'

All this means that I leave bamboozled and entirely empty-handed. A day or so later, a note arrives, thanking me for lunch. At the end, he has written, 'I only hope you got what you wanted.' I can hear his snuffle from here.

'I was thinking,' says an elderly voice, mildly but firmly, 'that it might be fun to talk over lunch, wouldn't it?' and of course, after that, there is no point in arguing. An hour or so later, we are making our way to the restaurant closest to his Kensington house. As we walk - very slowly, for he's a few weeks short of his seventieth birthday, and has had a limp since a teenage brush with polio, and in any case his manners are so painfully exquisite that he pulls back whenever we approach lampposts so that I can go on ahead - we see a crocodile of smart little London schoolgirls approaching, a battalion of Emilys and Jessicas in blue and grey blazers, paired off like Noah's cargo. When they've passed, Snowdon turns to me and asks, 'Do you think they might all be related?' Beneath all the whimsical twinkling, Snowdon is a man of secrets: his appetite for the frivolous is entirely compatible with his cast-iron discretion when it comes to more serious matters. As a result, he has never talked about his first wife, Princess Margaret, or the suicide of a long-term mistress four years ago, or the recent separation from his second wife, Lucy, or the affair which resulted in the birth of a son called Jasper in 1998 (all the things, in other words, that anyone might want to ask him about); yet even when he's deflecting a parry into his personal life, he does so with immense amiability. Consequently, he is a nightmarish interview subject. When he's not being vague or forgetful, he's being evasive. Yet somehow, his charm renders him untouchable: the Teflon toff. Having shed his Margaret Howell overcoat and a duck-egg scarf - a relic of Cambridge days, half a century ago - Snowdon is shown to his customary table ('I like to see who's coming around the corner') and sits down to consider the menu, juggling two sets of spectacles. His remarks to the waiter are characteristic: half-apologetic, in the way of the well-mannered top-drawer set, and half-bracing. He orders duck liver, followed by roast chicken, although the description of the gravy appears to irritate him slightly: 'What's the tarragon "jus"?' he asks, with a little bit of an edge. Though Snowdon accepted the life peerage offered to him in the new-look House of Lords, whereas the Duke of Edinburgh and his sons all refused theirs, he says he is not one for fancy titles. Talking about his forthcoming show at the National Portrait Gallery, he says, 'I hate the word "portraits". Portraits to me means something that is rather grand and old-fashioned, in oils. It's better to say photographs.' Then he adds, 'Hate the word "retrospective", too. It's a bit pompous. I didn't want it to be called a retrospective, but they wanted to, so I said, "Well, call it an obituary then." ' He snuffles a bit. The NPG exhibition probably says more about Snowdon than he ever will. In it, you can see traces of his society background, his interest in the arts, his royal connections, as well as his social conscience (he is reported to be staying on in the Lords to continue his campaigning work for the disabled). Perhaps it's modesty, or that posh trait of pretending not to take anything seriously, but he is relentlessly offhand about photography. 'When I started out, you only took photographs because you drew badly. It was a very lowly profession,' he says, and, 'It has all got too grand. It's pretty rubbish, they should just get on with it. We're reporters.' He can't resist asking whether I've seen a particular feature in a recent Tatler, a Mario Testino promotion for a mackintosh manufacturer, masquerading as the wedding album of Kate Moss and Lord Frederick Windsor. 'Have you seen those latest things, taken by Mario, which are very bizarre? No, I couldn't possibly comment on Mario's work... I am very fond of him, I know him a little bit.' His daughter from his second marriage, Frances, now in her early twenties, worked with Testino before moving on to be one of Paolo Roversi's assistants. Like the Great Wall of China seen from space, a Testino fashion spread is utterly distinctive, whereas Snowdon's work - like the earl himself - is altogether more difficult to pin down. When I ask him to describe its hallmarks, he looks horrified. 'I hope nothing,' he says, spooning bread sauce on to his plate. 'If I have a recognisable style, that's my failing. It would just mean that I'm repeating myself. I just want to capture something that relates to the [subject].' Later, he backtracks on this as well, as if it was too ambitious (I can't help feeling that his words have a bearing on our meeting, too). 'It's not always trying to get to the truth, it's trying to amuse as well. A lot of the time I'm playing games, and a lot of it's theatre, and a lot of it's cheating, in every possible way.' So which line to take on Snowdon? Some facts, at least, are unarguable. He was born in 1930, to a barrister and an heiress who divorced when he was five. He and his elder sister Susan spent their childhood at their father's estate in Caernarvonshire and with their mother - who swiftly remarried the Earl of Rosse - in Ireland and Yorkshire. He was sent to Eton and then, excused National Service because of the polio, studied architecture at Cambridge. He left without a degree but with a blue, having coxed the victorious side in the 1950 Boat Race. By then, he'd already begun to be interested in photography - or more accurately in cameras. (He's fascinated by mechanics. 'I walk around like a ferret,' he says, explaining how, on a recent visit to Paris, he was so transfixed by a water sculpture on the Champs Elysées that he laboriously tracked down its bewildered Greek creator. They had lunch together a few weeks ago. 'My Greek's not very good, and really it was so complicated, but I adored him because he was absolutely obsessed by his fountain. It drove me absolutely mad until I found out how it worked.') At school, he'd founded a photographic society, 'mainly because I wanted to go somewhere quiet', and invented an underwater camera: 'You had to surface every time you wound it on, so it only took one picture at a time. That's quite good training.' After Cambridge, his father paid for him to study at Baron's photographic studio, and then helped him rent his own in Pimlico. You might think this showed extreme tolerance, but the family had bohemian connections: a great-uncle was a Punch cartoonist, and Anne's brother, Oliver Messel, was a celebrated set-designer. During the Fifties, young Armstrong-Jones successfully reconciled the roles of snapper and debs' delight (he was a very popular walker) and won his first royal commission, taking the 21st birthday photographs of the Duke of Kent. In 1958, he met Princess Margaret and, in order to muffle the relationship as much as possible, rented an apartment in darkest Rotherhithe, where they ate fish and chips straight from the wrapper. They had two children and divorced in 1978. There's little doubt that Snowdon's career was partly inhibited by the match; after all, he was now as famous as anyone he was commissioned to photograph. So he returned to design: an electric wheelchair, and a collaboration with an architect and an engineer which led to the the aviary ('that funny old birdcage') at London Zoo, for which he was paid £145, 'and that included the model'. Snowdon has finished his glass of white wine, so I offer him another. 'No darling, let's have a red wine. A bottle. Can they afford it?' The matre d' is there in the blink of an eye. 'The house claret? Or would you prefer something fuller-bodied?' 'Ah, I wonder. No, no. I think that ordinary one.' The matre d' starts to ask whether I'd like another glass of white, but Snowdon is too quick. 'No, we'll have a bottle of the red, I think.' 'You'll have a bottle of it?' repeats the matre d', with emphatic neutrality. 'Well, don't sound so surprised,' says Snowdon, rather crossly. 'No, that's fine, it's just that you usually drink it by the glass, sir.' Snowdon subsides, like a balloon that has been left too close to the radiator. 'Oh, alright. We'll try it by the glass.' 'I'm happy to do whatever you prefer, sir,' the waiter offers, but Snowdon has given up. 'We'd better have it by the glass,' he repeats dispiritedly. When we're about to leave, he notices I haven't finished mine - 'Might drink that. Are you going to leave it?' - and polishes it off. After lunch, we walk back up the street to the house where he has lived since his first marriage ended, and where he now lives alone, surrounded by clocks, and mechanical toys, and a clutch of elegant scarlet chairs which he designed for the Prince of Wales's investiture at Caernarvon in 1969. Of course, I'd like to ask why he hasn't yet divorced from his second wife, Lucy; and whether he ever sees his son, Jasper, the result of a brief affair with a commissioning editor at Country Life which preceded the separation; and what went on with poor Anne Hills, who took an overdose on New Year's Eve 1996 after a 20-year on-off relationship with the earl; but instead, Snowdon is telling me about a trip to the cinema with Frances last week to see the new Scorsese film, which was awful, and about how he has converted her Paris bathroom into a darkroom, and how he's forever nipping over on Eurostar with his toolbox, and how he wishes the train would just shoot off the end of Brighton Pier with a great splash instead of slinking underground. This prompts another thought entirely, which leads to another, and to another: 'It's wonderful when you go to Moscow or St Petersburg - there are no railings in the parks or squares. It's all open, everyone can walk in. Why do we have to have these awful prissy little keys to go into a park? We should pull all the railings down. Get rid of them, open it all up, green grass, and make everyone welcome. It would be wonderful. It was like that during the war when all the railings were melted down. Unfortunately, they melted them up again. Why do you say "melt down" but not "melt up"? I was thinking about this the other day. You don't say, "It's trying not to rain," do you? But you'd say, "It's trying to rain." All these weather forecast things I love to listen to before I go to sleep. Don't you? The latest news from Fred Astaire and Rockall... We were going to do a film, John Betjeman and I. It was called Cloudy Bright, which used to be printed on packets of photographic film, I don't think it is any more. A lovely title, don't you think? Peter Sellers was going to be in it, and we had one meeting at the RAC Club in Pall Mall, for lunch, and we were stopped at the door because Peter didn't have a tie on, so he put one on, but inside the collar... those kind of rules drive me so mad. I remember once not being allowed into the dining room of the Mandarin hotel in Hong Kong because I wasn't wearing a tie, so I went out and bought a Mao jacket, and put it on, and they had to allow me in then because I was in the national costume.' All this means that I leave bamboozled and entirely empty-handed. A day or so later, a note arrives, thanking me for lunch. At the end, he has written, 'I only hope you got what you wanted.' I can hear his snuffle from here.

webTitle: It's been a good year for the rosaries...

fields.headline: It's been a good year for the rosaries...
fields.standfirst: The movies are full of priests and hellfire these days, says  Philip French. Why is Hollywood obsessed with Catholicism?
fields.trailText: The movies are full of priests and hellfire these days, says Philip French. Why is Hollywood obsessed with Catholicism?
fields.body:
Have you thought of escaping from TV repeats of the oppressively Catholic world of Father Ted and Ballykissangel or of finding refuge in the company of sensible vicars and rational rabbis in movies at your local multiplex? Forget it. Bell, book and candle, incense and confession will confront you at every turn.

With continental movies, of course, you expect to be faced with Roman rituals - the First World War funerals that punctuate Ra Ruiz's Time Regained; the Catholicism that informs the lives of everyone on Almodóvar's All About My Mother; the ethical-theological concerns that underlie the intrigues of films by Eric Rohmer, who recently completed his seasonal quartet with An Autumn Tale and back in the late Fifties co-wrote (with Claude Chabrol) a seminal book acclaiming Alfred Hitchcock as a great Catholic artist. But the cinema of the English-speaking world is currently obsessed with Catholicism.

The movie business and virtually all the major Hollywood studios were created by Jews. But every Jewish mogul had an Irish-American Catholic as his right-hand man (for example Brian Foy at Warner, Winfield Sheehan at Fox, Eddie Mannix at MGM) and the content of the cinema was determinedly Episcopalian in its upper reaches, Presbyterian in the middle registers and Roman Catholic when engaging with the immigrant working class. The Hollywood Production Code was created by a Catholic journalist, Martin Quigley, and a Jesuit priest, the Reverend Daniel Lord, then enforced by a prominent Irish-American layman, Joseph Breen.

Although the Italian-American Catholic Jack Valenti took over as president of the Motion Picture Association of America in 1967 and immediately abolished the restrictive code, he never attempted to influence social trends.

There are still, outside of Woody Allen's movies, surprisingly few Jewish characters in the cinema, and it is not without interest that the eponymous central characters in both of of Spielberg's Second World War pictures, Schindler's List and Saving Private Ryan, are Catholics. Perhaps Catholicism is more colourful and intense than Protestantism or Judaism, as well as a better focus for guilt.

This could explain why the cinema is currently giving the impression that the working classes of the British Isles are almost entirely composed of Catholics. You might expect it of Ireland, of course, the narrowly restrictive home from which the central characters of Angela's Ashes and Felicia's Journey flee. But the Glasgow family grieving for their mother in Peter Mullen's Orphans and the Yorkshire villagers welcoming a local miracle in The Darkest Light are fervent Catholics, while East is East begins with the children of a Muslim immigrant secretly taking part in a Catholic procession at their Lancastrian mother's behest.

No doubt, another factor - millennial angst - accounts for the Catholicism of three large-scale apocalyptic extravaganzas currently on release. In Dogma, two renegade angels threaten the existence of God himself by seeking to take advantage of a loophole offered by a liberal Catholic priest in New Jersey. In End of Days and Stigmata, both ecclesiastical horror flicks, agents of the Vatican struggle with dark forces bent on destroying the Church and civilisation as we know it. In the former, Gabriel Byrne plays Satan; in the latter he's a sceptical priest.

The two most notable films of this crop are by Martin Scorsese and Neil Jordan, both thought of as Catholic moviemakers. The former seminarian Scorsese has rarely been more anguishedly Catholic than in in his final film of the century, Bringing Out the Dead, which stars Nicolas Cage as a frayed paramedic working for a rundown Manhattan hospital called Our Lady of Perpetual Mercy. Jordan, a lapsed Irish Catholic, has adapted The End of the Affair, probably the Graham Greene novel that most challenges his Protestant admirers. One recalls the hero's remark in Jordan's first film, Angel, when the Ulster police inspector reveals that he's Jewish: 'Are you a Catholic Jew or a Protestant Jew?'

fields.headline: Toys keep swinging
fields.standfirst: You thrilled to Woody and chums in Toy Story. So be prepared to be seduced by Toy Story 2
fields.trailText: Philip French: [This] is a movie that is dazzlingly inventive in its graphic detail, tells an exciting, sophisticated story and raises complex ideas with clarity and wit
fields.body:
Few sequels are as good as, and hardly any better than, the works they follow. I was brought up to believe that the New Testament was superior to the Old Testament, and in the Seventies I arrived independently at the conclusion that The Godfather Part II was superior to The Godfather. I'm no longer certain about either of these judgments.

However, as of this moment and after a second viewing, I'm pretty certain that the computer-generated Toy Story 2 is even better than Toy Story , which brought us such delight back in 1995 when cowboy Woody, astronaut Buzz Lightyear, dinosaur Rex and piggy-bank Hamm first came slaloming down the slopes of little Andy's middle-American nursery.

The first film introduced the toys and pitted Woody, hero of the Old Frontier against Buzz, embodiment of the technological future. The sequel assumes our familiarity with its characters, who despite a certain playful friction work together as a mutually supportive team. The result is a movie that is dazzlingly inventive in its graphic detail, tells an exciting, sophisticated story and raises complex ideas with clarity and wit.

Andy is off for a few days at cowboy camp, but because Woody's arm is frayed at the shoulder, he doesn't take his faithful sidekick with him. After a film noir-style nightmare, in which he imagines himself consigned to a dust- bin, the intrepid Woody is kidnapped while saving Wheezy the penguin from a yard sale.

So he too becomes the object of a rescue mission led by Buzz Lightyear. Woody's abductor is the sinister Al, proprietor of Al's Toy Barn, a figure out of Pinocchio .

Al has recognised Woody as a collector's item, part of a 1957 set made up of Woody, the feisty cowgirl Jessie, Stinky Pete the Prospector, and a faithful horse, items in the merchandising that accompanied a black-and-white TV marionette programme called Woody's Round Up .

Woody is at first dazzled by his early fame, but discovers that the show was taken off the air before its climactic episode as a result of the October 1957 launch of the Russian Sputnik which supposedly made cowboys passé overnight. (This is, incidentally, after October Skies and The Iron Giant , the third movie of recent months to use the Sputnik launch as a pivotal background event.)

The prospector has never even been taken from his box and with a carefully restored Woody, the venal Al can sell the pristine set for a fortune to a toy museum in Japan.

The eminently decent Woody (voiced with touching sincerity by Tom Hanks) is torn between loyalty to his newly discovered team on Woody's Round Up and returning to the nursery with Buzz and his chums. The former choice offers him immortality, but in a glass case, untouched by human hand, the way those experts on The Antiques Road Show believe toys really ought to be kept. The latter choice is a form of mortality - among friends, loved by Andy, but knowing he'll he subject to wear and tear, eventually abandoned and ending up as the cynical Old Prospector says as 'landfill'.

It is breathtaking the way John Lasseter and his fellow computer wizards involve us emotionally with their creations, making us not only care for them as they risk their lives for each other, but also making us worry about their dilemmas and moral problems.

Of course, although adult human beings figure in the film - the egregious Al, Andy's solicitous mother - it is the toys that parents will identify with. They are the people discarded by growing children and left wondering about life's purpose. And there's a discomfiting feeling that this movie could induce guilt in children - or encourage them to hang on too long to toys and childhood.

Let me not make heavy weather out of the sunniest of movies just because it recognises the existence of rain and storms. I constantly roared with laughter - at the rescue team creating chaos as they cross a busy city street hiding beneath traffic cones, for instance, or at Buzz's attempts to convince an obtuse state-of-the-art version of himself that he's only a toy.

There is a brilliant joke about Star Wars that children will love, and a touching reference to John Ford's The Searchers that they won't get. At the end, nobody will leave the cinema before the lights go up because, like the same pro duction company's A Bug's Life , the final credits are accompanied by a series of hilarious out-takes.

Some involve pranks supposedly played by Woody on Buzz during shooting, but the most outlandishly post-modern of these jokes involves two characters from A Bug's Life making a brief guest appearance that ends on the cutting-room floor.

fields.headline: Jo Whiley
fields.trailText: There are so many scenes that stay with me, even when I have forgotten about the film. John Travolta exuding raw sex as he walks through the streets to 'Stayin' Alive' at the start of Saturday Night Fever. The village singing along to 'Tomorrow Belongs To Me' in a truly sinister moment in Cabaret.
fields.body:
There are so many scenes that stay with me, even when I have forgotten about the film. John Travolta exuding raw sex as he walks through the streets to 'Stayin' Alive' at the start of Saturday Night Fever. The village singing along to 'Tomorrow Belongs To Me' in a truly sinister moment in Cabaret.

The first of my favourites, though, is the opening of Jailhouse Rock. It is shot in black and white and the camera moves through deserted streets in the Deep South. It is so hot and sultry that you can feel yourself sweating as you watch it. Then you hear one gorgeous voice singing, "Crawfish"

My second scene is from The Eddy Duchin Story, a film about a famous concert pianist. At the climax of the film, Eddy, played by Tyrone Power, is diagnosed with an incurable disease. He begins playing this beautiful music on one of the grand pianos in the living room. Then his little boy starts to play along on another. It is incredibly poignant.

Another moment is the height of the competition in The Big Blue. The divers are swimming down and down, to see who can go the furthest and it becomes extremely claustrophobic. You experience an almost physical sensation of the pressure, and then the rush to the surface. I was watching it alone at three o'clock in the morning, because the others couldn't bear it, and I nearly had a panic attack.

webTitle: 100 top film moments: Neil Jordan's introduction to the list

fields.headline: 100 top film moments: Neil Jordan's introduction to the list
fields.standfirst:
Celebrated director Neil Jordan is happy to find a list that chimes with his own mind's way of storing films. But what do our favourite 'bits' say about the way film works its magic?
• The top 10 film moments
fields.trailText: Celebrated director Neil Jordan is happy to find a list that chimes with his own mind's way of storing films. But what do our favourite 'bits' say about the way film works its magic?
fields.body:
So instead of all the biblical plagues promised by the millennium, or the aluminium, as it's called in Dublin, we had the plague of lists. It was typical, somehow, of the desiccated nature of late 20th-century discourse and much, much safer than earthquakes, floods, volcanoes, skies spewing frogs, toads and computer-glitched aeroplanes. I've been asked to make them myself by a plague of publications, generally lists of my five, 10 or 100 favourite movies and have always said no. Not because I can't think of them, but because I can far more readily think of my favourite bits of movies than my favourite movies.
81/2, for example, will always live for me in the image of Marcello Mastroianni floating above a traffic-jam in Rome tied to a dirigible. Ziegfeld Follies may not be Vincente Minnelli's best movie, but there is an absolutely peerless three minutes in it where Judy Garland sings a paean to the woman in Belgium who invented the safety pin. For many critics, the Odessa Steps sequence is the highlight of Battleship Potemkin, but for me the most moving thing about the film is the way the whole bother was set in motion by a shot of an inedible bowl of soup. Eyes Without A Face will always be a film about a mask - that beautifully white, Japanese porcelain the doctor's daughter uses to cover her disfigured face - a version on any number of faces in the Scream series. And the first film I ever saw, I only ever remembered by a sound. It was a sound that heralded the approach of giant ants over a set of sand-dunes - which looked like every sand-dune I ever played on as a kid - in Them, a Fifties Warner B-movie.

I could go on. Many dull movies are redeemed by unexpected, accidental bits of poetry. Many classics are nothing but those moments of poetry, connected by a narrative that has no other function than to make the necessary connections. Think of Vertigo, an unlikely story about a painting of a long-dead woman called Carlotta, a faked death and a chance meeting. Nobody who remembers that film remembers the plot. They remember three, perhaps four sequences of transcendent poetry which are all about memory, oddly enough.

So perhaps a list of bits makes sense. Or says more about the way movies work on our consciousness than most of we filmmakers and critics would like to admit. And I perhaps could admit that this moment was one of those - Truffaut called them 'privileged moments' in that rather po-faced academic way of his - which brought a smart, rather predictable, decidedly commercial film to a different kind of life. But what was moving was not so much the poem, it was the image of those grey, working-class housing estates around the churchyard, that grey British rain in a film that was so resolutely about warmth, wealth and happiness deferred but inevitably achieved. But it is the poem that is remembered.

But if we examine the list further, we find the idea of quotation runs through it like the imitation stitching on a plastic football. The shower scene in Psycho has been quoted so often that the very sound - 'eee eee eee' - serves as a kind of shorthand for the whole of Hitchcock. The moments from 2001 and Apocalypse Now are wrapped in musical quotes - of Strauss and Wagner. Rutger Hauer's final speech in the rain in Blade Runner always seemed like a quote from Paradise Lost to me. Singin' In The Rain was quoted of course, by Kubrick in A Clockwork Orange, and if I come across another quote of De Niro's speech in Taxi Driver I think I will shoot the quoter.

If we examine it even further, we find many moments from the dictionary of movie quotation, so to speak, from what one could call the common grammar, so often quoted as to have the dusty feel of a Latin primer. Two lovers parting in gaberdines and hats, a propeller turning. A spike scything through the spokes of a chariot wheel. A motorbike sailing over a barbed-wire fence. A distant whorl of dust in an infinity of desert that turns out to be a man on horseback. An insect-like thing emerging out of a human stomach.

A bloodied male dying in a Christ-like position. A pram bouncing down a set of steps. An arm shooting up from a grave. An eye sliced by a razor blade.

We have been taught to 'read' movies, of course, by a generation of critics, academics and theoreticians who, ironically, wanted to establish their subjects' essential status as movies, as opposed to filmed theatre, or literature. Movie as reference, as quotable quotes, then followed in the Seventies. I have never been comfortable with that. I always wanted, purely and simply, to look at films, and some garden of Eden was lost to me the first time I saw a shot that referred me to another shot. It seemed obscene to me that the image couldn't trust itself, that it referred to another version of itself before it could reveal its meaning. One could, of course, and people did, call it shorthand. But shorthand is a hieroglyph, a form of writing. And there's the rub - or the irony. The theoretical framework that was to free movies from their imagined literary shackles made them…literal.

But I wish some historian could define for me the point at which audiences began to read movies the way they read a book or a magazine. I realised this point had well and truly arrived when I sat in Los Angeles at a screening of Austin Powers, The Spy Who Shagged Me, among an audience hooting with laughter at a shot of a sportscar driving up the Hollywood Hills. The joke was, of course, that the scene was actually set in the English countryside. Or, to be really pedantic about it, the subtext of the joke was that movies are sometimes forced to use Los Angeles for London, or the reverse, and the really cheap ones can't maintain the illusion. Or something like that. But the eerie thing was that the audience was not looking at the movie. It was reading it.

So maybe it is appropriate that at the top of the list is a kind of list. A shot of a noticeboard, filled with scrawled lists. Of all the images captured on celluloid since the invention of the camera, the favourite is one of a piece of handwriting. Should one laugh or cry? Or is this one of those Orwellian triumphs of the common sense of the ordinary public? Their favourite moment is where a story turns on a series of scrawls that have to be deciphered to reveal a secret. Their favourite moment in the history of movies is one they have to read.

webTitle: Lay off cannabis users says drug tsar

fields.headline: Lay off cannabis users says drug tsar
fields.standfirst: Drugs in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: The Government's drug tsar, Keith Hellawell, has called for a liberalisation of the law on cannabis in a radical overhaul of the way the criminal justice system deals with drug offenders.
fields.byline: by Martin Bright and Jay Rayner
fields.body:
The Government's drug tsar, Keith Hellawell, has called for a liberalisation of the law on cannabis in a radical overhaul of the way the criminal justice system deals with drug offenders.

In an exclusive interview with The Observer , he said the Government and the police should concentrate on the fight against heroin and cocaine use and stop being distracted by cannabis.

His comments, which were last night attacked as being 'defeatist', follow calls from the Liberal Democrats for a Royal Commission on decriminalising cannabis use. Mo Mowlam, the Cabinet Minister who has admitted smoking cannabis in her youth, is thought to be sympathetic to a softening of the law.

Hellawell said: 'What I have done is lift the stone on the hidden truth about drugs in Britain, which is that we need to discriminate between different drugs and the relative harm caused and then talk openly about the difference we can make. The focus is going to be on the drugs that cause the major harm.'

He said the police were convicting too many people for the possession of small amounts of cannabis to hit the drug crime targets.'By far the greater proportion of arrests are for cannabis and I am looking for a change on that. I am looking for a shift towards those dealing in heroin and cocaine.'

Although he said new legislation would not be needed, his comments will be seen as an attempt to reform the 1971 Misuse of Drugs Act by the back door. Under the Act, the possession of cannabis is a criminal offence punishable by prison.

His comments angered Ann Widdecombe, the shadow Home Secretary. 'What we need is a clampdown on the possession of cannabis,' she said. 'Hellawell is completely wrong. We should be looking at a zero tolerance policy.'

He said: 'Successive Conservative governments said the solution to the drug problem lay with the criminal justice system. Now funds are being shifted into treatment and education.'

His comments chime with the findings of a Police Foundation report on the 1971 Act to be published next month. The committee is set to recommend withdrawing prison sentences for possession of cannabis and taking ecstasy off the list of Class A drugs.

Hellawell added: 'The report will be a another step towards facing up to the reality of the situation. They are grappling with many of the issues we are taking care of.'

fields.headline: Heat of the moment
fields.standfirst: You can't beat chicken broth for keeping out of the cold
fields.trailText: You can't beat chicken broth for keeping out of the cold
fields.body:
The wind whistles and moans at my kitchen door, rattling the cat flap and sending in enough of a draught to rustle the pages of the newspapers on the breakfast table. With a glass door, three outside walls and three skylights in what is little more than a galley, my new kitchen is a cold and inhospitable place in which to cook. So much for the kitchen being the heart of the home. Of course, this is a recent addition to a much older house, a kitchen that was tagged on to the back when there were no longer staff to bring dinner upstairs from the original basement kitchen, which, incidentally, is as warm and welcoming as freshly buttered toast.

Old cookery books are full of recipes for keeping out the cold. While the French kept the wind at bay with goose fat and beans, and the Italians tuck into Bolito Misto, their national dinner of boiled meats in broth, the freezing Britons bubbled up potato-topped hotpots and made crusts of suet and flour. Leafing through early cookery books with their fatty lamb stews and steak-and-offal pies, you can see it was food, rather than swanky domestic heating, that kept the family warm. As the wind pierces every gap in my ill-fitting doors, it's a case of goodbye sushi, hello meat-and-potato pie.

Cooking is not especially easy right now. No 10-minute suppers or main-course salads. It is as if I have been thrown into another era. Every meal seems to start with peeling onions, scrubbing carrots and mashing potatoes. There are bones boiling and puddings steaming. I feel as if I should be wearing a mop cap and an apron down to my ankles.

In an effort to keep warm, I have taken to eating broth before supper. It warms and nourishes like nothing else, and has, so far, kept away the dreaded flu that has lain low so many of my friends. Nothing fancy, of course, just a good chicken boiled up with leeks, a parsnip, some carrots and several onions. I tuck in a few chicken wings for extra body and a tomato just to give it some colour. The broth that is left goes into the fridge and sets so stiff I can hold the dish upside down and it won't fall out. That's a free-ranger for you. The bones get strong on the exercise and are full of gelatin. A spoonful of that stock and I am once again ready to face the freezing cold. I tart up my bowl of broth according to my mood. Lemon juice and coriander - its soft leaves added at the last minute will invigorate. Parsley (why do we use this vivid green and earthy herb so little?) and some of the shredded chicken meat - blissfully bland and reassuring. I have also recently taken to boiling up a handful of pearl barley - its chewy nuttiness adds depth to any thin soup - and it takes just 20 minutes to boil. Overcooked and fluffy, it is even more sustaining.

'Tis the season for starch, and I must admit to adding pasta, potatoes or beans to almost everything I eat at the moment. The palest of soups or stews warms up enormously with the addition of a covering of potato slices, added early enough to soften and take up some of the juice. If you turn up the temperature towards the end of the cooking time it will brown the potatoes, too. For beans, you can also read chick peas and greeny-brown lentils. The other good thing about tiny lentils is that they have a touch of spice to them, which seems to add extra warmth.

This week, I made an old-fashioned stew with chicken and leeks, throwing it haphazardly together and chucking it into a low oven. I have never got the hang of oven timers, and setting the auto-cook programme on the average domestic cooker has always been a branch of rocket science to me. Successful slow cooking relies on my memory and the ability to smell when something is 'done'. In practice, I find stews are usually ready when I happen to remember they are still in the oven. But, with all that nourishing broth around, neither they nor I seem to come to grief.

Chicken-and-potato stew with parsley broth

You could use ready-cut chicken pieces here instead of buying a whole bird, except that you will be missing the undercarriage of the carcass, which adds much flavour as the stew simmers away in the oven. If you don't fancy jointing the bird yourself, ask your butcher - he will probably do it in about two minutes flat.
Serves 4

100g pot barley
a large free-range chicken, jointed
a couple of tablespoons of dripping, goose fat or olive oil
2 large carrots, peeled
1 large parsnip, peeled
2 leeks, trimmed and soaked to remove any grit
3 medium sized stalks of celery
1 large onion, peeled
a few bay leaves, 3 or 4 sprigs of thyme, and half a dozen sage leaves enough light stock to cover - though water will do
4 small to medium-sized potatoes, peeled unless their skin is very thin
a small bunch of curly parsley
You will also need a large, deep pan with a lid

Simmer the barley in salted water for about 20 minutes, until it feels reasonably tender, then drain it.

Lightly brown the jointed chicken in the fat in a large, deep pan. One to which you have a lid. I do this in a relay, three or four pieces at a time. Remove the browned chicken to a plate. While the chicken is browning, you need to cut the carrot and parsnip into large chunks and the leek and celery into short lengths. I think it is important to keep the vegetables in fat juicy chunks for this. Cut the onion in half and then into large segments. Once the chicken is out add the vegetables, turn them in the fat and let them soften a little, though don't let them colour. Bring the stock to the boil. Set the oven at 180C/gas mark 5.

Now return the chicken to the pan with the pearl barley then tuck in the herbs and pour over the hot stock, tucking all the herbs except the parsley in as you go. Now slice the potatoes the thickness of pound coins and lay them over the top of the chicken and vegetables - some will inevitably sink, others will sit on top, the stock just lapping at their edges.

Cover with a lid and place in the oven for an hour and a half, by which time the chicken and vegetables will be meltingly tender. Remove the lid, turn up the heat to 200C/gas mark 6 and leave for 30 minutes for the potatoes to colour here and there. Remove very carefully from the oven - the pan will be full and very hot - chop the parsley and sink it into the broth.

Spoon the chicken, vegetables, barley and plenty of broth in to shallow bowls with flakes of sea salt and the pepper mill.

Chicken pie with parsnip-and-potato mash
Serves 6

for the chicken
a medium-sized free-range chicken
a handful of chicken wings
2 leeks, roughly chopped
1 large carrot, scrubbed and halved
1 onion, halved but unpeeled
a tomato or two
bay leaves, parsley stalks, a few sprigs of thyme and
8 whole black peppercorns

for the pie
a large spoonful of fat from the chicken, goose fat or butter
2 medium leeks
2 sticks celery, cut into thick slices
5 rashers of green bacon, trimmed of its rind
bay leaves
6 medium-sized potatoes
4 medium parsnips
a small head of broccoli, snapped into large florets
a little flour
a thick slice of butter for the mash

Put the chicken into your largest saucepan, tucking the wings, vegetables, aromatics and herbs in around it. Pour in enough water to just cover the bird, then bring it to the boil over a high heat. As the water starts to bubble and froth, turn down the heat so that the liquid is moving only gently and giving the occasional 'glup', then scoop off the froth with a holey spoon. You can leave the chicken to cook quietly like this for a couple of hours, turning the bird once and making sure that it remains pretty much covered. By the end, the meat will be ready to fall from the bones with a gentle push and the cooking liquor will be a rich gold, shimmering with little globules of amber fat.

When the bird is cool enough to handle, drain off the stock through a sieve or colander and set it aside in a bowl. There will be more than you need for this recipe. Slide the meat from the bones, keeping it in large pieces, and taking care to include all the bits tucked under the carcass.

While the fat is melting in a heavy casserole, trim and discard the coarsest, darkest leaves from the leeks and slice the rest into thick rings. Rinse thoroughly to get rid of any grit trapped in the layers then add them to the warm fat. Cut the bacon into short, thick strips and, once the leeks show signs of softening, introduce it to the pan with the celery and a couple of bay leaves. Leave on a moderate heat, stirring now and again, for a good 15 minutes, until the vegetables are tender and the bacon fat pale gold.

Meanwhile, peel the potatoes and the parsnips, cutting them into hefty chunks for boiling. Bring them to the boil in deep water, add salt and leave them to simmer for 15 minutes or so until tender enough to mash. While they are cooking, add the broccoli to the leeks and bacon, cover, and let the broccoli cook for a few minutes in the steam.

It should be almost tender. Then stir in a couple of good tablespoons of flour and let it cook for a minute or two.

Pour 500ml of the hot stock on to the leeks and bacon, stirring over a moderate heat until the mixture starts to thicken into a thin sauce. Add the chicken, breaking up only the very largest pieces and turn off the heat. The remaining stock will keep in the fridge for a few days and can be used for risotto, soup or whatever. Season the sauce with salt and with a generous grinding of black pepper.

Drain and mash the potatoes and parsnips with a thick slice of butter. They need not be quite so buttery as normal mashed potato because of the richness of the sauce, but you do want the mash to be as lump free and creamy as possible. Cover the chicken sauce with the mash, letting it fall in large, loose dollops over the surface. Bake at 200C/gas mark 6 for a good half hour to 40 minutes, or until the mash has coloured here and there and the sauce is bubbling up from underneath.

Chicken pie with parsnip-and-potato mash Serves 6 for the chicken a medium-sized free-range chicken a handful of chicken wings 2 leeks, roughly chopped 1 large carrot, scrubbed and halved 1 onion, halved but unpeeled a tomato or two bay leaves, parsley stalks, a few sprigs of thyme and 8 whole black peppercorns for the pie a large spoonful of fat from the chicken, goose fat or butter 2 medium leeks 2 sticks celery, cut into thick slices 5 rashers of green bacon, trimmed of its rind bay leaves 6 medium-sized potatoes 4 medium parsnips a small head of broccoli, snapped into large florets a little flour a thick slice of butter for the mash Put the chicken into your largest saucepan, tucking the wings, vegetables, aromatics and herbs in around it. Pour in enough water to just cover the bird, then bring it to the boil over a high heat. As the water starts to bubble and froth, turn down the heat so that the liquid is moving only gently and giving the occasional 'glup', then scoop off the froth with a holey spoon. You can leave the chicken to cook quietly like this for a couple of hours, turning the bird once and making sure that it remains pretty much covered. By the end, the meat will be ready to fall from the bones with a gentle push and the cooking liquor will be a rich gold, shimmering with little globules of amber fat. When the bird is cool enough to handle, drain off the stock through a sieve or colander and set it aside in a bowl. There will be more than you need for this recipe. Slide the meat from the bones, keeping it in large pieces, and taking care to include all the bits tucked under the carcass. While the fat is melting in a heavy casserole, trim and discard the coarsest, darkest leaves from the leeks and slice the rest into thick rings. Rinse thoroughly to get rid of any grit trapped in the layers then add them to the warm fat. Cut the bacon into short, thick strips and, once the leeks show signs of softening, introduce it to the pan with the celery and a couple of bay leaves. Leave on a moderate heat, stirring now and again, for a good 15 minutes, until the vegetables are tender and the bacon fat pale gold. Meanwhile, peel the potatoes and the parsnips, cutting them into hefty chunks for boiling. Bring them to the boil in deep water, add salt and leave them to simmer for 15 minutes or so until tender enough to mash. While they are cooking, add the broccoli to the leeks and bacon, cover, and let the broccoli cook for a few minutes in the steam. It should be almost tender. Then stir in a couple of good tablespoons of flour and let it cook for a minute or two. Pour 500ml of the hot stock on to the leeks and bacon, stirring over a moderate heat until the mixture starts to thicken into a thin sauce. Add the chicken, breaking up only the very largest pieces and turn off the heat. The remaining stock will keep in the fridge for a few days and can be used for risotto, soup or whatever. Season the sauce with salt and with a generous grinding of black pepper. Drain and mash the potatoes and parsnips with a thick slice of butter. They need not be quite so buttery as normal mashed potato because of the richness of the sauce, but you do want the mash to be as lump free and creamy as possible. Cover the chicken sauce with the mash, letting it fall in large, loose dollops over the surface. Bake at 200C/gas mark 6 for a good half hour to 40 minutes, or until the mash has coloured here and there and the sauce is bubbling up from underneath.

fields.headline: The pink of health
fields.standfirst: With its vigorous shoots, decorative leaves and unmistakable tartness, rhubarb deserves to be a part of every garden
fields.trailText: With its vigorous shoots, decorative leaves and unmistakable tartness, rhubarb deserves to be a part of every garden
fields.body:
Sitting next to me at lunch yesterday was a man in search of rhubarb for his new garden. He said that he had been to his local garden centre and been laughed out of court. He had then asked and shopped around some more, but drew nothing but blanks. Perhaps it is just a country thing, but I think of rhubarb as a fixture - as much part of a garden as the lawn or buddleia. It is there because it has always been there. When I thought about it some more, however, I realised that I had got my own rhubarb from a highly unlikely source.

It was exactly 10 years ago, and I was filming a rhubarb farm near Wakefield. God, it was cold. Grey sky, grey, soot-streaked buildings and grey slag heaps from the mines. It was a shock to a soft southerner to see a farm set into an industrial landscape. The rhubarb was grown outside in the sooty soil until it had developed a sufficiently substantial root - about two years later. It was then lifted and brought into low sheds where it was placed in rows, each one tightly butted against the next, directly on to the ground. There was no light in the shed, except from a few candles used by the pickers. It was cold and dank, but still and very beautiful. The rhubarb was forced by the dark to grow pale pink and very straight. Exhausted by its crepuscular harvest, each chunk of root - looking like a cross between a tree root and a piece of tofu - would be cut back, two or three flushes of shoots removed at a time, and then thrown away. I asked for some of these rejects and was told that I could take what I could carry. So I filled a sack with warty rhubarb root-logs, and they have been doing fine here ever since.

Short of going round to a rhubarb farm in March or April when they clear the sheds, this, in principle, is the best way to get hold of some rhubarb: find someone with a mature plant and, some time in winter, after the leaves have died back, get them to lift a plant and chop it up into quarters with a sharp spade. Take a chunk with a couple of clearly visible buds and plant it in soil that you have dug and to which you have added plenty of compost or manure. The right depth should have the buds about an inch below the surface - but this is not critical. Mulch it thickly with more compost. If you have alkaline soil, it is a good idea to mulch each year with farmyard manure, as this tends to be acidic and rhubarb grows best with a pH of around 6.0. But it will survive and perform perfectly well on almost any soil, as long as it is well manured.

Do not pick any stalks for the first year, and cut the flowers off as they appear, because they will reduce the quantity of stalks that grow next year. By the second year, you should have a good crop followed by a really good one two years after planting. It is a good idea to repeat this division every four years or so, chucking away the centre of the old plant as the new exterior pieces will grow with much more vigour. But why could my lunching companion not get any plants? Has rhubarb become an anachronism, the vegetative equivalent of a fattening pig in the back yard? I hope not, because not only is it delicious to eat but it is also spectacularly decorative. I was going to say beautiful, but the beauty lies in the growing stems, before the leaves develop. In its summer maturity it is certainly impressive - but statuesque rather than beautiful.

For once, the vernacular name and the botanical classification share the same logical root, and rhubarb is clearly a corruption of Rheum rhabarbarum (although you are likely to find it also called Rheum x hybridum - a bit of botanical fudging). So, although rhubarb is restricted to the vegetable garden, it is first cousin to Rheum palmatum, which is inevitably part of any boggy or marginal planting. Rhubarb needs temperatures below 5¡C to break its dormancy and stimulate spring growth, and dislikes temperatures higher than about 30¡C. I suggest planting it with shade from the west, to protect it from the worst of the summer heat. But it does prefer a sunny site, so do not put it in deep shade. Baby leaves start to peek through the mulch that you spread thickly around it as soon as the leaves have died back. They come in two guises. If they are in the open, they are pink to the point of crimson, topped by a leaf so crinkled that it is almost as deep as it is wide. If you have forced the rhubarb by placing a bucket, old chimney pot or genuine bespoke terracotta rhubarb forcer over the top, the light-deprived shoots are much paler and the incipient leaf merely a lime-yellow spear-shaped spathe, a convoluted flame poised on top of a long, pink rhubarb candle.

Rhubarb was first recorded in China in 2700 BC and, for centuries, it was imported for use as a purgative. Its famous laxative qualities are, in fact, a simple result of the gut rejecting its unusually high level of oxalic acid - which is the reason it leaves your teeth feeling as though they have been vacuum cleaned. Oxalic acid is a poison, with a fatal dose of around 1,500mg. Rhubarb has about 500mg per 100g, so, in theory, a 300g helping of rhubarb could be fatal.

However, the chances of dying from over-enthusiastically eating rhubarb crumble or stewed rhubarb are remote, although your body would probably energetically reject the contents of your gut. But if you eat the leaves, you will certainly be ill. In the First World War, people ate the leaves as a substitute green vegetable, and some died because the level of oxalic acid is much higher in the leaves than the stalks. This level of oxalic acid in the leaves has probably evolved as a defence against grazing cattle. Rhubarb was first mentioned as a food in France in 1778, and forcing was discovered by accident at Chelsea Physic Garden in 1817 when crowns were covered over after a ditch was cleared. By 1861, when Mrs Beeton published her eponymous Book of Household Management, it was being made into pies, jam and wine in most households, and the floppy great leaves stood in the corner of every vegetable plot.

The Victorians devised bespoke covers for forcing, such as the huge terracotta belljars that could be put over an entire crown around Christmas, forcing the plant to produce its pale, vigorous, succulent shoots a month later. The tops always have a lid and, when I was a child, they always seemed to be capped by a hefty lump of manure. For years, I believed this to be an integral part of the art of rhubarb growing and solemnly did it myself, until I worked out that these crap hats were in lieu of the proper lids which must have all been lost or broken over the years. A tile or saucer would do just as well.

webTitle: Sex, drugs, bullets and Chardonnay, please

fields.headline: Sex, drugs, bullets and Chardonnay, please
fields.standfirst: Toby Litt mixes journalese with street argot, drug talk and girl shorthand as he takes us on a breathless tour of London in Corpsing
fields.trailText: Toby Litt mixes journalese with street argot, drug talk and girl shorthand as he takes us on a breathless tour of London in Corpsing
fields.body:
Corpsing
Toby Litt
Hamish Hamilton £9.99, pp374Toby Litt's favourite crime novels

I have not met Toby Litt, but if he is the model for Conrad Redman, the narrator of his second novel, then I would like to have dinner with him in Soho. We would eat puffball and plaice, asparagus and veal, and drink a 1992 Chardonnay.

That is what Redman and his pregnant ex, Lily Irish, are drinking when a hitman cycles up and shoots them both in Le Corbusier restaurant in Frith Street. Three shots send bone splinters through Lily's heart. She dies before dessert.

Redman misses coffee - for six weeks. When he comes out of his coma he turns wheelchair sleuth to find out who hired the executioner in the Dayglo stretch Lycra, crash helmet and mirror shades.

Litt/Redman has a good tale and he tells it well. He impersonates journalists, telesalesmen and gangsters to get his man. Despite resorting to the old reliable 'fake kidnapping' device to force a showdown, the suspense-filled prose hooks you. Each chapter, each bullet, brings a new twist.

Litt mixes journalese with street argot, drug talk and girl shorthand as he takes us on a breathless tour of London. There are Hoxton hitmen, jealous fortysomething wives, secret Soho liaisons, undeclared pregnancies, double crosses, telephone terrorists and sex with Lily's Volvo-driving relatives.

Better still, he gives a keenly observed and witty snapshot of thirtysomething London living. He does homes. A witness lives in 'a huge warehouse conversion on Old Street, right above the offices of Dazed and Confused. Stripped pine floors. Windows the size of cinema screens. Enough wall space to hang his six faux Rothkos. It was everything I'd ever aspired to and I hated it.'

He does culture - inventing a new way of amusing yourself during dull plays. 'I played my theatre tedium game. Spot the members of the cast who: (a) are sleeping together; (b) have slept together but don't any more; (c) will sleep together before the end of the run; (d) will sleep together after the last-night party; (e) hate each other's guts; (f) hate the director's guts; (g) hate themselves (easy, they all do).'

He does fashion. 'Alun, wearing a battered greatcoat, was every inch the windswept Welshman; Dorothy, sporting brightly coloured Afro-patterns, was Menopause Ethnic personified.'

And best of all he does - or at least tries to do - girls, using his own unique, direct approach. 'Can't we dump all this sexual-tension-being-nasty-to-each-other stuff? Why can't we just go to bed and fuck? Just a blow job then. How about that. Go on. Everyone is disgusting. Sex happens when two disgustingnesses coincide. I was just checking whether or not ours did... two hours later I had a phone number, a date for Friday, and a smile so wide I thought it would permanently disfigure my face.'

Corpsing - the cast is full of actors whose real-life or imagined characters 'die' on them - is a great evening in. Open the Chardonnay and let Litt take you on a thrilling ride from his Mortlake flat to the gents of a gangster pub in Bermondsey.

Better than dinner in Soho? That depends on whether you survive long enough for pudding.

webTitle: Union leader joins euro row as rate rise looms

fields.headline: Union leader joins euro row as rate rise looms
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Union leader Bill Morris, who is sceptical about the euro will confront pro-single currency colleagues and businessmen today at the Labour Party local government conference in Blackpool.
fields.byline: by Oliver Morgan and  William Keegan
fields.body:
Union leader Bill Morris, who is sceptical about the euro will confront pro-single currency colleagues and businessmen today at the Labour Party local government conference in Blackpool.

Morris is head of the 900,000-strong Transport and General Workers Union and a member of the influential Court of the Bank of England. He believes the pro-euro lobby is acting against Britain's interests by adding to uncertainty over the UK's future role in Europe.

Morris is thought to want the Government to rule out British entry to the single currency throughout the next parliament, the position already adopted by the Conservative Party.

On Monday Digby Jones, director-general of the Confederation of British Industry, said the organisation would stop campaigning for the single currency, leaving the Government to argue in its favour in public. And on Tuesday Trade and Industry Secretary Stephen Byers said the UK could join only after radical economic reform in Europe.

The euro spent the week below parity with the dollar, dipping to $0.9722 on Wednesday, and recovering to $0.9855 on Friday.

However, in an separate interview with The Observer CBI president Sir Clive Thompson said he saw no reason why Britain should not join in three years, if the Government called a referendum after the next election.

Meanwhile the strong pound looks set to continue: most City analysts expect the Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee to raise interest rates to 6 per cent when it meets this week. David Walton of Goldman Sachs says the only question 'is whether they will raise rates by 0.25 or 0.5 of a percentage point'.

Even Roger Bootle, author of The Death of Inflation , has stated in an analysis for Deloitte & Touche that he believes 'the evidence this month will lead the MPC to announce an interest rate rise of 25 basis points'.

The MPC raised rates by 0.25 points in January, to their present level of 5.75 per cent. But this was before the Bank's quarterly inflation forecasting exercise.With oil prices strengthening and another acceleration in the growth of house prices, the inflation forecast is thought to be close to the Bank's target of 2.5 per cent.

Analysts believe that recent output data - showing an annualised 3.2 per cent rise in GDP in the fourth quarter - also point to a further rise, aimed at assuaging worries about inflation.

Chancellor Gordon Brown hinted last week that he thought rates should go up.

From the political point of view, the Government wants all the agony of rate rises out of the way this year, before a general election, which is widely expected to be called in spring next year. The obvious embarrassment is sterling, which at one stage last week hit DM3.25, compared with its unsustainable exchange rate mechanism rate of DM 2.95 in 1992.

Bank Governor Eddie George recently repeated the MPC's view that, despite the damage being done to industry by high interest rates - Ford is the latest company to complain - the committee cannot put 'the economy as a whole at significant risk of rising inflation'.

The fact that both the US Federal Reserve and the European Central Bank raised their rates last week, however, means that a quarter-point rise in UK rates will not widen the previous interest rate differential.

fields.headline: Who's afraid of Michael Portillo?
fields.standfirst: He's a born again political star, big in Westminster, but that doesn't mean he's any more loved by the audience that really matters
fields.trailText: Andrew Rawnsley on the return of Portillo to the front-bench. He's a born again political star, big in Westminster, but that doesn't mean he's any more loved by the audience that really matters.
fields.body:
In politics, as in comedy, marketing and sex, timing is everything.

At the time that he was ejected from parliament by the voters of Enfield Southgate, everyone assumed (and huge numbers were delighted) that it was a disastrous, potentially fatal slither down the greasy pole for Michael Portillo. `Portillo's on the dole,' chanted a gleeful mob outside Conservative Central Office as they cheered the destruction of the man who encapsulated everything they hated about the toppled Tory regime. People asked each other: `Were you still up for Portillo?' The question was so symbolic of the relish which greeted the scalping of the Castillian quiff that it was even used as the title of an excellent book about the May Day massacre.

There is an alternative world in which the nation was deprived of that unifying surge of joy. Michael Portillo held his seat. In the Tory leadership contest that followed, and with William Hague as his campaign manager, Portillo overwhelmed all rivals to succeed John Major at the head of the Tory rump. Had that happened, I am fairly sure that the Tories would be little more loved , it is quite as likely that they would be even more loathed, than they are today. Were Michael Portillo already the Leader of the Opposition, I and the rest of the commentating class would regularly report on the menacing mutterings among Tory MPs about his failure to make any significant impression on Tony Blair. Widespread would be the speculation about the identity of the successor to Portillo after he had led the Tories to their inevitable defeat at the next election. Hague, heaped with praise by the parliamentary sketchwriters for his witty performances as Shadow Chancellor, would be much tipped as a man to watch as the next leader of the Conservative Party. He is christened the bald-apparent. Hague's regular protestations of undying loyalty to the leader , he calls Portillo `unassailable', are believed by no one. How big a chunk will Portillo have to take out of the New Labour majority to protect himself against a post-election leadership challenge by Hague? That is what everyone would very likely be writing.

Look at it this way and it's now evident that, far from being an awful blow to his career, Portillo's defenestration from the Commons was the best possible thing that ever happened to him. Not only has he been distanced from the Tories' failings, he has enjoyed the space to rebrand himself. He took a televised train voyage around his Spanish republican father. He swabbed the floors in a hospital and wrote of his admiration for those working in the health service. He groped towards a more compassionate brand of Conservatism. He self-outed himself, a step he would not have voluntarily taken had he become Tory leader after the election.

Most of all, he has not been required to prove in hard political combat that he would be more effective or popular as Tory leader than any of the alternatives. So long as Portillo has been absent from the front line, Conservative MPs have sighed to themselves, `If only'. If only El Caudillo was in charge, we wouldn't be submerged with this subterranean poll rating. If only Portillo was our leader, we wouldn't be such a joke. If only Portillo was the bull at the head of the herd, we might be within a shout of winning the next election.

In this respect, the absence of Portillo has been very undermining of William Hague. So it was sensible to accelerate his return to the front bench and, up to a point, shrewd to place him in the exposed position of Shadow Chancellor. Portillo is pitted against the formidable Gordon Brown who has already chewed up and spat out Peter Lilley and Francis Maude. We will now begin to see whether Portillo really does possess the Right Stuff. Alternatively, he will be exposed as a pair of lips, a hairstyle and a dash of aftershave masking an absence of original thought.

He made a brisk start by dropping Tory opposition to independence for the Bank of England and ending their hostility to the minimum wage. Both shifts have been signalled for some months. Both were inevitable. It was never going to be clever politics to fight the next election on a promise to put interest rates back in the hands of the same Tory politicians who presided over record home repossessions, and a pledge to cut the wages of two million people. It is a tribute to Portillo's panache , which could be another way of saying shamelessness, that most of the press coverage has described these U-turns as something of a personal triumph.

There is more dumping to be done. The Conservatives are also going to have to come to terms with the 48-hour maximum working week, unless they want to fight the next election with Labour posters declaring that the Tories would force millions of people to work longer hours.

I expect Portillo, always much more of a pragmatist than his ideological posturing tends to suggest, will be pretty ruthless at ditching voter-repellent bits of Tory baggage. Where he has so far been terribly weak , despite all that spare time he has had to spend thinking , is describing what the Conservatives are positively about. For someone often described as the philosopher-prince of a `New Toryism', he has been silent about what this might come to in either theory or practice. Are his ideas too alarming to be undressed in public? Or is the problem that he doesn't have anything less banal to say than he's in favour of freedom, choice and lower taxes.

Which raises the question whether any of that reinvention was more than skin deep. People talk of the New Portillo. Well, so they do in the Westminster Village and Media Gulch. What I wonder is whether he looks any different out there, beyond Parliament Square, in the real world where votes are cast. It's unarguable that he's a big hitter. In a Tory solar system mainly composed of black holes and brown dwarfs, Michael Portillo has stellar quality.

What doesn't necessarily follow, as the man himself would probably privately acknowledge, is that this means the voters like him anymore than they did before. The only opinion poll I've found that bothered to ask the question suggests that the Conservatives would be even less popular led by Portillo. He is the man who was, in one previous incarnation, the Minister for the Poll Tax. He was Chief Secretary to the Treasury during the humiliation of Black Wednesday and when VAT was imposed on fuel. He was the foam-flecked ranter to the lowest prejudices of the Tory party conference.

If these are not the things that the voters most recall about Michael Portillo, then you can be certain that Labour will do its best to remind the country why his defeat produced such paroxysms of delight. Elections are a contest between disillusion and fear: `kick the buggers out' versus `better the bastards you know'.

The roles played by Labour and the Conservatives at the last election, and the four elections before that, will be reversed at the next. The Tories, as the insurgents, must look to ways of attracting fresh support. Labour, as the incumbents, will seek to keep its coalition together by terrifying the voters about the alternative. Does the prospect of Michael Portillo being resurrected as a Cabinet Minister make it easier or harder for Tony Blair to scare the country with the thought of the Tories returning to office? I merely note that, when it was announced that he was back on the Tory front bench, what I did not see was a crowd outside Central Office joyfully chanting: `Portillo's off the dole.'
