fields.headline: Third Way loses its bearings
fields.standfirst:
Events are blowing this theory off course, says Simon Caulkin

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: As a concept, the Third Way is as slippery as compacted snow on a Davos ski slope. As my Observer colleague William Keegan has shown, it has been around since at least 1869, when its confident adoption in France failed to prevent either war or internal upheaval, the frying pan and fire it was supposed to navigate between.
fields.body:
As a concept, the Third Way is as slippery as compacted snow on a Davos ski slope. As my Observer colleague William Keegan has shown, it has been around since at least 1869, when its confident adoption in France failed to prevent either war or internal upheaval, the frying pan and fire it was supposed to navigate between.

Later it appeared, Cheshire-Cat-like, as a middle way between socialism and capitalism and a dimension 'beyond left and right'.

Today's Third Way has metamorphosed again, with its extremes now sharply drawn by global capital on one side and growing concerns for the environment on the other: Davos Man vs Seattle Man, the anti-capitalist protester, perhaps. However it is expressed, a constant element in Third Way-ism is the growing importance within it of markets and business.

As a speaker at a timely conference last week on 'A Third Way for Business' at Cranfield Management School observed, governments are everywhere decreasing their direct involvement in markets in favour of companies, increasingly using regulators and competition to hold the ring. In that sense, he predicted bluntly, companies in the future would run countries as much as governments did.

And not just countries. The globalisation of markets means that the world is interconnected in ways that go far beyond the ability of governments to control. $1,200 billion is traded every day on the foreign exchanges, 50 times the amount of world trade; international bank lending grew from $265bn to $4,200bn in the 20 years from 1975; in the same period, foreign direct investment was up from $21.5bn to $400bn.

However, with this kind of freedom and power to achieve their global ambitions, the confident appurtenances of Davos Man, comes something more uncomfortable: responsibility. Responsibility, in the eyes of Seattle Man, for such things as the state of the environment, widening disparities in global income, social and technological exclusion, and increasingly the lifelong learning and health of a firm's employees.

Some of these things seem more attainable than others. For instance, at the conference, BT managing director Bill Cockburn reaffirmed his company's commitment to sustainable development and stakeholding. BT's mission statement says that 'to continue to provide an excellent return on shareholder investment we must also take into account the expectations of all our stakeholders'. (This sentiment was unable to prevent BT's share price falling 20 per cent last week when it announced lower short-term earnings, however.)

Third Way-ism also gets a boost, at least in the UK, from post-1997 developments in the labour market. The TUC's senior policy officer, David Coats, said that beneath the rhetoric of flexibility and deregulation, the Government has engineered a massive swing towards European mainstream social policy, signing up (with very little fuss) to the directives on working time, parental leave and part-time workers, as well as introducing the minimum wage, enacting statutory union recognition rights and greatly extending the rights of individuals at work.

The extent of this change should not be underestimated. Nor should the TUC's commitment, on its side, to workplace partnership and 'high-commitment' employment practices.

But is 'stakeholding' enough? It's not just that the latest Workplace Employee Relations Survey shows just how small the inroads of such enlightenment have been at work. In other areas, companies seem part of the problem, not the solution.

Seattle Man might observe that a Haitian worker in a Disney factory will take 16.8 years to earn what Disney chief operating officer Michael Eisner pulls down in an hour; that, as George Soros acknowledges, unfettered capital markets greatly increase both risks and disparities as well as efficiency; that firms' cost-cutting behaviour is as relentless as their profit-seeking; and that the advances in management technology driven by such concerns in eager business schools often simply create more work and insecurity.

As French Prime Minister Lionel Jospin points out in his Fabian pamphlet, Modern Socialism, the potent combination of global finance and the information revolution means there is a widening disjunction between the 'new' and the 'real' economy. Global capital markets far outpace the adaptive capacity of society or production. Capitalism - 'a force that moves but [which] does not know where it is going' - risks careering out of the control of managers or politicians.

Seattle Man believes this stage has already been reached. What space do huge mergers leave for Third-Way ideas such as diversity and local devolution? If global electronic competition means that no firm will have a life in any one form of more than a few years, how can BT's stakeholding views and social responsibility programmes protect it? If the Internet, as one view has it, is daily dissolving the glue that holds societies together, is the Blairite Third Way out dated before it is properly defined?

Cranfield's Professor Joe Nellis repeatedly told the conference: 'Policy is a function of time and place.' The trouble is, the notions of time and place are themselves in a state of flux, so the best way of thinking about the Third Way may be not as 'in-betweenism' but as forever synthesising new ideas and rolling forward.

Some of the new ones, such as radical resource productivity, have barely been broached. Experiments with employee ownership need testing. Most firms don't know what to do about diversity - women, minorities, the young. And they are as crippled creatively as they are overdeveloped analytically.

Move over, Davos: the signposts for the Third Way are pointing a lot nearer Seattle than you ever imagined.

fields.headline: Health check
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: 'To me,' says Miss Jean Brodie in Muriel Spark's novel, 'education is leading out of what is already there in the soul....[not] putting in of something that is not there; that is not what I call education, I call it intrusion.'
fields.body:
'To me,' says Miss Jean Brodie in Muriel Spark's novel, 'education is leading out of what is already there in the soul....[not] putting in of something that is not there; that is not what I call education, I call it intrusion.'

To be fair, both approaches are needed today as we continue to look at improving the health of organisations, and the careers of those who work in them.

There are those who in every age interpret new technical advances and thinking and make them practicable and profitable to companies and their staff: such are those experts who deal with IT applications, marketing techniques, global communications, and business re-engineering.

But there are also those who try to build up the health and wealth of organisations by suggesting ways of realising the potential of individuals within the corporate structure. That is why the approach of, for example, Tomorrow's Company, a consultancy set up to promote good working practices, works so well. It involves stakeholders, and turns the traditional management pyramid upside down, letting the many at the workface service the market, supported by the management few.

So - inevitably - it comes down to individuals to create the success of organisations, and of the careers of people within them. But what is the best way of doing this?

Recognise the significance of the past: build on the strengths that made you who and what you are; adapt them, certainly, but don't ignore them.

Understand the reality of the present. Change is now with us constantly; learn to expect and welcome it.

Take responsibility for the future: use your talents to prepare for and grasp the opportunities that lie ahead. 'Carpe diem,' said Horace, and that does not mean 'whinge all day'.

Or, as another guru put it: 'to be employed is to be at risk; to be employable is to be secure.'

Good health!

webTitle: Each week we advise on readers' problems

fields.headline: Each week we advise on readers' problems
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: My local authority refused to upgrade my clerical job eight years ago. My terms of employment, however, allow me to go before an appeals council which includes people from outside the authority. But the authority refused to appear until last November. A hearing was arranged and then subsequently cancelled. My union has done very little to help. What can I do?
fields.body:
My local authority refused to upgrade my clerical job eight years ago. My terms of employment, however, allow me to go before an appeals council which includes people from outside the authority. But the authority refused to appear until last November. A hearing was arranged and then subsequently cancelled. My union has done very little to help. What can I do?

The council is probably in breach of contract. If your terms of employment allow you to appeal, the council will be under an obligation to set the hearing within a reasonable timescale. However, the council's breach of contract does not give you many extra rights. You could resign and claim constructive dismissal - but this route is not advised, as you probably want to keep earning a salary.

Write to the chief executive or the leader of the council, explaining what has happened. If the union has lost interest, it may be that the local union officials are not very competent or - more likely - that they think your case is poor. Also, if you have been in dispute with the council for eight years, your chances of promotion are clearly not high. Employing lawyers privately would be too expensive. If you can have a friendly chat with your union rep and ask them for a frank opinion, you may find out why they have not helped you more.

Legal advice from Pinsent Curtis.
Problem at work? Write to Neasa MacErlean, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1 3ER. Answers are for guidance only.

fields.headline: Sick building, sicker profits
fields.standfirst:
Work Unlimited

Well-designed offices could save employers up to £3,000 a year per worker, writes Jim Pollard
fields.trailText: You're not paranoid - that computer really has got it in for you. Studies repeatedly show that modern workers are up to 50 per cent less effective than they should be. Why?
fields.body:
You're not paranoid - that computer really has got it in for you. Studies repeatedly show that modern workers are up to 50 per cent less effective than they should be. Why?

It's partly because workers and employers do not think enough about their physical environment. Offices are boring. None of fiction's juicy visions of the future include them - unless I missed the Star Trek episode that had Captain Kirk slaving over a photocopier.

Nor has the working environment ever been top of management's priorities. The result, say experts, is workplaces that kill creativity, increase absenteeism, and undermine productivity. They are even implicated in this winter's flu outbreak.

But this may be about to change. 'We're beginning to unravel the two great mysteries of the modern workplace,' says John Jukes, an ergonomics and environmental stress consultant who has worked with companies in the UK, Europe and the US.

'Why do 90 per cent of computer installations fail to meet their productivity specifications? And why do over 80 per cent of staff in ordinary offices suffer from the classic sick building syndrome (SBS) symptoms of headache, tiredness, itchy and sore eyes, throat and skin, upper body pains, irritability and coughs?'

The answers are all around - magnetic fields, poor lighting, poor air quality, sound levels, poor design. A book, Creating the Productive Workplace, edited by Derek Clements-Croome of Reading University, pulls the international research together.

'We live and work through our five senses,' says Clements-Croome, 'and to thrive we need to use them. If they're blunted, we feel dissatisfied and creativity suffers. Why did monkeys die when we sent them into space? They suffered sensory deprivation and died of boredom. When this sort of deprivation occurs in the workplace, SBS symptoms result. They lower the immune system, so we succumb more readily to, say, a cold or flu.' (Couple this with a work culture that has us staggering on regardless of how sick we are, and you begin to see how a flu epidemic can take off.)

The solution is intelligent buildings, says Clements-Croome, who runs the world's first MSc in the subject. 'Intelligent buildings are those which are adapted to their environment and function. Many offices are neither. Intelligent buildings need not be expensive. An igloo, for example, is very intelligent. Workplaces should be demand-led. They should be designed for the individuals using them.'

He certainly does not buy the idea that the office will disappear with new technology. 'Working from home, virtual conferencing and so on will change the workplace - make it more fluid - not destroy it. People need the contact, the change of environment and the routine that shared work environments offer. What's important is that those environments, wherever they're found, provide the right conditions for productivity.'

Indeed, as offices get both bigger, call centres, and smaller - boxrooms and bedroom corners - the need to get the essentials right increases.

How does the research shape up in practice? Jukes worked through it systematically with a large UK service provider who wanted to close the 50 per cent shortfall between what its PC system was supposed to do and what the workforce were achieving.

Enabling staff to sit at their VDUs correctly helped. So did encouraging them to take regular breaks, to blink regularly and to change their eyes' focal length by looking away occasionally. Ionisers, which neutralise the positively charged air produced by high levels of electrical equipment and synthetic materials, brought further benefits.

The gap was finally closed when polarised daylight lighting was introduced. An ambient sound environment free of continuous machine noise took productivity into credit. When house plants finished off most remaining SBS symptoms, Jukes had a Eureka moment. 'We realised,' he says, 'that we were recreating the outdoors indoors. Not surprising really - as that's the environment we've evolved to cope with over 273,000 years.'

Subsidised gym memberships and more flexible leave arrangements are two of the ways in which companies are gradually beginning to recognise the importance of their employees' health.

Clements-Croome and Jukes expect this concern to move centre stage over the next few years - especially as research into the effects of emissions from electrical items develops. Their latest study suggests that the extremely low frequencies from VDUs and mobile phones interfere with the brain's alpha and beta rhythms rather like interference on a radio - and with similarly unpredictable results. Jukes believes this could be responsible for a third of SBS symptoms.

'Offices are moderately lethal places, and we could be sitting on a time bomb,' he says. 'Most effects are invisible but if you want to see one, clean the dust from your VDU screen. As most airborne dust is dead skin, it should be grey - but you'll find it's black. The dust gets fried by electromagnetic fields, creating carbonised particulates that break into fine pieces and wreak havoc in the body's defence mechanisms.'

If that does not convince your boss, here is the bottom line: 'I'm getting enthusiasm because companies see real money,' says Clements-Croome. 'The research shows that improving the working environment produces more fulfilled workers, who create bigger returns.'

One practitioner, John Doggart, MD of ECD Engineering and Environment, puts a figure on it. Well designed workplaces produce, he says, savings of 3 to 15 per cent - worth up to £3,000 per person a year on a £20,000 salary, including overheads. Intelligent building - happy director of finance.

Work it out
Among the factors involved in workplace productivity, four have been identified as so-called 'killer' variables:

1 Personal control over heating, lighting, ventilation and noise.
2 Prompt responses from equipment and management to environmental problems.
3 Narrow buildings - deeper buildings lower productivity and satisfaction (optimum depth is about 12m.
4 Smaller, well-integrated workgroups.

The good
 Broadgate, City of London
 Waterside, British Airways office near Heathrow
 Andersen Worldwide's Chicago HQ
 HQ of Swedish airline SAS in Stockholm
 KI building, Tokyo

The bad
Take your pick - it is estimated that one in three British offices are unhealthy including those of call centres and those converted from residential or warehouse use. For irony, try Alexander Fleming House at the Elephant And Castle in London (above) - now luxury flats, it was once the notoriously sick home of the Department of Health.
